sec.title: Asymmetries in the space domain
sec.p: Space is a fundamental dimension of human life, and is pervasive in human experience. Spatial perception, orientation in space, and spatial cognition in general have a significant impact on language in various ways: especially in the framework of Cognitive Grammar, space is considered a basic cognitive domain, providing the source for the conceptualization of more abstract domains. The linguistic encoding of space, including spatial concepts such as location, direction, path of motion and the like, has been central to virtually all theoretical approaches to semantics, and extensive research on space in language resulted in numerous publications.

Among several specific issues addressed in recent research on space is the possible asymmetrical nature of spatial relations, as shown by differences in encoding. Many studies have highlighted a number of differences in the encoding of goals and sources of motion: in general, some semantic roles seem to more ‘basic’, more likely to be expressed, or to display a wider range of coding strategies than others. For example, goals of motion have been shown to be expressed more frequently and in more fine-grained ways than sources (Section 2). Also, cross-linguistic coding tendencies seem to point to a separate status of path with respect to goal (allative), source/origin (ablative), and (static) location (locative), as it is less frequently flagged by a dedicated case. Interestingly, such asymmetries may correlate with certain types of landmark, as in the case of toponyms or of human landmarks (Section 4).

Even though these issues have been focused upon both in typological and psycholinguistic research, they remain largely open. With the papers in this collection, we would like to show that a diachronic approach may shed some light on the way in which asymmetries in the space domain come about over time, thus contributing to the clarification of synchronically puzzling facts. The papers collected in the volume address changes in the coding of spatial relations, with a focus on the coding of similarities and differences among spatial relations, or among subtypes of the same spatial relation, paying special attention to the asymmetries mentioned above. Topics discussed include the source–goal asymmetry, differential marking of spatial relations, polysemy and the lack thereof among markers of spatial relations, and related diachronic developments (Section 4).

sec.title: Asymmetries between sources and goals
sec.p: Recent research has demonstrated a number of differences in the encoding of goals and sources of motion. In general, goals of motion are expressed more frequently and in more fine-grained ways than sources (Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004; Regier & Zheng 2007, inter alia). The asymmetry also shows up in more subtle syntactic phenomena: unlike sources, which often behave as adjuncts, goals tend to share properties with verbal arguments, and they are also more likely than sources to be incorporated in the argument structure of verbal applicatives (Baker 1988; Filip 2003). Patterns of polysemy within systems of spatial marking also point in the same direction: static locations are commonly coded synchronically by the same markers as goals of motion, and in a way distinct from sources (Blake 1977; Noonan 2009; Nikitina 2009; Pantcheva 2010; Zwarts 2010).

Not that this pattern of polysemy means that diachronic mergers of source and location are not attested: much to the contrary, many individual locative markers in European languages – such as French dedans ‘inside’ or Ancient Greek ópisthe(n) ‘behind’ – often go back to ablative expressions, suggesting an earlier ablative-locative transfer, following the terminology in MacKenzie (1978). Such transfers typically occur with nouns that indicate spatial regions.

The development of French dedans is illustrated in Nikitina (this volume; see also Luraghi 2014; MacKenzie 1978). Starting from Latin intus, we find a repeated shift from ablative to locative, whereby every time a new ablative morpheme is added to the locative expression to restore the ablative meaning, which is then lost again. The full cycle can be summarized as: early Lat. in-tus ‘from inside’ > Cl. Lat. intus ‘inside’ (static expression) > VL de intus ‘from inside’ > OF denz ‘inside’ > OF de + denz ‘from inside > MF dedans ‘inside’; de dedans ‘from inside’.

MacKenzie (1978) discusses this and other examples from the Indo-European language phylum, as well as from non-Indo-European languages, notably Israeli Hebrew, and two Austronesian languages, Fijian and Sonsorol-Tobi. In Hebrew, he describes some adverbs that contain the ablative component mi-, which normally means ‘from’. With some nouns that refer to spatial regions, this prefix often indicates locative, and can exhibit some partial polysemy, as in mi-tzad ze ‘form/on this side’ (MacKenzie 1978: 147). With local adverbs, the transfer is complete, and the ablative meaning is no longer there, as in meal ‘above’ (resulting from mi ‘from’ plus al ‘on’).

More generally, the evidence adduced by MacKenzie, as well as other instances of the semantic extension described above (cf., for example, Bennett 1989; Nikitina & Spano 2014; Luraghi 2009 and 2010), seem to suggest that once a marker acquires the locative meaning, it loses the original ablative meaning. Apparently, polysemy is tolerated limited to nouns that refer to spatial regions, such as those meaning ‘side’ (but cf. Nikitina this volume for counterexamples). Thus, while the extension from source to location is attested, possibly even more frequently than commonly believed (see Luraghi 2014 for discussion), polysemy tends to be avoided. Note, however, that special types of landmarks (spatial referents, human beings) often allow some overlap in the use of ablative and locative encoding, and can be at the origin of ablative-locative transfers (Eckhoff, Thomason & de Swart 2013, Luraghi 2009 and 2014).

The papers collected in this volume show the relevance of historical data for the study of goal-source asymmetries, as well as suggest ways in which research on such asymmetries can contribute to a better understanding of patterns of historical change in the domain of spatial expression.

sec.title: Differential marking of spatial relations
sec.p: Another major issue addressed by the volume is variation in encoding locative roles, both across and within languages. When it comes to cross-linguistic variation, the role that has received very little attention is the role of path: as compared to sources and goals of motion, it remains largely understudied. In the light of cross-linguistic coding tendencies, goal (allative), source/origin (ablative), and (static) location (locative) seem to be more ‘basic’ spatial relations than path. As argued in Stolz (1992: 30), there is a tendency for case marking related to spatial relations to exhibit ‘Dreigliedrigkeit’, i.e. a tripartite structure featuring dedicated coding devices for location, direction, and source. Path, on the other hand, is often coded by cases/adpositions that usually indicate location, as in English Mary walks in the field. / The child is running in the street.

Variation within the same language is best illustrated by cases of differential marking of locative roles. The encoding of certain spatial relations depends on the type of landmark, and non-conventional landmarks (e.g. human beings) often require special types of encoding (Luraghi 2011). With time, such differential marking may give rise to markers that are no longer obviously related to the original spatial concept. For example, the Indo-European dative has been argued to be “genetically nothing else than an offshoot of the locative used with personal nouns” (Kuryłowicz 1964: 190; cf. also Aristar 1996).

Several papers in the volume explore factors that are relevant for the encoding of different locative roles, including path, and describe historical changes associated with that variation. The diachronic approach helps better understand patterns of differential marking that look puzzling at the synchronic level.

sec.title: Overview of the book
sec.p: The volume covers different aspects of the diachronic development of spatial marking in select European languages and language groups.

Annemarie Verkerk addresses the asymmetry between Sources and Goals by means of phylogenetic comparative methods. She analyses a parallel corpus of translations from English and argues that discrepancies in the encoding of sources and goals of motion in the present day languages point to an overall stability of the Source/Goal asymmetry. The results are interpreted as showing that ancestor languages were more likely to express information about Goals than information about Sources.

Olga Thomason and Hanne Eckhoff present a study of a parallel corpus of translations of the New Testament. They explore discrepancies in the encoding of different spatial relations, and identify possible contexts where syncretism may arise between different types of marking (in particular, they focus on cases of locative-ablative and locative-perlative syncretism). Syncretism is suggested to be enabled by the co-existence of two different perspectives from which the same situation can be viewed and described.

Tatiana Nikitina addresses the diachronic relationship between locative marking, on the one hand, and the marking of goals and sources, on the other hand. She discusses the strategy of describing static spatial relations by means of expressions normally used for goals and sources (as in to the left of the door), and suggests that in several Indo-European languages, the use of that strategy has been on the decline. That change is related to the development of new prepositions, and the replacement of directional adverbs, which played a prominent role in the encoding of spatial notions in ancient languages.

Claudio Iacobini, Luisa Corona, Noemi de Pasquale, and Alfonsina Buoniconto discuss the encoding of motion events in a corpus of texts in Ancient Greek and Classical Latin, in comparison with translations of the same texts into Modern Greek and Italian. They address differences in the encoding of Goals and Sources, as well as subtle differences in the way Classical Greek and Classical Latin combine prepositional marking on noun phrases with directional preverbs on motion verbs. In the subsequent evolution of both languages, the shift from a satellite-framed to a verb-framed type of encoding is suggested to originate in the potential non-complexity of path descriptions.

Thomas Stolz, Nataliya Levkovych, and Aina Urdze focus on the encoding of different spatial relations in interrogatives (such as where, whither, whence). Comparing the spatial interrogatives of modern Romance languages to the paradigm of spatial interrogatives of Latin, they discuss different paths that the languages took in restructuring the original paradigm. The different paths are shown to result in different patterns of syncretism.

Silvia Luraghi explores the role of animacy in the encoding of Goals and Sources in Ancient Greek. She traces the development of differential marking of Goals and Sources with several motion verbs in the period from Homer to Herodotus and Plato. While the animacy-based differential marking is not attested in Homer, later authors are shown to develop it to different extents. The results of the study are placed in the context of cross-linguistic research on differential goal marking.

Chiara Zanchi presents a study of the effects of the Source–Goal asymmetry on the grammaticalization of preverbs in Ancient Greek. Source-based and Goal-based preverbs are compared, and their relative rates of grammaticalization are assessed based on data from Homeric and Post-Homeric Greek.She argues that preverbs that originally encoded Sources are more obligatory and more likely to develop aspectual meaning than preverbs deriving from markers of Goals. The emergence of this asymmetry avoids the simultaneous coding of Place, Goal and Source by means of the same case.

Thanasis Georgakopoulos and Petros Karatsareas approach the Source–Goal asymmetry based on evidence from Modern Greek varieties of inner Asia Minor. The varieties are classified into conservative, intermediate, and innovative with respect to their encoding of spatial relations, and a general sequence of changes is established. The Goal–Source asymmetry is argued to account for a number of differences in the way the encoding of Goals and Sources changed over time.

Elisabeth Gibert Sotelo proposes a formal account of the asymmetry between the goal prefixes a- and en- and the source prefix des- in Spanish. The asymmetry, manifested in different productivity, is related to the change from the satellite-framed system of Latin to the verb-framed systems of modern Romance languages.

Luisa Brucale and Egle Mocciaro describe the encoding of spatial roles in Sicilian, focusing on instances of differential encoding of path of motion (in particular, on the variation in the encoding of multidirectional paths). Three different corpora are used to trace the diachronic development of the present day system from ancient Sicilian.

Anetta Kopecka uses translations of short narratives from Old to Modern French to identify changes that affected the way French encodes Goals and Sources. Old French is shown to express more frequently than Modern French complex events of motion involving descriptions of both Source and Goal. It is also shown to allow for relatively free combinations of satellites with verbs of motion. The changes are related to the development from a satellite-framed system, which encoded directionality by means of prefixes, particles, and adverbs, to a verb-framed one, where the path was mostly expressed in the verb.

Diana Lewis reports on a corpus-based investigation of the evolution of the source-oriented directional particle away in the Modern English period. She discusses changes in the particle's productivity and argues that the particle away is being gradually replaced by the particle off. The overall picture is complicated by patterns of lexicalization.

Natalia Philippova identifies factors that determine the choice of a coding strategy for trajectories of motion in modern Russian (prepositional phrase vs. noun phrase in the instrumental case). The factors include the type of Ground, the semantics of the motion verb, as well as lexical frequency of the noun describing the Ground. Instrumental noun phrases encoding trajectories are argued to be in the process of lexicalization as adverbs. Recent changes in the distribution of the two strategies are consistent with the general tendency toward increasing analyticity in Russian and other Slavic languages.

While focusing on different Indo-European languages and language groups, the papers address a variety of issues in the diachrony of spatial marking, including the development of differential encoding of the same spatial relation (Luraghi; Philippova) and syncretisms in the encoding of different relations (Brucale & Mocciaro; Nikitina; Stolz et al.; Thomason & Eckhoff); asymmetries in the grammaticalization of spatial expressions (Lewis; Zanchi) and typological changes in the encoding of motion events (Iacobini et al.; Kopecka; Sotelo). A number of papers discuss various aspects of the asymmetry between Goals and Sources (Georgakopoulos & Karatsareas; Iacobini et al.; Kopecka; Nikitina; Verkerk; Sotelo; Zanchi).

The different methodologies represented in the volume include the study of parallel corpora and translations (Iacobini et al.; Kopecka; Thomason & Eckhoff; Verkerk), direct comparison of lexical and grammatical resources (Stolz et al.); quantitative analysis of diachronic corpus data (Lewis; Philippova), and the use of phylogenetic methods (Verkerk).

title-group.title: The goal-over-source principle in European languages
title-group.subtitle: Preliminary results from a parallel corpus study
title-group.alt-title: The goal-over-source principle in European languages

contrib-group.aff: Reading, Evolutionary Biology Group, University of Reading

abstract.p: This paper investigates the linguistic encoding of source, trajectory, and goal in seventeen Indo-European languages. The data comes from translations of Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone in the ParaSol parallel corpus. The original English text and all translations display more frequent marking of goal than of source or trajectory and thus conform to the goal-over-source principle identified by Ikegami (1987). This goal bias is explained by a translation strategy where goal information is expanded upon to the demise of trajectory information, as goal information is most important for following the narrative. An attempt is made to explain cross-linguistic differences in path encoding using phylogenetic comparative methods, but unfortunately the dataset is too small to allow for generalizations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In discourse about motion, the places where moving entities end up are of special relevance, both in spoken conversation and in written text. Much of human action is purpose-driven, and therefore the endstate of motion is a frequent topic. This conceptual bias is reflected in language used to encode motion. Linguistic research has demonstrated an asymmetry in the encoding of various types of path: goals of motion are expressed more frequently and with more fine-grained linguistic resources than sources of motion (Ikegami 1987; Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004; Lakusta & Landau 2005; Wälchli & Zúñiga 2006; Regier & Zheng 2007; Nikitina 2009; Kabata 2013; among others). This bias has been called the ‘goal-over-source principle’ by Ikegami (1987), who first discussed it. How this bias is realized both conceptually and diachronically are relevant avenues of inquiry in psycholinguistics, historical linguistics, and typology.

This article investigates the linguistic encoding of various types of path in translations of written texts in seventeen Indo-European languages of Europe: French, Portuguese, Romanian (Romance), Dutch, English, German (Germanic), Bulgarian, Croatian, Czech, Macedonian, Russian, Serbian, Slovak, Slovene, Ukrainian (Slavic), Modern Greek, and Armenian. The path of motion can be thought of having a beginning point (source), a middle stage (trajectory), and an endpoint (goal). The current study uses parallel corpus data to uncover whether goals are more commonly encoded in this sample of languages, and a range of phylogenetic comparative methods, concepts from translation studies, and other analytical tools to explain the attested cross-translation variation. This study contributes to the already existing literature by presenting results of a study on the encoding of sources and goals in a sample of related languages, which would make it possible to study the diachrony of the goal-over-source principle. It is an early report on a larger project and as such gives an impression of the data, illustrates methods, and suggests a number of avenues for further research.

sec.title: The goal-over-source principle in path encoding
sec.p: Descriptions of spatial relations contain two types of information: (1) information about the configuration of figure and ground, and (2) information on whether the relation between figure and ground is dynamic or static (Nikitina 2009). Taken together, these two types of information can be represented on a semantic map of locative roles. When the relation between figure and ground is static, the locative role is that of place (‘work in the office’). When the relation is dynamic, different configurations of figure and ground give rise to an additional three locative roles: source (‘walk from the house’) and goal (‘walk into/to the house’) (Nikitina 2009), and additionally trajectory (‘walk through the house’). The dynamic locative roles can be construed on a path (Jackendoff 1983: 162; Talmy 1985: 57; Lakoff 1987: 275). In the context of motion, path can be defined as the route traversed by a figure; in a more general context, as the route towards a different state. In the long tradition of linguistic research on case systems, different elements of this route, including source and goal, have long had central roles (see Hjelmslev 1935: 37). This paper is concerned with these three dynamic locatives on the path traversed by a figure: the initial part (the source), the medial part (called path by Fillmore 1971: 26; Lakoff 1987: 275 and Verspoor & Dirven 2004: 83; route/via-path by Jackendoff 1983: 165–166; trajectory by Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004: 250), and the final part (the goal) (see Talmy 2000 (Vol. 1): 266 for the terms initial, medial, and final). I will call the initial part the source, the medial part the trajectory, and the final part the goal. The locative role of place is not considered in this paper, as the aim was to study different types of path concerned with motion. Place is a semantically closely related locative role. However, it is on the other hand also clearly separate from the dynamic locatives source, trajectory, and goal.

As stated in Section 1, a growing body of literature has demonstrated an asymmetry in the encoding of these various sections of path: goals of motion are expressed more frequently and with more fine-grained linguistic resources than sources of motion (Ikegami 1987; Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004; Lakusta & Landau 2005; Wälchli & Zúñiga 2006; Regier & Zheng 2007; Nikitina 2009; Kabata 2013; among others). The first to notice this asymmetry was Ikegami (1987), who termed the phrase ‘goal-over-source principle’. Ikegami (1987) found that sources are more easily substituted by goals than the other way around, source marking is more marked than goal marking, and semantic shift where source denotation is reinterpreted to denote goal is possible, but not the other way around.

Ikegami’s work can be seen as an extension of earlier work on locative roles and case marking. Blake (1977) and Andrews (1985) already discussed an apparent asymmetry regarding the marking of place, source, and goal in the languages of the world: goal marking is often conflated with place marking, with a different marker for source, while source marking is never only conflated with place marking to the exclusion of goal marking. This finding is elaborated upon in Nikitina (2009), Pancheva (2010) and Wälchli & Zúñiga (2006), among others. Out of these, Wälchli and Zúñiga (2006) investigate the largest cross-linguistic sample, of 117 languages. They find that the majority of languages consistently differentiates between source and goal (71 languages), some only have weakly grammaticalized source marking (29 languages), and some do not have separate markers for source and goal (17 languages) (Wälchli & Zúñiga 2006: 295). There is a clear areal distribution, such that Eurasia, South East Asia, Oceania, and Australia are consistently source–goal differentiating, while Africa is mostly mixed (only weakly grammaticalized source marking) and North America is mostly indifferent (no separate markers for source and goal). In addition, they find an association between the existence of adnominal markers and source–goal differentiation: languages with adnominal markers tend to differentiate between source and goal consistently, whereas languages that lack adnominal markers do not.

Since Ikegami (1987), the goal-over-source principle has been studied in many different languages that differentiate between source and goal, using a variety of methodologies. Several cross-linguistic studies have remarked upon the differential range of source and goal markers. Kabata (2013) finds that both case markers and prepositions that denote the allative (goal-oriented) can be used to cover a significantly larger range of semantic domains than ablative (source-oriented) markers. Svorou (1994) presents an overview of all morphemes relating spatial configurations in 26 languages and finds that 153 are goal oriented, whereas 68 are source oriented.

Other studies have focused on corpus data rather than morphological inventories. Stefanowitsch and Rohde (2004) investigated the goal-over-source principle in motion PPs in English using the North-American News corpus. They looked at a range of different motion verbs and how they are combined with motion PPs that encode source, trajectory, or goal. They show that whereas the deictic verb go combines more frequently with goal PPs, other motion verbs show other patterns. Jump and escape combine most frequently with source PPs, and stroll and cruise with trajectory PPs (see Nikitina 2009 for a similar observation in the Mande language Wan). They find that their corpus data is best explained by the hypothesis that “goal PPs have a higher information value than other path-PPs and are thus more useful in arriving at a complete conceptualization of a motion event” (Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004: 249). Exceptions to the goal-over-source principle, including the behavior of verbs like escape, stroll, and cruise, can be explained through the fact that not all motion events are conceptualized as having a source, trajectory and goal. Motion events for which goal is not relevant, including a sentence such as “Andrew was strolling through the park”, should therefore be expected to be exceptions to the goal-over-source principle.

Experimental work on the goal-over-source principle ranges from studies focusing exclusively on linguistic behavior to studies that investigate the interaction between language and non-linguistic cognition. Regier and Zheng (2007) find that speakers of Lebanese Arabic, Mandarin Chinese, and English make more fine grained distinctions in the description of endpoints rather than beginnings in joining and separating events. Lakusta and Landau (2005: 3) show that in all their three participant groups (children between three and seven, children with Williams syndrome, and adults), descriptions of events featuring both a source and a goal feature significantly more goals than sources. They also identify verb choice as an influential factor in path encoding. Papafragou (2010) demonstrates that both child and adult English speakers encode goals with higher degrees of detail: they include more references and supply more fine-grained lexical encoding for goals than for sources of motion. Lakusta (2005) demonstrated that the goal-over-source principle can be found in non-linguistic cognition as well.

Several explanations for the goal-over-source principle have been proposed. First of all, it can be stated that in everyday human experience, the goal, as it represents the purpose of action, is more important than the source (Verspoor & Dirven 2004: 84–85; Lakusta & Landau 2005: 30). Stefanowitsch and Rohde (2004: 251) call this the (psychological) salience hypothesis. This hypothesis would explain why the goal is encoded more often in corpora. It would also imply that languages would develop more morphological material in order to code goal often and with more precision, resulting in the bigger goal inventories found by Svorou (1994) and others. A second possible explanation provided by Stefanowitsch and Rohde (2004: 251) is that the goal is more relevant than the source if we are to infer the complete path of motion in a communicative context (they cite Ungerer & Schmidt 1996). Thirdly, Lakusta and Landau (2005: 31) propose that humans pay attention to events sequentially, and the spatial relationship at the end is most likely to survive memory wise (they cite Regier 1997). Despite these explanations, we do not expect the goal-over-source principle to be absolute, given that not all motion events are conceptualized as having a source, trajectory, and goal (Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004: 264). Additionally, some motion verbs may be associated with particular kinds of paths. Some verbs even require a particular path complement (Lakusta & Landau 2005: 3–4). These may even be analyzed as ‘chunks’ rather than compositionally.

It is also possible to look at the goal-over-source principle from the highly influential Talmian perspective on motion (Talmy 1985, 2000). Talmy famously developed the lexicalization approach to studying motion events, in which he separates languages that typically lexicalize the path of motion in the verb (verb-framed languages) from languages that lexicalize path in the so-called satellite (satellite-framed languages). His typology was refined to include more types (Slobin 2004) and has been adjusted to a continuum that captures language variation on a cline rather than in a dichotomy (Slobin 2004; Ibarretxe-Antuñano 2009; Beavers et al. 2010; Croft et al. 2010; Verkerk 2014). At first sight, we would not expect languages to show correlated behavior with regard to the goal-over-source principle and particular characteristics of the Talmian typology, as the goal-over-source principle is something of a supposed universal across languages, while Talmian motion characteristics are highly variable between languages. However, Wälchli and Zúñiga (2006) have shown that languages with adnominal markers tend to differentiate between source and goal consistently, whereas languages that lack adnominal markers do not. If languages with different terms for source and goal use adnominal markers to code for path, their adnominal markers could be viewed as satellites (not in Talmy’s original theory, but see for instance Beavers et al. 2010: 338). A potential correlation regarding the goal-over-source principle and Talmian motion typology could thus be that satellite-framed languages display a more pronounced goal bias. It would be a reasonable hypothesis to state that languages with adnominal markers for source and goal are likely to be satellite-framed, as path is marked outside the verb, and these languages are likely to have a larger goal bias than non-satellite-framed languages, because they have had ample opportunity to develop relevant goal markers. Clearly, potential interaction with other aspects of motion coding, as well as other grammatical characteristics, will have an impact on the extend of the goal-over-source principle.

In the current study, the focus is on parallel corpus data, and as such we are dealing with written, translated language (see Wälchli 2007: 132 for a summary of the biases of parallel texts as a data source). Characteristics of translated language as opposed to non-translated language have been studied extensively in the field of translation studies, especially since Baker’s seminal paper on the relevance of corpora for the study of translation in 1993 (see for overviews Tirkkonen-Condit 2002; Granger 2003; Xiao 2010). Baker (1993) proposed a set of translation universals, “features which typically occur in translated text rather than original utterances and which are not the result of interference from specific linguistic systems” (Baker 1993: 243). These include explicitation, simplification, and normalization (Baker 1993; Xiao 2010: 8ff). Explicitation refers to the tendency of translated texts to incorporate optional material, be it spelling out background information or using more connectives, for instance. Simplification implies that the target text is generally simpler than the source text, in lexical, syntactical and/or stylistic terms. Normalization indicates that translated texts tend to conform to normal native patterns, so much so that typical features of the target language may become overused. Although the existence of these universals is contested (see Tirkkonen-Condit 2002; Xiao 2010: 8 for references), special properties of translated texts need to be considered as potential explanations for any cross-linguistic effect we find. For the current paper, explicitation is the most relevant of the proposed translation universals. Explicitation implies more elaborate encoding of path information, including source, trajectory, and goal. However, explicitation does not predict that goal information is marked more frequently than source or trajectory information. The relevance of goal information over source and trajectory information (see above, Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004: 251) is potentially more important to explain a goal bias in written materials. A goal bias could be caused by pressure to keep the reader up to date on where the various protagonists are located in (imaginary) space. Goal-marking could be more prevalent in written text simply because the reader needs more goal information than source or trajectory information to follow the events that unfold in a novel.
The hypotheses of this study are as follows.

list-item.p: The original text, English, adheres to the goal-over-source principle and thus contains more goal marking than either source or trajectory marking.

The translated texts also have more goal marking than either source or trajectory marking, additionally the ratio of goal marking versus source and trajectory marking should be even more skewed, as translators impose an extra layer of the goal bias onto an already goal-biased original.

The translated texts display cross-linguistic differences in their marking of source, trajectory, and goal that pattern similarly as other, Talmian motion measures, see Verkerk (2014). Specifically, satellite-framed languages display a larger goal-over-source bias than non-satellite-framed languages.

sec.p: Section 4 will investigate these hypotheses regarding cross-linguistic explanations of the goal-over-source principle, but first, the data is introduced in Section 3.

sec.title: The current study: Data collection and coding
sec.p: The current paper gives an impression of the encoding of source, trajectory, and goal in translations into seventeen Indo-European languages. It presents the first results of a larger study of data on the translation of path in the ParaSol parallel corpus (von Waldenfels & Meyer 2006-present). For now, the language sample is entirely convenience-based, as it contains those languages for which Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone by J. K. Rowling was available in the ParaSol corpus in 2015: French, Portuguese, Romanian (Romance), Dutch, English, German (Germanic), Bulgarian, Croatian, Czech, Macedonian, Russian, Serbian, Slovak, Slovene, Ukrainian (Slavic), Armenian, and Modern Greek. In the future, we aim to include a more balanced sample of languages. Given this future expansion of the dataset, the results presented in Section 4 are preliminary and should be considered as such.

The ultimate aim of this project is to study source, trajectory, and goal as they are encoded in different types of motion verbs: path verbs, deictic verbs, and manner verbs (similar to Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004). However, the current paper reports on a preliminary dataset with only manner verbs. This dataset is obtained by consulting the list of manner verbs compiled by Levin (1993) in her Chapters 51.3 (roll and run verbs) and 51.4 (verbs of motion using a vehicle). I ignore Levin’s (1993) so called waltz verbs (51.5), as this category contains verbs describing various dances, as well as her chase verbs (51.6), which could be construed as path verbs (motion towards a moving entity) rather than manner verbs, although these verbs do encode a sense of urgency and speed. Also included are a handful of non-monomorphemic verbs that contain the nominal counterparts of certain manner verbs and thus came up during the search for manner verbs (take flight, give a jump, throw oneself, etc.). In total, I search the corpus for 246 manner verb types.

This search generates 490 tokens in Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone. The clauses in which these manner verbs appear are coded for animacy, tense, and path, as the aim is to obtain those sentences in which humans are described to have moved to a new location. For this purpose, I exclude the following: sentences with inanimate or non-human figures, sentences that encode unfinished events with verbs in non-past tense, or motion events in which the figure does not travel to a new location, as Exemplified in (1) through (3) respectively. Excluding these results in a sample of 169 relevant motion descriptions with manner verbs, either as the main verb, such as in (4), or as a gerund, as in (5).

list-item.p: His broomstick was still rising higher and higher, and started to drift lazily toward the forbidden forest and out of sight. (inanimate figure)
Harry noticed at once that Snape was limping. (non-past verb)
That evening, Dudley paraded around the living room for the family in his brand-new uniform. (verb in past tense, but no new location)

p.italic: Neville, his face tear-streaked, clutching his wrist, hobbled off with Madam Hooch, who had her arm around him.
Then, out of the shadows, a hooded figure came crawling across the ground like some stalking beast.

sec.p: This sample of 169 motion descriptions is only a small sample to base inferences on regarding source, trajectory, and goal encoding. Not only is it small and limited in scope because of the search only for manner verbs, it is also limited because these motion descriptions are taken from only a single literary work. This means that, for each language, we are dealing with only one translation and thus only with one translator who has generated the body of linguistic material under investigation. It would be better not to speak of language comparison in this paper, but rather of translation comparison – in the remainder of this paper, I use both the terms ‘language’ and ‘translation’ to refer to the specific doculects captured by the Harry Potter original and translations.

These 169 motion descriptions are coded further for the presence or absence of the three relevant types of path; source, trajectory, and goal. For the coding of path, I make a distinction between two types of path: those that implicitly or that explicitly include reference to a ground. This follows from Slobin’s (1996: 201) distinction between plus-ground and minus-ground clauses: in minus-ground clauses, the verb and/or satellite(s) indicate direction, whereas plus-ground clauses feature one or more (prepositional) phrases that encode path and ground (in addition to the verb and/or satellite). In the 169 relevant motion descriptions, a mixture of explicit and implicit paths is present. Sometimes the source, trajectory, and goal of motion are encoded explicitly by reference to a ground and its appropriate case, adposition, or role as verb complement. In all other cases, the path can be reconstructed on the basis of the context, but there is no explicit mention of a ground, and thus these paths remain implicit. Example (4) is an illustration: Neville and Madam Hooch move away from the rest of the class, as coded by ‘off’; and from the context it is clear that their destination is the infirmary. Their trajectory is unknown, but at the very least it involves a transition from outside the castle to inside the castle, where the infirmary is located. Although the path is clear, it remains implied, as neither source, trajectory, nor goal are explicitly coded. Both the context preceding and the context following the relevant clause is considered in the inference of an implicit path, although usually the relevant information precedes the clause under investigation. In Example (7), the goal of motion is explicitly coded through the explicit path phrase ‘to the stool’. The source of motion (the line of children waiting to be sorted by the Sorting Hat) and the trajectory (along the stage) are again left implicit.

Examples (5) through (7) illustrate the coding of explicit paths in Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone in English. There is one sentence in the sample that encodes all three types of path, source, trajectory, and goal, given in (6). In (6), the source is coded by the PP ‘out of the chamber’, the trajectory by ‘across the hall’ and ‘through a pair of double doors’, and the goal by ‘into the Great Hall’. This sentence is clearly exceptional in that it codes source, trajectory (twice), and goal, all explicitly. As the reader will note, source and trajectory information could have been left out (“…and they walked into the Great Hall” would have sufficed as well) or rearranged in difference clauses (“…and they walked out of the chamber. They went back across the hall…”). Many languages restrict the number of explicit paths in a single clause (Ibarretxe-Antuñano 2009: 405–408): Verb-framed Spanish, for instance, usually features only a single path complement, while verb-framed Basque, frequently uses two path complements per clause. English, on the other hand, allows the stacking of explicit grounds in a single clause displayed in (6). In spite of cross-linguistic variation, it is superfluous to use more than one, two, or in extreme cases, three or more explicit paths in the large majority of motion clauses across languages, as more explicit information on path is simply not needed – much remains implicit.

p.italic: Feeling oddly as though his legs had turned to lead, Harry got into line behind a boy with sandy hair, with Ron behind him, and

list-item.p: [they walked out of the chamber,]source
[back across the hall,]trajectory
[and through a pair of double doors]trajectory
[into the Great Hall.]goal

p.italic: Hermione almost ran to the stool and jammed the hat eagerly on her head.

sec.p: The 169 selected sentences include at least an implicit path, given the criteria listed above, but most of them also explicitly encode path through the overt mention of one or more grounds. Path is also coded on verbs, adverbs and verbal affixes in the languages of the sample. I chose not to study these in the current paper because unlike the recognition of explicit path phrases, the correct analysis of motion verbs, adverbs and verbal affixes requires detailed knowledge and analysis of each language, which was outside of the scope of this study. Perhaps it would have been possible to include adverbs in addition to explicit paths, as these are easily accessible, even to a non-specialist in these languages such as myself. However, I decided against this because it would mean adding a bias to the analysis, as the translation of adverbs is determined for a large part by the Talmian motion type of the target language.

As an example of this bias, in the selected 169 English sentences, 75 (44%) feature a path adverb. Out of these 75 sentences, in 39 the adverb appears in combination with an explicit path phrase, such as in Example (6), ‘(…) back across the hall (…)’. There are 36 (21%) sentences in which path is only coded with an adverb, as in Example (8). I checked the French translations of these 36 sentences to see which devices were used to code the English adverb. In 9 out of these 36 sentences, French coded the path with an explicit path phrase (Example (9)), in 16 of them, a path verb is used (Example (10)), and in 4, an adverb is used (Example (11)) (the remaining 6 sentences diverge too widely from the original to fit in this three-way classification). The most common strategy for verb-framed French is thus to encode the path encoded by the English adverb on a path verb. In satellite-framed German, for instance, this strategy would occur less often. Including adverbs in the study by looking if these are also translated by adverbs would thus be introducing a Talmian bias. To check whether adverbs are translated by explicit path phrases, verbs, or verbal prefixes would again be beyond the scope of this study, as this again requires a detailed knowledge of motion vocabulary semantics in each of the languages of the sample. Thus, the main dataset considered here is an assessment of whether or not explicit paths were present in the translations of a sample of 169 sentences in each of the 16 languages.

list-item.p: When Aunt Petunia and Dudley had run out with their arms over their faces, Uncle Vernon slammed the door shut.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: When it finally shouted, “GRYFFINDOR,” Neville ran off still wearing it, and had to jog back amid gales of laughter to give it to “MacDougal, Morag.”

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘”Gryffindor!” Neville rushed towards his friends without removing the hat from his head.’

p.italic: Half blinded, he staggered backward.

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘Half blinded, he stepped back staggering.’

p.italic: He stumbled backward and knocked over his lamp, which went out at once.

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘Harry fell backwards, turning over his lamp that went out instantly,’

sec.p: As a side note before continuing with Section 4, note that in the 9 French translations of adverbs with explicit path phrases, a ground is introduced that did not feature in the original, as in Example (9), ‘vers ses camarades’. These introduced explicit path phrases are clearly optional, as French has the means to translate the path in (9a) without introducing a ground, for instance using verbs that code path such as ‘enfuir’ or ‘s’eloigner’, or the adverb ‘loin’. There are many considerations in choosing the devices to encode path, several of which fall outside of the scope of this paper, including Talmian typology type, the fact that some motion verbs require an adpositional complement (Lakusta & Landau 2005), or the salience of the ground (Viti 2008). A start of an explanation of why translators opt to add such explicit paths in translations of Harry Potter is made in Section 5.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The first thing to consider is the distribution of explicitly coded paths in the original English text. Out of 169 sentences, 16 (9%) encode a source, 44 (26%) encode a trajectory, and 77 (46%) encode a goal. The English text thus clearly displays the goal-over-source principle, as it encodes goals more often than sources and trajectories.

When we consider the translations, there are two ways to look at the data: first, we can look at the absolute number of sentences that encode sources, trajectories, and goals. Second, we can look at the number of times a source, trajectory, or goal that is encoded in the English original, is left out or kept in the translation. These two measures tell us slightly different things about how sources, trajectories, and goals are treated in the translations.

The percentage of sentences that encode a source, trajectory, and goal is presented in Figure 1. In Figure 1, as well as in the following Figures, English as the language of the original text is on the left, with then to the right the Germanic, Romance, Slavic, Armenian, and Greek languages. The English scores give the percentages of sentences with explicit path coding present in the original text, the remaining scores give the same for the translations. Percentages rather than counts are given in order not to deflate the scores because of missing translations (the number of missing translations ranges from 1 (Croatian, Dutch, German, Ukrainian) to 14 (Romanian), median is 2). Missing data makes it impossible to test for significant differences between English and the translations using regular statistics such as Pearson’s chi-squared test. (Another complication would be that Pearson’s chi-squared test does not corrected for genealogical relatedness, which would be required for this dataset, see Section 5.1) Therefore, the patterns identified below should be interpreted as trends rather than significant differences between translations and languages.

caption.title: Percentage of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that encode an explicit source, trajectory, and goal in 17 languages. The English percentages are marked with dotted line for ease of comparison

sec.p: Figure 1 shows that some translations code source less frequent than English (most notably German, Bulgarian, and Macedonian), while others code source more often than English (most notably Slovak, Slovene, and Armenian). The encoding of trajectory is quite different. With few exceptions (German and Croatian), trajectories are coded less often in the translations. The most extreme case is Dutch, which only codes trajectories in 18% of the sentences, as compared to 26% for English. The pattern for the encoding of goal is yet again different: goal is, without exception, coded more frequently in the translations than in the original English text. This suggests support for the goal-over-source principal in this corpus. The types of contexts in which goal information is added and trajectory marking is removed are explored further in Section 5.2.

To further investigate the coding of sources, trajectories, and goals in the translations, it is possible to have a look at how often they are removed and added on a sentence-by-sentence basis in the translations.

caption.title: Percentage of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that remove or add an explicit source in 16 languages

sec.p: The source is removed for between 0.5% (Portuguese, Slovene) and 4% (Dutch) of the sentences in the corpus. They are added for between 0.5% (Czech, Macedonian, Serbian, Ukrainian) and 5% (Dutch, Armenian) of the sentences. What is interesting is that several languages remove source encoding about as often as they add source encoding, suggesting that the translator sees fit to add an explicit source in some contexts, but removes it in other contexts.

caption.title: Percentage of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that remove or add an explicit trajectory in 16 languages

sec.p: The trajectory is removed far more often than the source, only Croatian adds a trajectory more often than it removes it. This is especially extreme for Dutch, French, Romanian, and Greek.

caption.title: Percentage of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that remove or add an explicit goal in 16 languages

sec.p: The goal, as we had already seen in Figure 1, is added more often than it is removed across all sixteen languages. While all languages share this bias, some display a larger bias than others: German, Portuguese, Bulgarian, and Serbian add a goal to about 4% of the 169 sentence corpus, while Dutch, Slovene, and Greek add a goal to between 12% and 14% of the sentences.

In Sections 5 and 6, I aim to find an explanation for these patterns. I will first explain the general goal-over-source principle attested across languages in Section 5 and then discuss possible explanations for differences between languages in Section 6.

sec.title: Why do these translations display a goal bias?
Dependencies between path encoding measures
sec.p: In this Section, I present evidence suggesting that the path measures are correlated among themselves, suggesting interactions between goal encoding, source encoding, and trajectory encoding. In order to do this, I use PGLS regression analyses (short for Phylogenetic Generalized Least Squares, see Pagel 1997: 340 ff.). PGLS regression works the same way as other linear regression analyses. However, it takes into account any phylogenetic relatedness in the error term of the regression formula. This is necessary for the current dataset, as the languages in the sample are all related. PGLS regressions were used to investigate correlations between the overall percentages of different types of path encoding, as well as between the percentages of how often the different types of path were added and removed.

Like all phylogenetic comparative methods, PGLS regression analysis uses information on the history of a set of languages as captured by a phylogenetic tree to say something about the evolutionary history of a certain trait. For the current analyses (including additional ones in Section 6), a subsampled phylogenetic tree set containing 1,000 trees was taken from Bouckaert et al. (2012). All languages featured in this paper are included in the tree set except for Serbian, which was not sampled in the original tree by Bouckaert et al. (2012). The tree set was pruned to include 16 languages for the measures capturing how often source, trajectory, and goal are encoded (the dataset presented in Figure 1) and 15 languages for the measures capturing how often source, trajectory, and goal are removed or added on a sentence-by-sentence basis (the dataset presented in Figure 2 through Figure 4). PGLS was conducted using maximum likelihood with the R (R Core Team 2015) function pgls() in the R package caper (Orme 2011).

The results of these analyses are presented in Appendix 1, where relevant correlations that approach significance are marked in bold. These must be considered tentative due to the small language sample. Two potential correlations were discovered: languages that have a higher percentage of goal encoding, also have a higher percentage of source encoding (p = 0.08); and languages that have a higher percentage of goal encoding, have a lower percentage of trajectory encoding (p = 0.004). Although the first trend is not significant on the p < 0.05 level, it is reflected again in a positive (but not significant) relation between the percentage of added goals and sources (p = 0.07). The positive interaction between source and goal encoding is depicted in Figure 5. The negative correlation between trajectory and goal encoding is reflected again in the relation between the percentage of removed goals and trajectories (Appendix 1, p = 0.05). It is depicted in Figure 6.

caption.title: Percentages of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that encode an explicit goal (y-axis) and source (x-axis)
Percentage of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that encode an explicit goal (y-axis) and trajectory (x-axis)

sec.p: These interactions between source, trajectory, and goal encoding indicate that translations that encode goal more often, also encode source more often, and encode trajectory less often. This suggests a translation strategy: in order draw attention to goal (and source), these are added to translations, while trajectory is left out, possibly to avoid overburdening the text with path information. Section 5.2 will explore these interactions further.

sec.title: Goals are added to translations to avoid ambiguity
sec.p: The correlations presented in Section 5.1 suggest that each language has strategies for translating path information, such that goal and source are faithfully translated and goal is in some cases expanded upon, whereas trajectory is neglected. This is perhaps surprising given the supposed translation universal explicitation discussed in Section 2, which predicts that all background information in the original text (including source, trajectory, and goal information) has the potential to be made explicit in translated text. However, in the current context, it seems that only the most relevant information, namely goal information, is made explicit. In order to explore the interaction between explicitation and relevance, I consider in this Section the sentences that are translated differently from the original in most doculects. Additions and removals of source, trajectory, and goal information are not randomly distributed across the 169 sentences that were analyzed: almost a third of the sentences (54) are faithfully translated, with no added or removed sources, trajectories, or goals, whereas 12 sentences are changed eight to sixteen times. This is illustrated in Figure 7.

caption.title: Frequency plot of the number of changes to source, trajectory, and goal encoding per sentence (n = 169)

sec.p: This inspection of the data on a sentence-by-sentence basis firstly unveiled that goals are often added to avoid ambiguity or to emphasize the place that the protagonist ends up in, and thus can be seen as instances of explicitation. These are occasions where in the original, the goal of motion is established in the context, but even so, the translator finds it necessary to make the goal explicit, so that there can be no doubt of the new location of the protagonist. A good example for this is the following corpus sentence, in which an explicit goal is absent from the original English in (12), and is subsequently added in eight out of sixteen translations (12a–h) (unfortunately it was not possible to include gender and case information in the glosses). These eight translations all add a phrase relating that one of the protagonists, Draco Malfoy, is walking to a hat laying on a small stool. Even though the stool is well established within the context of this sentence, eight translators deem it necessary to add this information here again.

p.italic: Malfoy swaggered forward when his name was called

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘When Malfoy was called, he to-walked to the hat importantly.’

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘When Malfoy was called, Draco pompously went to the stool.’

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘When it was Malfoy’s turn, he walked with big, arrogant steps to the stool.’

list-item.label: d.
list-item.p: ‘When his name was called, Malfoy went forward with confident steps towards the stool.’

list-item.label: e.
list-item.p: ‘When they heard the name Malfoy, the boy advanced proudly to the stool.’

list-item.label: f.
list-item.p: ‘Then came Draco Malfoy’s turn, who headed strutting to the hat.’

list-item.label: g.
list-item.p: ‘When he heard his name, Malfoy proudly moved to the hat.’

list-item.label: h.
list-item.p: ‘When it came to Draco’s turn, he ostentatiously through-walked to the chair.’

sec.p: Figure 7 and Example (12) illustrate the goal-over-source principle at work in translation: for the narrative to move forward, it is important to know where people are, rather than where they are coming from or what they pass along the way. In contexts where the goal is not explicit, translators may add an explicit goal in order to avoid the reader losing track of where protagonists are. Wälchli and Zúñiga (2006: 290) likewise state: “Source unlike Goal is often given information in narrative discourse”.

Secondly, the sentence-by-sentence perspective reveals that trajectory information is removed to make way for goal information. The trajectory may be dropped when goal information is added, since having both may clutter the phrase with too much path information. An example is provided in (13), where the original English has an explicit trajectory, ‘down the front steps’, and goal, ‘onto the grounds’. Eight translators make changes to this arrangement of path information, removing either trajectory or goal information (or both).

p.italic: At three-thirty that afternoon, Harry, Ron, and the other Gryffindors hurried down the front steps onto the grounds for their first flying lesson.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p:
‘On that day, at three-thirty, Harry, Ron and the other Gryffindors, came out of the main entrance of the castle, and rushed towards the stadium behind the castle:’
(source, goal)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘At three-thirty in the afternoon, Harry, Ron, and the other Gryffindors walked hastily down the front steps for their very first flying lesson in the park.’ (source, goal)

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘At three-thirty this afternoon, the Gryffindor students went out into the park to get to the place of their first flying lesson.’ (goal only)

list-item.label: d.
list-item.p: ‘At three-thirty in the afternoon all students from the first class in Gryffindor went down the front stairs to their first flying lesson.’ (trajectory only)

list-item.label: e.
list-item.p: ‘In the afternoon, at three-thirty, Harry, Ron and all other Gryffindors stepped out for the first flying lesson.’ (no explicit paths)

list-item.label: f.
list-item.p: ‘At three-thirty in the afternoon, the same day, Harry, Ron and the other Gryffindors came down into the yard for their first flying lesson.’ (goal only)

list-item.label: g.
list-item.p: ‘It was about half past three in the afternoon, Harry, along with Ron and the other Gryffindor students hurried down the main staircase for their first flying lesson.’ (trajectory only)

list-item.label: h.
list-item.p: ‘At half-past four that afternoon, Harry, Ron and other Gryffindors poured from the castle and glasshouses into the castle park, which they will have their first flying lesson.’ (source, goal)

sec.p: In (13a) through (13h), Romanian drops both the trajectory and the goal and simply states that the Gryffindors went outside for their first flying lesson. French and Serbian drop the trajectory. French interestingly adds a second goal, as it explicitly mentions both the grounds and the ‘place where the first flying lesson is held’. Macedonian and Slovak drop the goal, which is possible as these translations still feature the purpose of the motion, i.e. attending the first flying lesson. Armenian, Dutch and Slovene rephrase the trajectory as a source, emphasizing that the students have left the castle. The trajectory is thus dropped or rephrased by six languages, and the goal by three – it seems that this sentence is judged as heavy on path information, and is consequently rephrased to convey the most relevant parts to the reader. The purpose of the motion, i.e. attendance of the flying lesson, is judged as most important, and this is faithfully translated, while the trajectory and (to a lesser extent) the goal are removed. This example illustrates that it is possible to encode purpose without reference to goal, as done by Macedonian and Slovak, by encoding the aim of motion without reference to where the flying lesson is held. Most often, goal and purpose are construed in the same phrase, as was the case for the translations in (12).

The goal-over-source principle attested in all sixteen translations can be explained by ambiguity avoidance, as goal information is most relevant, and the dropping of trajectory information could be caused by avoidance of too much path information. From a translation studies perspective, the results could be explained as an instance of explicitation, of spelling out already established background information (Baker 1993: 243–244; Xiao 2010: 8–9). However, if explicitation was the only factor acting on path elaboration, we would not expect source, trajectory, and goal information to be treated as differently as they are.

sec.title: Why do some translations display a larger goal bias than others?
Talmian typology does not explain cross-linguistic differences
sec.p: Now that the dynamics of the goal-over-source principle in the sample have been discussed in Section 5, in this Section the focus is on explaining why some translations display a large effect of the goal-over-source principle and others a small effect. The Talmian motion typology is a good starting point given the potential interaction of the goal-over-source principle, adnominal marking of goal and source, and the prevalence of the satellite-framed construction as identified in Section 2.

The work of Talmy (1985, 2000, among others) and Slobin (1996, 2004, 2005, and many more) has been very influential on studies of spatial semantics. Slobin’s studies especially have contributed to the identification of a set of interlinked features of motion event encoding across languages, including where path is expressed (in the verb or in the satellite), the size of manner verb and path verb lexicon, event segmentation, the amount of path/ground elaboration, and the availability of nonverbal manner elaboration (ideophones, verb compounding). As of yet, it is unclear how all these features interlink exactly, as only a few studies have investigated correlations over a wide sample of languages (Berthele 2013; Ibarretxe-Antuñano 2009; Verkerk 2014; Wälchli 2009). If anything, it has not been shown that satellite-framed and verb-framed characteristics line up exactly with preferences regarding explicit path stacking. Ibarretxe-Antuñano (2009) shows that Basque, while verb-framed, behaves very differently from verb-framed French and Spanish in this respect. However, it could be possible that if the size of the goal-over-source principle varies, as shown in Section 4, this cross-linguistic variation could be related to differences in motion features – stacking of path phrases, adnominal marking of path, and differentiation between source and goal (Wälchli & Zúñiga 2006) are all relevant cross-linguistic parameters.

In order to give a cross-linguistic, Talmian explanation for the results presented in Section 4, I include in Example (14) the translations of Example (6). This provides some insight in how the translations deal with the stacking of explicit paths in a single clause and also illustrates their position on the Talmian cline of verb-framed and satellite-framed languages. For reasons of space, I leave out the first part of the sentence and only include the translation that contains motion. I start with the original English repeated in (14) and the translations in Dutch and German in (14a) and (14b).

p.italic: Feeling oddly as though his legs had turned to lead, Harry got into line behind a boy with sandy hair, with Ron behind him, and they walked out of the chamber, back across the hall, and through a pair of double doors into the Great Hall.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘(…) In this manner they walked out of the room crossed the hallway, and went inside the Great Hall through double doors.’

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘(…) and in single file they left the chamber, went back through the hallway and entered the Great Hall through double doors.’

sec.p: Dutch and German are satellite-framed languages (both: Slobin 2005; Verkerk 2014; Dutch: Croft et al. 2010: 227; German: Berthele 2006). They generally allow the stacking of explicit path phrases (Slobin 2005), but neither of them does so in these two translations: they use one verb to code the departure from the chamber, one verb to code the crossing of the hallway, and one verb to code the entry, through the double doors, of the Great Hall.

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘(…) and the line of students left the room, crossed the hall again and then crossed a double door that opened into the Great Hall.’

list-item.label: d.
list-item.p: ‘(…) and everyone left the room, turned to cross the lobby and the double doors leading to the Great Hall.’

list-item.label: e.
list-item.p: ‘They left the room, and passed through the entrance hall and from there through some double doors, they reached the Great Hall.’

sec.p: French, Portuguese, and Romanian are verb-framed languages (Slobin 2005; Verkerk 2014), and, as other Romance languages, generally do not allow explicit path stacking of the extend that English and other Germanic languages do (Slobin 2005; Ibarretxe-Antuñano 2009 for Spanish). This is reflected in the translations of (14). All three languages use three verbs to code the total path, with French and Portuguese putting the last explicit ground in a relative clause. Note that these three Romance languages do not behave very different than Dutch and German, indicating that preferences regarding stacking of explicit path phrases do not necessarily appear in all contexts.

list-item.label: f.
list-item.p: ‘Behind him was Ron and so they out-go from the room, crossed the entrance hall and through two double doors into-go the Great Hall.’

list-item.label: g.
list-item.p: ‘They out-went from the chamber, returned to the lobby and into-went through the double doors into the Great Hall.’

list-item.label: h.
list-item.p: ‘(…) so all together they went from the chamber into the hall and through the double doors stepped into a large hall.’

list-item.label: i.
list-item.p: ‘(…) They went back through the corridor. Through a double door they entered the great hall’

list-item.label: j.

sec.p: The Slavic languages are renowned for their verbal prefixes that encode path and aspect (Bulgarian: Croft et al. 2010: 214–217; Lindsey 2011; Czech: Fibigerova et al. 2012; Serbian-Croatian: Filipović 2007; Slobin 2005; Russian: Slobin 2005; Verkerk 2014; Pavlenko & Volynsky 2015; Hickmann et al. to appear). They are mostly satellite-framed, but there is considerable variation: Lindsey (2011) shows that Bulgarian, and to a lesser extent Serbo-Croatian, is moving toward becoming a verb-framed language under pressure from verb-framed languages in the Balkan Sprachbund (she mentions Turkish, Romanian, Greek, and Albanian). Slavic languages such as Russian and Serbo-Croatian allow explicit path stacking but given their dependence on verbal prefixes to code path, they are less likely to do so than the Germanic languages (Slobin 2005). In (14f) through (14n), only the Slovene translation stacks all four path elements into one clause. The Bulgarian, Czech, Slovak, and Ukrainian translations use three verbs, similar to the Germanic and Romance translations. The Croatian and Macedonian translations (the latter of which leaves out the source), the Russian translation (which leaves out the hallway trajectory), and the Serbian translation use two verbs.
