list-item.p: ‘(…) and walking as a row they came out of the room, again they passed the hallway and through a pair of large doors into the Great Hall:’

list-item.label: p.
list-item.p: ‘(…) and they began all together to come out from the small room, crossing the hall again and enter the large dining room.’

sec.p: Armenian and Greek are both difficult to place within the traditional Talmian motion typology. Armenian patterns neither with verb-framed or with satellite-framed languages (Verkerk 2014), and the status of Greek has been debated (Hickmann et al. to appear; Soroli & Verkerk to appear). It is not clear from the literature whether they allow the stacking of several explicit paths. Here, they both use three verbs.

In Figure 8, I present again the percentages of source, trajectory, and goal encoding, but now the translations are ordered on a Talmian cline from ‘most satellite-framed’ (Russian) to ‘least satellite-framed’ (Armenian). This ordering was done on the basis of Verkerk (2014: 55) and the literature just cited, but of course is for a large part ad hoc as this sample of languages has not previously been compared in this respect. Simply eye-balling Figure 8 does not suggest any patterning between a larger goal bias and a more satellite-framed character. A quantitative analysis would be needed to rule out this possible effect altogether. Given the lack of further data on motion characteristics such as the amount of satellite-framed and verb-framed clauses in this sample, in Section 6.2, I present a test of phylogenetic signal. Several motion characteristics display phylogenetic signal (Verkerk 2014). If the goal-over-source principle does as well, that would be a reason to continue investigation further. If it does not, perhaps we should look elsewhere to explain the cross-translation differences in goal bias.

caption.title: Percentage of sentences in the 169 sentence sample from HP and the Philosophers Stone that encode an explicit source, trajectory, and goal in 17 languages, ordered from most ‘satellite-framed’ (left) to most ‘verb-framed’ (right)

sec.title: Language history does not explain cross-linguistic differences
sec.p: In this Section, phylogenetic comparative methods are used to first find evidence for any historical signal, and potentially secondly identify changes in path encoding and reconstruct ancestral states. Historical signal is present when there is evidence for a specific relationship between the behavior of languages and their genealogy; when it is true that more closely related languages display more similar behavior (see Verkerk 2014 for a discussion of finding historical signal in linguistic data). Many features of languages have historical signal – such as aspects of numeral systems (Zhou & Bowern 2015; Calude & Verkerk 2016), motion event encoding (Verkerk), and word order (Dunn et al. 2011). However, this is not always true: lack of variation in the feature, parallel change with other cultural or linguistic features, borrowing, and very rapid linguistic change are all relevant factors that impact the relationship between behavior and genealogical relatedness. Revell et al. (2008) write that it is difficult to assess the individual contribution of factors that act on the evolutionary process, and conclude that low historical signal in a biological feature is difficult to explain.

In this section, a commonly applied test for historical signal is used to assess whether the encoding of the various types of path in seventeen related Indo-European languages is determined by their shared history. The test is the optimization of a branch length scaling parameter called lambda (λ) (Pagel 1999; Freckleton et al. 2002). The λ phylogenetic signal test needs a (set of) phylogenetic tree(s) and a comparative measure, i.e. the measure on path encoding, and finds the most optimal value of λ given the comparative measure. λ takes a value between 0 and 1. If the optimized value is low, all or almost all topological structure is removed from the tree, and this indicates the absence of phylogenetic signal. If the optimized value is high, then all or almost all topological structure is retained in the tree, and this indicates the presence of phylogenetic signal.

For our nine path measures (overall percentage of source, trajectory, and goal encoding, and the percentage of source, trajectory, and goal encoding that is removed and added), λ was optimized using maximum likelihood with the R (R Core Team 2015) function fitContinuous in the R package geiger (Harmon et al. 2008). The results indicate that these measures carry no phylogenetic signal: the mean λ was < 0.02 for all measures but one; the percentage of added sources, which had a mean λ of 0.09. This means that the encoding of source, trajectory, and goal, measured in this way, is not determined by genealogical history. This confirms visual inspection of Figure 1 through Figure 4, where it is clear that closely related languages are not more similar than less closely related languages.

One concern here is the number of languages – when we assess the frequency of path coding, we deal with a sample of 16 languages, and when we look at how often source, trajectory, and goal are removed or added, we deal with a sample of 15 languages. Freckleton et al. (2002) demonstrate that a sample of ten species is too small for reliable historical signal testing: in trees with ten species, absence of historical signal was correctly identified in about 75% of their analyses, but presence was only correctly identified in about 48% of their simulations. These numbers rise to about 97% and 85%, respectively, for trees with twenty species. The current language sample is clearly on the small side for phylogenetic comparative analysis, a problem that will be addressed in the future. However, for the moment we must conclude that these measures for path encoding are not determined by language genealogy when their individual evolution is assessed.

As a final illustration of the lack of phylogenetic signal, Figure 9 presents a Neighbor-Net network (Bryant & Moulton 2004) made in SplitsTree4 (Huson & Bryant 2006). This analysis calculates the Hamming distances between the translations and represents how similar and disparate the different translations are from each other. There is no genealogical patterning present in Figure 9. Given that there is no historical signal in our individual measures relating the encoding of source, trajectory, and goal, it is pointless to reconstruct ancestral states at this point in time, or to further investigate the relationship with other motion features. However, diachronic analysis may become possible with a larger language sample as well as the inclusion of more literary texts, which is discussed further in Section 6.4. Section 6.3 aims to find evidence for influence of geography on the measures of path encoding.

caption.title: A split graph showing the results of a Neighbour Net analyses of path encoding in 169 sentences in 17 Indo-European languages

sec.title: Geographic distance does not explain cross-linguistic differences
sec.p: Another possible explanation for the cross-linguistic differences in path encoding is geographic distance: are translations in languages more similar to translations in languages spoken close to them and more dissimilar to translations in languages spoken further away? Note that the Mantel test, which has been used in the past to control for geographical distance and genealogical relatedness at the same time, is not suited to answer this question, as discussed by Legendre & Fortin (2010) and Guillot & Rousset (2012).

As all seventeen languages are national languages, the longitude and latitude of the capitals (Armenian: Yerevan, English: London, French: Paris, etc.) were taken as geographic locations. For our nine path measures (overall percentage of source, trajectory, and goal encoding, and the percentage of source, trajectory, and goal encoding that is removed and added), PGLS was conducted using maximum likelihood with the R (R Core Team 2015) function pgls() in the R package caper (Orme 2011). The results are presented in Appendix 2 and indicate that geographical location is not a significant predictor of any of the nine path measures, although there is one that approaches significance: the overall percentage of source encoding (longitude; p = 0.06). During PGLS regression analysis, λ is estimated in order to assess if there is phylogenetic signal in the error term. For all of the nine path measures except one (the percentage of source encoding removed), the median λ was 1 × 10−6, indicating there is no phylogenetic signal – the median λ for the analysis with percentage of source encoding removed was 0.18, which also is not indicative of the presence of an influence of shared history. An additional analysis with λ set to 1 was also conducted and is reported in Appendix 3, it shows that while the R2 increased, latitude and longitude are not significant predictors of any of the nine path measures.
These results suggest that in the current dataset, geographical distance is not an explanatory variable for variation in path encoding. Section 6.4 explores further possible explanations.

sec.title: Further explanations for cross-linguistic variation
sec.p: The general picture that emerges from the previous Sections is that across languages, goal information is emphasized as this information is most vital to the reader, while trajectory information is dropped, presumably to make place for goal information. Although this finding is interesting and it confirms earlier corpus studies that find goal biases, such as Stefanowitsch & Rohde (2004), it brings us no closer to explaining the cross-linguistic differences regarding the goal-over-source principle: why do some languages display a larger goal bias than others? Looking for ways to answer this question is important from a methodological perspective, as it is relevant to establish whether the limitations of the current dataset are at fault, or whether the methodology is not adequate to answer this question.

The first step would be to establish whether the variation in path coding between languages is larger than the variation within languages, and truthfully captured by these translations. This could be investigated by looking at different translations into the same language: if these pattern similarly, they truly capture some aspect of that language. If not, it would be likely that variation across translations is due to something other than true path coding preferences of that language, most likely random variation caused by translators making slightly different decisions. Another fruitful possibility is comparing translations with original texts, as done by Cappelle (2012).

Although the current dataset features only one translation per language, it does include two very similar languages: Croatian and Serbian. Croatian and Serbian are part of the same pluricentric language, usually called Serbo-Croatian or Serbo-Croat-Bosnian. Alexander (2006: 403) points out that there is a “lack of purely linguistic correlates which can be used to separate Bosnian, Croatian or Serbian clearly from one another”, suggesting that we can consider them varieties of the same language. However, the Croatian and Serbian translations are not as similar as one would expect. Euclidian distance scores for the encoding of goal for the Serbian translation range from 2.87 with Slovak (to which it is most similar) and 5.39 with Dutch (to which it is least similar). Distance scores for the Croatian translation range from 4.16 with Russian (most similar) and 5.26 with Armenian (least similar). The Euclidian distance between the Serbian and Croatian translations is 4.31 – especially the Serbian translation is more similar to translations in several languages, including non-Slavic ones, than it is to the Croatian translation.

The simple fact that translations into two varieties of the same language do not yield results as similar as one would expect, compounded with absence of Talmian patterns, as well as of historical and geographical signal, leaves me unable to explain the cross-linguistic differences presented in Section 4. There are several possible explanations that can be explored in future work.

list-item.p: The goal-over-source principle cannot be studied using parallel corpus data, as the current dataset measures the quality of the translation and not the presence of a goal-over-source bias.
The notion of an explicit path that features a ground is not a relevant cross-linguistic notion that can be used for typological comparison.
The source text itself is marked in its use of goal, trajectory, and source marking, causing translators to develop disparate strategies to deal with strangeness in the source text.

Path coding is determined by the lexical resources of each language: some motion verbs require certain argument roles to be filled, for instance by goal phrases, or are collocated with particular adpositions or case markers (Lakusta & Landau 2005: 3–4).

The current dataset is too small to uncover sufficient variation in the encoding of source, trajectory, and goal. Variation in path coding between languages does not outweigh variation within languages, and the differences between translations are not significant.

Differences between translations are entirely due to differences between translators, whose output varies not according to their native tongue but rather according to some other characteristic or translation strategy.

Differences between translations are due to different styles of translation found in different nations: some schools emphasize precision while others emphasize expressivity. Since we have one translator per language, it is impossible to tease apart effects of translation traditions from individual translator strategies.

sec.p: It is difficult to tease apart some of these explanations, but there is evidence against several of these and solutions for future work regarding others. I do not believe that (1) is true – the idea being that path phrases would be dropped more often in poor quality translations, whereas they would be retained in good quality, faithful translations. Sections 5.1 and 5.2 demonstrate that the distribution of changes in path information is not random, which it would be if only quality differences in translation were measured. I also do not believe (2) is true, as the explicit path (also known as plus-ground clause) have been studied by several motion researchers (Slobin 1996, Ibarretxe-Antuñano 2009, among others). Explanation (3) could be verified by comparing the use of source, trajectory, and goal in Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone with that in other novels. Further analysis of motion verbs and other spatial lexical devices in each language could verify explanation (4), which certainly must have some effect on the current results but which has not been addressed here as it requires significant investigation of the spatial system of each language.

Explanations (5), (6) and (7) are more difficult to tease apart and impossible to resolve given the current dataset. It seems that explanation (5) is true, and that the dataset is simply too small to say whether cross-translation differences are true cross-linguistic differences and not simply random variation or the result of individual translator strategies. In order to address this issue, translations of several literary texts should be considered in order to study if variation is governed by the attitudes of individual translators, or whether there is substantial cross-linguistic variation in path encoding. Ideally, these literary works should have different original languages, given Cappelle’s (2012) finding that English translations from (verb-framed) French do not contain native-like levels of manner verbs, whereas (satellite-framed) English translations from (satellite-framed) German do. Although the current study does not investigate levels of manner information in translation, Cappelle (2012) makes a clear case for translation effects due to typological differences. Further investigations comparing original and translated texts will be informative with regard to source and extent of translation effects in different semantic domains. This leaves us with the conclusion that a larger dataset is needed to tease apart cross-linguistic variation, influences of individual translators, and translation effects such as explicitation. My hope is that future investigations will expand the current datasets by investigating more parallel texts and by incorporating path verbs and deictic verbs.

sec.title: Conclusion: The encoding of source, trajectory and goal in Indo-European
sec.p: This paper considered the encoding of source, trajectory, and goal in seventeen Indo-European languages from a variety of perspectives. After presenting the parallel corpus data on path encoding in Section 4, the goal-over-source principle attested across translations was investigated in Section 5, while cross-translation differences in the extent of goal bias were investigated in Section 6. The goal bias that is present in all translations was shown to be due to a translation strategy that was evident more in some translations than others, where goal information was expanded upon and trajectory information was removed (Section 5.1, Figure 5, Figure 6). In most contexts in which this happened, goal information is added to avoid ambiguity regarding the goal of motion or to place emphasis on it (Section 5.2). With the current dataset, it is impossible to tease apart the effect of the goal-over-source principle and the translation effect explicitation, as both point in the same direction. In future work, comparison with non-motion features in translation could serve as a reference point.

In Section 6, an attempt was made to explain cross-translation variation regarding the goal-over-source principle between languages by looking at differences in Talmian motion typology (Section 6.1), as well as by studying the effects of historical signal (Section 6.2) and geographic distance (Section 6.3). None of these inquiries proved to be satisfactory, and ultimately I had to concede that the dataset is too small to make generalizations about cross-linguistic differences of goal bias. However, the next steps are clear: extend the dataset, in terms of verbs to be searched for in the corpus, in terms of languages, and in terms of literary texts. Translations of several literary texts should be considered in order to study if variation is governed mostly by the attitudes of individual translators, or whether the cross-translation variation that was found in Section 4 captures variation regarding path encoding. The ParaSol corpus allows for this, as it contains Mikhail Bulgakov’s The Master and Margarita and Umberto Eco’s The Name of the Rose in a wide variety of translations (von Waldenfels & Meyer 2006-present). I also have a large collection of Alice in Wonderland translations (Verkerk 2014) that could be used to further expand the dataset in the future.

This paper has found evidence for the goal-over-source principle in path encoding in 17 Indo-European languages of Europe using data from a parallel corpus. Goal information is more relevant than source or trajectory information for the inference of the complete path of motion in narratives (confirming Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004: 251). The notion of relevance is important to explain the goal-over-source principle in written language, where narrative cohesion must be maintained: if the reader is to keep track of protagonists as they move around in space, goal information is vital. The limitations of this study have also been pointed out. Unfortunately, analysis of the current dataset did not allow for a contribution to the study of the goal-over-source principle in diachrony. However, as more languages as well as literary works will be added to the current sample, I hope to unveil more about the diachrony of path encoding in Indo-European as well as the limitations and advantages of parallel corpus research.

title-group.title: Overlaps in spatial encodings
title-group.subtitle: Evidence from the Indo-European translations of the New Testament

contrib-group.aff: UT, The Arctic University of Norway

abstract.p: This paper is a contrastive study of spatial encodings in the Greek manuscript of the New Testament and their parallels in Latin, Gothic, Classical Armenian and Old Church Slavic. Our data comes from the PROIEL corpus (University of Oslo, foni.uio.no:3000). We take a strictly data-driven approach in this study and examine not only language-internal overlaps, but also cases where the five languages choose different strategies, e.g. where one or more languages select an ablative or perlative marker in a context where the rest of the languages use a locative marker. We find evidence for several types of overlaps among these counterparts: ablative-locative, locative-perlative and ablative-perlative (rare). The results show that these overlaps exist due to differences in perspectives from which a situation can be viewed. Prepositional phrases that deal with proximity or specify allative meanings, e.g. notions ‘behind/beyond’ and ‘in front of/before’ appear to be salient in these cases of overlap. Our contrastive approach to prepositional interactions reveals transitional zones between spatial notions which cannot be detected by a language-internal analysis. We see these zones as potential bridging contexts that may ease the semantic extension of spatial markers diachronically.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In this article we take a contrastive approach to spatial encoding overlaps. Using a parallel corpus of the Greek New Testament and its earliest translations into Indo-European languages, we look at encoding overlaps between Source and Location/Goal (ablative-locative), Location/Goal and Path (locative-perlative) and Source and Path (ablative-perlative).

The spatial domains of Location (where a trajector is located at a landmark), Goal (where a trajector moves toward a landmark) and Source (where a trajector moves away from a landmark) are commonly seen as basic to human cognition. All of them are frequently grammaticalized as separate case forms cross-linguistically. Path (where a trajector moves along a trajectory through or across the landmark) is a less obviously universal and more complex domain, sharing features with both Location and Goal. It is also less frequently grammaticalized as a specialized case (perlative) (Luraghi 2003: 22). In this article we will only look at spatial expressions insofar as they are encoded by prepositional phrases in Greek, as seen in typical Examples in (1)–(4).

list-item.p:
Location:
epì tês gês
on the ground.gen.sg
‘on the ground’

Goal:
eis tḕn thálassan
to the sea.acc.sg
‘to the sea’

Source:
apò tês Galilaías
from the Galilee.gen.sg
‘from Galilee’

Path:
dià tês thúras
through the door.gen.sg
‘through the door’

sec.p: Typological studies strive to describe and generalize over these main spatial domains (see e.g. Levinson 2003). The goal is to specify which notions are salient for each spatial concept and which types of linguistic markers are responsible for encoding these spatial ideas and their subtypes. Many markers are not limited to denotation of just one spatial notion and extend their semantics to expressing other spatial functions. Location-Goal syncretism is the most common case (Nikitina 2008; Shay et al. 2003; van der Zee et al. 2003), but other types of syncretism are also found.

This article focuses on less-studied interactions between the basic spatial domains – between locative and ablative and between locative and perlative. We use the term locative in this case to refer to both directional and static locative meanings (i.e., both Goal and Location) since the prepositional phrases that are being examined in our data regularly display the Location-Goal syncretism.

In our study, we use a parallel corpus of early Indo-European texts. Using parallel data has two important advantages. First, it allows us to look not only at language-internal domain interactions, but also at cross-linguistic interactions. We are able to study cases where a single marker covers, e.g., both Location and Source, as well as parallel situations where languages make different marker choices, for example where one language uses a typical Source marker, whereas the other languages opt for typical Location markers. We are thus able to identify encoding overlaps that might otherwise have been overlooked. The parallel approach also allows us to generate statistical semantic maps that are not based on any semantic pre-classification. In these maps overlap zones are easily visible, and in these zones we find possible bridging contexts for semantic extensions of spatial markers, which can lead to new syncretisms diachronically.

sec.title: Corpus and method
sec.p: Our data comes from the PROIEL corpus 〈foni.uio.no:3000/〉, 〈www.hf.uio.no/ifikk/english/research/projects/proiel/〉, developed at the University of Oslo, Norway. This source provides a solid parallel corpus of the Greek original of the New Testament and its translations into Latin, Gothic, Classical Armenian, and Old Church Slavic (OCS), and offers thorough annotations on the level of morphology, syntax, semantics, and information structure. For the purposes of our work on spatial semantics (see also de Swart et al. 2012; Eckhoff et al. 2013), all prepositional phrases (henceforth PPs) in the Greek New Testament were assigned semantic tags. Since all the texts are aligned at word token level, these tags can be used for the same situations in all the translation languages as well.

We take a contrastive approach to spatial concepts: instead of studying interactions within a single language, we examine how five closely related languages encode the concepts in identical situations, thus utilizing the basic idea of semantic maps and similarity semantics: that similar forms indicate similar meanings. This means that we focus on situations where one language has a typical Source or Path marker, but other languages do not. As practice shows, the contrastive approach employed in this paper brings out interactions that might have been overlooked otherwise.

In this article we use a data set similar to that of Eckhoff et al. (2013), to which we refer the reader for further details about the data, but add Classical Armenian data as well. To obtain this data set we extracted all occurrences of Greek PPs in the PROIEL corpus, with the following information included for each context:1 for each Greek preposition – token id, form, lemma, syntactic relation, PP semantic role, Gospel, for each governed dependent of a Greek preposition – form, lemma, case, number, animacy, part of speech, definiteness, and for each head of a Greek preposition – form, lemma, part of speech, verb semantics. The same information was extracted for corresponding renditions with the exception of semantic tags and, in the case of OCS, Latin and Classical Armenian, definiteness.2 Thus, our parallel linguistic data is grouped by situation (a correspondence set). We place only the two following restrictions on the selected situations:

list-item.p: Greek must have a PP.
There must be a corresponding expression (of any form) in each of the translation languages, which is token aligned with either the Greek preposition or its dependent.

sec.p: Restriction 1 entails that a certain amount of linguistic units with semantics similar to that of the PPs are excluded, such as Greek non-prepositional case usages and a series of Greek adverbs that are very close to PPs in function. Restriction 2, on the other hand, entails that we consider a much wider range of linguistic entities in the translation languages than in the original Greek. To include as much as possible, we also check for alignments with the complement of a Greek P if there is no alignment with the P itself.3 These two criteria strike a reasonable balance between including as much material as possible, and at the same time avoiding linguistic pre-categorization beyond the PROIEL corpus’ part-of-speech and syntactic tagging.

In Eckhoff et al. (2013), we included only OCS, Latin and Gothic as translation languages. After our selection, this data set yielded a collection of 2257 situations which are correspondence sets. In this article we make a map using a correspondence set which also includes Classical Armenian. Due to a number of lacunae in the Armenian text, this set is a little smaller, at 2008 situations – recall that we require all five languages to have an attestation for the situation to be included in the set. We illustrate this using 5 rows (with their headings) of our data set (Table 1).

caption.title: Correspondence set sample*

fn.p: The item diá=g should be understood as “diá governs the genitive” and per=a should be read as “per governs the accusative”, while =i means “non-prepositional instrumental” and quare= means “quare with no dependent”.

sec.p: As in Eckhoff et al. (2013), we analyzed this correspondence set using a semantic map approach borrowed from typology, closely following Wälchli (2010).4 We built a similarity matrix from the data set by first comparing the encoding of each of the 2008 situations to all other situations in the database. Applying this to Table 1 we compared row 1 to rows 2, 3, 4 and 5; row 2 to row 1, 3, 4 and 5, etc. language by language, as illustrated in Table 2. Such a pair was scored as completely similar (score = 1) if both the preposition and the case were the same, partially similar if the preposition, but not the case was the same (score = 0.5), and completely dissimilar if the pair had different prepositions or no match at all (score = 0).5 Thus, we get a similarity measure for each situation pair in each language. The scores for all languages were then summed and divided by the number of languages, resulting in an overall similarity score for each situation, ranging from full similarity (1) to no similarity (0). As we see in Table 2, row 1 is less similar to rows 2 and 3 (similarity score 0.6) than to row 5 (similarity score 0.8). Rows 1 and row 4 are the least similar (similarity score 0.1) – only the Greek preposition (but not the case) is the same.

caption.title: Similarity scores for row 1 compared to row 2–5

sec.p: Comparing every situation to all other situations in this way yielded a 2008-by-2008 similarity matrix. We visualized the similarity matrix using classical multidimensional scaling (MDS) using the cmdscale() function in the statistical software package R (R Development Core Team 2015). Multidimensional scaling takes a set of dissimilarities and returns a set of points such that the distances between the points are approximately equal to the dissimilarities, in a number of dimensions ranked by importance. When we plot the two first dimensions against each other, the output is an entirely data-driven semantic map, in which the Gospel situations are grouped according to the extent that they are encoded similarly.

sec.title: Interpreting the semantic map
sec.p: As described in Section 2, our similarity matrix is built entirely from information on preposition and case choice, and the analysis is not based on any semantic pre-tagging. However, since all Greek prepositional phrases in the PROIEL version of the New Testament have been manually semantically tagged by Olga Thomason, we can use those tags to interpret the resulting two-dimensional map (Figure 1), where we have overlaid the map with simplified versions of those tags.6

caption.title: MDS visualization of the Greek-OCS-Latin-Gothic-Armenian correspondence set, with semantic role overlay (G = Goal, S = Source, L = Location, O = Other (non-spatial)). 2008 situations

sec.p: We see in Figure 1 that all Source (S) situations are found in the left bottom corner of the map. This means that Source is important to the interpretation of both Dimension 1 and Dimension 2: both dimensions serve to differentiate Source from the other spatial roles. For a clearer view of the distribution of semantic tags, see Figure 2, where Goal, Location, Source and Path tags are overlaid on the map in separate panels, omitting the non-spatial tags, which are scattered across the entire map. This makes it easier to interpret the two dimensions in the map. Dimension 1 distinguishes between Source and Path to the left, and Goal and Location, which are mostly to the right of Source. Dimension 2 seems to distinguish between Source, Path and to some extent Location in the lower half of the map and Goal in the upper half of the map. Figure 1 and Figure 2 show that Location and Goal overlap substantially, while Source is confined to a small, well-delimited area, which overlaps less with the other two major spatial roles. Non-spatial roles (Other) are scattered across the whole map. These are largely the same findings as in Eckhoff et al. (2013), which did not include Classical Armenian data.

caption.title: MDS visualization of the Greek-OCS-Latin-Gothic-Armenian correspondence set, with semantic role overlay, spatial roles shown separately (G = Goal, S = Source, L = Location, O = Other (non-spatial)). 2008 situations

sec.p: In Eckhoff et al. (2013), we did not consider the Path role. There are only 16 Path situations in our correspondence set, but we see that they cluster near the very end of the diagonal stripe of Source expressions, in the company of e.g. a number of expressions of proximity. Approximately the same is the case for the four-language map of Eckhoff et al. (2013).
The map reveals a number of zones where the encoding of spatial semantics overlap in our five languages. The most interesting zones are marked with circles in Figure 3.

caption.title: Overlap zones in the MDS visualization, only spatial roles indicated

sec.p: The zones where two or more major spatial domains overlap indicate clusters of situations where these spatial domains have been similarly encoded across our five languages. One major overlap zone (4) stretches from −0.1 to 0.4 on the Dimension 1 axis and from 0.0 to 0.4 on the Dimension 2 axis. In this zone, Goal and Location overlap substantially. The zones of primary interest in this paper, however, are zones 1, 2 and 3, since they contain overlaps where Source and Path are also involved. Zone 1 (from −0.3 to −0.05 on the Dimension 1 axis) is the most interesting one, since it contains situations from all four major spatial domains. Zone 2 (around 0.1 on the Dimension 1 axis and −0.1 on the Dimension 2 axis) contains a number of Location, Goal and Path situations clustered closely together. Finally, zone 3 (from −0.4 to 0.25 on the Dimension 1 axis and between -0.4 and −0.15 on the Dimension 2 axis) contains a scatter of Source and Location situations – to the left we find “Source-like” Location situations, and to the right, we find “Location-like” Source situations.

We will not discuss the large Location-Goal overlap zone (4), but decided to create a zoomed version of the map in Figures 1–3 by including only the data points with a Dimension 1 coordinate lower than 0.3 and a Dimension 2 coordinate lower than 0.2, and rerun the MDS analysis using these data points only. This map thus includes all the spatial overlap situations where Source and Path are involved. The map is shown with Source, Location, Goal and Path overlays in Figure 4.

caption.title: MDS visualization of the Greek-OCS-Latin-Gothic-Armenian correspondence set, including only the area where Source, Goal, Location and Path overlap, with semantic role overlay (G = Goal, S = Source, L = Location, P = Path). 1195 situations

sec.p: In the map in Figure 4, Dimension 1 distinguishes Source (to the right) from Goal and Path, while Dimension 2 mostly seems to set Source and Goal apart from Location and Path. We see that Source overlaps much more with Location than with Goal and Path. However, all four spatial roles have a dense overlap zone in the top middle area of the map.

In Sections 4, 5 and 6 we will discuss examples from zone 1, 2 and 3. Before we move on to do so, we would like to draw attention to two potential problems with our approach. The first is the nature of the Greek source texts, the second is the heterogeneous nature of the overlaps we discover.

In our analysis, we use the Tischendorf edition of the New Testament (Tischendorf 1869) as our Greek reference, since this is the edition used in the PROIEL corpus. However, this version of the New Testament is not the exact original of any of the translations, in fact, they are sure to have somewhat different originals. There is therefore always the possibility that an apparent discrepancy between Greek and a translation language in a given situation is actually not a discrepancy at all, but a faithful recording of a missing Greek variant. This problem is exemplified by the two extreme values in zone 3 in Figure 3. First, there is a Location situation at −0.09 on Dimension 1 and −0.31 on Dimension 2, far away from all other Location situations. The situation is from Luke 5 : 3, where Jesus gets into a boat and teaches the crowds from the boat. Tischendorf has in+ dat ‘in the boat’ here, but all the four translation languages have Source expressions ‘from the boat’. This seems like a plausible perspective shift, but as it turns out, the Nestle-Aland text has ek+ gen, ek toû ploíou ‘from the boat’, in this passage. It therefore seems likely that the originals of the four translations also had this variant. The same thing appears to be case for another extreme value in zone 3, the very leftmost Source situation in the whole map, at 0.22 on Dimension 1 and −0.35 on Dimension 2. In this situation from Luke 1 : 61 ‘there is no one from/in your family with that name’, Greek and OCS have Source markers (ek + gen, otŭ + gen ‘from your family’), but the rest of the languages have Location markers ‘in your family’. As it turns out, several known textual variants of this passage have en + dat, which means that the Greek originals of the Latin, Gothic and Classical Armenian texts may well also have had it, although, again, the mismatch also seems like a plausible perspective shift. At least for unsystematic mismatches, then, this must be kept in mind as a possible source of noise, but extreme mismatches such as these are fortunately also easily visible in the MDS visualizations.

It should also be pointed out that the encoding overlaps that we find are of at least three types. First, we have situations where one of the languages uses, e.g., a typical Source marker, and where another language uses, e.g., a typical Location marker. Sometimes this is systematic, sometimes we find isolated occurrences. Whether or not such marking is clearly conventionalized, we will argue that the examples demonstrate that both perspectives on the situation are possible, and that this is a possible bridging context between the two types of markers, opening the way for syncretism. Second, we have situations where a single language has a preposition governing a certain case that can encode two different spatial domains, e.g. Source and Location. Third, we have situations where a single language has a preposition that can encode two different spatial domains, e.g. Path and Goal, but where the meaning is disambiguated by the dependent case. The two latter types are typically the outcomes of semantic extensions of a marker that originally only covered one of the domains.

sec.title: Ablative-locative interactions
sec.p: In this section we discuss examples of overlaps between Source and the two locative roles Location and Goal. These overlaps are all found in zones 1 and 3 in Figure 3 and to the right in the zoomed map in Figure 4.

sec.title: The notion of proximity
sec.p: In New Testament Greek the prepositional phrase ek + gen is predominantly employed as a Source marker to specify elative semantics where a trajector moves out of the boundaries of a landmark (Eckhoff et al. 2013: 319).7 As a rule, these instances of ek + gen are matched with this PP’s regular counterparts – prepositional constructions that serve as Source markers in the languages under consideration: de + abl in Latin, us + dat in Gothic, i + abl in Classical Armenian, and izŭ + gen in OCS, as shown in (5).

sec.p: This type of correspondences are part of the main Source cluster in the MDS visualization of the spatial domain in Figure 1 and in Figure 2. However, we also find passages where Greek ek + gen marks Location ‘near, at’ (see Examples (6) and (7)). There are 12 such situations in the correspondence set. In such instances this preposition is combined with nominals that specify the sides of a landmark. These usages of ek+gen present evidence for a language-internal ablative-locative syncretism where a Source marker extends to denote Location (see also Nikitina this volume; Nikitina 2014). We find that Gothic mirrors the situation in Greek. These Greek passages are systematically translated with Gothic af+dat – another regular Source marker in this language, which usually signifies ablative cases where a trajector moves away from the boundaries of a landmark (Eckhoff et al. 2013: 325–326). We find that the Gothic counterpart has undergone a semantic extension similar to the one recorded for Greek ek + gen and expanded its semantics to denotation of Location ‘near, at’ (6). Thus, we find a second instance of language-internal ablative-locative syncretism.8 Example (6) also shows us that the Latin Source marker ab + abl is also a possible correspondence in this type of situation, in fact it is the most common strategy in the correspondence set (8 occurrences). As Luraghi (2010: 26) points out, this encoding was already present in Classical Latin.

sec.p: It is important to note that the original elative semantics of ek + gen and the primary ablative meaning of af + dat and ab + abl are neutralized in the instances of their locative applications. As Nikitina (2014) points out, the situations do not involve motion from or out of a source, so the markers unambiguously denote static location. When we look at the parallel passages in (7), we find that Latin, Classical Armenian and OCS employ Goal/Location markers that are connected with the notion of proximity. Note that for Latin, this is not the most common strategy (since Latin usually has ab + abl in these situations), but at least for OCS, it is.

sec.p: In (7) we are not dealing with instances of language-internal ablative-locative syncretism. Instead, this is an example of the first type of correspondence discussed at the end of Section 3: Our contrastive approach enables us to capture evidence for ablative-locative interactions between languages.

Latin ad + acc is a productive Goal marker that that also marks Location when it is used with static verbs. This prepositional phrase specifies that a trajector does not reach the interior of a landmark; there is no immediate contact between a trajector and a landmark, but rather a trajector moves towards/up to or is located near a landmark (Luraghi 2010).

Classical Armenian ənd originates from IE *H2enti ‘in front and facing’, a locative singular form of the noun *H2ent- ‘front, forehead, face’ (Sihler 1995: 439; Watkins 2000: 4). This productive preposition governs six different cases: the accusative, the genitive, the ablative, the locative, the dative, and the instrumental. Practically all of these combinations exhibit spatial functions that range from denotations of Location, Goal and Path and even to random encodings of Source (Thomason 2006: 110–114). However, we see an attempt in Armenian to disambiguate these notions by means of different case governance, especially in the instance of ənd+abl. This prepositional phrase is reserved solely for denotation of Location ‘near’. Looking ahead, we should state that this preposition also presents an example of a language-internal locative-perlative transfer (see Section 4), since ənd + acc stems away from its original denotation of Location ‘in front’ and becomes a dominant Path marker in Classical Armenian.

Old Church Slavic o + acc is rarely used in the New Testament (cf. the more frequent prepositional phrase o + loc), but practically all of the instances are allocated to denotation of spatial meanings where a trajector is either on the surface or by the side of a landmark (Thomason 2006: 140–142). All of the 12 situations of this type in our correspondence set are encoded in this way. In (7), this prepositional construction specifies that even though there is no contact between the trajector and the landmark, the trajector is located in the immediate proximity of this landmark – namely on the right-hand side.

In Figure 3, we find all of these 12 correspondences in zones 1 and 3. The two situations where Latin has ad + acc and Classical Armenian has i + abl are found at −0.34 on Dimension 1 (the left most visible L in the map), while the two other ad+ acc correspondences are found in the lower left part of zone 1 – they are thus set apart from the cluster at the end of the diagonal stripe of Source situations, which also contains Goal and Path situations. The eight correspondences where Latin has ab+ abl are found around −0.25 on Dimension 1 and −0.15 on Dimension 2, i.e, in the upper left part of zone 3. Thus, the MDS analysis sorts these situations as decidedly Source-like.

A separate case of the language-internal locative-ablative syncretism is observed in passages with another common Source marker in Greek – the preposition pára ‘from, beside, alongside of’. This preposition governs the genitive, the accusative, and the dative. This combinatory flexibility permits to separate locative and ablative meanings by means of different cases: pára + gen acts as a regular Source marker (primarily with nominals designating human beings) while pára + dat and pára + acc are reserved for designation of locative meanings (Thomason 2006: 41–43). Thus, it is an example of the third type of overlap discussed at the end of Section 3. The idea of proximity is activated in all three of these prepositional constructions, and their semantics always implies that a trajector either originates from the vicinity of a landmark (Source) or is located beside, near a landmark (Location). In addition, our data set has a single example of the Source marker pára+gen developing a more abstract secondary connotation of possession through a metonymic extension ‘to come from someone’ → ‘to be possessed by someone’. This passage serves as evidence for another locative-ablative interaction among the languages in our study.

sec.p: This time Latin answers with a Location marker – apud + acc. This PP is used to indicate that as a trajector is located close to a boundary of a landmark. Thus, we see that the notion of proximity receives saliency once again and suggests additional evidence for fuzzy boundaries between ablative and locative notions. We have three pára + gen : apud + acc correspondences in our correspondence set – in the remaining 23 situations, Latin renders pará+ gen with ab + abl.

In (8) Gothic translates the Greek original with at + dat, another Location marker that is connected with the concept of proximity. It is important to add that even though the original semantics of this Gothic construction is locative since this preposition goes back to the IE preverb *ad- ‘to, near, at’ (Watkins 2000: 1), the correspondence between Greek pára + gen and Gothic at + dat is limited to those instances where a landmark is a human being. Thus, there is a chance that a locative-ablative transfer happens already language-internally and that at + dat extends to the denotation of Source. There are seven examples of this correspondence in our correspondence set. Except for (8), all of them have fairly clear Source semantics in the Greek, occurring twice with lambánō ‘take’ (Mark 12 : 2, John 10 : 18), thrice with akoúō ‘hear’ (John 6 : 45, 8 : 26 and 15 : 15) and once with eimí ‘be’ (John 17 : 7). The most frequent correspondence is the Source marker fram + dat (15 situations).

Classical Armenian translates Greek pára+ gen with the Source marker i + abl in (8). Like pára, this preposition takes different meanings with different dependent cases. The original Source semantics of this PP has no ties with the notion of proximity. This productive Armenian construction covers those Source meanings where a trajector moves out of the boundaries of a landmark (landmarks are viewed as containers in these instances; elative meaning) as well as those passages where a trajector moves away from a landmark (ablative meaning). Armenian i + abl consistently translates pára + gen when the Greek phrase designates Source (22 out of 26 situations in our correspondence set). Thus, it is not surprising to find that this correspondence remains unchanged even in those passages where the Greek counterpart exhibits a metonymic transfer Source → Possession: as in (8) ‘to come from someone’ → ‘to be possessed by someone’. Furthermore, i + abl marks Locations ‘near’ and ‘among’ in a few other instances in the New Testament, but the Greek original has prepositional constructions other than pára + gen (all of these Greek counterparts are connected with various aspects of Location) in these passages. For instance, two of the locative ek + gen examples discussed above have this correspondence.

Old Church Slavic u + gen in Example (8) is another interesting case of a language-internal locative-ablative transfer. When it comes to spatial meanings, this PP regularly marks Source ‘from’, and in these instances a trajector originates from the vicinity of a landmark (just as seen with Greek pára + gen). The landmark itself is often a human being, but not exclusively (Thomason 2006: 154–155). The Source semantics appears to be original, the preposition goes back to IE root *au- ‘off, away’ (Watkins 2000: 6). The semantics of this construction extends to denotation of Location ‘near, beside’ and once again the notion of proximity is influential here. Moreover, u + gen receives a vigorous semantic development in Slavic languages which is based specifically on the locative-ablative interaction and later extension to denotation of possession (Cienki 1995: 87–96). There are only two correspondences between pára + gen and u + gen in our correspondence set, the regular correspondence is the extremely versatile OCS Source marker otŭ + gen (found in 22 out of 26 situations in the correspondence set).

When we look for the non-Source correspondents of pára + gen in Figure 3, we find them in the upper left corner of zone 3. The correspondences with Latin apud+acc are found near −0.2 on Dimension 1 and near −0.15 on Dimension 2. This is also where we find the correspondences with OCS u + gen and some of the correspondences with Gothic at + dat (including Example 8, which has all three correspondences). The rest of the at + dat correspondences are found around −0.36 on Dimension 1 and −0.25 on Dimension 2, very close to the rest of the pará + gen situations. Again, the MDS analysis classifies these situations as decidedly Source-like, but the few situations where several of the languages have non-Source markers are located closer to zone 1, where all four spatial roles overlap extensively.

sec.title: Allative meanings
sec.p: A different set of interactions between ablative and locative meanings is presented by passages where a Greek Source marker is translated with the help of a PP that designates either a beginning or ending point of a motion. Such is the case with the Greek apó + gen ‘from, away from’ in (9):

sec.p: This instance of the Greek Source marker is rendered with Source markers in Latin, Classical Armenian and Old Church Slavic, but Gothic responds with the Goal phrase hindar + acc ‘behind, beyond, to the other side of’. This is also the case in the similar passage in Matt. 8 : 34. This locative-ablative interaction is due to the various perspective views available to the speaker. The Greek passage specifies Source and accentuates the notion of departure and separation by using apó as a preposition and as a preverb. The Gothic translation draws attention to the ending point of this motion – Goal ‘beyond’. Destination takes precedence over Source in the Gothic variant. Even the choice of the verbal form – galeiþan ‘to go, to come’ – confirms that the ablative meaning is absent in this sentence.9 If we go back to Figure 3 we find these two situations in the lower left part of zone 3, around −0.37 on Dimension 1 and −0.27 on Dimension 2. They are thus classified as very Source-like by the MDS analysis, since the other translation languages all use regular Source markers here.

The Gothic manuscript also offers another case of locative-ablative interactions in passages where the notion of opposition comes into play. Thus, the Greek Source markers ek + gen and apó + gen are rendered in (10) and (11) with Gothic in adwairþja + gen and faura + dat that regularly mark Location ‘before’.

sec.p: In (10) Greek ek + gen becomes part of a bigger phrase and governs a nominalized adjective enantíos ‘opposite’. In this example, we find ablative-locative interplay already on the level of Greek, since this example can reasonably be seen as related to the pattern in Examples (6) and (7) (cf. Nikitina 2014). Latin offers an analogous version and employs a Source marker ex + abl in combination with an adjective adversus ‘opposite’. However, Gothic and Old Church Slavic translators do not employ Source markers per se but rather employ Goal markers in this situation – in adwairþja + gen and prěmo + dat, that do not have ties with the notion of Source either in form or in meaning. In the case of Gothic, the prepositional construction is a compound that consist of the preposition in – a productive Location/Goal marker – and a noun adwairþi ‘presence, face, person’. The Old Church Slavic preposition prěmo + dat is used in the New Testament to mark Location ‘against, opposite’ exclusively. There is only a single example of this particular set of correspondences in our data set – note that it is not part of the correspondence set used for the MDS analysis, since there is no Classical Armenian parallel.

The passages in (11) present another interesting instance where the Greek Source marker apó + gen encodes Source (albeit more abstract) and presents the whole situation as an instance of separation of a trajector from a landmark. We find that in this situation all other languages in our study, with the exception of Gothic, follow this selection and use Source markers for the translation. The Gothic translation, however, has a different perspective. This time the prepositional construction faura + dat ‘before’ corresponds to the Greek Source marker. In the Gothic translation the same situation of fleeing is seen from a different angle: the PP can express either that a motion starts in front of the landmark, or that the trajector stays in front of the landmark even though both of them move, so that their relative positions do not change. We have nine examples of this correspondence in our data set, and all but one of them serve as arguments of avoidance verbs (also blépō in the sense ‘watch out for’, prosékhō ‘beware of’ and several verbs meaning ‘hide from’). Even though the patterns are probably highly conventionalized in both languages, the spatial origins of the conceptualizations seem clear, and we see this as an overlap context. In Figure 3, we find these situations in the lower left part of zone 3, around −0.37 on Dimension 1 and −0.26 on Dimension 2, very close to the apo + gen: hindar + acc correspondences discussed above (Example (9)).

sec.title: Locative-perlative interactions
sec.p: In this section we discuss examples of overlaps between Path and the two locative roles Location and Goal. These overlaps are found in zones 1 and 2 in Figure 3 and in the top middle part of the zoomed map in Figure 4. Again we see that the overlaps are often due to perspective shifts, which are especially expected with the Path role, since it shares some properties both with Goal and Location.

sec.title: Notion of proximity
sec.p: Constructions with Greek katá (originally ‘down(wards)’) are rarely used in the New Testament with spatial meanings. This preposition has a problematic origin: several researchers link it with the PIE root *km̥t (Frisk 1960 I: 800; Beekes et al. 2010: 656) while others trace it back to the PIE root *kat- (Watkins 2000: 37). But in any case the linguists assign katá the spatial meanings ‘down(wards), against, along, through’ as primary semantics. In our corpus katá predominantly specifies manner of actions and has strong semantic ties with the notions of distribution (Thomason 2006: 48–0). Instances where this preposition encodes Path are sparse (five situations in our correspondence set, three with accusative and two with genitive), but in these passages the semantics of katá comprises a downwards direction and a distributive notion. Thus in (12), Greek katá + acc marks Path in a situation where a downward motion is extended along the whole area of a landmark:

sec.p: The Latin counterpart per + acc in (12) does not capture the denotation of a downward directionality which is expressed in the Greek original, but it retains its perlative connotation. The rest of the languages in question deviate from the perlative semantics.

Gothic bi + acc generally encodes Topic (often with speech verbs): e.g., in Luke 9 : 45 jah ohtedun fraihnan ina bi þata waurd ‘and they feared to ask him about this word’. In those instances, where this phrase is found with spatial functions, it promotes the notion of proximity. In (12), bi + acc does not express the downward Path as does its Greek counterpart; rather it specifies that an action takes place in close proximity to the road.

Classical Armenian and Old Church Slavic authors choose a different strategy and employ Location markers for the translation here. Armenian generally prefers to use i + loc in those passages where a trajector is located or moves within the boundaries of a landmark (containment metaphor). Old Church Slavic opts for na + loc in those passages where a trajector is located on or moves along the surface of a landmark. Thus, both languages conceptualize the situation as locative, rather than perlative as in the Greek original. This perspective shift is not surprising, since both Path and Location imply that the trajector occupies the area of the landmark (Luraghi 2003: 22).

In Figure 3, we find Example (12) in zone 2, at 0.08 on Dimension 1 and −0.12 on Dimension 2. As we can see in Figure 3, this sets it apart from most of the other Path situations – the MDS analysis classifies it as more locative-like than the others.

sec.title: Allative meanings
sec.p: The Greek péran + gen is a good example of language internal perlative-locative interaction since this PP regularly designates both Goal/Location ‘beyond’ and Path. Thus, this is an example of the second type of interaction discussed at the end of Section 3. In Example (13), this Greek phrase clearly marks Path, since there is a separate prepositional construction eis + acc in the same sentence that specifies Goal:

sec.p: We see that Latin once again mirrors the Greek passage and employs the prepositional construction trans + acc that has a semantic load similar to the one that Greek péran + gen exhibits: this phrase is used to encode either Goal/Location ‘beyond’ or Path. Gothic answers with ufar + acc. Gothic ufar is another instance of a language-internal perlative-locative interaction where the two meanings are disambiguated with the help of case governance: ufar + acc encodes Path while ufar + dat designates Location ‘over’ in passages where a trajector is located above a landmark with or without a contact. Thus, in (13) Gothic follows the example of Greek and Latin and uses a Path marker.

Classical Armenian and Old Church Slavic take a different approach. In both cases, we find descriptive constructions that are based on Goal markers – i + acc and na + acc, correspondently. This perspective shift is not surprising, given the Goal-like properties of Path: both domains imply a trajectory (Luraghi 2003: 22). We have already seen these prepositions in (12), but there they governed a different case – the locative (to designate Location as opposed to Goal). These constructions have similar structure: a Goal marker governs a combination of a deictic and a nominal with the meaning ‘side’. Therefore, in these languages the focus is not on the Path of a motion but rather on the endpoint of this motion, namely the other side of a landmark. The translational perlative-locative transfers are due to two different perspective views that a speaker may have: one that focuses on Path ‘across, throughout, over’ and another that directs attention to the boundaries, limits of this Path. Armenian i + acc specifies that a trajector crossed the boundaries of a landmark and a motion ends inside of the landmark’s boundaries. Old Church Slavic na + acc is typically used when the Goal is a surface. In this case, it refers to the surface of the other side of Jordan, which is the end point of the motion.10

A similar strategy is found in Latin and Gothic in some sentences where Greek péran + gen is matched with Goal markers – Latin ultra + acc and Gothic hinder + dat that accentuate the directional idea ‘behind, beyond’.

sec.p: Both Latin and Gothic specify that a mentioned landmark – the river Jordan – is left behind when a motion is completed. The Armenian and Old Church Slavic versions continue their usage of periphrastic constructions. However, while the Armenian version does not differ from the treatment which was seen in (13) and still translates Greek Path marker péran + gen with the Goal marker ‘to that side’, the Slavic translator chooses a different preposition here. We find a switch from the preposition na ‘onto’ to the preposition po ‘over’, which brings the Slavic version from directional values back to the denotation of Path. The preposition po carries a distributive connotation, and in those instances where it is used with spatial functions denotes that an action or a motion occurs in every part of a landmark. sec.p: The construction obŭ + acc designates that after the completion of a motion a trajector is placed near a landmark, in this case the other side of Jordan. Thus, we see that this time the notion of proximity is activated and allows for locative-perlative transfer. The focus is on the location after the motion. The preposition obŭ goes back to PIE *epi/opi ‘near, at, against’ (Watkins 2000: 23). While the Greek marker accentuates the notion of Path, the Old Church Slavic counterpart states that there is contact between a trajector and an outer surface of a landmark.

When we return to Figure 3, we find all six situations where Greek has peran + gen in zone 2, where we also found Example (12). Thus, this is clearly the zone for locative-like Path situations and Path-like locative situations. As we have seen, these correspondences are typically perspective shifts that are due to the features that Path share with Location and Goal respectively.

sec.title: Ablative-perlative interactions
sec.p: Instances of ablative-perlative transfer are extremely rare in our corpus. We find no language-internal interactions of this type, but our contrastive approach captures several examples for this type of semantic connection among the Classical Armenian renditions of Greek katá + gen. We already discussed this preposition in Section 5.1 above and noted its association with distributive semantics. But in (12) katá governs the accusative, while in (16) it is combined with the genitive:

sec.p: Unlike katá + acc, katá + gen expresses spatial meanings more regularly in the New Testament. In passages like (16), this PP signifies that a trajector moves from a higher, more elevated level of a landmark to a lower level (cf. the original meaning of this preposition which is discussed in Section 4.1). The Armenian phrase disregards the perlative semantics of the Greek counterpart completely. This prepositional construction denotes Source (elative and ablative meanings). In (16) i + abl refers to Source as to a beginning point of a landmark from which a trajector moves. The Source semantics is underscored in Armenian with the help of an adverb anti ‘from there’. The distributive connotation of Greek katá + gen that marks that an action is a continuous motion throughout all parts of the cliff is likewise not reflected by the Armenian rendition. Thus, we have a case of a shift from perlative semantics to ablative semantics. The shift is rather similar to the observed shifts from Path to Goal: any trajectory must necessarily have a beginning as well as an ending point. Returning to Figure 3, we find Example (16) at the very bottom of zone 1 – if we look at the panels in Figure 3, it is the leftmost, and thus the most Source-like, Path situation, at −0.22 on Dimension 1 and −0.13 on Dimension 2. In the zoomed map in Figure 4, Example (16) is the rightmost Path situation in the map, surrounded by Source situations.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper we show that a contrastive approach using parallel data enables us to capture semantic connections that would be overlooked otherwise. This approach provides solid evidence for less-studied semantic relations – a locative-ablative interaction and a locative-perlative association. We are able to obtain examples of language-external locative-ablative and locative-perlative interactions in addition to language-internal ones. Our data shows that prepositional constructions that normally mark Location, Goal and Path are occasionally selected to render Source meanings. This type of correspondence is to be expected in instances where the notion of proximity is activated. In addition, mismatches in spatial encodings are common in situations where perspective shifts are possible. This is especially true for instances where the correspondences include prepositional constructions with allative functions. Location/Goal meanings ‘behind/beyond’ and ‘in front of/before’ stand out as particularly frequent and regular ones in these cases of overlap. Even though the discussed instances of the discrepancies in spatial encoding do not represent the most frequent usages of these prepositional phrases, these situations can possibly be viewed as bridging contexts that can facilitate the semantic extension of spatial markers into new domains. The encoding overlaps often reveal that more than one spatial perspective is possible, and further research might show that these zones are actually ones where subsequent changes did take place. The MDS visualizations of correspondences in the selected languages thus provide a valuable way of capturing various types of semantic overlap without semantic pre-categorization.

Classical Armenian has particles that are reminiscent of definite articles, but they were not analyzed as such in PROIEL.

Note that we selected the 2008 situations using automatically aligned texts. This necessarily made us miss some correspondences, whenever the automatic aligner failed to align the Greek PP with one or more of the translation correspondences. However, once selected, all the 2008 correspondences were hand-corrected before we ran the MDS analysis. For further discussion of the token alignment criterion, see Eckhoff et al. (2013), fn. 4.

title-group.title: Ablative and allative marking of static locations
title-group.subtitle: A historical perspective
title-group.alt-title: Ablative and allative marking of static locations

abstract.p:
The study addresses the diachronic relationship between locative marking and the marking of goals and sources of motion. In ancient Indo-European languages, and in some modern ones, static spatial relations can be described by means of inherently dynamic expressions, which are normally used for encoding goals and sources (as in to
the left of the door). I suggest that this strategy presents an alternative to the use of rich systems of spatial prepositions specialized for encoding particular configurations. Its use pre-dates the development of basic spatial prepositions, which came to replace, in Indo-European languages, directional adverbs (sometimes also described as particles). The directional adverbs played a prominent role in the encoding of spatial notions in ancient languages. After they were reanalyzed as spatial prepositions and verbal prefixes, the directional strategy continued to be used for the expression of peripheral spatial meanings, for which no prepositional expression had developed. I illustrate this phenomenon with data from Ancient Greek and Modern Russian, and discuss how it can explain the data commonly described by the somewhat mysterious term “ablative-locative transfer”.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Synchronic differences in the encoding of sources and goals of motion have drawn considerable attention (Stefanowitch & Rohde 2004; Lakusta & Landau 2005, inter alia), yet relatively little is known about the diachrony of that asymmetry. This study focuses on an aspect of the Goal–Source asymmetry that has been largely ignored in typological literature: the use of ablative and allative marking for the encoding of static locations. Surveying spatial expressions in Indo-European languages, one finds, in language after language, evidence for their ablative origin, even in the case of expressions that at present are only used in the locative sense. For example, the Ancient Greek preposition ópisthe(n) ‘behind’ is derived historically from an ablative adverb, suggesting that the original meaning was ‘from behind’, but at some stage the preposition started being used predominantly for static locations (Nikitina & Spano 2014; for examples, see (10a–c) below).

Ablative etymology is shared by a number of other Ancient Greek prepositions and adverbs, including several others that end in -then (Lejeune 1939; see also Georgakopoulos & Karatsareas in this volume for examples of non-ablative uses of expressions with apo- in Greek dialects). Similar evidence is commonly found in other Indo-European languages, suggesting that various originally ablative prepositions and adverbs came to be used as locative ones. In the literature, the change has been referred to as the “ablative-locative transfer” (MacKenzie 1978), suggesting an intimate diachronic relationship between static locations and sources of motion. As I argue below, this term in unfortunate in creating the impression of abrupt change, or reanalysis, while in reality, we see that the two meanings can and often do co-exist for long periods of time. I will suggest that the change is better described as ablative pro locative use, or as a result of a productive strategy of describing locations by means of directional expressions (including ablative ones). I discuss examples of this strategy both for ancient and for modern languages.

Etymological evidence shows an asymmetry between Source expressions and expressions used to describe Goals of motion. While we find abundant evidence for the ablative-locative diachronic connection in prepositions and adverbs of various Indo-European languages, allative etymology is less common. New locative prepositions and adverbs regularly derive from expressions that originally encoded Sources of motion (illustrated in Section 3), but they do not derive as often from expressions that originally encoded Goals.

The etymological asymmetry is especially surprising in light of the fact that Goals of motion and static locations often receive identical marking at the synchronic level. Many languages do not draw a systematic distinction between allative and locative expressions. In Romance languages, for example, goals of motion are normally distinguished from static locations by context only (1a); similar ambiguity is widely attested in American English (1b) and many other Indo-European languages (Nikitina 2008, 2009; Pantcheva 2010).

sec.p: This data suggests that the encoding of Goals and Sources of motion interacts in different ways with the locative meaning. Expressions for Sources of motion often develop into regular locative expressions, but expressions for Goals of motion rarely do so, even though Goals are often encoded by the same means as static locations, resulting in ambiguity.

In sum, this study addresses two questions: why are static prepositions and adverbs so often derived historically from ablative expressions, and why are they not derived so often from allative expressions? The answers I am suggesting can be briefly summarized as follows.

First, the ablative etymology of static prepositions and adverbs is explained by the fact that prior to the development of specialized static spatial prepositions, Indo-European languages described spatial relations by means of directional adverbs. Most of these adverbs were reanalyzed as new prepositions and verbal prefixes, and the prepositions became specialized for the expression of static spatial relations. The directional strategy survives, however, in some languages with peripheral spatial relations, for which no specialized prepositions or adverbs have developed.

Second, while both expressions for Sources and expressions for Goals of motion can be used for describing static spatial relations, there is an asymmetry in how these expressions function. Talmy’s notion of access path is helpful for understanding the difference. To locate a Figure in space with respect to the Ground, one can move from the Ground’s intrinsic part (e.g., It is away from the tree’s top) or toward an external area of space (It is upward from the tree). Cross-linguistically, new spatial relators tend to develop from nouns referring to intrinsic parts of an object (Svorou 1994). In access path constructions, intrinsic parts normally play the role of a source, and when such constructions develop into new static spatial relators, they may retain traces of their ablative origin. I explore these issues in detail below, starting with the role of directional adverbs in the expression of spatial relations.

sec.title: Static spatial relators vs. access paths
sec.p: We are so used to encoding spatial relations with specialized static prepositions that we often take their existence for granted, and ignore a powerful alternative that can be used in cases where a specialized static relator is not available. How do speakers encode a complex relation that does not have a corresponding preposition? Many languages allow their speakers to deal with that problem by using directional expressions that specify how one can get at the Figure’s location if they start from the Ground. Consider expressions such as five meters down from the top edge of the frame or right across the street from here. They encode the mental path one should take in order to determine the Figure’s location, and that explains why the Ground is encoded in them in the same way as Sources of motion normally are (from the top edge, from here). Such expressions are described by Talmy (1996: 242) in terms of access path, or a path “that some other entity might follow to the point of encounter with the object”. The use of access paths is in many ways similar to giving directions – something we do when we need to describe in a very precise way the location of a particular object (e.g., go to the next intersection, turn left, then walk toward the mall…).

Let us consider in more detail how the strategy of using access paths differs from using inherently static prepositions. Static prepositions directly locate the Figure in a region of space defined with respect to a Ground. They describe the Figure’s search domain; for example, the preposition above selects as the Figure’s search domain the area of space located higher than some other object on the gravitational axis, e.g. above the table. The use of static descriptions is similar to giving a specific address. The location is described in static terms, in a way that is independent of any access path. It can serve as a Source or a Goal of motion if the language allows static locations to be combined with ablative or allative marking (e.g., It fell down from above the table). Some of the inherently static prepositions have counterparts describing the same location as a Goal or a Source of motion (2a); others acquire a dynamic reading in combination with a motion verb (as in (1a)) or in combination with a noun phrase in a different case (2b), still others do not have any direct counterparts in dynamic contexts (as a result, descriptions of certain spatial configurations may be lexically restricted to static contexts, cf. the Russian preposition ‘in front of’ in (2c)).1 One line of research into the encoding of spatial relations has focused on the ways the meaning of motion interacts with the encoding of particular search domains (Talmy 1985, 1991; Nikitina 2009, 2013; Nikitina & Maslov 2013, inter alia).

sec.p: Access paths are a poorly studied alternative to static descriptors. They are vectors pointing from the Ground toward the Figure, so that the Figure’s search domain is determined by the vector’s direction. The vector’s direction can be described in one of two ways: by locating its starting point (possibly with explicit mention of the distance, as in five meters down from the top edge of the frame) or by locating its endpoint (cf. upward from the table, which locates the vector’s endpoint closer to the upward end of the gravitational axis than its starting point). The two types of access path expression are illustrated in (3a–b). In (3a), the Figure can be located by going away from the Ground (here) in the direction of the Southern Pole; the Ground can be explicitly given or left implicit and inferred from context. In (3b), the vector points away from the surface of the water, and the direction can be made explicit or left implicit; in (3b), it must be inferred from context whether the vector is pointing upward or downward.
