sec.p: I will refer to the two types in (3a) and (3b) as Goal-based and Source-based access paths, respectively. They both involve strategies that are normally restricted, in the language in question, to the expression of goals or sources of motion: in (3a) and (3b), for example, the prepositions to and from normally introduce goals and sources of motion (and they can only introduce goals or sources in combination with other types of Ground, cf. to the house or from the house). Where the two types differ is their interpretation possibilities: Goal-based access paths could be interpreted, in the context of a motion verb, as describing the Goal of motion, and Source-based access paths could be interpreted, in the context of a motion verb, as describing the motion’s starting point.

Access paths are inherently dynamic. Those that specify the vector’s starting point cannot easily be turned into Goals of motion (cf. *from to the south from here); those that specify the vector’s endpoint cannot easily be into a Source (cf. ?? toward two inches from the surface of the ground). In this respect access paths differ from static spatial descriptions.

Not all languages use access paths to the same extent, and many languages impose restrictions on the set of relations access paths can describe and on the ways their vector can be coded. These restrictions will be illustrated in detail in the next sections; I will relate them to the competition between the access path strategy and the use of static prepositions. I will argue that specialized static prepositions tend to be preferred, and the access path strategy is restricted to descriptions of complex relationships for which no ready-made static preposition exists. In this way, the use of access paths can be viewed as an auxiliary strategy for describing a search domain, just as complex directions are used in cases where no ready-made static description is available (e.g., in the form of address). Preference for the newly developed static relators can explain the restricted use of the access path strategy in some of the modern languages (e.g., Romance) as compared to the ancient languages from which they descend (e.g., Latin).

sec.title: Etymology of spatial prepositions
sec.p: The most striking and conspicuous evidence for earlier productive use of access path strategies comes from the etymology of a variety of spatial prepositions and adverbs (MacKenzie 1978). The prepositions and adverbs in (4)–(6), from different Romance languages, have an ablative origin, i.e., they derive from expressions that could originally encode sources of motion. Many of such prepositions can be traced back to a Latin source, and some have gone through the same diachronic change several times, repeatedly developing locative meaning for an originally ablative form.2

sec.p: The representation in (4)–(6) follows the way such transfers are traditionally presented, and implies an abrupt categorical shift from the ablative to a locative meaning. This view is, however, grossly oversimplified. If we look in more detail at the way some of the ablative-locative transfers occurred (where the data is of course available), we will see that the process involved stages of ambiguity, where the same expression could be used either in the ablative or in the locative sense. A more accurate description of how the changes represented in (4)–(6) occurred would look more like the picture in (7), illustrating the development of the Italian marker da.

list-item.p: Latin ab 'from' (source marker) > ab (ablative or locative) > de ab 'from' (renewed source marker) > dab, da (ablative or locative)

sec.p: In Latin, the same marker could be used, at least with some nouns, in two different functions: as a source marker, and as a static locative preposition. Later, the same ambiguity characterized the renewed ablative marker (De Felice 1954; Poppe 1963; Luraghi 2010: 26–27, 2011). At the ambiguity stage, the locative interpretation was often restricted to only some types of context, and in particular, to contexts referring to an object’s intrinsic parts, such as with nouns for ‘side’ or ‘part’ (see Sections 4 for Ancient Greek; Section 5 for Russian; cf. Luraghi 2010: 26 on Latin). Such restrictions are predicted if the locative use of ablative expressions is treated, at the ambiguity stage, as reflecting the access path strategy: such strategies are normally used in a limited number of contexts, and are easily replaced by specialized static relators when such relators become available. Why nouns for ‘side’ and ‘part’ appear particularly often in ablative constructions that receive a static interpretation, is discussed in more detail later in the paper; the simple answer is that they allow speakers to specify the starting point of the access path vector as a particular side of the reference object.

A similar process is illustrated in (8) for the modern French preposition dedans ‘inside’, which went through three cycles of analogous development. The preposition derives from an early Latin ablative expression, already used in the locative sense in Classical Latin. In Vulgar Latin, the term becomes a component of a new ablative, which also develops into a locative. In Old French, the new locative again becomes part of a new ablative expression, which in turn acquires a locative meaning in Modern French.

sec.p: Extensions from ablative to locative meaning were as common in Ancient Greek as in Latin and later in Romance. The Examples in (10a–c) illustrate multiple cycles of semantic change in the development of the Ancient Greek term for ‘behind’ (Nikitina & Spano 2014). The term derives from an ablative adverb, and in Homer it is still used predominantly in the ablative sense, as in (10a). In Classical Greek, the same term has a locative meaning: it describes static scenes not involving motion, and the original ablative use is virtually unattested (10b). In (10c), the adverb is used nominally (it is introduced by an article), as part of a new expression that features an ablative preposition but again receives a locative reading.

sec.p: The Examples in (10a–c) can be accounted for if we assume that Ancient Greek allowed ablative expressions to describe static spatial relations, in constructions with Source-based access paths. The same synchronic strategy can also explain what appears to be an etymological quirk of so many Indo-European languages: the ablative origin of static locative prepositions and adverbs. If we assume that in a restricted number of contexts, ablative expressions were used to describe static locative relations, it becomes clear why they were commonly reanalyzed as new specialized static relators, and as such could participate in the formation of new ablative expressions (e.g., dans > dedans > de dedans).

In Sections 4 and 5, I discuss further evidence for the productive use of motion-based strategies in ancient languages (based on Ancient Greek) and in some modern languages (based on Russian). After laying out the details my account, I discuss, in Section 6, why it presents a plausible alternative to the notion of “ablative-locative transfer”, or a mechanism that miraculously transforms, in one step, ablative expressions into locative ones.

sec.title: Motion-based strategies in ancient languages
sec.p: The use of Source-based access paths is widely attested in Latin with some types of expressions. In (11), that strategy is illustrated with a term for ‘behind’ (the example is discussed in Luraghi 2010: 26): despite the use of the ablative preposition, the interpretation is unambiguously static, and the situation involves no motion. A parallel example from Ancient Greek in (12) similarly imposes a locative interpretation on what is encoded as a Source of motion, with the expression for ‘right (side)’ (similar uses of ‘behind’ were illustrated in Examples (10b–c) above).

list-item.p: ‘because behind (them) were hills’ (Liv.2.65.2)
‘and on their right (were) Leukadians and other barbarians’ (literally, “from their right”) (Th.2.81.3)

sec.p: In the rest of this section, I focus on Ancient Greek, and on expressions for ‘right’ and ‘left’. I show that both Source-based and Goal-based access paths are widely used, but occur in different types of construction. Glossing over some complex details, their distribution can be summarized as follows: Source-based access paths are used with expressions referring to intrinsic parts of objects (they describe an object’s part as a starting point of the vector), and Goal-based access paths are used with expressions referring to extrinsic areas of space (they specify the direction by describing the vector’s endpoint). Let us look at the actual data in more detail.

In the most common type of example, the access path is defined in terms of its starting point, as leading away from a particular intrinsic part of the object or one of its sides. In (13), to arrive at the Figure (the people), one needs to move away from the king’s left hand (the noun ‘hand’ is modified by the adjective ‘left’). As predicted by the notion of a Source-based access path, in this type of example Ancient Greek systematically uses ablative encoding (in (13), the noun phrase ‘left hand’ is introduced by the ablative preposition ek(s) ‘from’).

list-item.p: ‘This word means in Greek “those standing on the left hand of the king”.’ (Hdt.2.30.5)

sec.p: A Goal-based access path can also be used, in a different type of context. With Goal-based access paths, the Figure’s location is described in terms of the endpoint of the vector, and the endpoint is typically an abstract extrinsic area. In (14), the nouns ‘right’ and ‘left’ are used on their own, without a genitive. They do not refer to an object’s intrinsic part, but point to abstract areas of space defined with respect to a particular observer’s perspective (the perspective can be made explicit by a dative noun phrase with a participle: ‘with respect to the one entering the temple’). The starting point of the access path can be is left implicit, and is understood to coincide with the observer’s location or the situation’s deictic center. As predicted by the access path model, in this type of example Ancient Greek uses allative expressions, such as the epi + accusative combination in (14).3

list-item.p: ‘Of them (the two bowls) the golden one was located on the right of those entering the temple, the silver one on the left.’ (Hdt.1.51.4)

sec.p: An interesting type of example involves a situation where a Goal-based access path is defined with respect to an intrinsic part of an object. As predicted by the access path model, such expressions do not describe in Ancient Greek the same type of relation as the one in (13), where the vector is directed away from one of the reference object’s sides. Rather, the vector is understood to start at some point within the object and to be directed toward one of the object’s sides. The Figure in such cases is understood to be located within the reference object, not outside it. In (15a), for example, the growing hair is located within the head (the combination of the preposition epi ‘on’ with the accusative normally encodes goals of motion). Similarly, in (15b), the Figure is located inside the battlefield, in proximity to its left edge.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘They let their hair grow long on the right side of their heads and shave the left.’ (Hdt.4.191.4)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘for he was fighting on the left of the entire battle by the banks of the Scamander river’ (Il.11.498)

sec.p: This is in contrast to the Source-based access path in (13), where the Figure is located outside the reference object whose side is mentioned. Hence, the use of Goal-based and Source-based access paths with descriptions of intrinsic object parts correlates with the difference between intrinsic and extrinsic localization (whether the Figure is located within or outside the object whose part is used in the description).

In sum, Ancient Greeks used a rather sophisticated system of motion-based expressions that described certain types of static locations not by means of static prepositions, but by means of constructions with access paths.4 Both Source-based and Goal-based access paths were widely used, and the choice between them was largely determined by the type of spatial relationship. Source-based access paths were reserved for cases where the Figure’s location is defined with respect to an object’s intrinsic part (e.g., ‘from the right hand’). Goal-based access paths are used to describe locations with respect to external areas of space or to describe locations within the object whose part is being referenced (‘within the head, but toward its right side’, ‘toward the right side of the battle’, etc.).

A similar system appears to have been used in Latin, although the details of the distribution are a subject for a separate study. A likely explanation for the distribution of Source-based and Goal-based access paths has to do with the ways such strategies function: sometimes we give directions based on the side of an object at which one should start (‘start from the main exit’, with a Source-based access path), and sometimes we give them based on an external landmark (‘go toward the lake’, with a Goal-based access path). Descriptions of intrinsic locations would correspond, in direction-giving, to using as a landmark an intrinsic part of a larger location-like object, when the starting point of the vector is understood to be located within the same object (‘go toward the northernmost part of the town’, again with a Goal-based access path). Strategies we use for direction-giving differ of course in a number of ways from the ways access paths are used to describe locations (partly because the latter are in severe competition with static expressions), but the underlying cognitive mechanism appears to be similar, and that allows us to use the analogy with giving directions to describe rather accurately the distribution of ablative and allative expressions with a static interpretation in Ancient Greek.

Modern descendants of Latin and Ancient Greek seem to only partially retain the original system of access path expressions. In Romance, Source-based access paths are no longer in use, and the distinct allative strategy has also been lost, for independent reasons. Modern Greek also no longer has distinct allative prepositions, but it preserves to some extent the use of Source-based access paths. Examples such as (16a), with an ablative preposition introducing the noun ‘left’, are readily accepted by some speakers of Modern Greek, but seem outdated to others (cf. Bortone 2010: 345). Examples with adverbs, such as (16b), seem to be more common.

sec.title: Lexical restrictions
sec.p: Diachronic data from Greek and Romance suggests that the access path strategy is no longer used in the modern languages to the same extent as what we see in ancient texts. The decline of Goal-based access paths was possibly related to the loss of distinct allative prepositions (eis in Greek) or the loss of case resulting in the absence of distinct allative preposition + case combinations (in + accusative, ad + accusative in Romance). The decline of the Source-based access path strategy, however, cannot be explained by any independent change. Outside the families in question, the Source-based strategy is virtually absent from English and German: it can still be used in expressions with distance measures, as in three inches from the surface of the water, but it does not appear with expressions such as from the right, from the south, from above, etc., even though such expressions are syntactically well-formed and perfectly acceptable on the Source reading. Goal-based access paths, too, seem to be restricted to only a few expressions, such as expressions with ‘right’ and ‘left’ (17a–b) or expressions referring to cardinal directions (17c), and even in these expressions, the inherently static counterparts ( on the left, in the south) seem to be the preferred option.5

sec.p: The restrictions on the use of access paths are highly conspicuous. Already in Ancient Greek and Latin, access paths are attested primarily with those spatial relations that did not, at that point, have a regular prepositional equivalent. Such are the (relatively infrequent) expressions with ‘right’/‘left’ and with cardinal directions, as well as distance-measuring expressions (such as two meters from the top), which do not correspond to specialized adpositional marking in any of the languages. Why are these relations unlikely to develop prepositional expression? There do not seem to be any special syntactic or semantic reasons: in many of the languages, expressions for ‘right’/’left’ and cardinal terms are nouns, just like terms for an object’s intrinsic parts. Expressions with ‘left’ and ‘right’ may also refer to intrinsic parts of an object, making them good candidates, from a semantic point of view, for becoming grammaticalized as spatial relators. Yet basic adpositional systems of Indo-European languages rarely include special relators for ‘right’/’left’ and cardinal direction terms.

The answer seems to lie in the expressions’ relatively low frequency. Consider the number of expressions for ‘right’ and ‘left’ as compared to ‘in front’ and ‘behind’ in Homer. The counts are only suggestive, since they include non-spatial uses (I did, however, exclude the preposition pro ‘before’, because of the high proportion of non-spatial uses). For expressions for ‘right’ and ‘left’, the counts also do not distinguish between nominal and adjectival uses, and no distinction is made between ablative, locative, and allative readings. Even with such rough counts, however, the difference in the distribution corresponds to the intuition that the relations of ‘left’ and ‘right’ are not talked about often, compared to other types of spatial relation (note that the relators for ‘behind’ and ‘in front’ are themselves relatively recent and infrequent in Ancient Greek, see Nikitina & Spano 2014).

I give below the counts, in thousands, of all adverbs/prepositions used to describe the corresponding configurations, irrespective of their orientation (allative, locative or ablative). Note that the adverbial relators for ‘right’ and ‘left’ are both infrequent and less numerous.

sec.p: These are of course only rough counts that do not take into account the peculiarities of actual uses, but the overall distributions are again suggestive. The expressions with ‘right’/’left’ and cardinal directions are simply not frequent enough to develop into new specialized static relators.

As for distance-measuring expressions (two meters from the top), they are normally too specific to be expressed by any particular term that would be susceptible to further grammaticalization, such as a specific body part term; at least they do not receive such expression in the languages here discussed. The low frequency or lack of conventional expression are crucial to understanding the restricted distribution of access paths: while the access path strategy is useful in describing relations for which there is no conventional static expression, it tends to lose the competition with specialized inherently static prepositions/adverbs when such prepositions/adverbs appear. As Indo-European languages developed rich systems of spatial prepositions, the prepositions took over the functions originally associated with access path expressions (of which we still have evidence in the etymology of spatial prepositions/adverbs).

sec.title: Access paths in Russian: ‘left’ and ‘right’
sec.p: Before spelling out the details of this account, let me examine in more detail the way access path strategies are used in one of the modern languages that still preserve a system comparable to the ones attested in Latin or Ancient Greek. Unlike in modern Romance or Germanic languages, both Source-based and Goal-based access paths are in wide use in Slavic. The Examples in (20a–b) illustrate this for Russian. In (20a), the term for ‘right’ is an adjective modifying the noun ‘side’, and the noun phrase is introduced by an ablative preposition. In (20b), the notions of ‘right’ and ‘left’ are expressed by directional adverbs that normally encode motion to the right and to the left, respectively. The examples come from the Russian National Corpus, and date back to the 18th and 19th centuries, but they are also accepted by present-day Russian speakers, and similar examples are found in abundance in contemporary literary and colloquial texts.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘Write it down nearby, on (lit., from) the right side.’ (Ushinsky, Rodnoe slovo, 1864)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘To the right of the door there stood a table.’(Pod’jachev, Mytarstva, 1903)

sec.p: Like Ancient Greek, Russian offers several syntactic options for expressing the concepts of ‘left’ and ‘right’, referring to intrinsic parts of an object or to abstract external areas of space. As in Ancient Greek, many expressions are ambiguous. In fact, the ambiguity is more prominent in Russian, and that explains a greater degree of variation in the choice between Goal-based and Source-based access paths, as compared to Ancient Greek.

The notions of ‘right’ and ‘left’ can be encoded by adverbs or by adjectives. I will start by describing the strategies involving adverbs, and will then turn to adjectives. With access paths, adverbs can specify either the starting point or the endpoint of the vector, i.e., both allative and ablative adverbs can be used. This variation reflects the ambiguity in the interpretation of adverbs: they can define direction with respect to an object’s intrinsic part or an external area. In (21a–b), either ablative or allative adverbs can describe a static location (the same adverbs can be used to describe motion from a source or motion toward a goal, respectively). In (21a), the ablative adverbs specify where the access path starts: to reach the location in question, one needs to move away from the observer’s left or right side. In (21a), the allative adverbs specify where the access path is pointing: to reach the location in question, one needs to move in the direction of abstract external areas ‘right’ and ‘left’.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘On the left I saw a black forest, and on the right behind the Rhine the Vosges were visible.’ (Puščin, Dnevn., 1813)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘To the right (there is) a forest on a low bank, to the left (there is) a high bank.’ (Radiščev, Zap. put. iz Sibiri, 1797)

sec.p: In (21a–b), the reference object with respect to which the relations of ‘right’ and ‘left’ are defined is implicit in the context, and not introduced overtly. It is understood to be the observer or the deictic center of the situation, as inferred from earlier discourse. In (21a), the left and right are determined with respect to the 1st person narrator’s position; in (21b), with respect to the perspective introduced by the preceding context: the protagonist’s position, the place where the previously described events take place, etc. Rather than leaving that information implicit, spatial adverbs in Russian can combine with a prepositional phrase that introduces explicitly the reference object with respect to which the relationship is defined. The prepositional phrase is headed by the preposition ot ‘from’, which combines with a genitive noun phrase. An example can be seen in (20b) above. The presence of such prepositional phrases does not affect the acceptability of the examples; e.g., one can add explicit reference objects in (21a–b).

The fact that reference objects are introduced with an ablative prepositional phrase is consistent with the access path model. With extrinsic locations, the access path leads away from the implicit reference object, independent of whether it is described in terms of its starting point or its endpoint. When that object is made explicit, the ablative marking is used to introduce it. It is predicted by this account that prepositional phrases introducing the reference object should not appear in descriptions of intrinsic locations, where the Figure is located inside the reference object. This prediction is borne out: ot-phrases cannot be used in examples such as (22), because the Figure is enclosed within the reference object.

list-item.p: ‘On the left (side) of the lake, the waves were bigger.’

sec.p: Besides adverbs, the notion of ‘right’ and ‘left’ can be encoded by adjectives. In access path constructions, the adjectives modify the noun storona ‘side’. That noun is ambiguous and can refer either to an object’s intrinsic part (e.g., pravaja storona dorogi ‘the right side of the road-genitive’) or to an abstract external area (e.g., dal’njaja storona ‘far-away land’, čužaja storona ‘foreign land’). As with adverbs, the reference object can be introduced by an ablative prepositional phrase, and as with adverbs, both Source-based and Goal-based access paths are used in these constructions, because of the ambiguous reference of the noun ‘side’. In (23a), the access path starts at the right side of the reference object (the city), hence the ablative encoding ‘from the right side’. In (23b), the access path is described as leading toward an external area of space: ‘to the right side’.6

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘As soon as we came to anchor, one of the mountains, the one to the right of the city, became covered with a cloud.’ (Gončarov, Fregat “Pallada”, 1855)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘To the right of the road, behind a river, a village has been built consisting of 36 homesteads.’ (Radiščev, Opisanie…, 1800–1801)

sec.p: There is a different in the syntactic options available to expressions with adjectives and with adverbs. The reference object can be encoded with adverbs by an ablative prepositional phrase with ot, and they can also be encoded in the same way with constructions with adjectives. With adjectives, however, the reference object can be described by a genitive argument of the noun ‘side’. Genitive arguments only appear on the intrinsic part reading of the noun ‘side’, i.e., when ‘side’ refers to the object’s intrinsic part, not to an external area. To describe locations next to an intrinsic part, Source-based access paths can be used. This is illustrated by the Examples in (24a–b). In (24a–b), the access paths start at the right and the left sides of the duelists, suggesting that the two Figures were standing on the duelists’ opposite sides. In (24b), the access path starts at the right side of the face.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘Xanykov and Biron’s aide-de-camp took a burning torch each, and stood one on the right, the other on the left of the duelists.’ (K. P. Masal’skij, Regentstvo Birona, 1834)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘The financial director was able to discern a huge bruise on the right side of the face right by the nose.’ (Bulgakov, M. i. M.., 1929–1939)

sec.p: Note that Source-based access paths are used independently of whether the Figure is located inside or outside the Ground (24a vs. b). This ambiguity makes Russian different from Ancient Greek. In Ancient Greek, Source-based access paths were used to locate the Figure outside, and Goal-based access paths, inside the Ground (in expressions such as ‘they let the hair grow toward the head’s right’). In modern Russian, both types of location are described using Source-based access paths.

sec.title: Access paths in Russian: Cardinal directions
sec.p: A very similar distribution characterizes the use of terms referring to cardinal directions, with subtle differences that are related to a syntactic difference. In Russian, cardinal directions cannot be encoded by adverbs, but they can be encoded by nouns such as sever ‘north’ and jug ‘south’ or by adjectives such as severnyj ‘northern’ and južnyj ‘southern’.7 Like adverbs referring to right and left, the nouns can refer either to the reference object’s intrinsic parts or to abstract external areas, and accordingly, they appear with both Source-based and Goal-based access paths. The reference object can again be left implicit or specified by an ablative prepositional phrase. In (25a), the ablative access path leads away from the seaside, starting at its northern part. In (25b), the allative access path is directed toward the abstract north, and the reference object is not specified. In (25c), the access path leads away from a sea, toward the abstract north, south, and east; the reference object is only coded explicitly with the first cardinal term, and left unspecified with the next ones.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘To the north of the seaside there loomed a powerful grouping of German troops.’ (Samojlov, Obsch. dn., 1977–89)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘Right before him, to the north, (mountain) spines were standing up ridge after ridge.’ (Bestuzhev-Marlinskii, M-Nur, 1836)

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘What was lying to the north of the sea known to the ancients, was named Europe; what (was lying) to the south, Africa; what (was lying) to the east, Asia.’ (Danilevskij, Ross. i Evr., 1869)

sec.p: Since cardinal directions can be encoded by nouns, the corresponding adjectives are not as frequently used as those for right and left. Still, the adjectives can combine with the noun storona ‘side’, and the combinations are again ambiguous: they can refer to abstract external areas or to an object’s intrinsic parts. Accordingly, both Goal-based and Source-based access paths are attested (although the Goal-based access path is perceived by some speakers as slightly outdated; such speakers prefer using the nouns, as in (25a–c), instead of the adjectives):8

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘On the northern side of the stake, at the distance of 10 cm, a mound is arranged.’ (V. Koncevoj, Sorvat’ i sjest’, 2003)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘And if one takes a closer look at the far horizons to the southwestern side…’(V. Ja. Šiškov, Emeljan Pugačev, 1934–45)

sec.p: When the reference is unambiguous – e.g., when a genitive argument makes it clear that the expression refers to an object’s intrinsic part, we find Source-based access paths:

list-item.p: ‘To the east of Arzrum, on the heights of Top-Dag, a Turkish battery was located.’ (Puškin, Putešestvie v Arzrum, 1835)

sec.title: Summary of the Russian data
sec.p: To sum up, both Goal-based and Source-based access paths are used productively in Russian (similar evidence is found in other Slavic languages, such as Polish, but I cannot explore it in sufficient detail here). The same motion-based strategies were used productively in ancient Indo-European languages such as Latin and Ancient Greek (and possibly old Germanic languages), but their modern descendants have lost either one or both of them.

In Russian, the distribution of Goal-based and Source-based access paths depends on factors that are similar to the ones relevant for Ancient Greek. Intrinsic parts of reference objects serve as the starting point of the path, and are encoded in the same way as sources of motion. Abstract external areas of space are described as the endpoint of the access path, and are encoded in the same way as goals of motion. Many descriptions are ambiguous, and can refer either to an object’s intrinsic part or to an external area. With such descriptions, both Source-based and Goal-based access paths are attested.

An important difference between Russian and Ancient Greek concerns situations with intrinsic location, where the Figure is located inside the reference object (‘toward the right side of the battle’, ‘toward the left side of the face’). In such cases, Ancient Greek resorts to the allative strategy, but Russian uses ablative constructions (24b). I cannot go into a detailed discussion of this difference between the two languages, but it may be related to differences in the meaning of Russian and Ancient Greek nouns referring to intrinsic parts (whether the nouns such as ‘side’ or ‘right (side)’ refer, on the intrinsic reading, to an area within the object or only to the object’s external surface).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Going back to the questions I began with, the answers that emerge from this study can be summarized as follows.

Why are static prepositions and adverbs so often derived historically from ablative expressions? An answer to this question is suggested by the notion of access path. The strategy of using access paths provides us with a convenient means for describing spatial relations where specialized static prepositions or adverbs are not available. Ancient languages made extensive use of access paths to describe various types of relation, and our modern static prepositions and adverbs often derive from such uses.

The origin of basic Indo-European spatial prepositions is reflected in the affinities between static prepositions and verbal prefixes (Meillet 1934; Horrocks 1981; Coleman 1991; Hewson & Bubenik 2006, inter alia). Both classes go back to the same directional adverbs (sometimes described as particles), which were reanalyzed as prepositions or prefixes depending on the adverb’s position. The adverbs commonly described direction, “reinforcing” the directional meaning of the verb. For example, in (28a–c), I present the contexts where an originally independent directional adverb ‘away’ developed into a preposition or a verbal prefix, based on the example for ‘I go from the ship’ from Bortone (2010: 133–134).

In short, the answer to the first question is this. Static prepositions and adverbs often derive from ablative expressions, because prior to their development, the same relationship was described by means of access path constructions, i.e., by constructions with ablative prepositions (as in French de-dans ‘from inside’) or affixes (as in Greek ópis-then ‘from behind’). It is from these dynamic expressions that new static prepositions develop.

Why are static prepositions and adverbs not derived as often from allative expressions as from ablative ones? In fact, we have seen that in languages such as Ancient Greek, Latin or Russian, both ablative and allative expressions can be used to describe static locations, because the same access path can be described in terms of its starting point (an intrinsic part of the reference object) or its endpoint (an abstract external area of space). So both ablative and allative expressions are used, in synchrony, in lieu of static locatives. Why then are traces of allative origin less likely to be preserved in the etymology of static relators than traces of ablative origin? I believe that the answer to this question lies in the general grammaticalization tendencies that characterize the development of new prepositions. As researched by Svorou (1986, 1994), body part terms and terms for intrinsic parts of objects are the most common sources for new prepositions (see also Aurnague 1996 for French, and cf. such still transparent English cases as, for example, inside or in front of). Access path constructions with intrinsic parts of objects typically involve Source-based encoding: we have seen above many examples where the path to a particular location is described as leading ‘from the right hand’ or ‘from the northern side’ of a reference object. When such constructions grammaticalize into new static spatial relators, they may preserve traces of their ablative origin.9

So my short answer to the second question is this. Both allative and ablative constructions may be used to describe static locations synchronically (with language-specific restrictions, of course), but constructions referring to intrinsic parts favor the development of new static prepositions. The access path model predicts that such constructions will tend to involve ablative marking, since intrinsic parts of objects are typically described as the starting point of an access path. This results in the ablative etymology of new static prepositions and adverbs.

While the tendency for terms for internal parts to grammaticalize into new prepositions explains the ablative etymology of many locative markers, it need not result in a synchronic association of locations with sources in contemporary languages. In fact, cross-linguistically, sources of motion are more likely to be distinguished from locations at the synchronic level than goals. Hence the ambiguity between goals of motion and static locations is very common synchronically, but rarely reflected in the etymology of static prepositions.

Two general implications of the study need to be further discussed. First, some Indo-European languages seem to have been undergoing a shift away from the access path strategy: modern Romance languages, for example, do not use Source-based access to the same extent as Latin. This shift is likely related to the development of rich prepositional systems, which came to replace the old system of directional adverbs. Traces of the old access path strategy are still visible in the etymology of some prepositions and adverbs across the Indo-European family. In addition, the access path strategy survives in some languages at the periphery of the spatial system, with relatively infrequent spatial relations that do not (or recently did not) have a corresponding specialized static preposition. These are first of all expressions involving cardinal directions and terms for prominent direction-defining landmarks, such as upward, southward, but also some infrequent terms for object parts, such as terms for left and right, and sometimes the less frequent object part terms, such as ‘front’/’back’ or ‘inside’/’outside’.10

Another class of expressions that favor the use of access paths are descriptions referring to occasional external landmarks, e.g. in expressions for the wall closest to the sea or in distance-measuring expressions, such as inches from my hand.11 The occasional spatial relationships such expressions describe are again not frequent enough to become conventionalized, and no specialized static prepositions develop for their encoding in the languages in question. In both Ancient Greek and in Russian, external landmarks are introduced by Source-based access paths (29a–b).12

sec.p: The shift in the prominence of specialized static encoding as opposed to access paths can be viewed as typological in nature, and there are languages that rely more on access paths than any modern Indo-European language does. For example, MacKenzie (1978) discusses the prominent use of Source-based access paths in Israeli Hebrew.13 Among other languages that often use motion-based strategies are Bashkir and Kazakh (Turkic, personal knowledge), and Yurakaré (isolate, Bolivia; Rik van Gijn p.c.). The cross-linguistic distribution of access path constructions requires a separate study.

Second, the phenomenon discussed in this study sheds light on the mysterious nature of so-called “ablative-locative transfers.” MacKenzie (1978) explained such transfers by occasional lexicalization that was due to contextual ambiguity. According to his account, ablative expressions were reinterpreted as locatives in ambiguous contexts; for example, in descriptions of milking a cow (= from/at a cow), the source of motion (for the milk) and the static location (where the milking takes place) are not sufficiently differentiated, and reinterpretation can occur. This account faces several problems. First, it does not explain the systematic nature of the change, and predicts that allative-locative transfers should be in fact at least as systematic. Intuitively, ambiguities between locations and sources of motion are relatively rare, and ambiguities between locations and goals of motion are at least as frequent (Nikitina 2009). The available etymological data, however, proves that prediction wrong: we do not see, in static prepositions and adverbs, traces of allative etymology nearly as often as traces of ablative one.

Another fact that MacKenzie’s account does not explain is the distribution of Source-based access paths. As discussed above, constructions with Source-based access paths, which are a natural origin of new static prepositions, are favored by peripheral spatial relations. The same preference is shown by constructions with Goal-based access paths in languages that still use them. If MacKenzie’s reinterpretation account were correct, one would expect ablative-locative transfers to happen in the most frequent ambiguous contexts first. Most frequent spatial prepositions, however, such as prepositions for ‘in’ and ‘on’, are less often related to directional expressions than infrequent prepositions (‘inside’, ‘on top of’), not to mention expressions involving right/left or cardinal directions. The access path account predicts exactly that: speakers resort to access path constructions in descriptions of spatial relations for which no specialized static preposition is available. The richer the system of static prepositions becomes, the fewer contexts remain where the access path strategy can be useful.

An important conclusion regarding so-called ablative-locative transfers follows. The examples are better accounted for not in terms of abrupt reanalysis, by as a reflection of productive use of the access path strategy at an earlier stage. The simplified picture in (4)–(6) should be replaced with more complex representations (cf. (7)). Instead of ablative-locative transfer, the data may be better described by an account based on the notion of strategic ablative-pro-locative use.

I am also grateful to the audience of our workshop at the ICHL in Naples, and to Anetta Kopecka, Colette Grinevald, Gabriela Pérez Báes, and other participants of the Atelier Typologie Sémantique at DDL in Lyon, where I presented this work.

fn.p: In Examples (2a–c), I tried to use prepositions that only differ in the locative role (Place, Goal, Source), but not in the search domain they define. It is difficult, however, to find exact equivalents, because the inventories of Place-defining prepositions are in general richer, and many Place-prepositions are more specific than their Goal- or Source-counterparts. Thus, the preposition from is more general than the preposition in, as it does not require the Figure to originate in the internal part of the container. The Russian preposition iz ‘from’ is a more exact counterpart of v ‘in’, because Russian describes motion away from the outside of a Ground with a different preposition, ot ‘from (the outside of)’.
The prepositions in (4)–(6) are but a small selection; for further examples and discussion, see MacKenzie (1978).

Note that some uses are inevitably ambiguous, since in the absence of a genitive possessor or a perspective-specifying dative expression, be hard to tell whether the noun refers to an object’s intrinsic part or an external area. As predicted, both Source-based and Goal-based access paths are attested in such examples (Nikitina 2011).
See Nikitina (2011) for details and further examples; note, however, that my present analysis differs from the previous one: it has been considerably simplified.

For further discussion of the loss of ablative-locative “syncretism” in the development from Old High German to Contemporary Standard German, as well as for evidence from Faroese and Icelandic, see MacKenzie (1978). Eckhoff et al. (2013) suggest that Gothic translations from Greek tend to follow the original more closely than Latin and Old Church Slavonic in the use of Source-based projections; I cannot pursue this question further in this paper.

The expression is allative, because the combination of the preposition v ‘in’ can only combine with the noun phrase in the accusative on the meaning of Goal of motion (static locations are described by a combination of the same preposition and a noun phrase in the prepositional case).

I do not consider here comparative expressions such as južnee ‘further to the south’ (literally, more on the south’), just as I do not treat comparative expressions with ‘left’ and ‘right’, such as leveje ‘further to the left’ (literally, ‘more on the left’).

The tendency to avoid Goal-based access paths with adjectives referring to cardinal directions may also be due to blocking: the expression v severnom (zapadnom, etc.) napravlenii ‘in the northern (western, etc.) direction’ is preferred over expressions with storona ‘side’ in descriptions involving such adjectives.

There may be an additional syntactic reason for the prominence of static prepositions with ablative, as opposed to allative, etymology. Prepositions have an argument, and commonly develop from combinations of a noun and its argument, such as combinations of nouns referring to intrinsic parts and their genitive arguments. In expressions based on access paths, intrinsic parts of a reference object are commonly described as the path’s starting point, predicting that prepositions should be more likely to derive from object part terms in ablative constructions.

Symptomatically, the ablative etymology is often attested with the relatively infrequent terms for ‘inside’ or ‘above’, but rarely with the very frequent terms for ‘in’ or ‘on’, cf. Russian iznutri ‘inside’ or sverxu ‘on top’ (both of ablative origin) vs. v ‘in’ and na ‘on’ (no trace of ablative origin is visible).
The latter is possibly the only surviving type of Source-based expression in present-day English.

In Russian, access paths are also used to encode static locations with combinations of the noun storona ‘side’ and modifying adjectives, such as etot ‘this’, tot ‘that’, drugoj ‘other’, protivopoložnyj ‘opposite’, obratnyj ‘reverse’, and some others. As predicted, expressions referring to intrinsic parts of the object, such as those involving the adjectives vnutrennij ‘internal’, vnešnij ‘external’, and the like, only appear with Source-based access paths (s vnutrennej storony ‘on [=from] the internal side’); ambiguous expressions may allow for allative marking if they refer to external areas.
His discussion of Fijian and Sonsorol-Tobi is only cursory and is open to alternative interpretations.
