title-group.title: How should a “classical” Satellite-Framed Language behave?
title-group.subtitle: Path encoding asymmetries in Ancient Greek and Latin
title-group.alt-title: How should a “classical” Satellite-Framed Language behave?

abstract.p: This paper discusses the encoding of motion events in a corpus of Ancient Greek and Latin texts, focusing on the differences in the expression of Sources and Goals in the two languages (both classified as Satellite-Framed in Talmy’s typology). For this analysis, we have adopted a number of parameters suitable for the investigation of Source and Goal encoding in Path expressions. The corpus has been manually tagged with the help of a software tool dedicated to motion event annotation (Modeg). The results of the analysis confirm the widespread tendency to express Goal more frequently and in a more detailed way compared to Source, and reveal subtle differences in the way in which Ancient Greek and Latin combine prepositional marking with directional preverbs. We argue that the common tendency to express simple Paths (mostly Goal-oriented) can be interpreted from a diachronic perspective as one of the main factors enhancing the diachronic change of both languages towards the preference for the Verb-Framed type of encoding.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to its conceptual and structural prominence, Path is a key notion in motion event representation. Therefore, it is regarded as an extremely relevant factor in linguistic typological classification. As a matter of fact, there is general agreement among scholars on distinguishing between two macrotypes based on the morphosyntactic means involved in Path expression. Talmy’s (2000) typology of lexicalization patterns is based on whether Path is expressed within a verb root (Verb-Framed type) or a satellite (Satellite-Framed type). Similarly, a number of scholars (cf., among others, Matsumoto 2003; Slobin 2008; Beavers et al. 2010; Croft et al. 2010) have proposed new versions of Talmy’s typology keeping the main focus on Path encoding (in vs. outside the main verb), cf. the recent review article by Filipović & Ibarretxe-Antuñano (2015).

As far back as Talmy’s (1985) systematization of motion events encoding, Path cannot be considered a monolithic notion. A number of studies have proven its articulated nature (cf. Talmy 2000: 53–57) and, more recently, have pointed out how Path-related information is rarely encoded within one single syntactic locus, thus allowing for a number of coexisting different encoding strategies (cf. Fortis & Vittrant 2011). The possibility for a language to encode Path subcomponents according to several strategies, however, does not necessarily imply that all of them are equally and simultaneously used in motion events constructions.

The present study will precisely deal with the overt linguistic encoding and distribution of the Path component within the sentence, as well as with the role of contextual and co-textual inference (cf. Iacobini & Vergaro 2014), particularly focusing on the asymmetries in the encoding of Source and Goal in a corpus of Ancient Greek (henceforth AG) and Latin texts.

The results of our corpus-based analysis, scanned with the help of the methodological tools discussed in Section 2, on the one hand, reveal some differences between the two languages; on the other hand, they confirm the widespread tendency shown by a number of languages to express Goal more frequently and in a more detailed way compared to Source (cf. Kopecka & Ishibashi 2011).

We have also noticed that the favored expression of Goal rather than Source affects the degree of Path articulation. Although in AG preverbs and prepositions can refer to different portions of Path, in Latin, preverbs tend to semantically coincide with prepositions, simply reinforcing their directional meaning. However, the two languages show a common tendency towards the encoding of no more than one Ground within a clause.

This tendency seems to be in disagreement with the conventional motion events classification. As a matter of fact, the availability of a wide set of lexical and syntactic strategies devoted to Path encoding, typical of Satellite-Framed languages, is often correlated with a high degree of Path granularity (i.e., a frequent and detailed expression of Path), cf. Slobin (1996), Ibarretxe-Antuñano (2009). However, the corpus-based study presented in this paper shows that the two classical languages do not meet the degree of Path articulation expected in Satellite-Framed (henceforth SF) languages, preferring, rather, to express simple Goal-oriented Path, which is a typical feature of Verb-Framed (henceforth VF) encoding patterns.

The scarce frequency of the linguistic expression of both Source and Goal within the same clause, combined with the tendency to encode a single Ground, can be interpreted as a triggering factor for the typological change from SF to VF encoding strategies. The diachronic change displayed in the preferred way of encoding motion in both Modern Greek (cf. Skopeteas 2008) and the great majority of Romance varieties (cf. Iacobini & Fagard 2011) – all belonging to the VF type – can be considered as a piece of evidence supporting this assumption.

Following this brief introduction, our study will unfold in four more sections. In Section 2, we present our corpus and describe the above mentioned data-analysis methodology. In Section 3, we discuss our results concerning Source–Goal asymmetry in the light of semantic, syntactic and quantitative criteria. In Section 4, we argue that a low degree of Path complexity in the actual linguistic use (as the one displayed by the two classical languages at issue) may represent a major factor in the typological change from SF towards VF constructions. Conclusions are drawn in Section 5.

sec.title: Corpus and methodology
sec.p: The investigation of the asymmetry in the expression of Source and Goal in AG and Latin has been supported by corpus-based data analysis of sentences from contexts expressing a translational motion (henceforth contexts), collected through a systematic scrutiny of four literary texts (two in prose and two in verse), which date back to the classical period of both languages: Book 1 of Herodotus’ Histories (5th century BC) and Euripides’ Bacchae (5th century BC) for AG; Caesar’s Gallic Wars (1st century BC) and Ovid’s Metamorphoses (1st century AD) for Latin.

In order to grant representativity to both languages, we have randomly selected 200 translational motion contexts from the prose texts (Herodotus’ Histories and Caesar’s Gallic Wars) and 100 from texts in verses (Euripides’ Bacchae and Ovid’s Metamorphoses) for each of the two languages. The prevalence of contexts from prose texts is justified by the metrical conditioning undergone by texts in verses, which, in some cases, makes these latter less representative of the actual linguistic use, bearing in mind that the notion of representativity has to be dealt with cautiously when tackling highly standardized closed-corpora languages such as AG and Latin. Poetry has thus been used as a ‘control genre’ in order to better account for phenomena which can be represented more elaborately than in prose texts, such as lexical richness in Manner expression.

Each context has been manually annotated according to an analysis grid for motion events named Modeg (an acronym for MOtion DEcoding Grid; cf. Iacobini et al. n.d.), a new methodological tool, developed in order to grant both intra- and cross-linguistic data comparability through the indexation and retrieval of combined morphosyntactic and semantic information.

The main reference framework for Modeg is the construction typology proposed by Fortis and Vittrant (2011, 2016). In line with this latter model, Modeg identifies four main loci for Path encoding, which correspond to two grammatical categories (verb and noun) and two functional categories (adverbal and adnominal). With respect to the grammatical categories, Modeg allows to distinguish and notate, for both verbs and nouns, a number of semantic subcategories. More precisely, verbal items are subdivided according to the following semantic subcategories: basic-motion verbs (‘to move’), manner verbs (‘to crawl’), caused-motion verbs (‘to push’), non-motion verbs used in Path-expressing contexts (cf. ‘to be on the way to home’), path verbs (further classified into Source, Median or Goal oriented, e.g. ‘to exit’, ‘to transit’, ‘to arrive’) and deictic verbs (‘to come’).

Nominal items, instead, are grouped into three classes: light-verb constructions (‘to have a walk’, ‘to set sail’), idiomatic expressions (‘to hit the road’, ‘to take a hike’) and action nouns ( ‘descent’, ‘movement’).

Besides the above described categories, which mainly refer to Path articulation, Modeg also takes into account other relevant parameters for motion events analysis, namely manner expressions outside the verb root (we distinguish two kinds of elements expressing Manner: non-finite verbal adjuncts – converbs, mainly – and non-verbal adjuncts, i.e., nominal adjuncts or adverbs) and the encoding of associated Path subcomponents. The associated Path subcomponents taken into account are Boundary Crossing, Spatial Orientation and Deictic Anchoring; since their encoding can be distributed among different linguistic elements, the presence in the sentence of any of these components is signaled by means of a yes/no value. Modeg allowed us to distinguish two types of Path granularity, which we propose to name Path Complexity and Path Conceptualization. The difference between these two notions, often overlapped in studies on such issues, will be further described in Section 3.

sec.title: Path asymmetry meets Path complexity
sec.p: Path asymmetry is a broad concept. The breadth of this concept is partly determined by the intrinsic complexity of the notion of Path. Thus, before describing the asymmetry in the linguistic expression of Path as well as the parameters adopted for its investigation, it is necessary to provide a brief introduction on what we understand as Path.

The most widely adopted definition for Path in the studies of motion event encoding is provided by Leonard Talmy (2000). This conceptual systematization is preceded and followed by a number of works (cf. Talmy 1972, 1985, 1991, 2005 – among the most influential ones), which represent the consequential steps of progressively refined typological research. The most crucial point in Talmy’s model is the idea that Path is not a primitive concept but a complex notion, articulated in three core components. In this work, we follow the definition provided by Grinevald (2011), where the Talmian notion is refined and replaced by a concentric multi-level definition of Path. Following Grinevald (2011: 55), we assume that the core notion of Path identifies “a vector, consisting of a line in space that is continuous, delimited by two points and oriented between those points”. This continuous line is conceived in relation to several Grounds, which delimit a vector at both ends with endpoints, named Source and Goal, and allow for points in between, called Median.

Grounds can be represented by non-dimensional points, or by bi- or three-dimensional entities which can be bounded or not; when a Figure moves in or out of a bounded Ground, the encoding of Path requires specific linguistic means (e.g. path verbs, telic particles).

The second level of Path description deals with notions concerning the nature of Ground (Boundary Crossing), Manner and Posture of the moving Figure. At the exterior layer (third level), we find some conceptual domains regarding the viewpoint of narrator (Deictic Anchoring), as well as the coordinate system that languages adopt to identify the location of an object (Spatial Orientation or Frame of Reference).1
Following this line of reasoning, we consider it appropriate to distinguish Path encoding according to two general principles: Path conceptualization and Path complexity.

Path conceptualization can be defined as the degree of Path specification in terms of the expression of its subcomponents (i.e., Manner, Posture, Deictic Anchoring, Spatial Orientation). Languages which tend to encode only one conceptual subcomponent of Path present a low degree of Path conceptualization. On the other hand, languages which tend to express more than one Path-subcomponent simultaneously present a high degree of Path conceptualization, also favoring the expression of complex Paths.

Path complexity, on the other hand, is found when a vector oriented with respect to more than one Ground (i.e., Source, Median, Goal) is encoded within the same clause. Such a definition corresponds to Slobin’s notion of plus-ground verbs, that is verbs accompanied by “one or more prepositional encoding source and/or goal” (Slobin 1996: 201) and opposed to minus-ground verbs, “bare verbs or verbs with satellites indicating direction or movement” (Slobin 1996: 201).

Thus, the expression of a motion event presents a simple Path only when just one of the three possible Grounds (Source, Median, Goal) is encoded, whereas it presents a complex Path when more than one Ground is encoded within the same clause.

Motion events notation via Modeg, which was initially designed precisely to assess Path Complexity, allows to specify the main loci involved in Path encoding together with the number and nature of the Ground(s) expressed. This labeling system grants an easy retrieval of information on Path asymmetry in Source and Goal encoding.

The study of Source–Goal asymmetry has its turning point in the works by Jones (1983) for French and Ikegami (1987) for Japanese, which gave rise to a rich tradition of studies on the subject, analyzed both from a cognitive and psychological perspective, and from a strictly linguistic point of view (see, among others, Nam 2004; Kopecka & Ishibashi 2011; Ishibashi 2012). According to these studies, “not all motion PATHs are born equal” (cf. Papafragou 2010: 2): in particular, it seems that the final section of Path (Goal) receives preferential attention compared to Source in both language expression (also during the acquisition phase) and non-linguistic representation (cf. Regier & Zheng 2007: 705–706, who claim that, in the perception of moving Figures, “endpoints do seem to be privileged in some way”).

On the basis of such contributions, we have identified a number of useful parameters to assess the encoding of Path endpoints. From a syntactic point of view, we have focused on the preferential locus of encoding (i.e., adverbal vs. adnominal) for each portion of Path and its frequency in the corpus (cf. Section 3.1). As far as semantics is concerned, we have dealt with two criteria: the semantic granularity of Source and Goal markers (cf. Section 3.2) and the cooptation of locative expressions for the encoding of Goal and Source (cf. Section 3.3).

sec.title: The main loci of Source and Goal encoding and their frequency in Ancient Greek and Latin
sec.p: As discussed in Section 2, Modeg allows to easily identify the main loci involved in Path encoding as well as the Ground(s) expressed in each of them. Furthermore, the counting function performed by Modeg is particularly useful for the study of the frequency of the Path construction types shown by the two languages, when expressing the two Grounds (Source and Goal).

As for the morphosyntactic status of particles encoding Goal or Source, we have observed that the two classical languages display different behaviors. For a comparative analysis, see the data reported in Table 1. The columns of the chart reporting on numeric data are subdivided into three parts. On the left, we have gathered motion events showing Complex Path encoding. Contexts are subdivided according to the two functional categories (adn for adnominal and sat for satellite) through which Source (S) ad Goal (G) are encoded. In the central column, we have reported Simple Paths differentiated in Source- Median- and Goal-oriented. On the right, we have collected motion events showing no overt Path encoding.

caption.title: General overview of Source and Goal encoding in AG and Latin

sec.p: AG data reveals a slight preference towards the encoding of simple Paths (57% of cases, 171 out of 300). However, complex Paths are far to represent an exception within the corpus. While Goal markers are preferentially expressed in the adnominal locus, Source markers mostly occur as preverbs. This results in a slight prevalence within the Greek corpus of the constructions such as that in (1), in which a generic motion verb, free from any directional interpretation, is preceded by a preverb expressing the Source and followed by a prepositional phrase expressing the endpoint of motion (Goal). It is worth stressing that here the Source information is not recoverable from the previous linguistic material.

list-item.p: ‘(He) returned to Sardis.’ (Hdt.1.22.2)

sec.p: The same pattern applies to Manner verbs as well: since most of them do not bear any intrinsic Path indication, as is shown in (2), their combinatory potential is higher than that of Path roots, which mostly combine with semantically consistent satellites and adnominals.

list-item.p: ‘So the crew sailed away to Corinth.’ (Hdt.1.24.6a)

sec.p: Despite the high frequency of the pattern described so far, the AG data shows some contexts in which both Source and Goal are encoded by means of adnominals (7% of cases, 21 out of 300), as in the following example.

list-item.p: ‘And when she moves from the chair to the bed…’ (Hdt.1.9.3a)

sec.p: As for simple Path, the option that AG largely prefers (31% of the cases, 91 out of 300) is the construction in which the final portion of Path alone is encoded. Such a construction is exemplified in (4) and (5), where Goal is respectively encoded in the satellite and in the adnominal.

list-item.p: ‘after I have entered’ (Hdt.1.9.2b)
‘going into the house’ (Eur.Ba.843)

sec.p: Like AG, Latin also presents some instances of simultaneous expression of Source and Goal within the same sentence, as shown in Table 1. This type of construction is attested in slightly more than 10% of the contexts (31 out of 300). Nevertheless, it is not possible to observe an evident tendency to Goal encoding in the adnominal locus with Source backgrounded in the adverbal locus. The rare encoding of a Complex Path is mostly carried out by constructions in which a prefixed verb is reinforced by an adnominal phrase expressing the Ground, whose preposition lexicalizes the same directional component as the preverb. The verb can also govern an additional prepositional phrase referring to a different Ground from the one encoded by the preverb, as in the Example in (6).

list-item.p: ‘They flew (threw) upon the foragers suddenly from all parts.’ (Caes.Gal.V.17.3)

sec.p: This pattern of Complex Path expression occurs especially in Caesars’ De bello gallico.

The most frequent construction type of motion events in the Latin corpus (i.e., 78,5%, 236 out of 300) shows Simple Path encoding. Latin exhibits a certain degree of what is called semantic congruence (cf. Borillo 1998) between the portion of Path encoded in the verbal locus and the one encoded in the adnominal locus. In other terms, preverbs and prepositions in the same clause generally encode the same portion of Path, as shown for the Goal expression in (7) and for the Source expression, either lexically coinciding in (8) or differing in (9).

list-item.p: ‘(She) moves her mouth towards his mouth.’ (Ov.Met.XII.424–5)
‘(The enemies) drew up their forces which they had brought out of the camp.’ (Caes.Gal.II.8.5)
‘They go forth from their territories.’ (Caes.Gal.I.2.1)

sec.p: Latin data also shows a remarkable preference for Goal-oriented Paths: 20% of simple Source-oriented Path (65 out of 300, 22 in Ovid and 43 in Caesar), 4,5% of Median-oriented Path (13 out of 300), and 54% of Goal-oriented Path (158 out of 300, 54 occurrences in Ovid, 104 in Caesar). Among the motion events extracted from Caesar, constructions such as the one in (10), in which a Goal-oriented verb (such as venio ‘come’ or contendo ‘proceed’) combines with a prepositional phrase encoding the Ground, proved very frequent.

list-item.p: ‘(He) proceeds into Further Gaul.’ (Caes.Gal.I.7.2)

sec.p: The remaining 11% (33 out of 300) of the motion events descriptions analyzed exhibits neither Source nor Goal encoding.

Summing up our crosslinguistic results in light of what has been claimed so far, we observe that both languages tend to encode motion events with plus-ground verbs, defined by Slobin (1996) as verbs denoting motion accompanied by both a satellite encoding a directional meaning, and by a Ground noun(s) expressing Source and/or Goal. Our analysis allowed us to point out that the main difference between the two languages concerns the degree of Path elaboration of the plus-ground construction. When in AG one finds within the same clause both a Source and a Goal expression, these two portions of Path tend to be encoded in two different loci: the Source in the preverb and the Goal in the adnominal locus. Thus, the Goal is more lexically characterized, due to its expression through a noun representing the Ground itself. The Source, instead, encoded by a verb satellite, behaves just as a directional component.

In Latin, the most frequent strategy for Path expression is the encoding of the same portion of Path in both preverbs and prepositions belonging to the same clause. Markers expressing the same directional component may differ from a lexical point of view (cf. the Example in 9).

sec.title: Semantic granularity of Source and Goal markers
sec.p: Among the possible linguistic realizations of the Source–Goal asymmetry, languages seem to make finer distinctions within Goal rather than Source spatial semantic fields (cf., among others, Regier & Zheng 2007; Papafragou 2010). In other words, crosslinguistic evidence shows that configurations at endpoints of motion are better discriminated (through a higher number of available linguistic elements) compared to configurations at starting points. In this Section, we will briefly describe the AG and Latin inventories of Goal and Source markers as they occur in our corpus, in order to investigate the behavior of the two languages with respect to this parameter.

Among the AG Goal satellites, eis ‘towards’ is the most generic and productively employed (cf. Brucale 2014: 306). Its semantics does not entail any final contact, nor a relation of containment between the Figure and the Ground. Rather, the particle simply encodes motion towards a Ground, and does not necessarily imply that the interior is eventually reached (cf. Luraghi 2003: 108). In (11) the Ground element is represented by the folds of the mountain Kithairon which, by virtue of their physical properties, cannot be crossed.

list-item.p: ‘going to the folds of Kithairon’ (Eur.Ba.62)

sec.p: Conversely, the Boundary Crossing in the final portion of Path seems to be marked by the distribution of the Goal information between the adverbal slot and the adnominal slot, as in (12).

list-item.p: ‘No sooner the Lydians had entered the hall.’ (Hdt.1.47.2)

sec.p: The second AG Goal satellite by frequency in our corpus, epí ‘upon, against’, selects the accusative case. The use of this preposition suggests that the Figure reaches a higher position with respect to the Ground. This is the reason why, as a preposition, epí tends to occur with the nouns for rivers and seas, as in (13).

list-item.p: ‘These came to our seas from the Red sea.’ (Hdt.1.1.1a)

sec.p: As a preverb, prós ‘in the direction of’ attaches to both Basic Motion roots (such as érkhōmai ‘go, come’) and Manner roots (such as réō ‘flow’). In its prepositional use with the accusative case, it expresses Goal attainment, and sometimes even the Figure’s final contact with a surface, as in (14), in which the preposition governs the dative case stressing the result of motion.

list-item.p: ‘Have you fallen on the ground?’ (Eur.Ba.603)

sec.p: The third most frequent Goal marker in our corpus-based analysis of AG is pará ‘to the side of’, which by and large occurs with the accusative case to express the allative relation with human Grounds. When selecting the genitive case, the preposition encodes the Source of motion. Example (15) shows the difference between eis combined with toponyms and pará governing nouns with human referents.

list-item.p: ‘Solon went to Amasis in Egypt and then to Croesus in Sardis.’ (Hdt.1.30.1a)

sec.p: As for the Source markers occurring in our corpus, we have only found two dedicated morphosyntactic items for the expression of the initial portion of Path (the previously mentioned pará plus genitive is not attested in the texts that we analyzed). This is in line with the expected “overgeneralization of separation words that refer to FROM paths” Papafragou (2010: 1065): in Classical authors, ek ‘out of’ and apó ‘away from’, previously distinct on the basis of the elative value of the former and the ablative nuance of the latter, display a wide overlap and are on their way to merge. As a result of what Luraghi (2003: 315) calls the “weakening of the Container Metaphor”, the preposition ek can occur with nouns denoting entities which cannot be crossed, such as a mountain in (16).

list-item.p: ‘who would come off that mountain’ (Hdt.1.36.1a)

sec.p: In (17) apó shows an analogous use and appears both as a preverb and as a preposition within the same clause.

list-item.p: ‘They leaped from their horses.’ (Hdt.1.80.6a)

sec.p: In Latin, the notion of Source can be further articulated into three subcomponents, depending on the initial position of the Figure with reference to the Ground. In this respect, the Figure can either be contained within the Ground, stand in a relation of contact with the Ground, or be in generic proximity with respect to the Ground. The spatial meanings of such relations are respectively named elative, delative and ablative, from the Latin prepositions and homonymous preverbs ex, de and ab, which govern the ablative case.

In our analysis, ex, de and ab do not occur in functional opposition, neither as satellites nor in the adnominal locus (for similar results, cf. García-Jurado 1991; Luraghi 2010; Brucale & Mocciaro 2015). In the adnominal locus, we can observe for Latin data the same “weakening of the container metaphor” highlighted for AG.
Boundary Crossing at the starting point of the motion event can be encoded in the adnominal locus not only by the expected preposition ex but also by ab and de, as the examples in (18)–(19) show.

list-item.p: ‘Lethe’s stream flows out of the deep stone.’ (Ov.Met.XI.602–3)
‘From the inner part a scorpion will exit.’ (Ov.Met.XV.370)

sec.p: In (18), the verb eo ‘go’ is modified by the preverb ex- with elative meaning, which contributes to defining the spatial semantics of this motion event. The same prefixed verb is shown in (19), in the reference edition for this work, contained in the Packard Humanities Institute 5 (PHI5) corpus. In other editions, however, the main verb in this context is exhibit from exhibeo ‘exhibit, appear’, a formation originally derived from ex- and the verb habeo ‘to have’, in which the preverb does not show a clear elative meaning (and even the morphotactic compositionality is not fully transparent).

The functional overlap between the different prepositions encoding Source is also attested by the use of ex to express the departure from a place which cannot be conceived as a container, as in (20). In this context, taken from Caesar’s prose, the soldiers – from a pile of corps as from an hill (tumulus) – cast their weapons against the enemies.

list-item.p: ‘As from a mound, they threw darts against our soldiers.’ (Caes.Gal.II.27.4)

sec.p: Goal encoding in Latin is lexicalized mainly by the prepositions in ‘in(to)’ or ad ‘to’ with the accusative case. Their distribution is governed by the Boundary Crossing parameter. As noticed by Luraghi (2011: 212–213), the preposition in indicates not only that a portion of the Ground coincides with a portion of the space occupied by the Figure, but also that the Ground is conceived of as a container. The preposition ad is used when there is no final coincidence between the Figure and the Ground. The distribution of these two prepositions is clearly not determined by the semantic features of the Ground noun alone; this semantic distinction is particularly evident if we consider motion events in which the same Ground type is expressed with a Figure performing Boundary Crossing as opposed to a Figure stopping at the borders of the Ground.
For example, regions or cities are normally conceived as container-Grounds for the Figure, so nouns referring to such Grounds are considered bounded and governed by in, as shown in Example (21).

list-item.p: ‘(They) fled into Britain.’ (Caes.Gal.II.27.4)

sec.p: However, when a Figure moves towards a region or a city stopping at their borders, the relation is expressed by ad, as in (22) and (23).

list-item.p: ‘(He) arrives at Geneva.’ (Caes.Gal.II.27.4)
‘Britain was reached with the whole fleet.’ (Caes.Gal.V.8.5)

sec.p: In (23), the Goal prepositional phrase introduced by ad is required by the verb accedo ‘reach’, an almost opaque prefixed verb derived from a combination of ad- and cēdo ‘move, proceed’.2

The different distribution of in ‘in(to)’ and ad ‘to’ can also be observed in Caesar’s prose with respect to Ground nouns, such as castra ‘camp’ or finis ‘boundary’. In is used when the Figure performs a Boundary Crossing movement entailing an actual entrance, as in (24), while ad is used to describe a generic arrival with a stop at the borders, as in (25).3

list-item.p: ‘He led his army into the territories of the Sotiates’ (Caes.Gal.III.20.3)
‘(He writes) to arrive with his legion to the frontiers of the Nervii.’ (Caes.Gal.V.46.4)

sec.title: Cooptation of locative expressions for the encoding of Goal and Source
sec.p: The second parameter on which we have evaluated the Source–Goal asymmetry in AG and Latin is the possible cooptation of Location terms for the encoding of Source and Goal (cf. Levinson 2006; Nam 2004; Papafragou 2010).

As in several other languages, in AG and Latin, locative markers can be employed for Goal expression, while the same does not hold true for Sources. Despite the gradual change in the dominant strategy for the encoding of motion, leading to the employment of motion verbs together with specialized directional preposition + case combinations in Classical Greek (cf. Nikitina 2013: 188 ff.), some traces of the Homeric pattern, namely the constructio praegnans recently analyzed in Nikitina & Maslov (2013) and Brucale (2014) are still present in our corpus. As stated by Nikitina & Maslov (2013: 3), this term refers to

disp-quote.p: constructions with two different types of mismatch between form and meaning (…). In one, a goal of motion is encoded by a prepositional phrase that normally describes static locations, and the idea of motion is inferred from the verb (…). In the other type of constructio praegnans, a prepositional phrase that is normally used to encode spatial goals appears, unexpectedly, with a verb that does not seem to describe any motion.

sec.p: Both the AG Examples in (26) and in (27), in which the locative particle en ‘in’ occurs with a motion verb implying a displacement of the Figure, are instantiations of the first pattern.

list-item.p: ‘They plotted to cast Arion overboard.’ (Hdt.1.24.2)
‘In order not to fall onto his son…’ (Hdt.1.34.3)

sec.p: In Latin, Location is generally encoded by means of prepositional phrases in which the preposition in selects the ablative case. Our corpus shows a number of contexts in which prepositional phrases with locative meaning can be coopted for the encoding of Goal. Nevertheless, as shown by Examples (28)–(29), this strategy is typically used with verb roots encoding change of configuration (consisto ‘place one's self anywhere’, constituo ‘set’, submitto ‘put down’), which are generally combined either with Goal markers or with markers expressing Location.

list-item.p: ‘He laid his tired head on the green grass.’ (Ov.Met.III.502)
‘From the dome of heaven she glided down and stood upon the earth.’ (Ov.Met.I.608–9)
‘(He) set the legion in the lower place.’ (Caes.Gal.VII.45.5)

sec.p: The latter example, taken from Caesar’s prose, turns out to be particularly interesting in the study of the possible cooptation of Location markers to express Goal. In the main handbooks of Latin, such as Hofmann & Szantyr (1965), it is claimed that the locative meaning for plain ablative in Latin is limited to some toponyms, such as names of cities and small islands, belonging to the inflectional classes of -ā- or -o- stems. The same use can also be found with a few nouns of prototypical Grounds, such as pars ‘part, side’ and regio ‘region, area’. As pointed out by Palmer (1954), there are also Old Latin examples of bare ablative with locative meaning for the noun locus ‘place, ground’, as in Pl.Am.568 tempore uno homo idem duobus locis ‘the same man in two places together at the same time’.4
In our corpus, beside the example from Caesar in (30), there is another example of loco with allative meaning, taken from Ovid’s Metamorphoses.

list-item.p: ‘The shade arrives to that place.’ (Ov.Met.X.90)

sec.p: In this context, loco can also be interpreted as a case of Goal encoding in plain dative, a rare and poetic use generally quoted in Latin handbooks with a reference example taken from Verg.Aen.V.451, it clamor caelo ‘the noise goes towards the sky’. In the comment to Virgil’s oeuvre composed by Maurus Servius Honoratus (IV–V BC) (in the PHI5 edition), a few other contexts with Goal encoding in dative are pointed out, such as the following: haedorumque gregem uiridi compellere hibisco (Verg.Ecl.II.30), in which the goats are ‘pushed to the green hibiscus’ (for weaning); [f]it strepitus tectis (Verg.Aen.I.725–6) ‘the scream rises toward the roofs’; inferretque deos Latio (Verg.Aen.I.5–6) ‘he brought his gods to Latium’; facilis descensus Auerno ‘the descent to Avernus (hell) is easy’.5 This use of the plain dative in Latin, following Palmer (1954) among others, could derive from the extension of the dative commodi with transitive trivalent verbs such as dare ‘to give’ and mittere ‘to send’ (caused motion verbs) or idioms such as manus tendere (in Cicero) or palmas tendere (in Virgil) ‘to land hands’. Such cases require the expression of the beneficiary in the dative case, which can also be interpreted as a Goal if the event is of dislocational nature. “This syntactical possibility once established in Latin, it was stimulated by the freer Greek use of such final local datives”, see Palmer (1954: 298).

Nevertheless, it is worth noting that in all the quoted examples a complete syncretism between the dative and the ablative forms occurs, which makes it difficult to identify the nature of the Goal encoding case. Further philological studies on scholia, as well as wider corpus-based research aiming at identifying the encoding strategies of allative and locative meanings of nouns with non-homonym dative and ablative, will help clarify the issue.

sec.title: Possible development lines towards the Verb-Framed type
sec.p: In this Section, we will discuss some of the features of the ancient languages under analysis, which seem to have paved the way for the typological shift towards the Verb-Framed type that occurred in Modern Greek as well as in most of the Romance varieties.

First of all, both AG and Latin exhibit a fair inventory of inherently directional verbs: see, for instance, Goal-oriented roots such as AG hékō, hiknéomai, ‘arrive, reach’, Latin intro ‘to enter’, and Source-oriented roots such as Gr. oíkhomai, khōréō ‘to leave, to go away from’, Latin linquo ‘to leave’, surgo ‘to rise, to get up’.

Secondly, on the basis of their preference for simple Paths, both AG and Latin can be classified as medium-low-Path-salient languages (cf. Ibarretxe-Antuñano 2009). As previously stated, in fact, both languages prefer to encode one portion of Path at a time in the adnominal slot. In other words, though possible (especially in AG), it is quite rare to find more than one prepositional phrase encoding different Path segments within the same clause. However, as for the relationship between the adnominal and the adverbal locus, the two languages show a slight intra-typological variation since, while AG allows semantic divergence between the preverb – often encoding the Source of motion – and the preposition – mostly assigned to the expression of Goal, Latin requires a partial or even total coincidence between the two items.

Despite this difference, both AG and Latin seem to dislike elaborated trajectories. We argue that such a shared feature could represent one of the main factors driving the typological change from Satellite-Framing towards Verb-Framing strategies. As a matter of fact, both the daughter languages, namely Modern Greek and most of Romance varieties, belong to the VF type.

As stated by Selimis and Katis (2010), Modern “Greek has been characterized as a Path language on the basis of both theoretical description and empirical evidence on speech habits”. Papafragou et al. (2002; 2006) have noted that, in Modern Greek, Path is mostly taken over by inherently directional verbs such as anevénō ‘ascend’, katevénō ‘descend’, bénō ‘enter’ and vjénō ‘exit’.

Comparing the two synchronic stages of the Greek language, namely the original texts of our corpus (cf. (32)) and their translations into Modern Greek (cf. (32)), one can notice that the original satellite-plus-verb combinations are commonly replaced by inherently directional roots, such as bénō in (32).6

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘No sooner had the Lydians entered the hall.’ (Hdt.1.47.2)

sec.p: As for Greek satellites, on the other hand, they undergo a process of univerbation, by which they tend to be dropped or lexicalized over time, toward the VF strategy of Modern Greek (cf. Imbert 2010).

The same process underlined for Greek takes place in the passage from Latin to Romance languages, as recently shown by Iacobini and Fagard (2011), Corona (2015) and Stolova (2015). We limit ourselves to mentioning an example (taken from Corona 2015: 290) of a fourteenth century Italian vulgarization of the Latin text (Le metamorfosi d'Ovidio volgarizzate da ser Arrigo Simintendi da Prato), in which the Path – originally expressed by a Latin prefixed verb, cf. (33) – is encoded within the verb root by an adverb-derived verb such as attorneare ‘to surround’ from attorno ‘around’, cf. (33).

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘He put the ropes around (her) underserving neck.’ (Ov.Met.I.630)

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The results of our corpus-based analysis have shown that both AG and Latin prefer to foreground only one among the different portions of Path. The preferred portion, in line with the tendency toward asymmetric encoding, is Goal.

The parameters that we have resorted to have allowed us to somehow assess the extent to which such a tendency occurs in the two languages under analysis, as well as to identify a degree of variation with reference to the typological expectations usually applied to SF languages.
As our study has pointed out, the most exploited strategy to highlight a Path section (i.e., to encode a Ground) involves the expression of the Goal within the adnominal locus.

Both AG and Latin exhibit, at least at the usage level, semantically richer Goal markers and a progressive overlap of Source particles tending to express the same basic ablative nuance (both in AG and in Latin, such a phenomenon neutralizes the higher number of Source markers available at the system level). As for Goal markers, AG resorts to an inventory of (at least) four items for which the Boundary Crossing is not pertinent, while this parameter represents one of the most relevant features distinguishing the two Latin prepositions.

AG and Latin exhibit a similar behavior with respect to the cooptation of locative expressions for the encoding of Goal, but, while AG employs the whole prepositional phrase normally committed to static relations in order to express Goal, Latin can resort both to the locative prepositional phrase (in + ablative) and, more rarely, to plain ablative.

When expressing both Source and Goal within the same clause, AG displays a clear preference for the encoding of the Source in the preverb and the Goal in the adnominal locus. Thus, Goal is more lexically characterized, due to its expression through a noun describing the Ground itself. This kind of asymmetric encoding does not seem to be confirmed in Latin, since, when both Goal and Source are expressed, the same portion of Path expressed in the preverb is also expressed by means of a prepositional phrase.

With respect to AG, Latin seems to dislike complex Paths segmented into the Source and the Goal within the same clause. As far as simple Path is concerned, in both languages Goal-oriented Paths are more frequent than Source-oriented Paths.

Our qualitative and quantitative corpus analysis has allowed us to investigate the link between two features of Path encoding, i.e., the asymmetric expression of the Source and the Goal and the articulation of Path as a whole. Combining these two elements, we have drawn a number of diachronic conclusions. In particular, we claim that the preference for the encoding of simple Paths, together with other factors, could have favored the rise of a verb-centered type of Path encoding (Verb-Framed type). In other words, the tendency to express one Ground element per clause represents an outstanding feature enhancing the typological shift from the SF towards the VF type, which typically avoids the expression of complex Paths.

fn.p: The examples mentioned by Grinevald (2011: 56) are (a) those of European languages, which contrast the absolute orientation of gravity with a horizontal orientation; (b) languages adopting angled orientation systems; (c) orientation according to the absolute reference frame of cardinal points; (d) orientation according to the intrinsic relative reference frame of landscape; (e) and orientation according to a relative reference frame, where the Figure is oriented in relation to the perceiver (mostly human body), a ground-object, and the figure itself (cf. Levinson 2003).

This verb, already attested in Old Latin, can also be construed with in plus accusative, plain accusative or plain dative. Pinkster (2010) discusses the distributional criterion of dative and prepositional phrases with access or approaching verbs (such as accedo and appropinquo). He also reports the assumption according to which, in classical authors (including Caesar), the dative case generally occurs with figurative meanings, whereas prepositional phrases preferentially encode Goal in actual dislocations. Our corpus-analysis confirmed that, in Caesar, the verb actually occurs with the plain accusative and with ad plus accusative in the description of real dislocations, such as in (23). The only context with the plain dative expresses a figurative meaning (quorum adventu et Remis cum spe defensionis studium propugnandi accessit (Caes.I.19.1) ‘by whose arrival both a desire to resist together with the hope of defense, was infused into the Remi’). In Ovid, the verb always governs the dative case. On the other hand, another approaching verb attested in the corpus, i.e., appropinquo, occurs 16 times in De bello gallico, always in the plain dative. This verb shows no occurrences in Ovid, thus confirming Serbat’s (1996: 518–520) idea, claiming that the distribution of the plain dative and of the accusative case governed by prepositions with verbs of approaching varies not only according to the author or attestation date but also according to the lexeme (verbs such as accedo and appropinquo, although exhibiting the same argument structure, preferentially express arguments with different adnominals), cf. also Corona (2015: 217–224).

As noticed in Iacobini & Corona (2016: 80), in Caesar’s De bello gallico, we can find the reverse phenomenon of the “weakening of the Container Metaphor”, which could be called extension or “Strengthening of the Container Metaphor”. In context such as Caes.VI.9.1 postquam ex Menapiis in Treveros venit ‘after he arrived from the Menapii(’s) to the Treveri(’s territories)’, the Source (Menapii) and the Goal (Treveri) are respectively expressed by the prepositions ex and in (instead of the expected ab and ad), implying that populations can be perceived as homogeneous entities in which a Figure can be metaphorically included, hence the use of the ablative and the illative prepositions.

Some nouns belonging to different inflectional classes, such as humus ‘ground, terrain’, rus ‘countryside’ or domus ‘home’, have residual locative forms (humi, ruri and domi) as in the following example taken from Caes.Gal.IV.1.6 illi domi remanent ‘the others remain at home’.

As argued by Servio Mauro, the Ground noun is also reported in other codices in the form Auerni: Serv.A.VI.126.1 FACILIS DICENSUS AVERNI legitur et 'Averno', id est ad Avernum; sed si 'Averni’, inferorum significat (…) ‘it reports FACILIS DISCENSUS AVERNI, or ‘Averno’, that is, ad Avernum; but if it is ‘Averni’, it means ‘of the hells’.

Cf. Slobin (2005) on the validity of translations as a fundamental methodological tool for comparative studies, and Kopecka (2013, this volume) for the comparison of descriptions of motion events in medieval narratives and their translations into Modern French.
