title-group.title: Differential Goal marking vs. differential Source marking in Ancient Greek
title-group.alt-title: Differential Goal marking vs. differential Source marking in Ancient Greek

abstract.p: Differential marking of Goal and Source is a relatively underresearched topic. Available cross-linguistic evidence points toward two possible triggers of differential marking of spatial relations, that is, nouns that denote spatial regions and animate nouns. In this paper, differential Goal and differential Source marking are studied based on the evidence of a diachronic corpus, consisting of the Homeric poems and Herodotus’ Histories. In Homeric Greek, differential marking with nouns that denote spatial regions is available to a marginal extent for Goal, and unavailable for Source, while no differential marking occurs in Herodotus. Animacy conditioned differential marking is well attested both for Goal and for Source in Herodotus, but Homer offers evidence only for differential marking of Source. Apparently, Goal adpositions used for inanimate landmarks are also compatible with animates, while Source adpositions developed at an early stage animacy conditioned meanings that make them unsuitable for indicating simple concrete motion away from a human being.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Differential case marking (henceforth DCM) has been thoroughly investigated especially in the case of grammatical relations, in the first place as a possible feature of direct object encoding. The tradition of studies concerning DOM, or differential object marking, has been especially prominent in Romance linguistics (see e.g. Bossong 1985), and has later extended to numerous other languages. Typologists have shown that DOM is quite frequent cross-linguistically, and that it is most often triggered by features such as definiteness, animacy, and topicality (see Iemmolo 2010; Iemmolo & Klumpp 2014 for an overview). Typological studies on DSM, or differential subject marking (see among others de Hoop & de Swart 2008), have often focused on the same parameters that have emerged as relevant for DOM. However, features typical of DSM are partly different, and may also include degrees of agentivity and volitionality.

As compared to studies on DOM and DSM, other types of DCM, not involving grammatical relations but rather semantic roles, are much less investigated, as remarked by Malchukov (2008). Studies of differential marking of Goal point toward animacy as a relevant parameter (Kittilä 2014), while more in general expectedness is also advocated as a trigger for a markedness opposition of spatial relations (Comrie 1986; Aristar 1997; Stolz et al. 2014). I will discuss these two parameters at length in the course of this paper. My purpose will be to assess the role of possible asymmetries in differential marking of Source and Goal with motion verbs in Ancient Greek, which I will set in the wider framework of differential marking of spatial relations. As the matter has never been thoroughly investigated, I have used a limited corpus, constituted by the Homeric poems and Herodotus’ Histories. In this way, I have been able to give a historical perspective to my investigation, using two sets of texts which are comparable in size (approximately 200,000 and 185,000 words respectively). Note further that the Homeric language, though featuring influence from several dialectal traditions, is basically Ionic and shows very limited Attic influence (see Hackstein 2010 and Tribulato 2010), thus it is closer to the literary Ionic of Herodotus than to the language of other prose writers.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 I discuss DCM. I start by briefly reviewing some cross-linguistic features of DOM and DSM that can also be relevant for other types of DCM, and proceed with a survey of previous studies on other types of DCM, especially concerning spatial relations. As we will see, while some research has been done on differential Goal marking, differential Source marking remains unexplored. In Section 3 I present the Greek data, and discuss the findings in Section 4. Section 5 contains the conclusion.

sec.title: Differential case marking
sec.p: In this section, I briefly discuss current research on differential marking of core arguments, that is, of direct objects and subjects, and on other types of DCM. As DOM and DSM are not the main topic of this paper, I will only highlight some features that can be useful for the discussion of differential marking of spatial relations, as I will argue in the second part of the section.

sec.title: Differential marking of core arguments
sec.p: Studies on DOM have often described differential marking as an opposition between an unmarked and a marked alternative, as in Iemmolo and Klumpp (2014: 271): “Differential object marking is the phenomenon whereby only a subset of direct objects are case marked depending on the semantic and/or pragmatic properties of the object referent.” (See further Malchukov 2008: 205–206 and the literature therein). Examples are Spanish, in which DOM is mainly dependent on animacy (or, better, on humanness), as shown in (1) and (2), and Turkish, in which it is based on specificity, as shown in (3) and (4).

list-item.p: ‘I saw Mario’s sister.’
‘I saw the movie.’
‘At the restaurant I always drink a certain wine.’
‘At the restaurant I always drink wine.’ (from Kornfilt 1997: 276–277)

sec.p: In (1) the preposition a encodes an animate/definite direct object, while the inanimate object in (2) is not marked. Similarly, in (3) an indefinite but specific object is marked by the accusative ending -ɩ , while the indefinite non-specific object in (4) is unmarked.

More recently, discussion on so-called ‘symmetrical’ DOM has highlighted cases in which both alternative encoding strategies are overtly marked, as in Finnish or other languages featuring partitive cases or genitive cases used as partitives (see Luraghi & Huumo 2014). In these languages, direct objects can be marked with the accusative case (often called genitive in Finnish grammatical descriptions) or with the partitive or partitive genitive depending on various parameters connected with boundedness and definiteness. Notably, languages that allow this type of variation for direct objects also allow it for subjects, contrary to more canonical types of DOM described above. Compare Examples (5)–(7) from Finnish.

list-item.p: ‘The soldiers were killing/killed some enemies.’
‘The soldiers killed the enemies.’
‘There were some soldiers killing enemies.’

sec.p: In Example (5), an indefinite object is encoded in the partitive case. Indefiniteness also has the effect of favoring an imperfective interpretation of the verbal aspect. In (6) the accusative case indicates that a definite number of entities has undergone the effects of the verbal action. This also triggers perfective reading of the verb. Example (7) shows that the same type of alternation involving the partitive can also affect subjects. Here, the partitive case indicates that an indefinite subject is introduced in discourse.

Partitive subjects in Finnish have also been discussed under the heading of non-canonical subjects (Sands & Campbell 2001): indeed, there is sometimes some overlap between the notions of non-canonical encoding of subjects or objects and differential marking, as discussed in Haspelmath (2001: 56–57). Non-canonical subjects, that is, subjects that do not conform to the normal coding and/or behavioral properties of subjects in a given language, often indicate participants that are not typical agents, such as, for example, experiencers or inanimate entities. Especially in the case of the latter, unexpectedness in the subject role has often been included among possible reasons for differential encoding (Malchukov 2008). As we will see, unexpectedness also seems to play the most important role in differential marking of spatial relations.

sec.title: Other types of DCM
sec.p: As already remarked, other types of DCM have been less investigated than DOM and DSM.1 In recent years, Kittilä has devoted a number of studies to differential Goal marking (see Kittilä 2008, 2014; Kittilä & Ylikoski 2011), in which animacy turns out to be the most important parameter for this type of DCM. It must be said that, especially with verbs of transfer and caused motion, animacy does not only bring about differential marking, but often results in triggering a different interpretation of semantic roles. With verbs such as ‘send’, an animate participant that represents the endpoint of the transfer is likely to be a Recipient. Indeed, in Kittilä (2008) this issue emerges quite clearly from the beginning, as differential Goal marking is abbreviated with no further specifications DRM (2008: 245). Kittilä later acknowledges the existence of differences between Goal and Recipient, which are however ignored (‘neutralized’ in the author’s words) in the discussion, as both types of participant can be seen as endpoints of a transfer. Thus the difference between the semantic roles encoded in PPs with to in occurrences such as The teacher transferred the book to the student/to the school is backgrounded in this paper (2008: 248). Among various problems, this approach also ignores possible differences between Recipients and human Goals, which can occur with the same verb.

In Kittilä & Ylikoski (2011) instead a distinction is made among Goal, Recipient, and Vicinal Goal. The distinction between Goal and Vicinal Goal is determined by the final position of the moving entity: with Goal, it is implied that there will be partial coincidence of the space occupied by the trajector with the landmark (Cuyckens 1993: 304; Luraghi 2003: 86), with Vicinal Goal this is explicitly ruled out. Clearly, human landmarks in normal situations can only be Vicinal Goals. As noted in Luraghi concerning landmarks of Location,

disp-quote.p: under normal circumstances human beings cannot be conceived as coincident in space with other entities, as more common landmarks of spatial relations do: thus, one can say of a certain trajector that it is located in a typical spatial landmark, such as a geographical location, but not that it is located in a human being, except for special entities (internal body organs, emotions).

sec.p: Similar remarks also hold for landmarks of directional motion: a trajector which moves toward an inanimate landmark often also enters its space, while this is never the case with human landmarks. In fact, in Kittilä and Ylikoski’s (2011) study of the verb ‘send’ in 12 Uralic languages coding distinctions of Goals and Vicinal Goals correspond to animacy based differential Goal marking. This is also due to the corpus used for this research, which is constituted by translations of two sentences from the New Testament that only contain one occurrence of a Vicinal Goal, featuring a human landmark. As a result of his study, Kittilä and Ylikoski found that virtually all languages in his sample show differential marking of Goal and Vicinal Goal. This would not be surprising in the case that Goal and Vicinal Goal in the corpus featured the same landmark (as e.g. in He went into the school/to the vicinity of/ toward the school). However, as they are distinct based on animacy, the finding is an interesting result in connection with differential Goal marking, as it shows that animacy is an important trigger of differential marking, and indicates a strong tendency in Uralic languages for differential encoding in such conditions. Note further that out of 12 languages, nine feature extra-marking when human landmarks occur in Goal expressions, as Vicinal Goal is encoded by cases and postpositions while Goal and Recipient are encoded by bare cases. Thus, while all types of Goal are overtly marked in these languages, human landmarks often require extra marking.

As we have seen, studies of differential Goal marking based on the verb ‘send’ often have to deal with ambiguity concerning whether the human participant must be taken as a Goal or as a Recipient. Motion verbs such as ‘come’ and ‘go’ do not bring about this complication, still they have been much less studied. Kittilä (2014), which discusses Goal marking with different types of landmark, also concentrates on verbs of transfer, such as ‘send’ or ‘put’, and devotes only little space to motion verbs. The same holds for the papers collected in Kopecka and Narasimhan (2012), which discuss events of putting and removing, including coding of Source participants. As the focus of the papers was not on differential marking, limited information is available on the matter. However, there is some negative evidence that Source encoding is less sensitive to animacy than Goal/Recipient encoding, as animacy mostly comes up as a relevant feature in the discussion of Goals/Recipients.

If one sets Goal and Source in the wider framework of spatial relations, especially by including Location, another type of differential encoding has frequently been observed, which concerns toponyms, nouns with spatial reference, and, more in general, all types of noun that are more likely to occur in spatial expressions. Such nouns often require less marking when they indicate some type of spatial relation. Comrie (1986: 3) describes case marking for locative in Armenian, and finds a similar distinction between natural locatives, marked with the locative case or unmarked when they occur in Location expressions, and other types of noun, marked with postpositions; he takes this as a demonstration that “the construction type which is least marked formally is also least marked in terms of properties of the real world” (1986: 2). In the same vein, Aristar (1997) argues that pairings of nouns with semantic roles can be typical or atypical, with atypical pairings often requiring extra marking. Note that, as has also been remarked in Stolz et al. (2014: 52), according to Aristar differential encoding in the case of spatial relations is always instantiated by an opposition between less and more marked. Aristar sees this as a difference between differential marking of core grammatical relations (involving structural case) and differential marking of other constituents (involving semantic case), whereby the former, but not the latter, is instantiated by an opposition between unmarked and marked. In fact, this is not the case, as differential marking of spatial relations often involves zero marking of nouns that are most expected in spatial expressions: this is true of many languages, including Indo-European, such as Armenian (the example discussed in Comrie 1986) and Hittite (on which see Luraghi 1997: 12). Many more examples are available in the thorough cross-linguistic study of zero marking of spatial relations by in Stolz et al. (2014).

That nouns whose semantics is compatible with certain semantic roles need less marking than nouns whose semantics is less compatible has also been pointed out for other semantic roles. Turing back again to DSM, as I have already remarked one of the triggers seems to be the occurrence of a noun that does not refer to a typical Agent as subject. With passive verbs as well inanimate Agents are often encoded in a different way with respect to animate ones (see Luraghi 1986). A mirror phenomenon is animacy based differential marking of Instruments. In Ancient Greek, for example, the semantic role Instrument is normally encoded by the dative case, as in (8) (see also ophthalmoîsin ‘with (my) eyes’ in (13)). However, if a human being is presented as being used by other human beings, extra marking is required, with diá + gen , as in (9) (see Luraghi 1989 and 2003: 177–180).

list-item.p: ‘Rinsing (the intestine) with palm wine and bruised spices.’ (Hdt.2.86.4)
‘(The daughter) whose son he is now killing by means of me.’ (Hdt.1.109.4)

sec.p: Inanimate, concrete entities are highly manipulated, and are likely to be used as instruments by humans. On the other hand, humans can, under circumstances, be manipulated by other human beings, but this is an exceptional situation: more often, they tend to play other, more agent-like roles. For this reason, they trigger a more complex encoding when they occur in Instrument expressions.2

sec.title: Differential marking of spatial relations in Ancient Greek
sec.p: In this section, I review the data from Ancient Greek. As no former studies on DCM are available for spatial relations in Ancient Greek, I limited my study to three motion verbs, baínō, eîmi and érkhomai, which are non-deictic, can be translated into English as both ‘come’ and ‘go’ depending on the context, and do not entail either the Goal or the Source. These are also three very frequent verbs, and occur around 1,700 times in the Homeric poems, with over half of the occurrences featuring a spatial expression. Besides Goal or Source, Path expressions, with PPs such as diá + gen ‘through’, pará + acc ‘along’, katá + acc ‘around, among’ are also frequent with these verbs, coherently with their non-deictic meaning.

I discuss two types of landmarks that, as I have shown in Section 2.2, often trigger DCM cross-linguistically, that is, spatial regions and human beings. Notably, in the case of nouns that denote spatial concepts, differential marking of Goal and Source cannot be investigated without a parallel study of differential marking of Location.

sec.title: Nouns with spatial reference
sec.p: In Homeric Greek, toponyms, nouns with spatial reference such as (the forms given here are dative marked) aithéri ‘in the sky’, oúresin, ‘on the mountains’, agrôi ‘in the field’, dómōi ‘home’, nomôi ‘in the pastures’, póntōi ‘on the sea’, khérsōi ‘on the dry land’, as well as nouns denoting social locations, such as trapézēi ‘at (somebody’s) table’, agorêi ‘at the council’, mákhēi ‘in battle’, polémōi ‘in war’, may occur in Location expressions in the dative, without adpositions, even though adpositional phrases also frequently occur (see Chantraine 1953: 78; Luraghi 2003: 66).3 Compare (10) and (12), which contain the Location expressions Árgei ‘in Argos’, mákhēi ‘in battle’ and agorêi ‘in the assembly’ encoded in the dative, with (11) and (13), in which similar Location expressions ‘in Argos’ and ‘in battle’ are encoded by adpositional phrases with en and its variant éni ‘in’. Notably, in (11)–(13) the constructions do not require a Location expression, so the locative meaning of the dative, though being connected to specific lexemes, is not indicated by the predicate. This indicates that the two types of expression, the bare dative and the dative with a locative adposition, are equivalent. Both are frequent, and constitute possible metrical variants.

list-item.p: ‘He remained there, while my father lived in Argos.’ (Il.14.119)
‘Then, though being in Argos, you shall ply the loom at another’s bidding.’ (Il.6.456)
‘The son that he generated is worse than he in battle, though in the place of gathering he is better.’ (Il.4.400)
‘I have seen him with my eyes, many times in the battle.’ (Il.24.391–392)

sec.p: While adpositionless encoding of Location is comparatively frequent in Homer, the situation is different for Goal and Source. In particular, with non-deictic motion verbs adpositionless Goal expressions in the accusative are very infrequent, as I will show below. Toponyms and nouns which refer to spatial regions may occur without adpositions, but in this case they are virtually always accompanied by the enclitic allative particle =de, as in (14).

list-item.p: ‘Either going to Pylos.’ (Od.2.317)

sec.p: More specifically, the verb baínō never occurs with an accusative NP without any further specifications of the allative meaning (the only apparent exception is bḗseto díphron ‘mounted the chariot’ in Il.3.262 = 3.312, but note that the sigmatic aorist as opposed to the asigmatic aorist is transitive, as evidenced by the English translation). The verb eîmi occurs with adpositionless allative accusative twice. In one occurrence (Ex. (15)) we find the word dô ‘home’, while in the second occurrence the expression khoròniénai means ‘join the dancing’ (Od.18.194).

list-item.p: ‘As many men went to their homes’ (Od.1.176)

sec.p: A third occurrence of the adpositionless accusative features the word hodón ‘road’, and has a perlative meaning. Such meaning is also associated with the adpositionless accusative with the verb érkhomai, with four occurrences of hodón (Il.1.151, Od. 3.316, 15.13, 21.20), and one with káleutha ‘paths’ (Il.12.225). The verb érkhomai is also more frequent than baínō and eîmi with Goal expressions in the plain accusative: there are three occurrences in the Iliad, one with the word klisíēn ‘hut’ (1.322), one with dómous ‘homes’ (22.483) and one with a toponym in (16). In the Odyssey the plain accusative of Goal occurs four times, with oîkon ‘house’ (19.313), dô ‘home’ (2.262), húdōr ‘water’ (4.478), while in (17) gámon érkhesthai conveys the complex meaning of ‘marry’, and the accusative indicates a purpose rather than a goal.

list-item.p: ‘And this is now my eleventh day, since I came to Ilios.’ (Il.21.156)
‘Before the day of open marriage.’ (Od.6.288)

sec.p: This is not to say that the adpositionless accusative does not frequently occur in Goal expressions, even without the particle =de: however, apart from the few occurrences mentioned above, this always happens with prefixed verbs that incorporate an adverbial element which expresses the directional component, like eisérkhomai ‘go (in)to’ in (18), and with verbs whose lexical meaning requires a Goal expression, as kikhánō, aphiknéomai and híkō ‘reach’, ‘arrive’, as in (19).

list-item.p: ‘Now have I gone to the land of Phrygia, rich in vines’ (Il.3.184)
‘Let’s go to the father’s palace.’ (Od.6.296)

sec.p: The occurrence of the plain genitive in Source expressions is even more constrained than the occurrence of the accusative in Goal expressions: indeed, it is limited to verbs that incorporate the Source component, either because they are prefixed, as éxerkhomai in (20), or because they incorporate the Source, as eíkō in (21).

list-item.p: ‘Having gone forth from the city.’(Il.22.417)
‘O daughter of Zeus, flee from the battle and the fight!’ (Il.5.348)

sec.p: Occasionally, the plain genitive occurs with eîmi and érkhomai, but in such cases it has a perlative meaning, as in (22).

list-item.p: ‘Passing over a great plain.’ (Il.5.597)

sec.p: In addition, the plain genitive can also encode Location, as in (23) and (24). Remarkably, while in (23) the verb ‘be’ can be said to require a Location expression, and thus condition the meaning of the genitive NP Árgeos ‘in Argos’, in (24) the locative meaning of the genitive NP halòs ‘at sea’ cannot be seen as dependent on the lexical meaning of the predicate.

list-item.p: ‘Was he not in Argos?’ (Od.3.251)
‘That you may not suffer pain either by sea or on land.’ (Od.12.26–27)

sec.p: Goal expressions in the plain genitive also occur, mostly with verbs that incorporate Goal, as epibaínō in (25).

list-item.p: ‘You will mount upon our towers.’(Il.8.165)

sec.p: This apparently puzzling behavior of the genitive is connected with its partitive meaning, which in Ancient Greek seems to be more readily associated with the adpositionless genitive than the ablative meaning, unless some contextual cue requires the latter.

Similar to Goal expressions, which can feature the allative particle =de, Source expressions also can feature a special ending in Homer, the ablative ending -then. There is an important morphological difference between the two, as =de is an enclitic which is added to the noun inflected in the accusative, while -then is a suffix, frequently used for spatial adverbs. A verb such as ágō ‘lead’ frequently occurs with adpositional phrases, both encoding Goal and encoding Source, and never with adpositionless Goal or Source expressions, unless they are accompanied by =de or -then, as in (26) and (27).4

list-item.p: ‘Leading the stranger through the town to the place of assembly.’ (Od.17.72)
‘For his son he was bringing from Sparta the daughter of Alector.’(Od.4.10)

sec.p: Note however that even in this case Source expressions are more constrained than Goal expressions, as adpositionless NPs with =de occur with baínō, eîmi and érkhomai, while adpositionless NPs with -then do not.5 The clitic =de and the suffix -then are not limited to toponyms or nouns that indicate spatial regions or social location, but can occasionally occur with other types of NP, including personal pronouns. Notably, Location expressions can also feature a special ending, -thi.

Summing up, toponyms and some other nouns that due to their lexical meaning are highly expected in spatial expressions can be said to feature differential marking, even though not obligatorily, in Location expressions, but much less in Goal expressions (as I showed in this section, there are seven occurrences with the verbs analyzed here) and virtually not at all in Source expressions. Focusing now on asymmetries between Goal and Source, the extent to which differential marking occurs, though limited, is more significant for Goal then for Source. Indeed, with motion verbs that do not incorporate either Goal or Source I have found a small number of Goal expressions in the plain accusative, but no Source expressions in the plain genitive. In addition, with the same verbs and especially in the case of toponyms and other nouns typical of local expressions Goal is often encoded by the adpositionless accusative with the allative particle =de, but never by NPs with the ablative suffix -then.

sec.title: Goal expressions with human landmarks in Homer
sec.p: With typical inanimate landmarks, Goal may be encoded in different ways. In particular, in the Homeric poems we find:

list-item.p: eis/es + acc
en + dat
prós/protí + acc
epí + acc
epí + gen
epí + dat
enclitic =de

sec.p: Notably, only eis and the clitic=de among coding possibilities for Goal indicate the simple direction and correspond to English ‘to’, ‘into’ with all types of inanimate landmarks. With some verbs, such as bállō ‘throw’ and títhēmi ‘put, place’, both eis + acc and en + dat can indicate Goal, the former profiling the direction and the latter the endpoint of it (see Luraghi 2003: 83–84; the same holds for the plain dative, ib. 66). Adpositional phrases with prós/protí + acc indicate motion toward a landmark, while epí shows an interesting pattern of case variation, which is partly dependent on the type of landmark. In particular, the dative and the genitive can both occur with motion verbs and encode a sublative relation, whereby a movement ends in contact with the surface of the landmark, but the genitive typically occurs with nouns that denote vehicles, while the dative is associated with other landmarks. The accusative remains more clearly distinct, as it normally indicates motion toward a landmark.

In order to assess the scope of DCM a distinction must also be made between more or less individuated human landmarks. Individuated landmarks are indicated by singular count nouns, or plural count denoting salient entities, for example plural personal pronouns or proper names. Landmarks denoted by more generic plurals and especially by collectives are less individuated, and can be conceived as similar to inanimate entities: they can, for example, be conceived as containers when a trajector is located among their components, as shown by the occurrence of the adposition en ‘in’ in (28). As the example shows, this does not only hold for collective nouns, but also for plural count nouns, which can be conceived as covering an area: in this case, the trajector can be conceived as located inside the area, and the landmark, in spite of being human, is construed as a container.

list-item.p: ‘He strode high-spirited among the first.’ (Il.11.296)

sec.p: Among adpositions that occur with inanimate landmarks in Goal expressions, epí + gen is not attested with human landmarks, while epí + dat% and epí + acc occur with all three verbs and human landmarks. With baínō and eîmi epí + dat retains part of its sublative meaning in that it implies final contact with a surface, and means ‘against’, as in (29) and (30). In (31), Menelaos is fighting the Trojans after Patroclos’ death, and the PP epì Patróklōi refers to his corpse lying on the battlefield: the adposition does not mean ‘against’ in hostile sense, but it rather indicates spatial orientation, as shown by the occurrence of the same type of PP with the perfect form of baínō, bebḗkei ‘he stood’ at verse 706.With érkhomai there are two occurrences of the same formula featuring epí + dat, shown in (32). In this passage, a human being moves among a crowd until he reaches a specific group of persons: the final point of motion is highlighted by the meaning of the PP, which implies contact.

list-item.p: ‘When they saw Odysseus’ blood, all the Trojans moved against him.’(Il.11.460=Il.13.332)
‘When they came near, marching against each other.’(Il.11.232)
‘He stood over Patroclus and hurled with his bright spear.’ (Il.17.574)
‘(The son of Atreus) came to the Aiantes going through the throng of warriors.’ (Il.4.273)

sec.p: With all three verbs, epí + acc means ‘to’, and is one of the possible ways of encoding human Goal. This is consistent with its meaning with inanimate landmarks, with which it means ‘toward’, without implying a final contact of the trajector and the landmark, hence no implication of sharing the same space. Examples are (33)–(36).

list-item.p: ‘This thing seemed to him the better to go against the son of Atreus.’ (Il.14.24)
‘The strong Argeiphontes departed, and the nymph went to Odysseus.’(Od.5.150)
‘Speak, and come not silently toward me.’(Il.10.85)
‘And this plan seemed to him the best, to go first of all to the son of Neleus.’ (Il.10.18)

sec.p: The adposition eis with the accusative, which most frequently indicates Goal with inanimate landmarks typical of spatial relations, is also comparatively frequent with human landmarks, but it mostly occurs with érkhomai, as shown in (37) and (38). Landmarks are highly individuated entities, denoted by proper nouns or pronouns (other occurrences are Od. 3.318, 5.77, 6.327, 11.331). The adposition eis never occurs with human landmarks with baínō, while with eîmi the only human landmarks in adpositional phrases with eis are plēthún in Il. 17.31 and hómilon in Il. 17.129, both meaning ‘throng’, ‘crowd’. As noted above, these are referents with a low degree of individuation, which often show features of inanimate entities.

list-item.p: ‘To go to Achilles swift-foot.’ (Il.17.709)
‘All this might he learn, and come back to us.’ (Il.10.211)

sec.p: PPs with pará + acc occur with human landmarks, but motion is not always implied. Indeed, this type of PP may encode Location at the side of a human landmark, as in (39) and (40). Remarkably, similar occurrences with inanimate landmarks feature pará + dat (see Luraghi 2003: 135), which also occurs with human landmarks in Homeric Greek.

list-item.p: ‘Beside him, the young men held in their hands the five-pronged forks.’ (Il.1.463)
‘So there Odysseus slept, and beside him slept the young men.’ (Od.14.523–524)

sec.p: In occurrences with the motion verbs analyzed here, pará + acc% most often highlights that the final position of the trajector will be by the landmark’s side, as shown in (41), or co-occurs with some other Goal expression, as in (42).

list-item.p: ‘And he came and stood by Hector’s side, and spoke to him’ (Il.7.46)
‘I will go to the great Olympus, to Hephaestus.’(Il.18.143)

sec.p: This is coherent with the meaning of pará + acc with inanimate landmarks: it indicates Vicinal Goal as in (43) to a limited extent, while its most frequent function is to encode Path, as shown in (44). The latter is the only meaning featured with baínō, eîmi and érkhomai.

list-item.p: ‘He cast the lot upon the ground beside his foot.’ (Il.7.190)
‘The two of them went along the shore of the unresting sea.’ (Il.1.327)

sec.p: In several occurrences, érkhomai co-occurs with a dative NP that indicates a human participant, as in (45)–(47).

list-item.p: ‘To him, as an unexpected evil, came the divine Achilles.’ (Il.21.39)
‘Straightaway Helios came to him as messenger.’(Od.8.270)
‘Or a much desired god has come to her in answer to her prayers.’(Od.6.280)

sec.p: In most occurrences of this type, the subject is accompanied by a predicate noun, as in (45) and (46) or an adjective as in (47), which provide an additional predication to the motion event. The dative landmark certainly indicates the direction of motion, but it also represents the participant who takes advantage or disadvantage from the event, that is, it can be taken as a Beneficiary (or Maleficiary). This is especially clear when inanimate entities occur as subjects of the motion verb as in (48).

list-item.p: ‘Death will come for you/to you from the sea.’(Od.11.135)

sec.p: Note that the dative also regularly occurs with Goals of verbs indicating an approaching motion that does not include the final segment, and does not imply final coincidence in space between the trajector and the landmark, such as pelázō ‘approach’ and hépomai ‘follow’. This would make it a good candidate for animacy triggered DCM. However, as we will see in Section 3.4, its use with érkhomai remains connected with the occurrence of a Beneficiary/Maleficiary.

sec.title: Source expressions with human landmarks in Homer
sec.p: Source expressions in Homer features the following ways of encoding:

list-item.p: ek + gen
apó + gen
pará + gen
suffix -then

sec.p: The two basic adpositions are ek and apó. While the former has an elative meaning ‘out of’, the latter is a more generic ablative. Note however that it does not explicitly encode motion from the proximity of a landmark: this is the meaning of pará ‘beside’, which encodes in combination with case variation Location by a landmark, Vicinal Goal with human referents (see Section 3.2), and motion away from the vicinity of a landmark. As we will see, not surprisingly, this adposition increasingly specializes for human landmark (see Section 3.4). Occurrences with inanimate landmarks are (49) and (50), with ek see ex halós ‘from the sea’ in Example (48), and with -then see Oikhalíēthen ‘from Oechalia’ (a city name) in Example (51).

list-item.p: ‘(He) went forth toward the ships from the host.’(Il.10.336)
‘The cow came from the plain and from the swift ship came the comrades of Telemachus.’(Od.3.431)

sec.p: Source expressions with human landmarks are infrequent, in keeping with the cross-linguistic preference for Goal over Source. With highly individuated entities, singular count or proper names, Source is encoded by pará + gen, as shown in (51) and (52).

list-item.p: ‘Idomeneus … was on his way from a comrade that had just now come from the battle smitten in the knee.’ (Il.13.211)
‘As he was journeying from Oechalia, from Eurytus.’ (Il.2.596)

sec.p: PPs with ek and apó occur with generic plurals, as in (53) and (54).

list-item.p: ‘For he has but lately come from a strange land, from a folk no one would hope in his heart to return.’(Od.3.318)
‘So Aias moved away from the Trojans.’(Il.11.557)

sec.p: There is an occurrence of apó with a proper name, apò Patrócloio in Il. 17.666, but it refers to Patroclos’ corpse lying on the battlefield (cf. the discussion of Example (31)). In several other occurrences with ek or the suffix -then, the landmark is Zeus or the gods, as in (55).

list-item.p: ‘When they saw that it was from Zeus that the bird had come.’ (Il.8.251)

sec.p: In this passage, the Greeks are waiting for an omen from Zeus; when they realize that the bird was sent by the god, they start back fighting. Rather than a Source, here the landmark is conceived as actively having caused the motion of the trajector. In other occurrences, par Diós or Dióthen occur with the expression ággelos érkhesthai ‘go as messenger (on behalf of somebody)’ (Il. 2.786, Il. 24.194 = Il.24.561) and can be taken as Beneficiary expressions of the type of so-called behalf- or surrogate-Beneficiary (see Luraghi 2010).

sec.title: DCM in Herodotus
sec.p: In Herodotus, adpositionless encoding of spatial relations is virtually inexistent even for nouns that allow differential marking of Location in Homeric Greek. DCM with human landmarks, in its turn, shows some interesting developments, as I will argue in this section.

Human landmarks with non-deictic motion verbs show major changes, only partly following trends that were already detectable in the Homeric poems. It must be said that the distribution of verbs is not the same in Herodotus as in Homer. In general, unprefixed verbs become less frequent: this concerns in particular baínō, which only occurs seven times in the Histories in its unprefixed form (occurrences in Homer are around 400). In addition, the verb eîmi, which has only the present stem, after Homer acquires a future meaning and is used as the future of érkhomai.

Adpositions that occur in Goal expressions with human landmarks with érkhomai are pará + acc and eis. There is a substantial difference between the two types of adpositional phrase, as only pará + acc occurs with all types of landmark, including singular, highly individuated ones, while eis only occurs with plural nouns. An occurrence on esemé ‘to me’ with the first person singular pronoun in Hist. 1.93 does not have spatial reference, but means ‘up to my times’. In practice, eis becomes much more specialized than it was in Homer, and limited to the meaning ‘into’, implying motion of a trajector to the interior of a landmark. In the case of animate plural nouns, the landmark, constituted by a plurality of individual entities, is conceived as a container, coinciding with the space occupied by the landmark, and eis indicates motion along a trajectory whose final segment is inside the group of entities that forms the landmark.

On the other hand, and contrary to Homer, pará + acc in Herodotus does not highlight the final position of the trajector as being on a side of the landmark, as shown by comparison of (41) with (56) and (58).

list-item.p: ‘I came to you to ask about (my) speech.’ (Hdt.4.155.4)

sec.p: Adpositional phrases featuring epí + dat and epí + acc no longer indicate motion toward a human landmark with no further implications. In particular, epí + dat exhibits a more limited spatial meaning than in Homer, most often superessive, and not connected with motion verbs. Its occurrences with human landmarks are not numerous; the meaning is often ‘against’, not necessarily in hostile sense, and never with érkhomai. In its turn, epí + acc% occurs with human landmarks comparatively frequently, usually meaning ‘against’ in hostile sense, as in (57). Otherwise, it can indicate purpose, as in (58), which also contains a Goal expression with a human landmark, pará + acc.

list-item.p: ‘They came out with all their force to meet the returning exiles.’ (Hdt.1.62.3)
‘For it was Cyrus who sent (someone) to Amasis asking for his daughter.’ (Hdt.3.2.1)

sec.p: The dative occurs with érkhomai to a more limited extent than in Homer: only twice does the verb indicate concrete motion with a predicative expression, similar to the Homeric usage, as in (59) (compare with (45)–(47)) (note further that aggéllō ‘announce’ takes the dative, so toîsi barbároisi ‘to the barbarians’ in (59) could also be an Addressee);in two other occurrences it indicates the coming of a dream, and the co-occurring dative clitic pronoun refers to an Experiencer.

list-item.p: ‘Immediately thereafter there came a man of Histiaea in a boat to the barbarians, telling them (of the flight of the Greeks from Artemisium).’ (Hdt.8.23.1)

sec.p: Source expressions with érkhomai are very infrequent.6 With human landmarks, the Source meaning is ambiguous between simple movement away from a human landmark, and movement instigated by the Source participant. The latter is the case for adpositional phrases with ek, as in (60); note further that I did not find any occurrence of ek with singular count nouns and the verb érkhomai.

list-item.p: ‘It appeared to him that a messenger had come from the Persians.’ (Hdt.3.30.2)

sec.p: Adpositional phrases with pará + gen can also be ambiguous, but notably this type of adpositional phrase is the only one that occurs with singular count nouns, as in (61).

list-item.p: ‘Thrasyboulos led the man coming from Periander outside the town.’ (Hdt.5.92F2)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Differential marking of spatial relations triggered by degrees of expectedness is limited in Ancient Greek. Even in Homer, the extent to which nouns with spatial reference trigger DCM remains marginal. In the first place, it mostly concerns Location expressions, and in the second place it is not obligatory, as nouns with spatial reference can be, and frequently are, encoded as other nouns, as shown in Section 3.1 (cf. Examples (10)–(13)). Differential encoding of Goal is even more limited. Indeed, a bare accusative of Goal only occurs in seven passages with motion verbs, while adpositionless Goal NPs featuring =de cannot, strictly speaking, be considered as instantiating differential Goal marking for nouns with spatial reference: notably, while it is true that the latter are the most frequent nouns that take the clitic, it must be stressed that it also occurs with other types of NPs, including personal names and personal pronouns (see Liddell & Scott 2009
s.v.). Differential Source marking in its turn is inexistent: in fact, the genitive, which would be the possible candidate for such function, when occurring with baínō, eîmi and érkhomai indicates Path or Goal. Similar to the particle =de, the adverbial ending -then, though frequently occurring with nouns that indicate spatial regions, also occurs with other types of NPs, including personal names and personal pronouns (Chantraine 2013).

Summing up, in spite of the partial extent of DCM for spatial relations in Homeric Greek, one can set up a markedness hierarchy, whereby Location is the only spatial relation that significantly requires lesser means of encoding for nouns with spatial reference, being possibly encoded by the plain dative rather than an adpositional phrase. Though only occasionally (as shown above, I counted seven occurrences), Goal can also be encoded by the bare accusative, while the plain genitive cannot encode Source. Note that this cannot possibly depend on the size of the corpus, as the adpositionless genitive has a different meaning with unprefixed, non-deictic motion verbs. Hence we can set up the scale in (62), which shows an asymmetry between Goal and Source. Notably, this asymmetry does not develop over time, as no DCM is found in Herodotus for nouns with spatial reference.

list-item.p: Location > Goal > Source7

sec.p: Human landmarks in Goal and Source expressions show a variety of possible means of encoding in Homer. In particular, concerning Goal expressions, the meaning ‘to’ with respect to a human referent is conveyed by epí + acc and eis, the latter being the most frequent type of PP both with human and with all other types of landmark, while epí + dat and pará + acc are less frequent. With both types of PP, the Goal meaning is mostly accompanied by some other specification: a hostile meaning for epí + dat, and the indication that the real Goal is a side of the landmark for pará + acc. Remarkably, this is in accordance with the meaning of pará + acc with other types of landmark. In Herodotus, the picture changes: only pará + acc occurs with singular human landmarks, and the notion of Vicinal Goal is no longer on the foreground. Adpositional phrases with eis and human landmarks are infrequent and limited to plurals, while epí + dat or + acc no longer indicate simple motion toward a human landmark. The typically Homeric construction featuring érkhomai with another predicative expression and a human landmark in the dative, which should be taken as a Beneficiary or recipient, rather than as a Goal, appears to be declining in Herodotus. In practice, in Homeric Greek DCM for Goal was not relevant, as the various types of adpositional phrase that occur with human landmarks also occur with other types of landmark, with the same shades of meaning and, most important, the same proportion, as the most frequent among them is eis irrespective of the landmark’s animacy. In Herodotus, on the other hand, eis remains limited with human landmarks, while pará + acc becomes the standard way to indicate Goal.

Source expressions with human landmarks in Homer also feature a variety of encoding possibilities. Notably, however, the only type of adpositional phrase that indicates motion away from a singular, living human landmark is pará + gen. This is also in accordance with the data from Herodotus. Thus, the data point toward an asymmetry between Source and Goal: while DCM is already established in Homer for Source, it only emerges in Herodotus in the case of Goal.

If we broaden our view to Location, we can note that Location expressions with human landmarks consistently feature pará + dat% from Homer onwards. The inessive adposition en is unsuitable for this function, and it can occur with human landmarks only with different meanings (see Luraghi 2003: 86–87). The elative adposition ek occurs with human landmarks both in Homer and in Herodotus, but is elative meaning ‘out of’ specializes for Origin, and, as demonstrated in (55), especially with singular count nouns it does not simply indicate motion away from a landmark, but implies that the landmarks had some active role in originating the motion (concrete or abstract) of the trajector. One may wonder why apó does not feature in Source expressions with human landmarks, as its meaning is neutral: however, as we have seen, in the case of human landmarks it does not feature in Source expressions with singular count nouns, except in one case in which the landmark is the corpse of a human being, hence a stationary entity.

Contrary to Location and Source, the illative adposition eis in Homer does not show either incompatibility or a special semantics with human landmarks: in fact, it is the most frequent adposition in Homer, in much the same way as with inanimate landmarks. This can be due to the fact that a Goal is a landmark that is only prospectively reachable, hence the illative meaning is tolerated even with landmarks with which a trajector cannot coincide in space (see Luraghi 2003: 108–109). In Herodotus, this type of PP remains limited to plural landmarks, while pará + acc becomes the standard way of encoding human Goals. Remarkably, both in the case of Location with pará + dat and in the case of Source with pará + gen this adposition remains virtually limited to human landmarks starting from Herodotus (the same can be said for Attic prose writers).8 Interestingly, with pará + acc human landmarks in Herodotus are more numerous than in Homer, but inanimate landmarks do not show a similar decrease.
Summing up, DCM is fully developed and instantiated by pará with the appropriate case both for Goal and for Source in Herodotus, but only Source triggers differential marking in Homer.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, I have discussed differential marking of Goal and Source in Ancient Greek. Based on earlier studies on DCM, I have considered possible relevant triggers of DCM expectedness of certain referents in spatial relations and animacy. I have then studied Goal and Source encoding with three non-deictic motion verbs in Homeric Greek, and have shown that, with verbs that do not incorporate either the Goal or the Source, some nouns that indicate spatial regions may occasionally show less complex marking than other referents, while this is never the case for Source. I have argued that, far from being an accident due to limits of the corpus, this asymmetry depends on the more complex meaning of the genitive case with respect to the accusative. Indeed, the genitive has ablative meaning only in a limited number of PPs and with verbs that incorporate the Source. Elsewhere, it functions as a partitive, and it is unsuitable for the encoding of Source.

With human landmarks, I found various possibilities for Goal encoding, including epí + acc and more marginally +dat, eis, and pará + acc. Interestingly, the meaning conveyed by the last PP always highlights motion toward a side of a referent, while eis indicates simple motion toward a referent. This is the most frequent adposition with all types of landmark in Goal expressions in Homer, so that one can conclude that there is no animacy-based differential Goal marking. (Possible dative encoding of Goal participants with érkhomai is part of a construction that also contains an additional predication, and points toward a beneficiary or recipient reading of the dative NP.) In the case of Source, I found PPs with ek, apó and pará + gen. Only the last type of PP can indicate concrete motion away from a human being. Thus, in spite of the limited number of occurrences, one can identify a pattern of differential Source marking, whereby ek and apó occur with inanimate landmarks, and pará + gen with human landmarks.

In Herodotus, DCM for nouns that denote spatial regions is inexistent. With human landmarks, Goal is consistently encoded by pará + acc, which has acquired a more generic meaning than in Homer, while eis is limited to plural landmarks, and the meaning of epí + acc specializes as ‘against’ or ‘for’. Human Source remains connected with pará + gen. It appears from the data that differential marking in Ancient Greek has emerged at an earlier stage in the case of Source than in the case of Goal. I have explained this different timing in two ways. In the first place, ek with human landmarks specialized for the encoding of Origin, hence it conveys different meanings rather than physical movement away from a landmark. In the second place, in spite of the fact that eis is etymologically related to en ‘in’, it does not necessarily always activate the expectation that the trajector and the landmark will coincide in space at the end of motion, hence its possible occurrence with human landmarks.

fn.p: Note that I am considering only cases in which DCM holds between overt expressions. In particular, I am not considering differences brought about by the choice between overt vs. non-overt expression of Goal, which has been a deeply investigated topic (see Nikitina & Maslov 2013), especially with respect to the verb’s semantics and in relation to Talmy’s typology (see Talmy 2000).

Note that in Ancient Greek the use of diá + gen for human Instruments also has the function of avoiding ambiguity with Recipient and Beneficiary expressions, which are encoded by the plain dative (see Luraghi 2003: 63).

Ancient Greek adpositions are usually referred to as prepositions, as they are normally preposed in Classical Greek. However, as well known, their position in Homeric Greek enjoyed more freedom, as they could be both pre- and postposed. For this reason, I have decided to use the term adposition throughout the paper when referring to Greek.
More precisely, the verb ágō occurs 305 in the Homeric poems. In 102 occurrences it is accompanied by an adpositional phrase, and by an NP with =de or -then and no adposition.
To be sure, this could be an effect of frequency, since Goals are more frequent than Sources.
Goal expressions with eis are , while Source expressions with ek and apó counted together are 29

A reviewer wonders whether it is significant that the hierarchy corresponds to the roles’ overall frequency. Apart from the fact that I am not aware of studies concerned with the relative frequency of the three roles in the Homeric poems, as I have argued above, adpositionless NPs for Location are a viable alternative to adpositional phrases, while adpositionless NPs for Goal are exceptional, and adpositionless NPs for Source are inexistent.

In Herodotus pará + gen only occurs with human landmarks, while pará + dat occurs with inanimate landmarks in seven occurrences and with human landmarks. The difference between Herodotus and Homer is striking, as in the Homeric poems, pará occurs with the dative over 200 times, and more than half of these occurrences contain inanimate landmarks.
