abstract.p: This paper provides new evidence for Source–Goal asymmetry by analyzing the synchronic behavior and the diachronic developments of Ancient Greek preverbs. This investigation is based on a diachronic corpus, including Homer as well as later prose, obtained by selecting a number of verbs representing different verb classes. Ancient Greek preverbs show both synchronic and diachronic asymmetries. The Goal is expressed by a larger number of preverbs than the Source, and is often associated with Location. Source-preverbs are more advanced in grammaticalization than Goal-preverbs: they are more obligatory, more easily repeated, and show a stronger tendency to develop actional meanings. Moreover, compounds with Source-preverbs often take a Goal-participant, whereas the opposite is not attested. These asymmetries are due to the syncretism undergone by Ancient Greek cases, which turned the genitive into a highly polysemous case.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Preverbs and their diachronic developments are widely researched topics in Indo-European and Ancient Greek (henceforth AG) linguistics (cf. among many others Chantraine 1942; Kuryłowicz 1964; Horrocks 1981; Cuzzolin et al. 2006; Hewson & Bubenik 2006; Viti 2008a, 2008b). In the linguistics of space, Source–Goal asymmetry has recently received much attention, though it has mostly been investigated from a synchronic point of view (cf. among others Stefanowitch & Rohde 2004; Lakusta & Landau 2005). This paper aims at putting together these two fields of study by examining Source–Goal asymmetries that are both synchronically (in their encoding and distribution) and diachronically (in their grammaticalization process) related to AG preverbs.

In order to do that, I selected a number of verbs, i.e., ágō ‘carry’, aeírō ‘lift’, aíssō ‘shoot, dart, glance’, állomai ‘jump’, baínō ‘walk’, bállō ‘throw’, dúō ‘sink’, eîmi ‘come/go’, eimí ‘be’, ékhō ‘hold, have’, elaúnō ‘set in motion’, érkhomai ‘come/go’, hairéō ‘take’,híēmi ‘let go’, keîmai ‘lie’, leípō ‘leave’, lúō ‘loosen’, nízō ‘wash’, píptō ‘fall’, stréphō ‘turn’, títhēmi ‘put’, trépō ‘turn’, trékhō ‘run’, thrṓiskō ‘leap’, phérō ‘bring’, pheúgō ‘escape’, khéō ‘pour’. This selection of verbs aims to represent different verb classes including the following:

list-item.p: motion verbs (e.g. baínō ‘walk’) as well as location verbs (e.g. keîmai ‘lie’);

motion/location verbs proper (e.g. baínō ‘walk’, keîmai ‘lie’) as well as verbs comparable to them, such as verbs of putting/taking (e.g. títhēmi ‘put’) or verbs of washing (e.g. nízō ‘wash’, whose behavior resembles that of verbs of removing);
motion verbs both implying and not implying a specific endpoint of motion (e.g. elaúnō ‘set in motion’ vs. dúō ‘sink’, píptō ‘fall’);
verbs both oriented and non-oriented towards the starting point/endpoint of motion (e.g. leípō ‘leave’ vs. eîmi ‘come/go’).

sec.p: I then analyzed the semantics and syntax of their combinations with AG preverbs, both in Homeric Greek (extensively) and in later prose (partially). I only considered the spatial and actional meanings of preverbs, thus leaving out the additional abstract meanings that AG preverbs might develop. Accordingly, I excluded the preverb sún ‘with’ from my investigation, as it shows no spatial meaning, not even in Homer (cf. Section 4).1

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, I describe my theoretical framework. I start by explaining how spatial relations are conceived in Cognitive Grammar. Then, I briefly introduce Talmy’s (1985, 2000) typology of motion verbs. Lastly, I recall the basic claims of grammaticalization theory, and clarify why grammaticalization is a useful framework for analyzing the development of AG preverbs. In Section 3, I show how verbs, satellites (i.e. adverbs, preverbs, and prepositions), and cases contribute to the expression of spatial relations. I focus on the growing importance of satellites in clarifying the spatial value of Greek cases. Sections 4 and 5 are devoted to Source–Goal asymmetries. The former addresses the matter synchronically, from the point of view of encoding and distribution. The latter thoroughly investigates the asymmetries in the grammaticalization paths of preverbs. In Section 6, I summarize my findings and propose an explanation for the asymmetries set out in Sections 4 and 5.

sec.title: Spatial relations in Cognitive Grammar
sec.p: In Cognitive Grammar, spatial relations are asymmetric relations involving a more prominent entity and a less prominent one (cf. among others Talmy 1983; Langacker 1986; Svorou 1994). The more prominent entity is the Trajector (henceforth TR) or Figure, i.e. the located or moving entity. The less prominent entity is the Landmark (henceforth LM) or Ground, i.e. the reference entity with respect to which the TR is located. If a spatial relation involves movement, a third element is introduced: the Trajectory, which is the path covered by the TR with respect to the LM.
Usually, TRs are not generally located (or do not generally move) with respect to LMs, rather with respect to a specific region of space pertaining to LMs, as shown in Examples (1) and (2):2

list-item.p: ‘They went back beside the ships.’ (Il.9.657)
‘As he was going into the ship…’ (Od.2.226)

sec.p: Examples (1) and (2) include the same verb eîmi ‘go’. However, this verb takes two different prepositional phrases (henceforth PPs), parà nêas ‘along the (line of) ships’ (1) and en nēusìn ‘into the ships’ (2). Such PPs select two different regions of space: in (1) the TR moves within a region close to the ships, whereas in (2) it moves toward the region inside the ships. All in all, the region of space can be defined as the search domain for the localization of TRs with respect to LMs.

Let us take another look at Examples (1) and (2). The two PPs also encode different locative roles (henceforth LRs). In (1) parà nêas ‘along the (line of) ships’ describes the Trajectory covered by the TR (LR = Path). In (2) en nēusìn ‘in(to) the ships’ is the endpoint of the motion event (LR = Goal). The LRs considered in this paper are Location, Goal, Source and Path. I refer to Luraghi (2003: 20 ff.) for their definitions and examples in AG. Briefly, Location is the LR played by the LM with respect to which the TR is located. If a spatial relation includes directional motion, the LM can play either the LR of Goal (or Direction, in case the TR moves toward the LM), or the LR of Source (in case the TR moves away from the LM). A further LR is Path, that is, “a state of affairs in which the trajector moves along a trajectory through, or across a landmark” (Luraghi 2003: 22; also see the discussion of Example (11)).

sec.title: The typology of motion verbs
sec.p: As Talmy (1985, 2000) pointed out, the Path of motion can be expressed by verbs or by other elements within the sentence, by the satellites. Verb-framed languages express the Path through verbs, whereas satellite-framed languages express the manner of motion through verbs and delegate the expression of Path to satellites.
According to Talmy (1985: 102), satellites are “certain immediate constituents of a verb root other than inflections, auxiliaries, or nominal arguments.”

list-item.p: ‘And white-armed Arete urged (her) maidens place bedsteads under the portico, and to lay on (them) fair blankets of purple.’ (Od.7.337)

sec.p:
In (3) the TR is rhḗgea kalà porphúre’(a) ‘fair blankets of purple’, which are displaced by the maidens ‘on (them)’ (lit. ‘in them’). The preverb em-, an allomorph of en- ‘in’ contained by em
baléein ‘throw in’, expresses the Goal. This preverb further selects a region of space inside the LM and establishes a reference with the previous linguistic material, that is, démni’(a) ‘bedstead’.3 According to Talmy’s definition, the preverb em- is a satellite.

A broader definition of satellites also exists: “satellites are all non-predicative elements that indicate (a part of ) the Path of the movement of the Figure. This includes adpositions, adverbs, case markers, verbal prefixes, etc.” (Verkerk 2014: 42; Filipović 2007; Beavers et al. 2010; Croft et al. 2010).

list-item.p: ‘(And as in the recess of a wondrous cave bats fly about shrilling,) when one has fallen from the rock out of the chain…’ (Od.24.7)

sec.p:
In (4), a number of elements other than the verb contribute to the encoding of the Source: the preverb apo- contained in apo
pésēisin ‘fall from’, the nouns in the genitive case hormathoû ‘chain’ and pétrēs ‘rock’, and the place word ek ‘out of’.4 According to the broader definition just set out, all of these elements should be regarded as satellites. In this paper, I adopt the stricter Talmian approach to satellites.

sec.title: Grammaticalization theory
sec.p: The grammaticalization theory is particularly fitting to describe the development of AG preverbs, which used to be free-standing locative adverbs.5 As defined in Lehmann (2004, 2015), grammaticalization is a diachronic process in which a linguistic sign gradually loses its autonomy, thus becoming more subject to the constraints of the linguistic system. Accordingly, locative adverbs increased their obligatoriness throughout the history of Greek: as discussed in Section 5, Homeric Greek preverbs are not as compulsory to the expression of certain spatial relations as are those of later prose.

Moreover, their degree of fusion with verbal stems increased. It is well-known (e.g. Chantraine 1953: 82–86; Watkins 1964) that Homeric preverbs can be separated from the verbal stem that they semantically modify both by fully lexical words (5) and by postpositive particles (6). Such a separation (what is called ‘tmesis’) is no longer possible in Classical Greek, except for reasons of literary style.

list-item.p: ‘As we have taken the sheep, we stepped into (the ships).’ (Od.11.4)
‘Then the heroic wooers came in.’ (Od.1.144)

sec.p:
In my view, Examples (5) and (6) attest to two different stages in the grammaticalization process undergone by locative adverbs. In particular, Example (5) shows a less advanced stage than that in Example (6). In (5), a particle (=dè), a noun phrase (tà mêla ‘the sheep’) and a conjunct participle (labóntes) split the putative compound em-
baínō ‘step into’. In (6), instead, the compound es-
érkhomai ‘go to’ is only interrupted by the postpositive particle =d’(e). According to Wackenagel’s law, clitic particles strongly select the second position in ancient Indo-European languages. Thus, in (6) Wackenagel’s law overrides the tendency for univerbation of locative adverbs and verbal stems. Also, the elided particle =d’(e) serves the meter in (6): it lengthens the vowel of es, thus constituting the first long half of a spondaic foot.

Moreover, the same preverb can show different degrees of compositionality, even in combination with the same verbal stem. The preverb apo- behaves in this way in the compound apo-
nízō ‘wash away’, as shown in (7) and (8):

list-item.p: ‘Who might wash away the blood from (our) wounds.’ (Od.24.189)
‘The scar, …while I was washing it, I recognized (it).’ (Od.23.75)

sec.p:
In (7), the compound apo
-nízō ‘wash away’ takes a plain accusative of the removed substance (bróton ‘blood’) and a PP of the thing washed, ex ōteilôn ‘from (our) wounds’. This PP specifies the meaning of the preverb apo- ‘away’, contained in apo
-nízō. Thus, the preverb retains its original meaning of Source. In (8), instead, the meaning of apo- is more bleached: the argument structure of apo
-nízō is different, as the compound only takes the accusative of the thing being washed.

The fact that the same set of morphemes can show different degrees of obligatoriness, fusion, and semantic bleaching – that is, of grammaticalization – in a single variety of a language can also be accounted for by the grammaticalization theory. Indeed, grammaticalization is a continuum of processes that gradually develops in diachrony, and usually has as a categorial gradience outcome in synchrony (Traugott & Trausdale 2010).

sec.title: Encoding spatial relations in Ancient Greek
sec.p: AG is usually regarded as a satellite-framed language (e.g. Skopeteas 2002; Imbert 2010; Verkerk 2014). As shown by Nikitina & Maslov (2013: 134 ff.), however, it is more accurate to describe AG as a language that is increasingly consistent in encoding LRs by means of satellites. This typological change is related to the ongoing grammaticalization undergone by satellites, which develop as follows: free-standing adverbs > preverbs/adpositions. In AG, a number of linguistic elements may contribute to expressing spatial relations: verbs, satellites, and cases (e.g. Luraghi 2003, 2009). The constituency relation between these elements changed throughout the history of Greek. At the origin, the combinations of satellites + verbs/ satellites + cases used to be free combinations of free-standing locative adverbs with free-standing noun verbs/phrases. Later on, as the obligatoriness of satellites increased, they underwent grammaticalization processes into preverbs/adpositions (Kuryłowicz 1964; Cuzzolin et al. 2006; Hewson & Bubenik 2006). This is shown in Examples (9) and (10) (see also Examples (5) and (6)).

list-item.p: ‘(And at early morning) he went up to great heaven and Olympus.’ (Il.1.497)
‘(But they are accustomed) to sacrifice to Zeus, going up to the highest peaks of the mountains.’ (Hdt.1.131)

sec.p:
Examples (9) and (10) include the same compound verb, i.e. ana
-baínō ‘(lit.) walk upwards’. The preverb ana- ‘upwards’ is intrinsically oriented towards an upper Goal (< *án-ō ‘upwards’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 82; Dunkel 2014b: 50). In Example (9) from Homer, only the plain accusative ouranòn Oúlumpón te ‘to heaven and Olympus’ specifies the upper Goal. In Example (10) from Herodotus, instead, the Goal is expressed by a prepositional phrase with a satellite, i.e. epì
tà hupsēlótata ‘(lit.) up to the highest places’. In (10), the satellite epí is compulsory for syntactic reasons, and not to avoid semantic ambiguity. The direction of motion would have been clear even without the overt mention of epí ‘on, up’: the satellite ana- means ‘upwards’ and the localization of the LM epì
tà hupsēlótata ‘(lit.) up to the highest places’ (i.e. the endpoint of motion) is clearly upper in respect to that of the TR.

How do verbs, satellites and cases contribute to expressing spatial relations in AG?6 Verbs define a spatial relation as either static (e.g. keîmai ‘lie’) or dynamic (e.g. érkhomai ‘come, go’). They may further specify the manner of motion (cf. baínō ‘walk, step’ vs. trékhō ‘run’). In AG, as well as in the majority of ancient Indo-European languages excluding Hittite (Verkerk 2014: 85, 95), motion verbs are usually non-deictic (cf. érkhomai ‘come, go’ and eîmi ‘come, go’) with a few exceptions, such as AG iknéomai and aphiknéomai ‘come, arrive at’ (< *seik- ‘reach, grasp with the hand’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 462; Beekes 2010: 586).7 As iknéomai and aphiknéomai are Goal-oriented, they may still take the plain accusative, indicating Goal in Homeric Greek. However, these verbs usually take a PP in later prose (cf. Hdt.7.118, Th.7.86, etc.), consistently with the increasing obligatoriness of AG satellites (cf. above in this Section).

Satellites usually select a region of space pertaining to the LM. For example, the place words apó (<* áp-ō ‘away from’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 98; Dunkel 2014b: 66), ek (ex < PIE *éĝh-s ‘out of’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 353; Dunkel 2014b: 205), and pará (< PIE *pr̥h2ó ‘next to’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 857; Dunkel 2014b: 650) can all encode Source in combination with the genitive case. However, apó properly has a generic ablative value (‘away from’), ek an elative one (‘out of’), and pará specifies that there is no contact between the TR and the LM (‘from beside’) at the starting point of the motion event (Luraghi 2003: 95, 118, 131 ff.). Such a distinction sometimes remains clear when these place words occur in verbal composition: compare apo
-baínō ‘go away, leave’ and ek
-baínō ‘go out, exit’. However, the preverb para- in para
-baínō expresses Goal or Location ‘go by the side of, stand beside (in perfect)’, rather than Source (i.e. ‘go away from the side of’). This is due to the fact that both apó and ek are exclusively Source-satellites, and accordingly they only combine with the genitive case. By contrast, pará can combine with the genitive, dative and accusative cases to express different semantic roles (cf. Luraghi 2003: 131 ff.).

Another enlightening example is that of the particles epí (< *épi, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 358; Dunkel 2014b: 245), hupér (< *up-ér ‘above’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 1157; Dunkel 2014b: 835) and hupó (< *súp-ō ‘under, down(wards)’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 1160; Dunkel 2014b: 746). The place words epí and hupér select a region of space located on top of the LM. However, epí implies contact between the TR and the LM (‘on’), whereas hupér the lack of it (‘over, above’). By contrast, hupó selects a region of space located at the bottom of the LM (‘under’) (cf. Luraghi 2003: 214, 225, 298).

Lastly, cases make the LM overt (cf. Slobin’s 1996: 201 ‘minus-ground’ clauses), besides being devoted to the specification of LRs (i.e. Location, Goal, Source, and Path; cf. Section 2.1). It is well-known that in Homeric Greek, plain cases partially retain their concrete and spatial value and may encode LRs alone, although to a limited extent (Chantraine 1953: 38–81; Luraghi 2003: 52–71). By and large, AG cases express LRs as shown in Table 1:

caption.title: The spatial values of Ancient Greek cases

sec.p: However, the historical development of AG cases complicated the picture in Table 1. First, the encoding of the Goal was only one of the functions inherited by the AG accusative (Delbrück 1879: 29–37). Specifically regarding its concrete functions, the AG accusative also has perlative value (what is called the accusative of extension), thus expressing Path (Chantraine 1953: 45 f.).8

list-item.p: ‘(As he sailed over the wide sea on that journey) on which he brought Helen.’ (Il.6.292)

sec.p: In (11), the relative pronoun hḕn ‘(on) which’, referring to the antecedent tḕn hodòn ‘that way’, indicates the Path covered by the TR, i.e. the omitted subject (Aléxandros ‘Alexander’, cf. v. 290). On the one hand, Path shares some properties with Goal, i.e. the spatial role expressed by the directional accusative: Path implies that the TR is covering a Trajectory, which Goal does as well. Nevertheless, Path also has something to do with Location: the Trajectory overlaps with the area of the LM, as in the case of Location (Luraghi 2003: 22). The complexity of Path is mirrored by morphology: the presence of the perlative in a case system is comparatively infrequent. Indeed, locative case systems tend to encode a threefold distinction between Location, Goal, and Source of movement, thus disregarding Path (Malchucov & Spencer 2009: 614).

The AG dative and genitive cases are syncretic (Chantraine 1953: 50 ff., 67 ff.), which is the reason for their polysemy. The dative results from the merging of three PIE cases: the dative proper, the locative and the instrumental. I leave out the syncretism between the dative and the instrumental (cf. Chantraine 1953: 74–77; Luraghi 2003: 51, 63 ff.), which is not relevant for our purposes, and I turn to the syncretism between the dative and the locative. The latter is also attested for other IE languages (e.g. Hittite), and has been argued to be morphologically motivated (see Kuryłowicz 1964: 190). The dative proper can express Goal as a second argument of motion verbs, especially with animate LMs (12), although not exclusively (13):9

list-item.p: ‘The goodly swineherd went back to Odysseus and (his) son.’ (Od.16.452–453)
‘He brought to the all-nourishing earth all (these), one after another.’ (Il.8.277)

sec.p: Moreover, as a syncretic case with the IE locative, the AG dative often expresses Location, as in (14), Il.6.397, 16.595, 719, Od.6.162 and many other examples.

list-item.p: ‘I am a dear guest-friend for you in the middle of Argos.’(Il.6.224)

sec.p: The AG genitive derives from the merging of two PIE cases, the genitive and the ablative. To some extent, the plain genitive retains the functions of the ablative, including that of expressing Source, mostly with verbs requiring an ablative complement (15) or verbs compounded with ek ‘out of’, apó ‘away from’, katá ‘downwards’, hupó ‘under’ or pará ‘beside’ (16).

list-item.p: ‘The Argives withdrew from the ships.’ (Il.15.655)
‘Gentle son of Capaneus, dismount from the chariot!’(Il.5.109)

sec.p: The compound in (16) means ‘go downwards’ (kata- < PIE *kát-ō ‘downwards’, cf. Chantraine 1999 (1968): 505). The plain genitive can only express Source in this context, as our encyclopedic knowledge suggests that one is more likely to go down from a chariot, rather than to go down toward a chariot.10 Later on, the ablatival genitive becomes almost exclusively prepositional (Luraghi 2003: 58–59). Such limitations are likely to be due to the merging of the ablative with the (partitive) genitive.

In AG, the partitive genitive is highly widespread: it can occur in all syntactic functions other than indirect object, including that of complement of PPs (Conti & Luraghi 2014). Plain partitive genitives encoding Location (17) and Goal (18) are attested, but not as frequently as prepositional partitive genitives encoding Location and Goal.11

list-item.p: ‘(Menelaus) was not in Achaean Argos.’(Od.3.251)
‘(They) heaped the corpses upon the pyre.’(Il.7.428=431)

sec.p: Both plain and prepositional partitive genitive preferably select discontinuous LMs, as shown in (19), in which the LM (the crowd) is a multitude constituted by many single entities:12

list-item.p: ‘(The son of Oïleus cut the head from the tender neck, and with a swing) he sent it rolling through the throng like a ball.’ (Il.13.204)

sec.p: As Conti and Luraghi showed, probably due to the frequency of the partitive genitive,

the genitive without prepositions could express the meaning of an ablative only under special contextual conditions, with verbs or adjectives that required such a meaning. When no such indication was available from the context, apparently, the most readily available interpretation of a genitive was the partitive (Conti & Luraghi 2014: 467).

Even with motion verbs, unless they require an ablative complement, the genitive tends to indicate Goal, as occasionally do the plain accusative and the plain dative cases (see Chantraine 1953: 38–49, 67–81).

To conclude, due to their historical development from PIE, all three AG cases are polysemous in encoding LRs. The highest degree of polysemy is shown by the genitive case, which can express Source (< ablative), Location (< partitive), and Goal (< partitive). Table 2 summarizes the LRs encoded by AG cases, alone or in combination with satellites.

caption.title: The polysemy of AG cases in expressing locative roles

sec.title: The synchronic Source–Goal asymmetries
sec.p: Typologically, Goals tend to be expressed by a larger number of morphemes and to show a wider range of distinctions than Sources (see among others Svorou 1994; Regier & Zheng 2007). As shown in Table 3, this is also the case regarding AG preverbs. Table 3 only takes into account the spatial usages of AG preverbs, thus disregarding their abstract meanings. Accordingly, it does not include the satellite sun-/xun- ‘together, with’, as it shows no spatial meanings, even in Homer.13 In Table 3, italics are used to underline Source with respect to the LRs of Goal and Location; the LRs in brackets are those expressed by preverbs only in combination with a specific case or under specific contextual conditions (see discussion below in this Section).14

caption.title: Locative roles encoded by AG preverbs

tr.td: éneimi ‘be in’,énēmai ‘be seated in’ embaínō ‘step in(to), embark’, entíthēmi ‘put in’
ápeimi ‘be away’, apekhō ‘keep away’apobaínō ‘go away’, apophérō ‘carry away’
páreimi ‘be by’, párēmai ‘be seated beside’ parabaínō ‘go by the side of’, ‘pass by’ parérkhomai ‘pass by/alongside’(post-Homeric) parairéō ‘take away from’, paraphérō ‘turn aside/away’
proéimi ‘be before’, proékhō ‘hold before’probaínō ‘step forward’, proḯēmi ‘send forward’
(post-Homeric) antékhō ‘hold against’ antiphéromai ‘set oneself against’, (post-Homeric) antibaínō ‘go against’
diéerkhomai ‘go through’, diatrékhō ‘run across’ diaphússō ‘draw away’ diairèō ‘take apart’
anabaínō ‘walk upwards’, áneimi ‘go up’, anékhō ‘lift up’
katabaínō ‘go downwards to’, káteimi ‘go down’ katabaínō ‘go downwards along’ katabaínō ‘go downwards from’ [?]
huperékhō ‘hold over’ huperbaínō ‘step over’, huperbállō ‘cast over/beyond’
hupérkhomai ‘go/come under’ hupékhō ‘hold under’, hupókeimai ‘lie under’ hupodúnō ‘come from under’ [+ gen.]
méteimi ‘be among’, metaḯzō ‘seat beside’ metérkhomai ‘go/come among’, metabaínō ‘pass over (from one place to another)’
amphibaínō ‘go around’, amphibállō ‘throw around’, ampékhō ‘hold on both sides > surround’
peribaínō ‘go round’, peribállō ‘throw around’(post-Homeric) periékhō ‘encompass (< hold all around)’
próskeimai ‘be laid by’, prosízō ‘come and sit near’ prosbaínō ‘approach’, próseimi ‘approach’
epibaínō ‘go upon’, epérkhomai ‘approach’ epékhō ‘have/hold upon’, epíkeimai ‘be laid upon’

sec.p:
Regarding the encoding, preverbs expressing Goal (14 out of 17), alone or together with Location and Path, are more numerous than those expressing Source (6 out of 17). However, a closer examination of the data reveals that preverbs expressing Source per se are even fewer. Let us first consider dia- ‘through, across, apart’. Its etymology is related to that of the numeral ‘two’: dia- derives from *dis-a ‘in two pieces’, which in turn goes back to *du̯í-s ‘in two times’. As such, it indicates separation in space or time (Chantraine 1999 (1968): 276; Dunkel 2014b: 145 ff.). AG attests to the semantic development ‘in two pieces’ > ‘through’, which can be explained as follows: if one has to go to place1 in time1 and then to place2 in time2 (separation in place or time), the shortest way to do so is probably going through the space dividing place1 from place2. The verb di
-ékhō is interesting in respect to this semantic development, as it exclusively means ‘go in the way of/through’ in Homer (see (20), Il.11.253, 13.520), but also ‘keep apart’ in post-Homeric Greek (21):

list-item.p: ‘(The sharp arrow fled through the armor, it) passed right through.’(Il.5.99–100)
‘The river, as it keeps the streams apart one from another.’ (Hdt.9.51)

sec.p:
In combination with motion verbs, dia- mostly means ‘through’ and indicates Path: di-
érkhomai ‘go/pass through’, dia-
baínō ‘step across’, dia
-trékhō ‘run across’, (post-Homeric) dí
eimi ‘pass through’, and so on. The preverb dia- usually retains its original meaning of separation with verbs implying physical or mental separation (cf. di
-airéō ‘take apart, divide’, dia
-máō ‘cut through’, di
-arpázō ‘tear in pieces’, dia
-phússō ‘draw away’, dia
-skedánnumi ‘scatter abroad’, di
-ístēmi ‘(act.) set apart, (pass.) be divided’, dia
-légō ‘pick out’, dia
-skhíō ‘cleave asunder’, dia
-krínō ‘separate one from another, distinguish’), though not exclusively (cf. dia
-phérō ‘bring through > bring into the way of > differ’).
Another preverb, kata- ‘downwards’, apparently indicates Source in a single Homeric passage:

list-item.p: ‘So saying, she went down from the bright upper chambers.’ (Od.18.206)

sec.p: The motion event described in (22) is inherently directed downwards from the upper chambers. This inherent direction needs no special encoding: the verb itself means ‘go downwards’ and the LM is located ‘upper’ (huperṓïa) with respect to the TR. Thus, the LM is unambiguously the Source of motion. The plural accusative huperṓïa sigalóenta ‘upper chambers’ occurs elsewhere in the Odyssey without prepositions, and always occupies the second half of a hexameter (cf. also Od.16.448, 19.600, 22.428).

list-item.p: ‘So having said, she went up to (her) bright upper chambers.’ (Od.19.600)

sec.p:
Example (23) suggests that in (22) the bard probably manipulated a formula by simply substituting ana-/an- ‘upwards’ with its opposite, i.e. kata- ‘downwards’. This substitution had the side-effect of modifying the meaning of the compound kata
-baínō ‘go downwards > go downwards from’. Furthermore, the plain accusative with kata
-baínō encodes Source only in (23); it usually expresses Goal (cf. Od.2.337) or Path (Od.1.330).15 Crucially, even in contexts that allow for unambiguously inferring the direction of motion, the preverb kata- never indicates Source. This LR is instead specified by a devoted preposition, such as ap’(ó) ‘away from’ in (24):

list-item.p: ‘(He) fell from the deck.’(Od.12.414)

sec.p:
With verbs of falling, such as kata
-píptō, and with upper LMs, such as ikrióphin ‘deck’ in (24), the direction of motion is not ambiguous (Nikitina 2009). As falling implies motion downwards, the LM ikrióphin ‘deck’ (gen.) must play the LR of Source. Nevertheless, in (24) the genitive is specified by the satellite ap’(ó) ‘(away) from’.16
In a number of Homeric passages (see (25), Il.2.154, 2.310), the preverb hupo- in combination with a genitive noun phrase encodes Source:

list-item.p: ‘Goodly Odysseus came forth from beneath the bushes.’ (Od.6.127)

sec.p: In (25) both the genitive (indicating Source) and the preverb hup(o)- (indicating the region of space) contribute to convey the meaning ‘from under’. In contrast, the same compound acquires a different meaning in combination with the accusative case, i.e. ‘slip in under’, as shown in (26):

list-item.p: ‘As she plunged into the bosom of the sea…’ (Od.4.435)

sec.p:
However, the compound hupo
-dúō shows ablatival meaning without a genitive in a single passage from Xenophon:

list-item.p: ‘For the horse is less (likely) to slip from under (the rider) and throw the rider up (off).’ (X.Eq.8.7)

sec.p:
In (27) Xenophon is explaining how a rider should assist the movements of his horse in order to not be thrown off. The rider is named ana
-bátēs, i.e. literally ‘the one who proceeds (being) on (the horse)’ (Chantraine 1999 (1968): 157–158); thus, the horse is located hupó ‘under’ the rider, and when it throws the rider off, it literally ‘slips from under’ ( hupo-
dúō) the rider.
The combination of either the preverb hupo- (28) or the preposition hupó (29) with the genitive must have been already ambiguous in Homer:
‘Zeus takes Hector away from beneath the missiles and the dust, from the man-slaughter and the blood and the din (of the struggle).’ (Il.11.163)

list-item.p: ‘(He) hit him beneath the jaw and (under) the ear.’(Il.16.606)

sec.p: In (28), the LR played by the LMs is clarified by the preposition ek ‘out of’. In (29), the PP hupò gnathmoîo kaì oúatos, in combination with the motion verb bállō ‘throw’, does not indicate Source, but Goal.17 This data is confirmed by the behavior of the preposition hupó in later Greek: after Homer, hupó+genitive no longer expresses Source, as in Example (30), but only Location or Goal (Luraghi 2003: 238).

list-item.p: ‘He suddenly arose from behind the throne.’(Od.22.364)

sec.p: The preverb para- ‘besides’ can encode Source, Goal and Location. However, these LRs are not expressed by para- itself, but depending on the case taken by the compound verb (accordingly, in Table 3 these LRs are shown in brackets). The major involvement of cases in expressing LRs in combination with the preverb para- is consistent with what Luraghi (2003: 131) remarks about the preposition pará. This preposition seems to behave more ‘adverbially’ than the other ones, in that it is not sensitive to the plexity of LMs.18 This feature has a number of consequences. For example, the genitive case with pará/para- is less ambiguous than the genitive with other prepositions/preverbs, as it can only indicate Source (< ablative), and not Location or Goal with discontinuous LMs (< partitive). For this reason, plain genitive occasionally still encodes Source with compounds containing para- in post-Homeric Greek:

list-item.p: ‘If the river has taken away from a man part of (his) land…’ (Hdt.2.109)

sec.p:
In (31), the compound par
-airéō ‘take away from’ takes an animate Source-like argument in the plain genitive, i.e. tinos ‘anyone’.19 By contrast, when the same verbal stem is compounded with ek-, it takes a PP:

list-item.p: ‘As if the Spring would have been taken away from the year.’ (Hdt.7.162)

sec.p:
In conclusion, there turned out to be only two preverbs that per se license Source, i.e. ek- ‘out of’ and apo- ‘away from’. Out of these, ek- normally stack only onto motion verbs, thus expressing Source, whereas apo- can also stack onto state verbs (33), thus encoding Location away from a LM. When ek- is associated with a stative root, such as ékhō ‘have, keep’, it usually gives it a dynamic nuance of meaning: see e.g. the difference between (post-Homeric) ex-
ékhō ‘project from’ (Ar.V.1377), which is a dynamic verb, and ap-
ékhō ‘keep away from’ in (33), which is a static verb.

list-item.p: ‘Apollo kept all defacement (away) from him (his corpse).’ (Il.24.19)

sec.p: In (33), no previous motion is implied: the TR, i.e. aeikeíēn ‘defacement’, was never close to the LM, i.e. toîo ‘him’. Interestingly, the preverb dia-, which can indicate a generic type of separation, also expresses location (cf. (21)).

As Table 3 shows, AG preverbs can often encode both Goal and Location (7 preverbs out of 17), depending on the verbs onto which they stack (motion vs. stative verbs). This polysemy is possible as certain verb classes preferably select certain LRs: motion verbs select Goal, whereas stative verbs select Location. Also, the case taken by the compound verb may also contribute to disambiguate the LRs, as happens with the highly ‘adverbial’ preverb para- ‘beside’ (see above in this Section). However, in combination with satellites not allowing for case variation, verbs are only able to disambiguate the LRs played by the noun phrase, as shown in Table 4.

caption.title: Disambiguation of polysemous preverbs

sec.p:
AG preverbs scarcely attest to a polysemy between Goal and Source, consistently with the typological data (Nikitina 2009; Pantcheva 2010; Zwarts 2010 among others). In AG, this fact arguably also has a functional explanation: the Source–Goal polysemy would not be disambiguated by the nature of the verb, as both Sources and Goals require motion verbs. This polysemy would not be solved by the case of the LM (genitive vs. accusative) either: as seen in Table 2, Greek cases are highly polysemous, due to their historical syncretism. E.g. epi
-baínō ‘go upon’ contains the preverb epi-, which as a preposition combines with the partitive genitive expressing Location and Goal. It can take the plain genitive encoding Goal, as in Example (34):

list-item.p: ‘But on the tenth day we set foot on the Lotus-eaters’ land.’ (Od9.83)

sec.p: However, the plain genitive can also encode Source in combination with compounds containing other preverbs, such as hupo- in (16), para- in (31), apo- in (33), and ek-. Out of these, only hupo- ‘under’ and para- ‘besides’ can express both Goal and Source. However, the ambiguity of hupo- is removed in post-Homeric Greek: hupo- still encodes Source in a single passage from Xenophon (27). The polysemy of para- instead survives longer (see (31)), as it can be solved by case alternation: compounds containing the preverb para- must take a Source genitive (< PIE ablative).

A number of Goal-preverbs also do not encode Location: these are es-/eis-, pros-, ana- and kata-. The preverb es-/eis- is a relatively late formation (< *en- ‘in’ + -s = modal ending), only found in certain Greek dialects including Attic-Ionic (see Chantraine 1999 (1968): 326; Dunkel 2014b: 226 and references therein). In those dialects in which it is attested, this preverb is stacked onto motion verbs, but not onto location verbs.20 It competes with en-, which can stack both onto motion verbs and onto location verbs (Chantraine 1953: 103).21

The preverb pros- occasionally comes to denote Location in post-Homeric Greek: cf. prós-
eimi (pros + eimí ‘be’) ‘be placed by > be added at > be present as well’. Elsewhere, however, it provides the stative verb with a directional nuance: cf. ékhō ‘have, keep’ and pros-
ékhō ‘hold to, offer, bring to’ (cf. the behavior of apo- and ek-, set out above in this Section).

The preverb ana- ‘upwards’ derives from PIE *an-ō, in which -ō is an ancient directive ending (Dunkel 2014a: 154; cf. also kata- < *kat-ō, whose meaning is extensively described above in this Section). However, the preverbs apo- ‘away from’ (<*ap-ō, cf. Dunkel 2014b: 71) and pro- (<*pr-ō,
Dunkel 2014b: 636) contain the same ending -ō and nevertheless encode Location.

sec.title: Source–Goal asymmetry in the grammaticalization of preverbs
sec.p: In this Section, I focus on the diachronic asymmetries found in the grammaticalization process undergone by Source- and Goal-preverbs. As shown below in this Section, Source-preverbs seem to be more grammaticalized than Goal ones, in that they are more obligatory, more easily repeated, and show a stronger tendency to develop actional meanings. Moreover, compounds containing a Source-preverb often take a Goal-participant, whereas the opposite is not attested.

This finding on AG preverbs contradicts the typological tendency (see e.g. Kabata 2013) according to which Goal-markers usually undergo grammaticalization processes more extensively than Source-markers, thus developing a higher number of abstract meanings. However, Imbert (2010) already showed that AG constitutes an exception to this tendency. In her investigation of multiple Homeric Greek preverbs, she writes the following:

disp-quote.p: multiple preverbation constructions involving a [+Goal] morpheme as RelP tend to grammaticalize (and eventually lexicalize) to a much lesser degree than other multiple preverbation constructions. Constructions involving a [+Goal] morpheme tend to occur in [+argument] constituent structure types and, somehow, prevent the loss of the overt expression of the Ground.

sec.p: Even though Imbert’s claim is basically true, the fact that [-Goal] morphemes occur without any overt mention of the LM cannot per se be regarded as a piece of evidence for a more advanced grammaticalization. As mentioned in Section 3, AG preverbs developed from previous free-standing locative adverbs. As such, they were originally not syntactically linked to any linguistic element within the sentence.

Nevertheless, AG data provide other pieces of evidence consistent with Imbert’s claim, as I show below in this Section. First of all, Source-preverbs are more obligatory than Goal-preverbs. Let us consider the behavior of hairéō ‘take’, a verb that requires a Source-participant.

list-item.p: ‘(A cap) that Autolycus at a time stole out of Eleon.’ (Il.10.266–267)
‘The other one took out of the quiver a sharp arrow.’ (Il.8.323)
‘But now, when he had taken from my hands (my) prize…’ (Il.9.344)
‘And once he had taken by the hand fair-cheeked Briseis, he led her…’ (Il.1.323)

sec.p:
On the one hand, Examples (35) and (36) include the compound verb ex
-airéō ‘take out’. The Source-participant is encoded by a PP with ex in (35) and by a plain genitive in (36). On the other hand, Examples (37) and (38) contain the plain verb hairéō, which takes a PP with ek in (37), while taking a plain genitive in (38). The participants encoded by the plain genitive play different semantic roles in (37) and (38). In (36) pharétrēs ‘from (the) quiver’ is a Source-like participant, whereas in (38) kheiròs ‘by hand’ is the partitive genitive of Briseis’ body part, by which the subject comes into contact with her. The presence of a Source-satellite, in the function either of preverb (36), of preposition (37), or both of them (35) disambiguates the meaning of the genitive.23

In other passages lacking a Source-satellite, the plain genitive encodes Location, rather than Source. This is shown by the comparison between Examples (39)–(40) on the one hand, and (41) on the other hand.

list-item.p: ‘As (they) washed the black blood away from the wounds…’(Od.24.189)
‘When the wave of the sea had washed away the abundant sweat from their skin.’ (Il.10.574–575)
‘As (he) had washed (his) hands in the grey sea…’ (Od.2.261)

sec.p: In (39), two Source-satellites, i.e. the preverb apo- ‘away from’ and the preposition ex ‘out of’, contribute to the disambiguation of the genitive ōteiléōn ‘wound’. The preposition apó ‘away from’ has the same function in (40). In (41), the plain genitive poliês halòs ‘grey sea’ occurs without any satellite, thus playing the semantic role of Location (or Instrument), in which hands are washed.

The plain genitive can also encode Goal in combination with some motion verbs, including érkhomai ‘go, come’ (44), in spite of the fact that the semantics of this verb does not require a specific locative participant, neither Source nor Goal.

list-item.p: ‘I went away from my native land.’(Il.24.766)
‘(You dared) to go out of the wall.’ (Il.22.237)
‘They march toward the plain to fight against the city.’ (Il.2.801)

sec.p:
In case the plain genitive is taken by a compound verb containing a Source-satellite, such as ap
-érkhomai ‘go/come away from’ in (42) and ex
-érkhomai ‘go/come out of’ in (43), it plays the LR of Source. By contrast, with no Source-satellites, the plain genitive functions as a Goal, as shown in (44).24

By contrast, compare Examples (42)–(44) above with (45)–(48) below. Examples (45)–(48) are intended to show how the Goal is expressed in combination with the verb érkhomai ‘go/come’, both modified (45)–(46) and non-modified (47)–(48) by a Goal-satellite:

list-item.p: ‘He entered the chamber.’ (Od.4.802)
‘If you, after entering within the gates and the high walls…’ (Il.4.34)
‘(I send that man forth to the swift ships,) to go to Achilles.’ (Il.17.709)
‘…before that you had gone again to the waters of Egypt.’ (Od.4.478)

sec.p: On the one hand, the first three passages above include the Goal-satellite eis ‘to’, either as a preverb (46), as a preposition (47), or both (45). On the other hand, Example (48) contains no Goal-satellites. Nevertheless, the plain accusative unambiguously expresses Goal in (48), despite referring to a non-prototypical locative entity (húdōr ‘water’). To sum up, whereas the plain genitive with érkhomai does not encode Source without further Source-satellites (i.e. the Source-satellites are obligatory), plain accusative does encode Goal, even without any additional Goal-satellite (i.e. Goal-satellites are not obligatory).

In Homeric Greek, the satellite en ‘in(to)’ sometimes encodes Goal as well as Location. Interestingly, en shows the same behavior as that just set out for eis/es ‘into’. This is exemplified in combination with the verb bállō ‘send, throw’, a motion verb requiring a Goal-participant, in passages from (49) to (51):

list-item.p: ‘And (she) would have sent me unseen into the sea from heaven.’ (Il.14.258)
‘And (each man) threw (his lot) into the helmet of Agamemnon.’ (Il.7.176)
‘(The one) who, after marking it (his lot), had thrown it into the helmet.’ (Il.7.187)

sec.p: In particular, Example (51) shows that the presence of the Goal-satellite en is not compulsory: the dative kunéēi‘into (the) helmet’ alone can express Goal.25

Source-preverbs, such as ex- in (52), are sometimes repeated as Source-adpositions even in Homer, whereas Goal-preverbs, such as eis- in (53) and (54), are usually repeated only since post-Homeric Greek.

list-item.p: ‘…until (your) craft led you out of the cave, as you were thinking you would have died.’ (Od.20.21)
‘Idomeneus brought to Crete all (his) comrades.’ (Od.3.191)
‘As they brought (me) into the large room,…’ (Hdt.2.143)

sec.p:
Examples (52)–(54) contain the same verbal stem, i.e. that of ágō ‘lead’. In (52) ágō is compounded with a Source-preverb, i.e. ex- ‘out of’, which is repeated as a preposition in the phrase ex
ántroio ‘out of the cave’. By contrast, in (53) and (54) the compound includes a Goal-preverb, which is not repeated in Homer (53), but only in later authors, such as Herodotus (54).26
Usually, compounds containing a Source-preverb or a Goal-preverb accordingly take a Source-participant (a) or a Goal-participant (b):

list-item.p: Preverbg -Verb Participantg .

sec.p: However, in case there is a mismatch between the LR expressed by the preverb and that played by the verbal participant, compounds containing a Source-preverb can take a Goal-participant (c), whereas the opposite is not attested (d):

list-item.p:
Preverbs -Verb Participantg
(see Examples (55) and (56))
*Preverbg -Verb Participants.
‘(The ship) that had carried Protesilaus to Troy, but did not bring (him) back (from Troy) again to his native land…’ (Il.15.706)
‘Meanwhile Hector caught his breath, and leaping back into (his) wagon he drove it (away from the battle) forth into the crowd, (and avoided the black fate.)’ (Il.11.359–360)

sec.p: Source-participants are more likely to be omitted than Goal-participants, because they are usually less informative than Goals, as well as less useful for the complete conceptualization of a spatial event (Ungerer & Schmidt 1996). This Source-over-Goal principle has also been interpreted in psychological terms as follows: “[any human activity] involves human volition and we tend to be far more interested in the goal of the action than in the source of the action. Therefore, when human action is involved, goal is far more salient than source” (Verspoor, Dirven & Radden 1999: 98). In examples above, Sources seem to be omitted because they are active in the discourse, thanks to the linguistic (55) or extra-linguistic context (56). In (55), the Source is mentioned in the immediately preceding discourse (Troíēn ‘Troy’). Thus, the preverb ap- arguably establishes an anaphoric reference to it.28 In (56), instead, the Source can be inferred from the context: Hector is escaping death by Achilles’ hands, by driving his wagon away from the battle (the Source) toward the crowd. Thus, Examples (55) and (56) show how Source-preverbs are more prone than Goal-preverbs to refer to previously mentioned elements (55), or to participants that are familiar to speaker’s encyclopedic knowledge (56). This can be regarded as a further piece of evidence for their grammaticalization: as demonstrated by Viti (2008a), one of the reasons for the grammaticalization of AG preverbs is their ability to refer to anaphoric, topical and non-salient referents.

Source-preverbs, rather than Goal-preverbs, modify locative and non-locative verbal roots, already adding aspectual information in Homer (Chantraine 1953: 93, 97). The telic value of apo- and ek- (cf. ek
diabaínō ‘pass quite over’, ex
anabaínō ‘get to the top of’, ek
thnḗiskō ‘die away’, ek
pínō ‘drink up’, ex
akéomai ‘heal completely’, ap
óllumi ‘destroy utterly’, apo
thnḗiskō ‘die away’, ap
anúō ‘finish entirely’ exapo
tínō ‘satisfy in full’ and so on) can be grounded as follows: events can be conceptualized as paths; then, the ending of an event could be understood as the ending of a path. Interestingly, univerbation to the verbal stem is not necessary for Source-preverbs to convey telic meanings:

list-item.p: ‘After that the gods themselves totally destroyed your purposes.’ (Il.7.360)

sec.p: In (57), no ablative meaning can be ascribed to ex ‘(lit.) out of’, which occurs in the initial position. Rather, ex provides óllumi ‘destroy’ with telic actionality.

The preverb dia-, which conveys a generic idea of separation, also developed telic meanings, especially in combination with consumption verbs (e.g. di
óllumi ‘destroy utterly’). The aspectual meaning of dia- is even clearer in a compound such as dia
mígnumi ‘mix up’ (post-Homeric): the meaning of mígnumi ‘mix’ is not consistent with the idea of separation conveyed by dia- in its concrete usages.

The Goal-preverbs ana- and kata- also show actional meanings (Chantraine 1953: 90, 112). Ana- develops inchoative or iterative actionality (cf. phaínō ‘be manifest’ vs. ana
phaínō ‘appear, reappear’). Instead, the actional meanings developed by kata- can be traced back to its Path-value: in the same way that Path is essentially atelic (Luraghi 2014: 103), kata- can emphasize the duration of an action (cf. légō ‘say’ vs. kata
légō ‘tell, narrate’; ékhō ‘hold’ vs. kat
ékhō ‘hold back’). However, kata- can also convey telic meanings, mainly with verbs of passing away or killing ( kata
thnḗiskō ‘die’, kata
kteínō ‘kill’).

sec.title: Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: In this paper I simultaneously analyzed the synchronic and diachronic aspects of Source–Goal asymmetry from the point of view of AG preverbs. In particular, I showed that AG preverbs present a number of synchronic Source–Goal asymmetries, which only partly seem to be consistent with the typological findings on the matter (cf. Section 4). As expected, Goal is expressed by a larger number of preverbs than Source, and it is often associated with Location. The occurrence of locative or motion verbs with Goal/Location-satellites disambiguates the meaning of the satellites. I also showed that the only preverbs that per se encode Source are apo- ‘away from’ and ek ‘out of’. The former also expresses Location, whereas the latter usually provides verbal roots with dynamic meanings. Interestingly, a number of Goal-preverbs do not also express Location.

I have also pointed out a diachronic asymmetry (cf. Section 5) between Sources and Goals. Namely, much evidence suggests that Source- preverbs are more advanced in their grammaticalization processes than Goal-preverbs. Even in Homeric Greek – a variety in which locative adverbs have not fully undergone grammaticalization process into preverbs or adposition – Source-preverbs are more obligatory, more easily repeated, and show a stronger tendency to develop actional meanings. Moreover, compounds containing a Source-preverb often take a Goal-participant, whereas the opposite is not attested.

These Source–Goal asymmetries, including those involving the grammaticalization of preverbs, can be explained both cognitively and functionally. Goal-expressions are often said to be more stable than Source-expressions because of the Goal-bias in human cognition. This bias was observed in several psycholinguistic studies, concerning both linguistic comprehension (e.g. Freeman, Sinha & Stedmon 1981) and linguistic production (e.g. Lakusta & Landau 2005). It has been explained in various ways, including the following:

list-item.p: Goal is usually more important than Source for human actions, as it involves human volition (Ikegami 1987; Verspoor, Dirven & Radden 1999);
Goal is more informative than Source, as it is more useful for the complete conceptualization of a motion event (Ungerer & Schmidt 1996; cf. Section 5).

sec.p:
However, generalizations of the kind just outlined often raise a number of issues. First, as remarked in Section 5, other relevant works seem to point towards a different direction: Kabata (2013), for example, argues that it is normally Goal-markers that more extensively develop abstract meanings. Moreover, it is difficult to assume asymmetries similar to those of AG for other languages in which spatial satellites undergo grammaticalization processes becoming markers of actionality; see English and German, in which not only Source-satellites can mark the endpoint of an event: aus-
trinken ‘drink up (lit. ‘out’)’, auf
-essen ‘eat up’, write down / up .29

This points to the demand for a functional, diachronic, and language-specific explanation. As shown in Section 3, the AG genitive is a syncretic case, resulting from the merging of PIE ablative and genitive cases. This syncretism made the genitive case highly polysemous: as far as LRs are concerned, it can encode Source, Location and Goal. In parallel, the accusative, which can express both Goal and Path, is also polysemous, but to a lesser extent than the genitive. Moreover, the polysemy of the accusative is less problematic than that of the genitive case, as it puts together only Goal and Path. Among LRs, Path is normally regarded as marginal; furthermore, Path shares semantic properties with Goal (see the discussion of Example (11)).

In contrast, the genitive case has come to encompass both Source and Goal (besides Location), that is, two LRs that tend to receive separated encodings (cf. Nikitina 2009; Pantcheva 2010; Zwarts 2010; see further Lestrade 2010: 104, who writes that “the syncretism pattern between Goal and Source is a semantically unmotivated diachronic accident”). From this perspective, the earlier grammaticalization undergone by Source-preverbs can be understood as a means of disambiguating plain genitives, thus keeping Sources distinct from Goals. A further piece of evidence in favor of this explanation is the behavior of compounds containing para-, which still take the plain genitive in post-Homeric Greek. As mentioned in Section 4, pará as a preposition is not sensitive to the plexity of LMs, and only takes the ablatival genitive. Thus, the genitive with para- is less ambiguous with respect to the encoding of LRs, and as such may continue to express Source per se.

As this paper only takes into account the spatial and the actional meanings of AG preverbs (partially discussed in Section 5), it could be of interest to focus on the whole range of abstract meanings developed by AG preverbs in order to check whether such an asymmetry, which contradicts the findings by Kabata (2013), receives further confirmation.

fn.p: Throughout the discussion of the usages of plain cases, I also included some examples from traditional grammars (e.g. Delbrück 1879; Chantraine 1953).

In glosses, the nominal number is specified only if it is plural or dual (singular is not indicated), gender is not indicated unless it is feminine or neuter. Among verbal categories, indicative mood and active voice are likewise not indicated.

In (3) the subscript G indicates that the preverb em- expresses the Goal of motion, while the subscript i draws an anaphorical reference with démni’(a). In other examples, subscribed S and P mean Source and Path. Subscribed ?, instead, means that the LR is under discussion.

In (4), it is not clear whether ek should be associated with the preceding or the following genitive case. The fact that Ancient Greek mainly has prepositions would speak in favor of pétrēs ‘rock’. However, other factors suggest that ek is linked to hormathoû ‘chain’: first, in Homeric Greek, place words could also be postposed to the noun phrase that they modify; second, the elative value of ek is more suitable with a LM such as hormathoû ‘chain’, than with a LM such as pétrēs ‘rock’.

As is well-known (cf. Section 3 and references therein), the grammaticalization process undergone by locative adverbs led to a functional bifurcation: they either developed into preverbs or into prepositions in Classical Greek. Here, I focus on the kind of grammaticalization process undergone by preverbs, as they are the topic of this paper.

This summary does not aim to be exhaustive. My point here is to show which portion of spatial meaning is conveyed by verbs, which one by satellites, and which one by cases in AG. For a comprehensive description, I refer to Chantraine (1953) and Luraghi (2003).

On the deictic and non-deictic usages of érkhomai, see Létoublon (1985). This verb became deictic in Modern Greek (Ricca 1993). The PIE root for eîmi is non-deictic: *h1ei- ‘walk, move, go’. The subsequent rise of deictic verbs of coming and going likely goes back to the aspectual opposition between the present root *h1ei- indicating motion per se, and the aorist root *gwem- implying a definite goal (Buck 1949: 693).
On the distinction between grammatical and concrete usages of cases, see Kuryłowicz (1964).

It is disputed whether the Goal meaning of the AG dative was inherited from the PIE dative proper (thus contributing to the reconstruction of an original allative value for the PIE dative), or extended from the PIE locative (see Luraghi 2003: 339, fn. 5).
Even in Homer, this compound occasionally takes a PP with ek (Il.13.17) or a Source-adverb in -then (Il.11.184). See also Example (22), in which the same verb shows a different meaning.

Though change of configuration verbs often combine with static Locations, as shown by Nikitina (2013), the context suggests that the plain partitive genitive purkaïês ‘(lit.) of pyre’ actually expresses Goal in (18). Here, the Acheans are described while collecting corpses and firewood and bringing them upon the pyre to be burnt.
Discontinuous LMs/TRs are constituted by more than one entity, whereas continuous ones are only made up by a single entity. This feature of LMs and TRs in called plexity by Talmy (1988).
For its etymology I refer to Neri (2013), whereas for the etymologies of all other preverbs I refer to Chantraine (1999 (1968)), Beekes (2010), Dunkel (2014b) and references therein.
Contrary to what an anonymous reviewer suggested, I did not include a column for cases in Table 3, as my purpose here is to show which LRs are encoded by preverbs per se.

In post-Homeric Greek the verb kata
-baínō takes a PP with katá+genitive expressing Path (e.g. Lys. 1.9) (see further the discussion on the ongoing grammaticalization of satellites in Section 2.3 and in Section 3).
As Tatiana Nikitina pointed out (p.c.), interestingly, the behavior of the preverb corresponds to that of the preposition.

As discussed for kata-/katá (see fn. 16) and for para-/pará below in this Section, it is interesting to notice that the preverb and the corresponding preposition show similar behaviors. This is arguably due to the fact that neither preverbs nor prepositions were fully developed in Homeric Greek yet, thus they were still comparable.
See fn. 12.
The genitive tinos should be interpreted as a Source rather than as a Possessor, as the latter type of genitive usually occurs in between the article and the noun expressing the Possessee.

Es-/eis- does not exclusively stack onto motion verbs: it is also attested to in combination with stative verbs not related to spatial relations, such as eis
-noéō ‘perceive’ (cf. noéō ‘perceive, think’).
See Nikitina & Maslov (2013) on the expanding use of the preposition eis/es+accusative encoding Goal at the expenses of en+dative.

By RelP, Imbert (2010) means ‘relational preverbs’, i.e., preverbs that morphologically behave as actual preverbs (i.e. as clitics), but syntactically as adpositions, and, as such, are able to govern the case of the verbal argument. Within a sequence of stacked preverbs, she regards the most external one as relational, as she argues that multiple preverbs have undergone grammaticalization processes from previous postpositions. For a totally different view on multiple preverbs, see Zanchi (2014).

See also ex-
ágō ‘lead out/away’ vs. ágō ‘lead’: the plain genitive with ágō is not an ablatival genitive, but a partitive one (see Od.3.439).

Within my corpus, other relevant passages are Il.5.597, 13.191 (with eîmi ‘go, come’), 10.257, 10.261 (with títhēmi ‘put’), 13.650 (with híēmi ‘send’), Od.2.224 (with khéō ‘pour’), Od.2.416, 15.284 (with anabaínō ‘step upwards’).

The previous discussion does not imply that plain genitive never encodes Source in Homer in combination with non-compound verbs. Actually, this rarely happens with verbs selecting a Source-participant (such as pheúgō ‘escape’ and lúō ‘loosen’) and assigning the genitive case (see Nikitina & Maslov 2013 on the so-called constructio praegnans).

In Homeric poems, the Source-preverbs ek- and apo- are also repeated in Il. 3.265, 5.257, 8.492, 2.690, 7.336, 7.435, 9.331, 10.95, 17.188, 24.459, Od. 8.106, 8.279, 24.7, and 24.189. The Goal preverb eis- is repeated only in Il.21.610 and Od.4.802.
See Boley (2004: 56–58) on the anaphoric value of Indo-European preverbs.

However, Slavic languages, in which preverbs have fully undergone grammaticalization processes into markers of perfectivity, seem to confirm the Source–Goal asymmetry identified for AG (Peter Arkadiev p.c.). As Dickey (2012: 84) points out: “It is interesting that many of the productive perfectivizing prefixes in Slavic are originally source prefixes.”

title-group.title: A diachronic take on the Source–Goal asymmetry
title-group.subtitle: Evidence from inner Asia Minor Greek

abstract.p: A bulk of typological and crosslinguistic evidence on the internal structure of motion events has shown that Goals and Sources behave asymmetrically. Such an asymmetry exhibits several morphosyntactic and semantic realizations: Goal markers are morphologically simpler than Source markers; there tend to be more fine-grained semantic distinctions within the Goal domain than within the Source domain, leading to higher numbers for the encoding of Goal than of Source (type level); Goals are more frequently zero-marked than Sources; and, Goal relations are encoded more frequently in discourse (token level). In this chapter, we report similar imbalances in the behavior of Sources and Goals in inner Asia Minor Greek. We find that Goal markers are more numerous than markers denoting Source and that Goal paths are more often explicitly expressed in discourse. Additionally, we test the diachronic validity of such findings, which have been reached on the basis of mostly synchronic investigations, by examining the historical developments that the Modern Greek dialects of inner Asia Minor underwent in the formal expression of Goal and Source. We analyze the (a)symmetrical relations that hold between the two locative roles as evidenced by the qualitative and quantitative use of the prepositions se ‘to, at’, os ‘up to, until’, tʃax/tʃaus ‘up to, until’, and apo ‘from’, focusing specifically on the implications that the diachronic loss of se, the most frequent Goal marker, had for the spatial system of inner Asia Minor Greek. Our analysis shows that Goal markers remain morphologically less complex than Source markers across diachronic stages; and, that the Goal marker develops into zero marker earlier than the Source marker. These findings support the Goal-over-Source predominance hypothesis. However, our analysis also indicates that the asymmetry could under certain circumstances work in the opposite direction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The fact that Goals and Sources of motion behave asymmetrically has drawn sustained interest from numerous linguists. Most studies to date report a prevalence of Goal over Source (see, among others, Ikegami 1987; Lakusta 2005; Lakusta & Landau 2005; Papafragou 2010) and this prevalence exhibits several morphosyntactic and semantic realizations. More specifically, it has been shown that Goal markers are crosslinguistically less complex from a morphological point of view than Source markers (see Stolz et al. 2014: 22 ff.). On the syntactic level, it has been proposed that Goal paths are more likely to be core arguments, while Source paths are more likely to behave like peripheral arguments (or adjuncts; Nam 2004; but see Gehrke 2008). A further manifestation of the asymmetry is evident in the detail with which speakers describe motion events, tending to include Goal paths in their descriptions but to omit Source paths (Lakusta & Landau 2005). This tendency has been confirmed by a recent corpus study focusing on non-prototypical motion events, namely, on transitive motion events that encode change of possession (Georgakopoulos & Sioupi 2015). On the semantic level, one major indication supporting the prevalence of Goals over Sources shows up in crosslinguistic patterns of polysemy in the marking of spatial relations. For example, identical encoding of Place and Goal markers is more frequently attested than identical encoding of Place and Source markers, which reflects the fact that Places are semantically closer to Goals than to Sources (Nikitina 2009; Lestrade 2010; Pantcheva 2010; cf. Luraghi 2014).

Another piece of evidence corroborating the general tendency of languages to give priority to Goals comes from Stolz et al.’s (2014) work, which has shown that Goals are more frequently zero-marked than Sources. Stolz et al. propose that, when it comes to the Goal argument of motion events, the expectations that either the speaker or the hearer have in their interaction determine its realization. The Goal function has to be explicitly expressed, but not necessarily with an overt marker. This scenario opens the way for the Goal becoming a zero-marked member of the spatial relation paradigm. Conversely, the speaker and the hearer do not develop similar expectations regarding the expression of the Source argument of motion events. As a consequence, it does not suffice to mention the Source location alone without an overt marker.

However, most studies, both those that focus on overt markers and those that examine zero markers, have addressed the phenomenon of the Source–Goal asymmetry from a synchronic perspective (see, though, Georgakopoulos 2013; Kabata 2013; Nikitina 2014; Nikitina & Spano 2014), thus overlooking a crucial dimension which, we believe, can significantly enrich our understanding of the factors underlying the asymmetrical behavior of the different Path elements. In this chapter, we address this shortcoming by investigating the types of innovations that the marking of Goals and Sources can undergo over time and the implications that diachronic rearrangements within a spatial system can have for the preservation of polysemic patterns in the expression of spatial relations.

The chapter is organized as follows: after briefly presenting the historical and linguistic profile of the dialects under examination (Section 2), we outline our theoretical and terminological background (Section 3). We then proceed to the analysis of the various manifestations of the Source–Goal asymmetry in the iAMGr dialects on the basis of both qualitative and quantitative criteria. In our investigation, we mainly focus on the loss of the inherited Goal-marking preposition se from the prepositional inventory of three iAMGr varieties and the repercussions it had for the (a)symmetrical relation between Sources and Goals in terms of markedness and complexity (Sections 4 and 5). We finally discuss our main findings as well as the implications of this study (Section 6).

sec.title: The inner Asia Minor Greek dialect group and the diatopy-as-diachrony method
sec.p: The iAMGr dialect group consists of three distinct dialects that were spoken by the Orthodox Christian population of a number of Greek-speaking enclaves in the historical provinces of Cappadocia and Lycaonia, in the south-eastern part of today’s Turkey: (a) Cappadocian, which was spoken in twenty villages dispersed between the towns of Nevşehir, Kayseri, and Niğde; (b) Pharasiot, which was spoken in the village of Phárasa and another five surrounding villages to the east of Niğde; and, (c) Silliot, which was spoken in the village of Sílli in the environs of the town of Konya. The three dialects were spoken in their respective locations until 1924, when Greece and Turkey undertook the exchange of populations stipulated by the Convention Concerning the Exchange of Greek and Turkish Populations, which had been signed in Lausanne on 30 January 1923. After the exchange, iAMGr speakers relocated to central and northern Greece. At present, only a few Cappadocian and Pharasiot varieties are spoken natively but are on their way to extinction.

All three dialects are known in the linguistics literature thanks to the exceptionally high number of contact-induced features found in all levels of grammar, besides the lexicon, as a result of the intense language contact with Turkish in which the three dialects developed for over eight centuries (Dawkins 1916; Thomason & Kaufman 1988; Janse 2002, 2007, 2009; Johanson 2002; Winford 2005). More recently, however, an increasing number of scholars have started to focus on phenomena of diachronic change that cannot be exclusively attributed to the influence of Turkish. Rather, historical evidence preceding the onset of contact between iAMGr and Turkish and other, structural types of evidence suggest that many diachronic changes were caused by a combination of language-internal and external factors (Dressler & Acson 1985; Janse 1999, 2003; Karatsareas 2009, 2011a, 2011b, 2013, 2014, 2016a, 2016b; Markopoulos 2014; Bağrıaçık 2016; Melissaropoulou 2016; Pantelidis 2016).

Research into the diachrony of iAMGr has benefited from the fact that the different dialects, and – in certain cases – even different varieties of the same dialect, often represent chronologically distinct stages in the development of specific diachronic innovations. The fact that some dialects are more conservative while others are more innovative compensates for the scantiness of the historical record of iAMGr in the period before the mid-19th century, when the first reliable sources begin to appear. It allows us to treat the different dialects (and varieties) as distinct diachronic stages and to compare them in reconstructing the origin and subsequent development of change. In other words, it allows us to treat diatopy as diachrony.

The development of the markers used to encode Goal and Source in iAMGr lends itself to the application of the diatopy-as-diachrony method. The different dialects and varieties can be classified into three groups based on the means they use to mark Goal, Place and Source (cf. Karatsareas & Georgakopoulos 2016):

list-item.p: Conservative or Stage I varieties, in which Goal and Place are syncretically marked by the inherited preposition se whereas Source is marked by reflexes of the inherited preposition apo. This group includes all Cappadocian varieties, with the exception of Phloïtá and Ulaghátsh Cappadocian, and Pharasiot.

Intermediate or Stage II varieties, in which Goal and Place are syncretically marked either by se or zero, the distribution of which is syntagmatically conditioned in the sense of Stolz et al. (2014), whereas Source is marked by reflexes of apo. This group includes Phloïtá Cappadocian and Silliot.
Innovative or Stage III varieties, in which Goal and Place are syncretically marked by zero whereas Source is marked by reflexes of apo. Only Ulaghátsh Cappadocian is found in this group.

sec.p: Our subsequent discussion and analysis is based on this classification. We first examine the various manifestations of the Source–Goal asymmetry in Stage I varieties and then turn to how these are affected by the loss of se in Stage II and Stage III varieties. Before that, however, in Section 3 we give the basics of our theoretical and terminological background.

sec.title: Theoretical and terminological background
sec.p: We are primarily concerned with the spatial information that is expressed by means of linguistic elements other than the verb such as adpositions and adverbs. In the domain of localization, such linguistic elements as adpositions describe the relation between a localized entity, the Figure, and the location at which this entity is found, termed Ground (Talmy 1985, 2000). The spatial relation between the Figure and the Ground could be either static or dynamic. The notion of Place describes static relations. In dynamic relations, a distinction is made between starting points (spatial relation: Source or Ablative), median points (spatial relation: Path or Perlative), and ending points (spatial relation: Goal or Allative; see Jackendoff 1983, 1990; also Fillmore 1971). These distinctions are illustrated in (1).

sec.p: Our attention is drawn to Goal and Source relations, which are the most frequent dynamic relations in iAMGr. Details about the relevant inventories are given in Section 4. Suffice to mention at this point that the approach adopted in the present study allows the inclusion in the inventories of both phonologically realized and unrealized markers, that is, both overt and zero markers.

Stolz et al. (2014: 39) distinguish between two types of spatial zeroes: syntagmatic and paradigmatic. Syntagmatic zeroes occur as a result of a choice speakers make to use the linguistic expression referring to a spatial relation bare, that is, without an overtly realized marker. This choice is conditioned by grammatical, semantic or pragmatic factors. For example, in Maltese, the preposition fi marks both Place and Goal but can be optionally omitted with toponyms, preferably when they are Goals, and with common nouns that refer generically (2a); when common nouns are used with a specific referent in mind, fi is preferably used (2b). Paradigmatic zeroes, on the other hand, have no overt alternative. In Egyptian Arabic, Goal-encoding NPs appear bare in all contexts regardless of their grammatical, semantic or pragmatic properties (3).

sec.title: Source–Goal (a)symmetry in inner Asia Minor Greek
Manifestations of (a)symmetry
sec.p: In what follows, we examine the (a)symmetrical relations between Source and Goal in iAMGr with reference to the following three criteria:

list-item.p: The formal complexity of the markers used to express each of the two relations.
The number of markers used to express each of the two relations.
The quantitative distribution of expressions encoding each of the two relations.

sec.p: We drew our data from two sources: (a) grammatical descriptions of iAMGr (Costakis 1964; Dawkins 1916; Fates 2012; Fosteris & Kesisoglou 1960; Kesisoglou 1951; Kostakis 1968; Mavrochalyvidis & Kesisoglou 1960), and (b) a corpus consisting of all the known published texts in Cappadocian and Silliot. The corpus is divided into the following three subcorpora based on Karatsareas and Georgakopoulos’s (2016) classification of the iAMGr dialects into three groups with respect to the preservation or innovation of the inherited preposition se to mark Goal and Place and apo to mark Source (see Section 2):

list-item.p: the Stage I subcorpus, which includes the conservative iAMGr dialects and varieties: Delmesó, Ferték, Araván, Ghúrzono, Mistí, Axó, Malakopí, Sílata, and Potámia Cappadocian. The relevant texts are published in Dawkins (1916: 304–346, 384–408, 440–464);

the Stage II subcorpus, which includes the intermediate iAMGr dialects and varieties: Phloïtá Cappadocian and Silliot. The relevant texts are published in Dawkins (1916: 284–304, 410–441) and Kostakis (1968: 116–130);
the Stage III subcorpus, which includes the innovative iAMGr dialect: Ulaghátsh Cappadocian. The relevant texts are published in Dawkins (1916: 346–384).

fn.p: The frequencies of the adverbs that encode the spatial regions interior, superior, inferior, and anterior follow a certain hierarchical pattern, which is consistent with asymmetries found in the Greek diachrony, as well as with asymmetries reported in psycholinguistic studies (see Skopeteas 2008 for Ancient Greek; Goutsos 2007 for Modern Greek; Johnston & Slobin 1979 for psycholinguistic evidence). More specifically, the following hierarchy is detected: interior > superior > inferior > anterior. The difference between interior and superior is significant, nint (89)> nsuper(60), χ2 (1) = 5,26, p < .05; the difference between superior and inferior only marginally approaches significance, nsuper(60) > ninfer(40), χ2 (1) = 3,62 p = .057; and the difference between inferior and anterior is not significant, ninfer(40)> nanter(37), χ2 (1) = 0.06, n.s. The numbers are not large enough to enable us to draw definite conclusions from these differences, but they, nevertheless, show a clear tendency.

sec.p: The majority of the postpositional elements in Table 3 can combine with both apo and se in expressing Source and Goal relations, respectively. Still though, as was the case with the prepositional elements, Goal-denoting combinations exceed Source-encoding combinations in number. Interestingly, apo sometimes combines with a simple postpositional element resulting in a more complex one without necessarily yielding an ablative meaning. Consider, for example, apokáto. In (12), apokáto takes part in an allative relation whereas in (13) it participates in a locative one depending on the occurring verb (static vs. motion verb). The ablative meaning is possible when such elements are further accompanied by the Source preposition apo as in (14).
