sec.p: To this point, we have analyzed the differences between Sources and Goals on the type level. We now turn to the investigation of the behavior of the two Path components on the token level. We measured the distribution of Source and Goal expressions accompanying motion verbs in our Stage I subcorpus. Overall, 394 token clauses of both adpositional phrase types, Prepositional Phrase and Circumpositional Phrase, were collected. The distribution of Sources and Goals in the subcorpus is presented in Table 4 and Table 5.

caption.title: The frequency distribution of Source and Goal in Stage I
The frequency distribution of Source and Goal per phrasal type in Stage I

sec.p: The distinction between Prepositional Phrases and Circumpositional Phrases does not play a role in the frequency distribution of the two Path types in the Stage I subcorpus or in any of the other subcorpora, for that matter. The statistical analysis of the token clauses reveals that there was no significant association between the type of phrase and whether Source or Goal is used (p = .55). On the contrary, when taken together, the frequency distribution of Sources differs from the frequency distribution of Goals. According to a chi-squared goodness-of-fit test, the frequency distribution of the two Path types significantly deviates from the expected one (χ 2(1) = 183.66; p < .0001): Goal expressions with motion verbs were observed 332 times although they were expected 197 times (the total 394 tokens divided by 2), and Source expressions with motion verbs were observed 72 times. In sum, the qualitative and quantitative investigation of the whole set of Stage I adpositional phrases – be it of the simple, prepositional or of the complex, circumpositional type – reveals that the system is more complex in the Goal domain: the Goal inventory is richer than the Source inventory and Goals are more frequent than Sources in discourse. The former finding is a symptom of the priority of Goal over Source as it reflects the need for neater distinctions in descriptions of Goal relations. Similar imbalances have been reported in recent literature for several languages. In Polish, for example, speakers draw upon a larger pool of markers in the expression of placement (i.e., Goal-oriented) events than in the expression of removal (i.e., Source-oriented) events and even use Source-oriented prefixes for the former (Kopecka 2012: 343; see also Landau & Zukowski 2003: 130–131). The latter finding is also in line with the tendency of motion verbs co-occurring more frequently with Goal rather than Source expressions in discourse (see the conclusions drawn in Stefanowitsch & Rohde’s 2004 corpus study; cf. Georgakopoulos & Sioupi 2015 for events that express non-prototypical dislocation).

sec.title: Source–Goal (a)symmetry in Stage II and Stage III varieties
sec.p: Despite the differences highlighted in Section 4.2, Source and Goal markers do not differ in morphological complexity in the conservative Stage I varieties. On the contrary, in Phloïtá Cappadocian and Silliot, the intermediate Stage II varieties, an innovation emerges in the use of the Goal-marking preposition se, signaling the beginning of the differentiation of Goals and Sources in terms of complexity.

In these two varieties, the expression of Goal fluctuates between the use of the overt marker se and zero marking; see (15).Apo continues the state of affairs that we described for Stage I in being always overtly expressed in marking Source (16).

sec.p: The crucial development takes place in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian, in which se has been completely lost from the prepositional inventory (Dawkins 1916: 83; Kesisoglou 1951: 54; Karatsareas & Georgakopoulos 2016). The innovation is found in both Goal- and Place-encoding utterances, and has affected both syntactic contexts in which se was originally used, that is, in Prepositional Phrases and in Circumpositional Phrases. This results in two novel syntactic ways for the expression of the two spatial relations: bare, accusative-marked NPs of the type [NPACC] and Postpositional Phrases of the type [NPACC + postposition]. Source relations remain expressed by Prepositional Phrases or Circumpositional Phrases introduced by apo; see (18) and (19).

caption.title: The prepositional inventory of Ulaghátsh Cappadocian

sec.p: The loss of se in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian, however, does affect the asymmetrical behavior of Source and Goal. By being marked by zero, the expression of Goal becomes morphologically less complex than the expression of Source, which remains overtly marked by the as and ap reflexes of apo. In Stage I dialects, Goal and Source exhibit the same degree of markedness (equal complexity), whereas, in Stage III Ulaghátsh Cappadocian, Source and Goal differ in markedness (unequal complexity).

The Ulaghátsh Cappadocian case shows that the directionality of change can have a clear vector, which is determined by the position Goal and Source occupy on the markedness hierarchy (Goal is positioned higher than Source in the hierarchy): if a change from overt marking to zero takes place that disrupts the balance in morphological complexity, this will first and foremost affect Goals, since Goal occupies a higher rank on the hierarchy than Source. The transition from balance to imbalance in the degree of markedness in the iAMGr is graphically shown in Figure 1.

caption.title: The diachronic development of the markedness hierarchy in iAMGr (based on the representational conventions in Stolz et al. 2014: 23ff)

sec.p: Figure 1 shows that the transition from equal to unequal complexity is a gradual process, which includes an intermediate stage signaling the beginning of the change.

We have also added Place in the Figure to highlight the similarity in the behavior of Places and Goals in iAMGr. Recall that se marks both Place and Goal and, once this preposition is lost, both relations are similarly expressed by zero coding. This means that their relation remains stable across all diachronic stages. In this respect, although the diachronic rearrangement within the spatial system leads to a shift from symmetry to asymmetry, this development only had a local effect in the reorganization of the system. That is, despite the loss of se from the prepositional paradigms of Stage II and Stage III varieties, the original global picture (Goal = Place ≠ Source) was kept intact in the transition from Stage I to Stage III and holds equally for all iAMGr varieties.

As with the Conservative varieties, we measured the distribution of Source and Goal expressions accompanying motion verbs in the subsequent stages. In the intermediate varieties, 296 token clauses were collected and in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian 180 clauses were collected. These numbers include Prepositional Phrases, Circumpositional Phrases, bare accusative-marked NPs and Postpositional Phrases. The distribution of Sources and Goals in our Stage II and Stage III subcorpora are presented in Table 7, 8 and 9, 10, respectively.

caption.title: The frequency distribution of Source and Goal in Stage II
The frequency distribution of Source and Goal per phrasal type in Stage II
The frequency distribution of Source and Goal in Stage III
The frequency distribution of Source and Goal per phrasal type in Stage III

sec.p: Concerning the Stage II varieties, no significant association is found between the type of phrase and whether Source or Goal is used (p almost equals to one). The possibility of such an association was not examined in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian due to the low number of occurrences of Circumpositional Phrases. The crucial finding for our purpose is again the difference in the overall number of the two Path types (the significance was tested by the chi-squared goodness-of-fit test): Source vs. Goal (Stage II): χ 2(1) = 89.76; p < .0001; Source vs. Goal (Stage III): χ 2(1) = 95.34; p < .0001. These results confirm the predominance of Goals over Sources and indicate that neither the variable diachronic stage nor the variable type of phrase play a role in the distribution of the two Path types.

sec.title: Further developments in the marking of Source and Goal in iAMGr
sec.p: The examination of the iAMGr textual record reveals two further developments in the marking of Source and Goal in the varieties in which se either is on its way to disappearing or has fallen completely in disuse. Looking first at Silliot, we find that op, the local reflex of apo, does not participate solely in ablative relations but can also be found in contexts where the Figure moves across or along the Ground as in (21). No such uses are attested in the Cappadocian texts.

sec.p: Most interestingly, however, op is also used in Silliot to mark the final point of the Figure’s movement (Kostakis 1968: 112). An example of this function is given in (22) in which the op-marked expressions encode the semantic role of Goal. This is found with physical landmarks, e.g. vuní ‘mountain’ (22a), and three-dimensional artificial landmarks, e.g. dúma ‘room’ (22b).

sec.p: These are neither ablatives nor perlatives. Considering also the fact that op shows no signs of developing a Place meaning (at least not in its prepositional uses), the Silliot examples may be regarded as rather exceptional from a typological point of view. Recent research has shown that the patterns of neutralization of the formal distinctions between the three locative roles Source, Place, and Goal are not equally distributed crosslinguistically (Creissels 2006; Rice & Kabata 2007; Nikitina 2009; Lestrade 2010; Pantcheva 2010; Luraghi 2014). It is common to find a language that uses the same marker for Goal and Place, but a specialized marker for the expression of Source. However, it is uncommon for a language to have identical encoding for Goal and Source, but a distinct form for Place. In her typological study, Nikitina describes this pattern as “existing, although extremely uncommon and perhaps exceptional” (2009: 1116), the only example in the literature being the Ardeşen variety of Laz (Kutscher 2010). Similarly, Kabata (2013) confirms the rarity of the pattern since she did not find any Source markers expressing Goal meanings in the 24 languages of her sample. In our view, the system found in Silliot is a counterexample to the predominance of Goal over Source, because the asymmetry works in the opposite direction in that the Goal meaning developed out of a Source meaning and not the other way round, as would be predicted by the Goal bias hypothesis.

A different development occurs in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian. In this variety, in which se has been lost altogether from the prepositional inventory, we find two instances of zero-marked Sources in addition to the standard zero-marked Goals and Places. See the examples in (23), in which we find zero-marked Sources with verbs that select a Source-like argument.

sec.p: Although the small number of zero-marked Sources does not allow generalisations of any kind, the very fact that we do find them might indicate that Ulaghátsh represents an incipient stage of a development, the final result of which would be the generalization of zero marking in all syntactic and semantic contexts, including Source relations. What is important, though, regarding the asymmetrical behavior of Sources and Goals is that the development of the zero Goal marker precedes that of the zero Source marker.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: The present findings confirm prior data on the asymmetrical behavior of Source and Goal motion paths. Consistent with previous corpus studies (e.g., Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004), the investigation of the distribution of both motion paths across different iAMGr varieties revealed that Goal paths are more often explicitly expressed in discourse than Source paths. Furthermore, they indicate that neither the variable diachronic stage nor the variable type of phrase play a role in the distribution of the two path types, since the difference between Goals and Sources was found significant independently of these two variables. Additionally, in line with similar asymmetries reported in the literature (e.g., Kopecka 2012), it is shown that Goal markers are more numerous than markers denoting Source. Conjointly, these results confirm the predominance of Goals over Sources.

Most importantly, the present findings also extend prior research on the Source–Goal asymmetry. They indicate that diachronic developments within a spatial system can be well described, if we take into account the general tendency of languages to give priority to Goal as compared to Source. The phenomenon that was mainly addressed in our study was the investigation of the diachronic dimension of zero-marking of spatial relations in iAMGr varieties. Stolz et al. (2014: 302) have highlighted the necessity of conducting research along these lines by considering such investigations as one of the “pressing issues as to the theory of zero-marking”. The present study therefore could be seen as a systematic effort in this direction.

By examining the diachronic paths that the marking of Goals and Sources underwent in the iAMGr, we were able to answer some core questions regarding the development of zero-marking of spatial relations and to provide recommendations for future diachronic investigations. First, the state of affairs found in the Stage II varieties, in which Goal is already marked by zero (as well as by se), could be seen as a first step in answering the more general question about which overt marker is more likely to develop into zero marker, the Goal or the Source.

Second, the innovation that the marking of Source underwent in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian, namely the fact that we find (a very limited number of) zero-marked Sources, helps us to formulate one additional working hypothesis regarding the particular ordering in the development of zero markers: in cases in which both an overt Goal marker and an overt Source marker develop into zero markers, the development of the zero Goal marker will precede that of the zero Source marker. The confirmation or rejection of this hypothesis must await further data from more languages.

Third, the rearrangement within the iAMGr spatial system, which led to the development of a paradigmatic zero in the Goal but not in the Source domain in Ulaghátsh Cappadocian, and the resulting difference in markedness between Sources and Goals, supported the idea that such changes first affect Goals. In the conservative varieties, the two path types exhibit the same degree of formal markedness, but in the innovative varieties they differ, the Goal being the least marked member of the pair. Which domain is responsible for the turn from equal to unequal complexity is determined by the higher rank Goal occupies in the markedness hierarchy in comparison to Source. Despite the imbalance in morphological complexity, the Source–Goal asymmetry remained stable over time as did the manifestation of the crosslinguistically robust tendency for Place and Goal to be expressed similarly and for Source to be kept distinct. This finding extends typological research on the encoding of Place, Source and Goal in that it indicates that the generalizations formulated for overt markers generally hold for zero marking, as well (see also Stolz et al. 2014; cf. Creissels 2006; Nikitina 2009; Lestrade 2010).

From a typological point of view, one remarkable innovation is the polysemy of the preposition op, the reflex of apo, in Silliot. Op expresses both the Source and the Goal function while simultaneously excluding the Place function, a pattern which occurs crosslinguistically only scarcely. Note that additional typologically rare patterns were evident in other iAMGr varieties, as well. For example, Ulaghátsh Cappadocian exemplifies a “rare type of language in which the same means of formal marking is used for the encoding of the direct object, the indirect object, the goal and the locative” (Karatsareas & Georgakopoulos 2016). Taken together, these facts call for an upgraded role of dialectology in serving as an additional data source to typology (see also Kortmann 2004).

title-group.title: Spatial interrogatives
title-group.subtitle: Typology and dynamics (with special focus on the development from Latin to Romance)

abstract.p: This paper explores the diachronic behavior of the paradigms of the spatial interrogatives where, whither, and whence in forty-five contemporary Romance varieties by way of comparing them to the facts reported for their common ancestor: Latin. It is shown that the vast majority of the paradigms have undergone leveling in the sense that the erstwhile (phonological) suppletion of the Latin paradigm was replaced by ternary sets of word-forms sharing the same stem. This shared stem is identical to that of Latin ubi ‘where’ (= locative) in many of the sample languages. At the same time, an almost equally strong group of Romance varieties has generalized Latin unde ‘whence’ (= ablative) over the paradigm. These facts are inquired into against the backdrop of the general linguistic discussion about the nature of syncretism of spatial relations in language.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hitherto, the paradigmatic organization of systems of spatial interrogatives has not been studied on a sufficiently broad scale neither in synchronic nor in diachronic perspective. We argue that it is worthwhile researching this domain in a typologically well informed way. Previous investigations such as those by Ultan (1978), Wąsik (1982), Siemund (2001), Zeshan (2004), Cysouw (2007) and the contributions to the volume edited by Chisholm, Milic and Greppin (1984) are indicative of the wealth of insights a comprehensive inquiry into the grammar of interrogatives holds in store for general and comparative linguistics. Yet, none of these otherwise greatly inspiring scholarly papers focuses on the properties associated with spatial interrogatives, which are usually mentioned only in passing, if at all. It is surprising to see that the many contributions to the study of what may be termed the grammar of space (Svorou 1993) do not give any noticeable degree of prominence to spatial interrogatives either. Our study is meant to show that this neglect of spatial interrogatives in the relevant literature is unjustified linguistically. The neglect is unjustified for three reasons: (a) any grammar of space that claims to be comprehensive cannot remain silent about spatial interrogatives; (b) the evidence from research dedicated to spatial interrogatives in many cases led to the formulation of the hypothesis about the properties of spatial language that are gained on the basis of declarative sentences; (c) at the same time there are also phenomena in the domain of spatial interrogatives whose description calls for a revision of some of the generalizations which have been put forward in the domain of the grammar of space. The factors (a)–(c) render spatial interrogatives highly interesting linguistically. We highlight some of these interesting aspects associated with spatial interrogatives in this paper.

To this end, we adduce evidence from (a) the cross-linguistic project on the typology of paradigms of spatial interrogatives we are currently conducting (cf. Section 3) and (b) the diachronic development of spatial interrogatives in Indo-European languages with special attention to the members of the Romance branch of this language family (cf. Section 4). The general conclusions are drawn in Section 5. Before proceeding to the empirical part of this study, we want to briefly clarify some issues for ease of exposition to address possible questions readers might encounter (Section 2).

sec.title: Theory, methodology, and basic notions
sec.p: We conceive of spatial interrogatives as conventionalized mono-word or multi-word constructions (Fischer & Stefanowitsch 2006: 4–7). According to Booij (2010: 5–6) a construction “denotes a schematic pairing of form and meaning”. This means that mono-word expressions like the English spatial interrogative of Place and Goal where counts as a construction on a par with the expression of the corresponding English spatial interrogative of Source from where, which, however, is an example of a multi-word expression. Spatial interrogatives are employed to inquire into the whereabouts of a given Trajector (aka Figure) and the destination or point of departure (i.e., the Landmark aka Ground) of the movement in which the Trajector is involved (Langacker 1986). According to the guidelines of the Lingua Descriptive format (Comrie & Smith 1977), we assume three categories of general location that cover the three spatial relations of Place, Goal, and Source (Talmy 1983), and which correspond largely to the basic meaning of the English prepositions at, to, and from, respectively. Owing to the scarcity of reliable data, we exclude Path – the fourth category of general location – from this investigation. On this basis, the members of the emerging ternary paradigm (Robbeets & Bisang 2014: 5–6) can be captured by the currently somewhat outdated Early Modern English set of spatial interrogatives where (Place), whither (Goal), and whence (Source) (Dixon 2012: 408). We employ these English expressions to translate the spatial interrogatives of the languages that we discuss in this study.

The canonical version of the paradigm is free of morphological mismatches (Corbett 2007; cf. below in this Section). The canonical paradigm consists exclusively of spatial interrogatives that express the spatial relations overtly. According to the canonical approach to typology and morphology (Corbett 2005) to which we adhere, each construction in this paradigm should reflect the combination of at least two categories, namely that of interrogativity (= Q) and that of the spatial relation (= SR) it is dedicated to.1 The canonical construction can be captured by the formula [Q+SR]spint with the symbol + serving as a variable of all degrees of fusion of the constituents, including the absence of fusion. The canonical paradigm of spatial interrogatives may come in different shapes according to the language-individual rules of linearization and the choice of analyticity or syntheticity (Schwegler 1990). Table 1 assumes synthetic word-forms with a Q-stem hosting three distinct suffixes as exponents of the three different spatial relations.

caption.title: Canonical paradigm of spatial interrogatives

sec.p: The canonical paradigm shown in Table 1serves as yardstick to compare the empirically attested paradigms of spatial interrogatives we discuss below.
The mismatches to which we refer in this study are as follows:

list-item.p: syncretism: this mismatch applies if “two or more cells within a […] paradigm are occupied by the same form” (Stump 2001: 212);
suppletion: this mismatch applies if within a paradigm word forms coexist which cannot be derived from each other by synchronic phonological roots (Mel’čuk 1994);
overabundance: this mismatch “occurs when a cell in a paradigm is filled by two synonymous forms which realize the same set of morphosyntactic properties” (Thornton 2012: 253).

sec.p: As to the processes of language change, we mention in the subsequent sections, we provide the following explanations:

list-item.p: pull-chain: a gap is created via language change in the structural system and this gap attracts a new filler from a neighboring domain of the language system (Boretzky 1977: 121);
push-chain: a given element of the language system expands its territory to the detriment of its neighbors (Boretzky 1977: 122);

renovation: the typical case of renovation involves the creation of a new expression for an already established grammatical category whose erstwhile expression is replaced with a new one (Lehmann 1995: 20);

reinforcement: reinforcement is the label employed for cases in which the expression of a given grammatical category is subject to the addition of further morphological elements without change of meaning (Lehmann 1995: 22).

sec.p: In addition to adhering to the canonical approach in typology, our study is indebted to Basic Linguistic Theory (Dixon 2010)2 and follows the general principles of functional typology (Cristofaro 2011).3 To narrow down the scope of our investigation, we take note exclusively of those spatial interrogatives that occur in direct questions of the content brand. Furthermore, we simplify matters considerably by way of comparing modern varieties directly with their historical ancestors without taking into account what has happened during the many centuries in between. Our practice can be defended on grounds of the absence of sufficiently reliable philological documentation of the bulk of the Romance varieties that we address in Sections 4.1 and 4.2.

The data on which Section 3 is based stem from a world-wide sample of 434 languages (including non-standard varieties), which is employed for our ongoing typological project on spatial interrogatives (Stolz et al. forthcoming). In the sample, there are 297 extra-European languages and 137 European languages. The languages which belong to this synchronic typological sample are listed in Appendix 1. Each continent (Africa, America, Asia, Australia/Oceania, and Europe) is represented with at least 65 languages. All language families and isolates for which information on the complete paradigm of spatial interrogatives was accessible are included in this sample. For the extra-European languages, we rely on the information provided in descriptive grammars, dictionaries and further linguistic studies.

For the languages of Europe including the members of the Romance branch of Indo-European as discussed in Sections 4.1 and 4.2 we have made use of a parallel literary corpus consisting of the French original of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s novel Le Petit Prince and its translations into 137 languages of Europe (the bibliographical information on the 45 Romance versions of the sample text are given in the Sources-section at the end of the paper). This corpus text contains seven direct questions which involve spatial interrogatives. We have extracted these seven instances of spatial interrogatives for each of 137 languages of Europe. Each of the spatial relations (Place, Goal, and Source) is represented twice in the extracted sentences (with a third example for Place). We have then identified the members of the paradigm of spatial interrogatives for each of our European languages on the basis of the extracted sentences. Furthermore, we have determined which expression is used for which spatial functions in order to identify patterns of syncretism. If there was evidence of competing expressions with identical functions, we have taken these cases as examples of overabundance. If the phonological shape of the members of the paradigms was such that the spatial interrogatives could not be related to each other by synchronic phonological rules, we have classified these examples as instances of suppletion.

The Romance varieties and their paradigm of spatial interrogatives are listed in the Appendices 2–4. In the Appendices 2–4, the Romance languages come in alphabetical order. Appendix 2 hosts those of the Romance languages which have generalized Latin ubi ‘where’ as a Q-stem across their paradigm. Appendix 3 surveys those Romance varieties which show that Latin unde ‘whence’ has survived as spatial interrogative of Source. Appendix 4 contains those languages which attest the generalization of Latin unde ‘whence’ over the entire paradigm of spatial interrogatives.

sec.title: Typology – synchronic and diachronic data
sec.p: In the literature on spatial relations, the distinction between possible and impossible syncretic patterns is a recurrent topic. This is why syncretism (Baerman, Brown & Corbett 2005) is in the foreground of the subsequent paragraphs.

Creissels (2006) for instance assumes that paradigms in which all distinctions of spatial relations are neutralized are banned from the grammars of European languages whereas they abound in Africa (especially south of the Sahara). On the grounds of linguistic theory, Pantcheva (2010) goes as far as excluding the possibility of Goal and Source being expressed syncretically unless the spatial relation of Place also partakes in the syncretic pattern. The author also casts doubt on the possibility of Place being expressed syncretically with Source – but not with Goal. Lestrade (2010: 104) argues that “the syncretism pattern between Goal and Source is a semantically unmotivated diachronic accident.”

Spatial interrogatives do not figure prominently in the discussion we have outlined above. Therefore one could ask whether or not the generalizations put forward by the above authors also hold under the conditions of interrogativity. Nikitina (2009) identifies the logically possible patterns that may affect ternary paradigms of spatial relations as follows:

list-item.p: Pattern I: Place ≠ Goal ≠ Source
Pattern II: (Place = Goal) ≠ Source
Pattern III: Place ≠ (Goal = Source)
Pattern IV: (Place = Source) ≠ Goal
Pattern V: (Place = Goal = Source)

sec.p: Except Pattern I, with three distinct members of the paradigm, all of the patterns involve syncretism. Patterns I, II, and V are generally believed to be relatively frequent across languages, whereas Patterns III–IV are attested only marginally. Wälchli and Zuñiga (2006) and Kutscher (2010) present evidence of the existence of Pattern III in a number of languages, i.e., the neutralization of the dynamic spatial relations is in the focus of their interest. In this study, (indirect) evidence for Pattern IV is scrutinized diachronically.

These five patterns can be identified cross-linguistically also in the domain of spatial interrogatives. The canonical paradigm of Table 1 corresponds (nicely) to Pattern I. In Table 2 we provide examples of paradigms of spatial interrogatives (from non-Indo-European languages) for each of the Patterns I–V. Syncretic constructions are highlighted by both boldface and grey shading of the paradigmatic cells. If overabundance applies, the cell is further subdivided horizontally.

caption.title: Internal organization of paradigms (Patterns I–V)

sec.p: As predicted by Lestrade (2010: 96–97) for patterns of encoding of spatial relations in general, the distribution of the five patterns over the languages of the world is uneven in the case of spatial interrogatives as well. However, Lestrade (2010) does not specifically refer to the behavior of spatial interrogatives. We survey the cross-linguistic distribution of syncretisms in paradigms of spatial interrogatives in Diagrams 1–2. In Diagram 1 the absolute numbers of extra-European languages are given in brackets for each of the continents. Since some of these languages tolerate overabundance in their paradigms of spatial interrogatives, the absolute numbers for the Patterns I–V exceeds that of the total of languages in a given continent. The different macro-areas are represented by different shades of grey.

caption.title: Frequency of Patterns I–V across extra-European languages

sec.p: According to our basic statistics, each of the patterns constitutes to a share of 20% of the sample languages. However, Diagram 1 suggests that Patterns III–IV are clearly underrepresented since neither the one nor the other reaches the 10%-mark on any of the continents outside of Europe.

The preference for Patterns I, II, and V corroborates the extant hypotheses about the typologically admissible syncretisms of spatial relations. Diagram 2, which is based on the analysis of 137 contemporary languages of Europe, resembles the distribution painted by Diagram 1 insofar as Patterns III–IV are also exceptional in Europe although Pattern IV exceeds the 10%-mark with non-Indo-European languages.4 In analogy to Diagram 1, the absolute number of languages of each sub-group of the European segment of the sample is given in brackets. Except for the group of non-Indo-European languages, there are cases of overabundance in all of the other groups represented in Diagram 2, so that the total number of patterns adds up to slightly more cases than there are languages in a given group.

caption.title: Shares of Patterns I–V across European languages

sec.p: The absence of evidence of Pattern V is in line with Creissels’ (2006) assumption according to which completely neutralized paradigms of spatial relations fail to show up in Europe. What distinguishes the European results further from those of the extra-European languages is the differential behavior of the different branches of Indo-European as to their choice of favorite pattern. The Romance languages stand out in the sense that they are characterized by a marked preference for Pattern II. In contrast to the Romance language, it is Pattern I which occupies the highest rank on the list of the options of the Germanic languages.
That the members of language families do not necessarily give evidence of genetic solidarity can be gathered from the Turkic data in Table 3.

caption.title: Bipartition of the Turkic languages

sec.p: In Table 3, there are altogether seventeen Turkic languages (including Old Turkic). They can be divided in three sub-groups according to the pattern of their paradigms of spatial interrogatives. The largest of the sub-groups comprises ten languages which provide evidence of Pattern I. In contrast, seven languages make use of Pattern II – either exclusively (= four languages) or alongside a second set of spatial interrogatives which exemplify Pattern I (= three languages). If syncretism applies, it always affects Place and Goal but never Source. The modern variety of Crimean Tatar (as spoken in the Bulgarian Dobrudja), Kyrgyz, and Kazakh display a combination of both Pattern I and Pattern II which coexist in one and the same language. Interestingly, all instances of syncretic spatial interrogatives of Place and Goal are synthetic word-forms whereas the disambiguation of the spatial relations is achieved by analytic constructions in two out of three cases. Since Old Turkic is an example of those languages which opt for Pattern I, it can be assumed that Pattern I represents the older historical layer, so that Pattern II can be considered a relatively recent innovation via language change – either with or without external triggers. Note also that several of the above Turkic languages make use of two different Q-stems, namely nV- vs qV-/kV-. There is thus overabundance in some of the cells the fillers of which seem to be in a relation of free variation to each other.
The change from Pattern I to Pattern II is a process that can be observed in the history of numerous languages, among which we mention the case of Georgian, as shown in Table 4.

caption.title: From Old Georgian to Modern Georgian

sec.p: In Old Georgian, there was overabundance in the cell of Goal, which hosted three allomorphs, one of which was identical with the spatial interrogative of Place. The other two allomorphs, however, were distinct from all other members of the paradigm. In the further diachronic development, Georgian has lost the two allomorphs of the spatial interrogative of Goal that were fully distinctive, so that all relics of the erstwhile Pattern I vanished from the paradigm to give way to the competing Pattern II. We notice that Source is not involved in any syncretic pattern. At the same time, however, the spatial interrogative of Source of Old Georgian has been replaced with a new expression which is unrelated etymologically to that of the early phases of the documented history of this South Caucasian language. Modern Georgian saidan ‘whence’ can be associated with Modern Georgian sad ‘where, whither’, Old Georgian sada ‘where, whither’, and Old Georgian sadait ‘whither’, whereas Old Georgian vinaj ‘whence’ bears some resemblance only to Old Georgian vidre ‘whither’. Their resemblance is based on the initial CV-sequence vi- which is common to both expressions. It can be concluded that in the course of the history of Georgian the paradigm of spatial interrogatives experienced a major reorganization in the sense that the erstwhile suppletion (with two different stems sa- and vi- co-existing in the same paradigm) has ceded to a more regular kind of relation of the members of the paradigm, all of which are based on the same Q-stem sa-. The spatial interrogative of Source has accommodated its expression to those of the spatial interrogatives of Place and Goal.

On the basis of these data it is tempting to assume that Pattern II functions as a kind of diachronic attractor for the development of other patterns and that Source only reacts to the changes that happen in the domain of Place and/or Goal. In Section 4, we review the evidence, especially from those Indo-European languages which document the change from Pattern I to Pattern II, in order to check whether or not there is a hidden story behind the replacement of one pattern with the other.

sec.title: Indo-European
sec.p: Spatial interrogatives are not immune against language change in Indo-European languages. Table 5 recapitulates the developments that the paradigm of spatial interrogatives has undergone from the Old English period to modern times.

caption.title: Spatial interrogatives throughout the English language history

sec.p: Only in modern times has Pattern I disappeared to the benefit of Pattern II. Place-Goal syncretism can thus be considered to be a relatively recent innovation. The establishment of Pattern II was preceded by the introduction of optional prepositions to accompany the spatial interrogative of Source although the latter was formally distinct from the other members of the paradigm probably because of its residual case inflection. What happened during the interval between Early Modern English and contemporary English is captured nicely by Luraghi’s (1991: 68) statement according to which “the loss of concrete cases seems to have resulted in a tendency towards the use of analytical expressions for encoding local roles in most Indo-European languages.” The spatial interrogative of Place has usurped the function of Q-stem when the purely morphological distinction between Goal and Source via their synthetic expressions became obsolete. On the basis of the new Q-stem where, the replacements of whither (with the occasional substitute where to) and (from) whence were created. This process is reminiscent of the above Georgian situation. The facts from the diachrony of English thus allows us to give the following generalization: the spatial interrogative of Source may depend formally on the expressions employed for those of Place and Goal. In Sections 4.1–4.2, we will see that this dependence is not necessarily universal.

sec.title: From Latin to Romance
sec.p: That the generalization of the development of the English paradigm of spatial interrogatives is premature can be demonstrated by way of comparing the paradigm of spatial interrogatives of Latin with those of its Romance offspring. In Table 6 we present the spatial interrogatives of Classical Latin as discussed in Touratier (2013: 251–3).

caption.title: Spatial interrogatives in Classical Latin

sec.p: There is overabundance (Thornton 2011) and suppletion but no syncretism in this paradigm. Classical Latin illustrates Pattern I with fully distinct word-forms for the three spatial relations. In the case of Place, we are facing a situation of overabundance, since two allomorphs compete with each other. Synchronically, the paradigm is characterized by suppletion, since the four word-forms are distributed over two different stems.5

In the transition from Latin to its successor languages, the consonant-initial spatial interrogatives disappeared from the paradigm. The disappearance of quā ‘where’ did not cause any major problems since its functional equivalent ubi ‘where’ could take over. This is different in the case of the spatial interrogative of Goal because with quō ‘whither’ gone there was an empty cell and thus a case of a defective paradigm as shown in Table 7.

caption.title: The potential creation of a gap*

fn.p: The table has to be read as follows: We distinguish two diachronic stages, namely “before”, which referrers to a time when there were still spatial interrogatives in each of the three cells of the paradigm, and “after”, which referrers to a time when quō was lost already. The arrows are indicative of those spatial interrogatives which survived into the “after”-stage. Those interrogatives which were lost diachronically are stroked out. There are two cells for Place under “before” because at that stage there was overabundance, meaning: two synonymous expressions competed with each other. The question mark in the cell of Goal under “after” serves as a placeholder of new fillers, which replace the original quō. Since these fillers vary across the Romance languages, the question arises which of the Romance languages use which renovated spatial interrogative of Goal, this is what Section 4.2 is about.

sec.p: However, none of the Romance languages provides evidence of an incomplete paradigm. All of the Romance varieties we have checked show fully equipped ternary paradigms of spatial interrogatives. This means that the potential loss in the domain of Goal must have been compensated for. One might imagine a push-chain scenario according to which Latin quō ‘whither’ was driven out by another expression either from outside or from inside the paradigm. Alternatively, the loss of quō ‘whither’ could have triggered a pull-chain which resulted in the attraction of another expression to fill the empty space in the paradigm. The clarification of which of the two scenarios captures the historical processes in the most adequate way is of no great importance to the analysis of the phenomena which we are going to scrutinize in the remainder of this section.

On the basis of the parallel literally corpus we have been able to determine that Latin quō ‘whither’ has never been replaced with an expression from outside the paradigm of spatial interrogatives. What has happened instead is that either the successors of ubi ‘where’ or those of unde ‘whence’ have laid claim to the cell which hosts the spatial interrogative of Goal. Diagram 3 is suggestive of a relatively balanced distribution of expansive ubi and expansive unde over the Romance sample. This finding has been checked against and corroborated by the extant normative grammars, descriptive grammars and dialect grammars of Romance varieties to which we refer in this text only if concrete examples or quotes are taken directly from these sources. For a number of the Romance varieties of our sample, no grammatical description was accessible. In these cases, we rely entirely on the data gathered from the above parallel corpus.

caption.title: Distribution of expansive ubi ‘where’ and unde ‘whence’ over the Romance sample

sec.p: In almost half of the sample languages, ubi alone occupies the cell which formerly belonged to the domain of quō. The percentage of languages that provide evidence of unde alone claiming the former territory of quō is only slightly lower than that of ubi. In addition, there is a minority of languages that provide evidence of a competition between ubi and unde in the function of Goal spatial interrogative.

The sentential examples from four languages in Table 8 may illustrate the employment of the spatial interrogatives in actually attested sentences (for the Latin case cf. below). The data stem from the parallel literary corpus. Boldface highlights the spatial interrogatives in the original and the English translation.6

sec.p: The Latin version of Le Petit Prince is of course an anachronistic text. Its degree of linguistic reliability cannot be determined in this paper. French – the language of the original of the corpus text – is representative of a language which has generalized ubi as Q-stem across the paradigm of spatial interrogatives (cf. Appendix 2)). In contrast, Portuguese illustrates the generalization of unde over the paradigm of spatial interrogatives (cf. Appendix 4). According to Table 8, Asturian seems to belong to the group of Romance varieties, which show that unde survives as spatial interrogative of Source (cf. Appendix 3). However, as several other languages, this Ibero-Romance variety allows for the coexistence of different sets of spatial interrogatives (Academia de la Llingua Asturiana 2001), cf. Table 9. The four languages featured in Table 9 serve as point of departure for the ensuing discussion (Asturian, Piemontese, Genovese and Romanian are therefore not listed separately in the Appendices 2–4).

caption.title: Romance languages with expansive ubi and expansive unde

fn.p:
Silvia Luraghi (p.c.) argues that the combination of the spatial interrogatives andoa/doa/d’anté is impossible in the varieties of Piemontese she is familiar with. Our data are taken exclusively from the Piemontese translation of Le petit prince where all of the five spatial interrogatives reported for Piemontese in Table 9 are actually attested. We do not know which variety of Piemontese serves as the basis for the translation. For the purpose of this paper, we take the textual evidence at face value although we are aware of the possibility that the paradigm needs to be revised in the future. The evidence for the questionable paradigm can be found on p. 18 of the Piemontese translation (cf. List of translations of our sample text at the end of this paper): [ D’anté ] Source
ch’it ven-e, omnet? ‘Where do you come from, little man?; [Anté]Place ch’a l’é toa ca? ‘Where is your home?’; [Doa]Goal veus-to mné mia fèja? ‘Where do you want to take my sheep?’ Boldface highlights the spatial interrogatives.

sec.p: The reflexes of the Latin spatial interrogatives (ubi ‘where’ and unde ‘whence’) come in different phonological shapes: Asturian ú ‘where, whither’ goes back to Latin ubi ‘where’; ande ‘where, whither’ is etymologically connected to Latin unde ‘whence’, as is Piemontese anté ‘where, whither’ (but cf. below in this Section); Romanian unde ‘where, whither’ is of course the most faithful continuation of the Latin etymon. How Latin ubi ‘where’ can be identified in the phonological chains of Romanian încotro ‘where, whither’ and dincotro ‘whence’ is explained in Section 4.2 below.

What is striking is the scarcity of constructions which consist only of the direct successor of the spatial interrogative of the ancestor language Latin. Except in Asturian ú ‘where, whither’ and Romanian unde ‘where, whither’, Latin ubi ‘where' and unde ‘whence’ hide in constructions which host at least one additional component that was not already there in the Latin paradigm of spatial interrogatives. In Table 9 we find the following constructions containing the Latin spatial interrogatives: Genovese [d{ove}ubi]where=whither , Piemontese [d{oa}ubi]where=whither , Genovese [d{onde}unde]where=whither=whence , and Piemontese [d{anté}unde] whence.7

Another special case is that of Genovese (Tosco 1997), which neutralizes the three spatial relations by way of admitting the employment of [d{onde}unde]where=whither=whence ‘where, whither, whence’ in all of the cells of the paradigm. This situation contradicts the expectations as formulated by Creissels (2006), who excludes Pattern V from the repertoire of syncretisms in the systems of spatial categories in the languages of Europe (cf. Section 3). Moreover, what is remarkable about this case is that the presence of the preposition de ‘from’ as part of the multi-functional spatial interrogative presupposes a succession of diachronic processes that can be interpreted as an instance of history repeating itself.10
Table 10 recounts the potential chronology of events that have led from the situation in classical Latin to that reported for Genovese in the modern era. To simplify, we use the Latin spatial interrogatives as labels to represent the spatial interrogatives throughout the supposed processes of language change.

caption.title: From Latin to modern Genovese – unde > donde
From Latin to modern Genovese: ubi > de dove

sec.p: The scenario we have sketched in Table 11 is especially interesting because it presupposes a change of orientation between Steps 4 and 5. In the beginning, ubi ‘where’ proved to be strongest in the sense that it was able to spread over the entire paradigm to the detriment of unde ‘whence’. However, when the renovation of the spatial interrogative of Source was achieved via adding the ablative preposition de ‘from’ to the otherwise polysemous spatial interrogative *ubi ‘where, whither, whence’, this new construction began to diffuse to yield a fully neutralized paradigm. The lack of distinction between spatial relations was solved with the second renovation of the spatial interrogative of Source, which now boasts a construction that contains two consecutive instances of the same ablative preposition de ‘from’ diachronically. Since instances of diachronic stagging are by no means rare in our Romance data-base, a closer look at additional examples of this kind promises further insights into the nature of cyclic processes.

sec.title: Reinforcement and renovation
sec.p: We follow the lead of Lehmann (1995: 19–24) when we invoke the notions of renovation and reinforcement in connection with the phenomena that can be observed in the diachrony of the paradigms of spatial interrogatives in Romance varieties. There can be no innovation in the strict sense of the term because the paradigm of spatial interrogatives forms a closed shop within which only neutralization and renovation are admitted (since defectivity does not seem to be a viable option because a gap in a paradigm would mean that a given spatial relation cannot be inquired into by speakers of the variety).
The preposition in is also involved in a number of further cases of reinforcement although not exactly in the same way as in the previously mentioned varieties.

There are four Romance varieties whose spatial interrogatives pose problems as to their segmentation. In all these four cases, it is possible to identify the final vowel of the phonological chain as a successor of Latin ubi ‘where’. The problems arise with the underlined parts of the following constructions:

list-item.p:
Wallonian (and Wallonian (Central)) [
èw {ou}ubi ]where=whither vs [ d| èw {ou}ubi ]whence,

Valdotain [
ya {ou}ubi ]where=whither vs [ de | ya {ou}ubi ]whence, and

Picardian (Borain) [
ay {u}ubi ]where=whither vs [ d| ay {u}ubi ]whence.

sec.p: What can be concluded, independently of the solution of the remaining etymological riddles, is that thirty-five of the forty-five Romance varieties provide evidence of the diffusion of the formal expression of Source over the entire paradigm of spatial interrogatives starting either from Latin unde or from Romance de ubi. This means that the 78% of the Romance sample languages have experienced the expansion of the expression of Source at least once during the course of their history. Five of the Romance varieties – Genovese, Niçard, Piemontese, and Spanish – have experienced this process even twice. Twenty-four languages reflect the opposite development (nine of them repeatedly), namely from Place via Goal to Source. This number is equivalent to the 53% of the Romance sample languages, several of which have undergone more than one process of paradigmatic leveling that could start with Place and others at the opposite end with Source. The above percentages differ substantially so that it is justified to claim that the reorganization of paradigms of spatial interrogatives is preferably based on Source in the Romance branch of the Indo-European language family. Note that there are only six languages (= 13%) for which it can be shown convincingly that Goal has been the starting-point of a diffusion process – normally only as secondary development after the diffusion of a Q-stem from either the cell of Place or that of Source. Diagram 4 shows the statistical discrepancies of Source, Place and Goal as points of departure of paradigmatic leveling.

caption.title: Points of departure of processes of leveling

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The diachronic developments from Latin to Romance that we have sketched in Sections 4.1–4.2 above largely corroborate the findings of MacKenzie’s (1978), who assumes that erstwhile expressions of the spatial relation of Source (= ablative) may come to be used for the purpose of representing that of Place (= locative). The abundance of instances of the cognates of Latin unde ‘whence’ ousting the cognates of Latin ubi ‘where’ in the history of the Romance branch of the Indo-European language family strongly supports Luraghi’s (2014) hypothesis according to which ablative-locative transfers are anything but rare in the diachrony of languages. The fate of the Romance successors of Latin unde ‘whence’ also confirms the idea that the ablative function of an erstwhile expression of Source is bound to being lost as soon as the very same expression acquires the locative function (Bennett 1989; Luraghi 2009, 2010; Nikitina & Spano 2014). As a matter of fact, if in a Romance variety the cognate of Latin unde ‘whence’ fulfills the function of the spatial interrogative of Place it cannot also function as spatial interrogative of Source. Therefore, a new construction is created for the latter function – a construction which tends to be more complex morphologically than that of Place. The higher degree of complexity is usually achieved more often than not by way of adding an ablative preposition to the cognate of Latin unde ‘whence’. This recurrent process of renovation via reinforcement yields a paradigm which is organized in conformity to the ban on ablative-locative syncretism as put forward by Pantcheva (2010).13 This means that those syncretisms of spatial categories which are excluded from the synchronic structural phenomenology may originate diachronically from a strong association of exactly those categories that should never attract one another. As Eckhoff et al. (2013) argue, there may be certain contexts in which this bilateral attraction proves to be especially strong so that it overrides the synchronic obstacles. Interrogativity is perhaps a good candidate for the status of special context in which the association of otherwise unrelated categories is tolerated or even enhanced.

Furthermore, our data confirm the recurrence of the processes discussed in Sections 3–4, meaning: we are not dealing with exceptions. Robbeets and Bisang (2014: 9) state that “in spite of formal renewal, languages tend to restore old paradigms in cyclic processes of grammaticalization.” This quote invokes Jespersen’s (1917) cycle in the domain of negation. Romance languages are renowned for the cyclicity of diachronic processes (Kabatek 2003). We conclude that paradigms of spatial interrogatives give additional testimony of cyclic developments – not only in the case of Romance languages but in all probability also beyond. Accordingly, spatial interrogatives constitute fertile ground for diachronic and typological investigations aiming at determining, on the one hand, how the dynamics of closely-knit paradigms is organized, and, on the other hand, in which way the spatial categories represented by the spatial interrogatives relate to each other and to their equivalents outside the domain of interrogativity.

fn.p: Corbett (2005: 26) explains that “[i]n a canonical approach, we take definitions to their local end point and build theoretical spaces of possibilities. Only then do we ask how this space is populated. There are of course precedents to this approach; […]. It follows that canonical instances (the best examples, those most closely matching the canon) may well not be the most frequent. They may be indeed be extremely rare, or even non-existent. However, they fix a point from which occurring phenomena can be calibrated, and it is then significant and interesting to investigate frequency distributions”.

In contrast to formal theories of grammar, Basic Linguistic Theory is “worked out inductively” (Dixon 2010: 2) and forms “a single cumulative theory” (Dixon 2010: 3). This means that no purely theoretic foundations are presupposed. All our generalizations are based on the interpretation of empirical evidence.

In agreement with Polinsky and Kluender (2007: 273) we assume that “language structure is shaped by communicative needs of speakers [and] that the functional orientation of typology does not entail rejection of structure; rather, functionalism in typology manifests in the recognition of communicative, social, or processing needs as the reasons grammars are the way they are.”
In Appendix 1 we indicate the languages which represent Germanic, Romance, and Slavic branch of Indo-European as well as the genetically mixed group of sundry Indo-European languages.

Although ubi ‘where’ and unde ‘whence’ probably lost their erstwhile initial unvoiced velar plosive /k/ as the effect of reanalysis (or internal sound-change) so that Table 6 depicts phonological i.e., secondary suppletion (Brugmann 1911: 350). We assume that speakers of Latin were not aware of the historical facts which tie ubi/unde to quā/quō.

The spatial interrogatives are glossed as follows: P = Place, G = Goal, S = Sources. In case of syncretism, the spatial interrogative is glossed for both of its functions (e.g. P/G for Place-Goal-syncretism). Multi-word constructions like Portuguese para onde ‘whither’ represent prepositional phrases the constituents of which are not glossed separately.

The modern reflexes of the Latin spatial interrogatives appear in indexed curly brackets, the additional elements are printed in boldface and the construction in its entirety is put in indexed square brackets to indicate the modern function. It must be emphasized that the format in which we present the spatial-interrogative constructions reflects exclusively the diachronic components of these constructions, which in many cases might no longer correspond to the synchronically most plausible morphological analysis of the same constructions.
For further cases which involve an initial segment d-, cf. Nikitina (this volume).
At this point of our research we cannot yet determine with certainty that these locative markers go back to Goal constructions. This is a question that has been raised by one of our reviewers.
Silvia Luraghi (p.c.) reminds us of the fact that this cyclic change is common in Romance, cf. from Latin to Romance foris > de foris > dehors , intro > de intro > dentro etc.
One of our reviewers suggests that the final CV sequences -là: might go back to illac (> Italian là, Southern varieties llà, ddà etc. ‘there’).
According to one of our reviewers the initial da- might be a historical relic of the combination of the prepositions de + ab.
Nikitina (this volume) argues that such supposedly “impossible” syncretisms do exist, even though they are lexically restricted. To our mind this is a problem for models such as Pantcheva’s (2010).

This appendix is organized as follows. Except for Europe, the languages are listed alphabetically for each of the continents. Since, in this paper, we do not touch upon the distribution of structural phenomena over language families, we skip indicating the genetic affiliation of the extra-European languages. In the case of Europe, however, we employ a relatively coarse genetic classification because one of the sub-branches of Indo-European (Romance) is in the focus of this study. The labels “sundry Indo-European” and “non-Indo-European” are only ad hoc and do not imply that we are dealing with well-defined brunches of language families.
