title-group.title: Asymmetries in path encoding in Sicilian
title-group.subtitle: A diachronic overview
title-group.alt-title: Asymmetries in path encoding in Sicilian

abstract.p: This paper proposes a description of the encoding of path within the system of the spatial relations in present-day Sicilian, with a retrospective glance to the diachronic developments of that system. Two features characterize the spatial relations in present-day Sicilian: (a) consistent with a cross-linguistic tendency, the relation between source and direction is asymmetric, as the latter receives a richer and more fine-grained expression; moreover, direction may conflate into locative expression; (b) in contrast with a cross-linguistic tendency, which predicts a lower degree of autonomy for path, this role has a dedicated preposition and makes use of a non-prepositional strategy, namely a reduplicative construction expressing the spatial extension through which the event is brought about. The diachronic development of present-day system has been reconstructed by means of the scrutiny of corpus data from 14th to 19th centuries. This analysis has shown a substantial consistency in the encoding of spatial relations over time, although a certain degree of variation of the linguistic means expressing them.

sec.title: Spatial relation in Sicilian: Preliminary remarks
sec.p: The relationship between the major spatial roles appears to be asymmetric in the languages of the world. Recent studies (especially in the field of psycholinguistics) have shown an asymmetry in the linguistic expression of source and direction: adults and children more frequently mark the endpoint of motion rather than its origin in the linguistic descriptions of motion events containing salient source and goal objects (Lakusta & Landau 2005). This ‘goal bias’ (or source vulnerability) is deeply rooted in the cognitive system of humans, which is inherently forward-looking, proactive rather than reactive, driven by goals, plans, desires, hopes (Baars & Gage 2013: 233).
This cognitive feature is mapped onto the linguistic systems of spatial relations and emerges in a number of cross-linguistic tendencies, among which:

list-item.p: When a language has a source marker for a particular spatial relationship it also has a corresponding direction marker, but the reverse is not necessarily true (e.g. English under or behind lack corresponding source expressions, cf. Regier 1997).
In general, goals of motion are expressed more frequently and in more fine-grained ways than sources (Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004; Regier & Zheng 2007, inter alia).

Languages frequently use location markers to encode direction, rarely to encode source. Based on the presence of patterns of conflation in the world languages, which can be frequent, rare or absent, Nikitina (2009, following Haspelmath 2003), argues that direction and source are maximally distant and distinct in the languages of the world.
The encoding of path, finally, appears to be less autonomous compared to source, goal, and location at the cross-linguistic level, and it is frequently based on location (see Stolz 1992).

sec.p: In what follows, we will try to assess the extent to which the system of spatial relations in Sicilian fits into the cross-linguistic scenario. For this purpose, we propose a description of such a system, focussing in particular on the encoding of path. The description is based on the insights of Cognitive Grammar (Langacker 1987, 1991), according to which spatial relations involve two entities, that is, a foregrounded entity (trajector, henceforth TR) and a background entity (landmark, henceforth LM) serving as a reference point for locating the former. The spatial relation is the position of the TR relative to the LM, and it is typically encoded by means of prepositions and cases. As Langacker (1987: 217) observes, “The term trajector suggests motion, and in processual predications describing physical activities […] the trajector generally does move through a spatial trajectory. Note, however, that the definition makes no reference at all to motion, either physical or abstract, so this schematic description is applicable to both static and dynamic relations”. Due to this characterization, Langacker defines the relation between TR and LM as “atemporal”, as it does not inherently express a dynamic component (i.e., “(TR) at/through/ towards etc. (LM)”). While the relation is per se static, the presence of other contextual elements determines the possible expression of motion, namely the presence of motion verbs adding temporality (i.e., a “processual” meaning, in Langacker’s terms) to the spatial scene, depicting it as a sequence of sub-events along which the TR metaphorically “moves” (Langacker 1987: 244 ff.).

Data from contemporary Sicilian are based on the systematic control of the existent literature on this language (e.g. Leone 1995, as well as more specific studies to which we will refer in due course) and reference works on the Italo-Romance varieties (e.g. Rohlfs 1968).

Besides, we propose some diachronic observations deriving from the scrutiny of texts of the 14th to 19th centuries, collected in various corpora, both published and electronic. Three caveats are related to our primary sources:

list-item.p: Sicilian language never underwent a process of standardisation and, hence, it is better conceived of as an aggregation of areal varieties, which, despite the fundamental structural homogeneity, may exhibit major differences at the lexical and morphosyntactic level. We will account for this kind of variation whenever it produces differences in the encoding of the spatial relations.

Ancient Sicilian texts experienced an early and strong influence of other linguistic models, namely Latin (used in formal contexts, e.g. administrative or legal) and, starting from the 15th century, Tuscan (constituting the linguistic basis of Italian). This situation clearly emerges from our texts, where fully Sicilian forms not rarely coexist with non-native correlates. As a consequence, the analysis of such texts requires a close collaboration between linguists and philologists.

On the whole, our corpus is not homogeneous as far as textual types and genres are concerned. While present-day data testify to oral language, most ancient texts (14th to 18th centuries) are mainly archival documents (e.g. administrative texts, depositions, wills etc.), and the 19th century is represented by a collection of tales and folk stories, that is, fictional narrative texts. This heterogeneity (which embraces several levels, that is, oral vs. written, formal vs. non-formal, literary vs. practical etc.) surely constitutes a limitation (unfortunately, insuperable) for a coherent analysis of the data.

sec.title: Source vs. Direction (and Location)
sec.p: Consistent with the cross-linguistic tendencies outlined in Section 1, Sicilian data show asymmetry in the relation between source and direction, as the latter is more frequently encoded and receives a richer and more fine-grained expression; moreover, while direction merges with location, source never does and is always expressed by dedicated means.

sec.title: Source
sec.p: Source is expressed by means of the preposition d(i) ‘from, of’ (< Lat. de ‘from’, also in the variant ri in some areas of Sicily, see Rohlfs 1969: 207–208), irrespective of the features of the LM and the kind of event described by the verb, as in (1) where di is followed both by a prototypical goal, the place noun casa ‘house/home’, and a non-prototypical one, i.e., the animate noun dutturi ‘doctor’.

list-item.p: ‘I come from your house / the doctor’s office.’

sec.p: The use of di remains stable throughout the history of Sicilian. It is attested in all the stages of the language, since the 14th century texts (see Examples (2), (3), (5) and (6)), whereas occasional instances of da ‘from’ reveal the influence of the Tuscan model, such as da intru ‘from inside’ in (3), where it co-occurs with the Sicilian form (di fora ‘from outside’), and da Mascari ‘from Mascari’, in (4):1

list-item.p: ‘(These things) come out of its nose.’ (14th century , Mascalcia, ARTESIA/OVI, 578. 31)
‘If the wares come from inside or outside Sicily […]’ (14th century, Rinaldi 1, 2)
‘Coming… from Mascali’ (16th century, Sardo B16) 1574)
‘To go out of the aforesaid tower’ (18th century, Sardo B8) 1700)
‘The son comes back from the school’ (19th century, Pitrè LXX)

sec.title: Location and direction
sec.p: Recent studies, among which Nikitina (2009), have shown that in many languages adpositional marking is not sensitive to the distinction between direction and static location.

Consistent with this general tendency, static location in Sicilian can be expressed by the same prepositions as direction. The specific spatial value of the prepositions in question depends on the presence of a state or motion verb respectively, as in (7).

list-item.p: ‘I am at home / in Catania – I am going home / to Catania’

sec.p:
Moreover, in contrast with source, whose expression is entrusted to one preposition only (i.e., di or, alternatively, the variant da ‘from’, see Section 2.1), location and direction can be expressed by diverse prepositions, depending on the type of LM, the lexical semantics of the verb, the type of spatial relation. Three prepositions are mainly employed in these functions: a, (i)n, nn(i). While a and (i)n are ancient forms directly inherited from Latin ad ‘towards, near to, by’ and in ‘in(to)’ respectively (cf. Rohlfs 1969: 203–4, 209–10; Varvaro 1988: 723),2
nn(i) is a more recent form, very frequent in the spoken language and only found in the most recent texts of our corpus.

In contemporary Sicilian the most typical instances of location and direction, those involving place nouns, are expressed by the preposition a ‘at, to’, denoting either a static relation where a TR occupies a portion of the space occupied by the LM, or a dynamic one in which a TR moves towards the LM, as in (7).

A coexists with (i)n in the expression of location/direction throughout the history of Sicilian, although, as we shall see in 2.2.1, their distribution is different at the various stages of the language.

In present day Sicilian, the preposition (i)n is only found in association with bare nouns. More specifically, (i)n is typically employed with non-determined LMs, that is, generic place nouns for ‘city’, ‘country’, ‘mountain’ as in (8), or proper names of states, as in (9), or metaphorical places, as vacanza ‘holiday’ in (10):

list-item.p: ‘I want to live in /go to the countryside’
‘Tomorrow I go/I am on holiday’
‘I want to go to/stay in France’

sec.p: As we will see in Section 2.2.1, the functional domain of (i)n was more extended in the most ancient texts, where the preposition constituted in fact the non-marked choice to express location/direction. Thus, it typically occurred with prototypical locations such as city names. This diachronic scenario may explain the frequent, even if residual, association in present-day Sicilian (at least in some varieties, such as the dialect of Palermo) of (i)n with Palermo, that is, the administrative, cultural and touristic capital of Sicily, as in (11), even if city names are generally associated with a, as showed in (7) above.

list-item.p: ‘I am going to / I am in Palermo.’

sec.p: Finally, (i)n frequently occurs, as well as a, with telic verbs denoting change of position (or ‘final location’, as in Luraghi 2003), such as càriri ‘to fall’ in (12):

list-item.p: ‘Be careful not to fall to the ground!’

sec.p: As for nn(i), the etymology is discussed. It was traced back to the Sicilian adverb unni ‘where’ or to Latin intra or intus (ad) ‘inside’ (cf. Rohlfs 1969: 228; Varvaro 1988: 723; Leone 1995: 52). When it is followed by a word starting with i- it takes the reduced form nn’. The same form is found when the preposition occurs with a noun preceded by a definite article (singular: fem. a and masc. u/o, plural: i); in this case nn(i) fuses with the article giving rise to an articulated preposition, as in (13). In the same contexts it also occurs in the form nt- which, however, is less used in contemporary Sicilian.
Nn(i) selects definite and highly individuated LMs, more specifically, along an increasing hierarchy of individuation:

list-item.p: inanimate nouns preceded by a determiner (article, possessive, demonstrative adjective) as in (13)
animate nouns preceded by a determiner as in (14)
proper nouns (denoting persons or businesses) as in (15)3
oblique forms of personal pronouns, e.g. nni mìa/tia, nn’iddi ‘in/to my/your/their place’ as in (16)
‘I am at the doctor’s office/ my aunt’s house
I am going to the doctor’s office/ my aunt’s house.’
‘I am at Vincenzo’s place /Ikea
I am going to Vincenzo’s place /Ikea.’
‘I am at your place
I am going to your place.’

sec.p: In addition to the three main prepositions expressing location and direction, we can less frequently find (i)ntra ‘within, inside’. It is traced back to the Latin adverb intro followed by the preposition ad (cf. Rohlfs 1969: 210–211). Intra always precedes a sequence determiner + LM, as in (17) , and expresses spatial coincidence between TR and LM, also conveying the idea of occupying/entering a bounded space conceptualized as a container.

list-item.p: ‘He was/went inside a cave.’

sec.p: Finally, ppi ‘through, throughout, all around, along; for’ (also in the variants pri and per, cf. 3.1) may occur in directional expressions always with place nouns. An example is given in (18).

list-item.p: ‘I leave for Palermo/France.’

sec.title: Diachronic perspectives
sec.p: Conflation between location and direction is testified since the oldest texts. Location is preferably expressed by (i)n, eventually followed by the definite article, as in (19), and only occasionally by a, as in (20):

list-item.p: ‘The tavern placed in the district of the Old Fair.’ (14th century, Rinaldi 60.1)
‘These are the things that the aforementioned has in Messina at home.’ (14th century, Rinaldi 58.25)

sec.p: The Example in (20) shows the co-occurrence of the two prepositions, namely: in Missina testifies a wider use of the case of ‘in Palermo’ discussed in 2.2 (Example (11)), allowing the association of the preposition with other city names; a chasa sua illustrates the presence of a to express location according to a choice that is only emergent in these texts, but will be prevailing over time.

A mainly occurs in association with LMs such as ‘air’, ‘sun’, ‘wind’, ‘fire’, as in (21), where it conveys a relation in which the TR does not occupy a portion of the space occupied by the LM, but is placed in front of it.

list-item.p: ‘Dry it out by the sun or the fire.’ (14th century, Mascalcia, OVI 585, 24–25)

sec.p: Nevertheless, in these texts a is more frequently found in alternation with (i)n in directional expressions as in (22), where the two prepositions exhibit a high degree of overlap:

list-item.p: ‘To bring back that thing in the place from where he will have taken it.’ (14th century, Rinaldi 1.65)

sec.p: Location and direction can be expressed by nn(i) starting from the 19th century texts. In (23), nn(i) expresses direction with a prototypical LM, i.e., cammara ‘room’, while in (24) it is found with a human LM, i.e., lu Re ‘the King’:

list-item.p: ‘He leaves into his room.’ (19th century, Pitrè LII)
‘He wants to go to the King.’ (19th century, Pitrè LVI)

sec.p: An example of location conveyed by nn(i) is in (25), where the preposition (nni lu sularu ‘in the attic storage room’) occurs in the reply to a question containing the verb ‘to be’ and, hence, in a static context:

list-item.p: ‘«Where is the Dragon?» «He is here, upstairs, in the attic storage room»’ (19th century, Pitrè CXXX)

sec.p: Nn(i) may alternate with ‘ntra, that is always used to indicate location, as in (26), or direction, as in (27), into a bounded LM.

list-item.p: ‘There were many things inside the building.’ (19th century, Pitrè LXVI)
‘He went into the room.’ (19th century, Pitrè LIV)

sec.p: Occasional instances of ppi/pri/per in directional expressions occur throughout the corpus:

list-item.p: ‘And it was that morning that I went to Palermo’ (17th / 18th century, Sardo P22)
‘He jumped towards the head of the rooster.’ (19th century, Pitrè LII)

sec.title: Path
sec.p: As we have already mentioned (see Section 1), it is generally argued that the encoding of path appears to be less autonomous compared to source (ablative), location (locative), and direction (allative) at the cross-linguistic level. However, Sicilian has a dedicated preposition to express path, that is, (p)pi ‘through, throughout, all around’. This specialized means coexists and partially overlaps with the locative preposition nn(i) ‘in’, discussed in 2.2, which may convey a path meaning as well, and with a non-prepositional strategy, namely nominal reduplication.

sec.title: The preposition (p)pi ‘through’
sec.p: The preposition (p)pi continues Lat. per ‘through’; it may also appear as pri (see Rohlfs 1969: 212) or, especially in the more ancient written texts, as pir and per.

From a semasiological perspective, (p)pi configures various types of relations, according to the contextual information, which adds details to the basic semantics. Like the Latin preposition from which it originated, in fact, (p)pi only depicts an extended location, that is, a multiplicity of contiguous points occupied by a TR through a LM (cf. Brucale & Mocciaro 2011).4 This basic meaning can be variously instantiated in more specific TR/LM relations, depending on the features of the LM and, largely, on the lexical semantics of the verb.

In the most typical instances of Sicilian texts, (p)pi describes a unidirectional trajectory along a LM consisting of a surface, such as a street, a field etc. Whether the trajectory is progressively covered or occupied by the TR in a static way depends on the semantics of the verb.

The unidirectional path reading is more likely associated with a motion event. This is the case of caminari ‘to walk’ in (30), describing an “imperfective path”, in terms of Taylor (1993: 158), that is, a non-goal oriented path having an indeterminate extent; in this case, the atemporal relation expressed by the preposition refers to an arbitrary portion of the path:

list-item.p: ‘I was walking along that street.’

sec.p: Goal-oriented paths may be instead suggested by directional motion verbs, such as veniri ‘to come’ in (31), or by motion verbs denoting some sort of “crossing”, such as passari when it means ‘to cross, to overshoot’, as in (32) and (33). In these cases, the verb attributes a telic (i.e., “perfective”) trajectory to the TR, while (p)pi describes a boundary-crossing trajectory through a LM conceived of as a bi- or three-dimensional entity (i.e., a bounded piece of land and a city door, respectively):

list-item.p: ‘He came through that street.’
‘Peter passed through the acreage.’
‘She was crossing the Garibaldi gate.’

sec.p: But the goal implication is only an effect of the overall context (e.g. the inherent goal orientation of the verb or the structure of the LM) and it does not inherently belong to the semantics of (p)pi. As a matter of fact, the unidirectional path it expresses is more typically unspecified as far as the endpoint is concerned, as illustrated in (34), where it occurs with the verb iri “to go”:

list-item.p: ‘Peter went away through that street.’

sec.p: Stative verbs trigger a static reading. Cases in point are the two examples of essiri ‘to be’, in (35), where the mobile TR (the unexpressed 1st person pronoun) provisionally occupies an unspecified point within the trajectory, and in (36), where the house is placed at a point of the path in a stable way. In both cases, however, the context (namely the noun strata ‘street’, a LM which is typically “travelled”) still suggests motion, whether actual, as in (35), or fictive (i.e., hypothetical), as in (36).

list-item.p: ‘I am coming, I am on my way.’
‘Maria’s house is along the street.’

sec.p: Finally, with atelic motion verbs, such as firriari ‘to wander, roam’, and LMs denoting extended and bounded areas (e.g. a city or a village, as in (37)) or with plural LMs (such as streets in (38)), the preposition describes a multidirectional and scattered trajectory, whose scope is entirely inside the LM:

list-item.p: ‘She goes all around the village.’
‘She is hanging around the streets of the village.’

sec.title: The locative preposition nn(i) ‘in, inside’
sec.p: A path may be described in terms of location. In this case, the preposition nn(i) ‘in’ is selected, which partially overlaps with (p)pi in denoting an extended location within which an activity takes place;5 in this value, in fact, nn(i) occurs with atelic motion verbs, such as curriri ‘to run’ in (39):

list-item.p: ‘I was running on the beach.’

sec.p: This usage of nn(i), however, is not attested in the ancient Sicilian texts, and is not highly productive in present day Sicilian, where it seems to be limited to specific and individuated LMs, as in (39), where ‘beach’ may only indicate a specific beach and not a generic one.

sec.title: Nominal reduplication
sec.p: The multidirectional relation expressed by (p)pi in cases such as (37) and (38) is more frequently encoded in Sicilian by means of a non-prepositional construction consisting in the doubling of a place noun, such as strata ‘way, street, road’ or casa ‘house, home’. This mechanism, called nominal reduplication (henceforth NR), produces new adverbial forms expressing the spatial extension of the event denoted by the verb (e.g. strata strata ‘(lit.) street street > along / throughout the street / somewhere in the street’).

The existence of such constructions is anything but rare in the world languages (see Haspelmath 1995). As for Sicilian, it has been traditionally observed in the dialectological research, but studies such as Caracausi (1977), Migliorini (1968), Rohlfs (1969: 89–92) have been especially concerned with the origin of the construction, variously said to be generically Italo-Romance (“polygenetic hypothesis”) or specifically Sicilian (or, more widely, Southern Italo-Romance) on a Greek basis (“monogenetic hypotheses”).

More recently, NR has received renewed attention on the basis of the current linguistic theories, and various studies have especially highlighted its syntactic behaviour (Sgarioto 2005; Amenta 2010) or the morphological status (Todaro 2012; Todaro, Villoing, Gréa 2014); we will refer to these studies in more detail in what follows.

In Sicilian, NR belongs to a wider phenomenon involving various other lexical categories, namely verbs (e.g. manciannu manciannu ‘by dint of eating’), adjectives (nicu nicu ‘small small > very small’), other adverbs (uora uora ‘now now > just now’). The adverbial forms produced by NR exhibit, however, some restrictions (cf. Sgarioto 2005: 39; Amenta 2010: 124; Todaro, Villoing, Gréa 2014), such as: (a) no insertion possible between nouns (*casa and casa); (b) single primary stress ([kasa’kasa]); (c) no recursivity (*casa, casa and casa). The observation of such a behaviour has suggested to Todaro, Villoing, Gréa (2014) an analysis as a lexical unit (NNadv), rather than as a syntactic segment. According to them, when the result of reduplication does not meet these criteria, it should be better characterized as “reiteration”, that is, a syntactic rather than morphological mechanism. While we agree with these authors on the relevance of the presence or absence of such restrictions and, therefore, on the specific character of NR, we will not take a stance here on the exact status, whether morphological or syntactic (or in the between of them), of the form we are dealing with.6

Syntactically, as an adverb, the result of NR is frequently an adjunct, although it may hold argumental function when the argumental structure of the verb it occurs with requires to be filled with a locative element (e.g. with ‘to be’, as in i cuasetti sunnu casa casa ‘the socks are somewhere at home’).

NR mainly occurs with atelic motion verbs (e.g. caminari ‘to walk’, curriri ‘to run’), but it also typically involves caused motion verbs (e.g. purtari ‘to bring’, stricari ‘to rub’) and stative verbs (e.g. essiri ‘to be’, stari ‘to stay’).7 Only rarely, it occurs with telic motion verbs (e.g. venire ‘to come’, cited in Caracausi 1977: 386). Depending on the verb, as well as the features of the LM, NR describes different types of trajectory.

When occurring with atelic motion verbs, such as rruzzulàrisi ‘to fall’ in (40) and caminari ‘to walk’ in (41), or with transitive verbs implying motion, such as ciccari ‘to look for’ in (42), NR indicates a multidirectional trajectory within a LM conceived of as an extended and bounded surface (e.g. house, village, etc.):

list-item.p: ‘Pino fell down the stairs.’ (adapted from Leone 1995: 32)
‘I am walking throughout the house.’
‘I looked for that in various drawers /everywhere in the drawers.’ (adapted from Leone 1995: 32).

sec.p: It should be observed that NR shows number sensitivity, as the presence of plural LMs triggers a “distributive” interpretation (‘from a street to another’, see Caracausi 1977: 386; Sgarioto 2005: 39), as in (43), lacking instead when the LM is instantiated by singular nouns, as in (40).

list-item.p: ‘Pino is shouting around the alleys.’ (adapted from Caracausi 1977: 386)

sec.p: In the multidirectional cases in (40)–(43), NR partially overlaps with the prepositional phrase introduced by (p)pi in the uses described in (37) and (38).

In other cases, however, NR describes a unidirectional path within the LM, when the LM is a linear extension, as binariu binariu ‘along the railway’ in (44). Like (p)pi in (30), NR here refers to an unspecified segment of the overall path, thus fitting the “imperfective” (i.e., not goal-oriented) indication already provided by the atelic verb caminari ‘to walk’:

list-item.p: ‘They walked along the railway.’(Todaro, Villoing, Gréa 2014: 181)

sec.p: The structure of the LM undoubtedly favours a “linear” interpretation of the path in (44). The same goes for ciumi ciumi ‘(lit.) river river’ as in scinniri ciumi ciumi ‘to go down along the river’. However, the presence of stative verbs, as ‘to be’ in (45), suggests a vaguer localization, so that ciumi ciumi here means ‘somewhere in the river’ (Todaro, Villoing, Gréa 2014: 183–4):

list-item.p: ‘Peter is (somewhere) in the river.’

sec.p: Thus, we should conclude that path interpretation in cases such as (44) results from both the structure of the LM and the semantics of motion verbs.

The role played by the verb in triggering the path interpretation is confirmed by the possible occurrence of NR in telic contexts, although these contexts seem to be very limited. Caracausi (1977: 386) cites the deictic venire ‘to come’, in cases such as veniri mari mari ‘to come through the see / along the beach’. In such cases, the goal orientation of the verb suggests a (unidirectional) path reading even if the LM mari mari ‘(literally) sea sea’ does not inherently describe a linear extension. The same may hold true for iri ‘to go’ when expressing a displacement meaning, as in jirisinni acqua acqua ‘to go away through the water’ (Caracausi 1977: 386); as in the case of ppi in (31), here ‘to go’ triggers a unidirectional path reading, unspecified as far as the goal is concerned. More typically, however, iri (or irisinni) is involved in the expression of multidirectional or distributive trajectories, as in iri voschira voschira ‘to go around the woods’, iri scirbi scirbi ‘to go around steep places’ (Caracausi 1977: 386).

With stative verbs, instead, the path interpretation cannot be activated and NR expresses other types of spatial configuration, also depending on the features of the TR, e.g. when the TR is an inanimate mass noun, such as fangu ‘mud’ in (46) or with plural TRs, such as chiova ‘nails’ in (47), NR denotes its homogeneous distribution all over the LM (Todaro, Villoing, Gréa 2014: 184–85).

list-item.p: ‘The mud is (spattered) all over the wall.’
‘The nails are all over the wall.’

sec.title: Diachronic perspectives
sec.p: The diachronic observation of the data shows the early presence of (p)pi to express the path relation. This is not unexpected, as (p)pi continues Latin per. However, the native form coexists with the semantically equivalent per, which reflects the influence of external linguistic models, namely Latin itself (for a long time, a formal model for administrative and legal texts, widely soaked with “formulaic language”) and/or Tuscan, that is, the linguistic forerunner of Italian (see Sardo 2008: 9 ff.).
(P)pi/per expresses:

list-item.p: a unidirectional trajectory along a surface (e.g. a sea), when occurring with motion verbs or, as in (49) and (50), caused motion verbs;
a boundary-crossing trajectory, with LMs conceived of as channels (e.g. nostril), as in (51);
a multidirectional trajectory, with extended or plural LMs and atelic motion verbs, as in (52) and (53).

‘The horse expels all the moisture through the nostrils.’ (14th century , Mascalcia, ARTESIA, 585, 15.15)

sec.p: Nominal reduplication is very early attested, already in medieval Latin texts, such as a document dating back to the age of Henry VI (12th century), dealing with the definition of territorial boundaries, reported in Rolfhs (1969: 89): Hi vero sunt termini…incipit enim a mandra Bufalorum…et deinde vadit per cristam cristam Gipsi…et vadit vallonem vallonem ad flumen Hymbelno et vadit flumen flumen usque…et vadit viam viam… et ascendit flumen flumen. The example shows both the simple reduplication of the noun in the accusative case (vallonem vallonem, viam viam, flumen flumen) and the redundant presence of the preposition per to govern the doubled noun. Both forms actually appear in the traditional collections of Medieval Latin texts of Sicily, such as Garufi (1899), e.g. recipit viam viam (1131 CE); deinde cristam cristam (1159 CE); descendit per cristam cristam (1092 CE); ascendit per flumen flumen…per vallonem vallonem (1115 CE); vadit per montem montem (1172 CE) etc. According to Caracausi (1977: 390), the presence of per should be interpreted as an attempt to adapt to the Latin syntax a non-Latin (most likely Greek) influence. As argued by Rohlfs (1925, 1964, 1969), in fact, NR widely occurs in Greek documents of Sicily (and Southern Italy) of the Medieval age.8

Interestingly, this form is absent in the most ancient texts in Sicilian language, probably due to the pressure of the Latin and Tuscan models, which produced a split between oral and written (formal and formulaic) language. As a matter of fact, first documentation (thus, we suppose the emergence of a form obscured for a long while in the written language) is in Pitrè’s (1875) collection of tales and folk short stories.

list-item.p: ‘He begins to tumble down the stairs.’ (Pitrè LXVII)
‘And the sailors began to run throughout the boat.’ (Pitrè LI)

sec.title: Spatial relation in Sicilian: A systematization
sec.p: On the whole, the system of basic spatial relations is quite stable throughout the history of Sicilian. We can summarize the diachronic development of spatial relations in Sicilian, as it emerges from the scrutiny of our data, as in Table 1:9

caption.title: Development of the spatial relations system in Sicilian (14th to present day language)

sec.p: Less schematically, the history of spatial relations in Sicilian can be described as follow:

list-item.p: Source. This spatial relation is stably associated with a preposition only, i.e., di, which co-occurs with the form da in texts influenced by the Tuscan model.
Location and Direction. These relations exhibit a high degree of overlap since the oldest texts, although the ratio of the diverse prepositions varies at the different stages of the language.

In the most ancient texts, the unmarked choice to express location and direction appears to be (i)n ‘in’, with both determined and non-determined LMs; a, instead, occurs only occasionally, especially in cases of spatial non-coincidence TR/LM and mainly to express direction. The functional domain of a spreads throughout the history of the language, so that it prevails in contemporary texts, beside nn(i).

Nn(i) is not attested before the 19th century, when it starts to occur copiously in literary texts of our corpus to express both location and direction (and this sudden stability suggests that the preposition was already established in the oral language). Nn(i) erodes the functional domain of (i)n, limited in present day language to bare nouns. It does not disappear, however; rather, the coexistence of old and new forms becomes, somehow, a functional opposition, so that (i)n comes to express mainly indefinite LMs, whereas nn(i) is specialized for the marking of definiteness (along a scale of individuation: personal pronouns, proper names, common nouns with determiners). Table 2 summarizes the distribution of (i)n and nn(i):
Table 2.
Distribution of (i)n and nn(i) in present day Sicilian
(i)n
nn(i) (definiteness)
Indefinite name of places (e.g. campagna ‘country’) Personal pronouns (oblique forms)
Indefinite names of metaphorical places (vacanza ‘holiday’) Inherently individuated nouns (proper names)
Syntactically individuated nouns:
–
human common nouns plus determiner
–
inanimate common nouns plus determiner
(Peripheral inconsistency: names of State; Palermo in some varieties of Sicilian)

Since the most ancient texts, nn(i) alternates with (i)ntra ‘in, into, within, inside’ both in location and in direction expressions; (i)ntra has however a more restricted use throughout the corpus and is exclusively found in contexts where there is coincidence between TR and LM, and the latter is conceived of as a container.

Direction may also be expressed by ppi ‘for (‘through’)’ (also in the variants pri and per, the latter due to the pressure from the Latin and/or Tuscan model), which is occasionally found already in the oldest texts of our corpus.

Path. Ppi and its variants, however, are better specialized throughout the history of Sicilian in the expression of path. Basically, ppi depicts an extended location, i.e., a succession of contiguous points occupied by a TR through the LM. When involved in motion (or caused motion) events, it can describe both a unidirectional and a multidirectional path. A unidirectional interpretation is most likely associated with a (goal-oriented or not goal oriented) directional motion event or with verbs denoting a kind of crossing; a multidirectional reading is, instead, activated in constructions with atelic motion verbs and LMs denoting extended and bounded areas or with plural LMs.

sec.p: Starting from 19th century texts, ppi denotes multidirectional trajectories beside nominal reduplication, i.e., a non-prepositional construction consisting in the doubling of a place noun (e.g. strata strata ‘lit. street street’), which produces adverbial forms. Although attested since Medieval Latin texts, this mechanism is absent in the most ancient texts of our corpus, probably because of the pressure from the Latin and Tuscan models, which produced a split between oral and written language.

In the expression of multidirectional paths, NR with atelic motion verbs and caused motion verbs; in these cases, it expresses the scattered spatial extension of the event denoted by the verb. Sporadically, if the LM represents a linear extension, NR may also express a unidirectional path within the LM.
This description highlights two major aspects characterizing the system of spatial relation in Sicilian:

list-item.p: consistent with a cross-linguistic tendency, the relation between source and direction is asymmetric, as the latter receives a richer and more fine-grained expression; moreover, direction conflates into locative expression;

in contrast with a cross-linguistic tendency, which predicts a lower degree of autonomy for path, this role has a dedicated preposition, ppi ‘through’, and makes use of a non-prepositional strategy as well, namely a nominal reduplication.

sec.p: While these observations surely describe the present situation of Sicilian, further details may emerge from a more in-depth (and merely synchronic) scrutiny of contemporary data, which also should include local variation. This is a starting point for further research.

ack.p: The whole paper results from the close collaboration of the authors. However, Luisa Brucale is responsible for Sections 2 and 4, and Egle Mocciaro for Sections 1 and 3.

fn.p: Di and da differ etymologically. The former continues the Latin preposition de ‘from’ and, while it expresses a wide range of meanings both in Sicilian and in Italian (e.g. genitive, partitive, cause, origin as in è di Napoli ‘he is from Naples’, topic, etc.), it is associated with Source only in Sicilian (and in other Southern varieties of Italo-Romance). In present-day Italian, instead, the expression of Source is entrusted to da, an Italo-Romance innovation deriving from the fusion of the de + ab, both meaning ‘from’ (see Rohlfs 1968: 219–221; Vincent 1997: 213; Luraghi 2011: 221). It should be noticed, however, that in more ancient stages of Italian, di may express the same ablative meaning as da (see Andreose 2010: 656 ff.).

The two prepositions, however, are connected with different spatial scenes, namely: ad basically expresses the position of the TR in the vicinity of the LM with no consequent coincidence between TR and LM, thus designating mere proximity to a LM; in schematically indicates, instead, coincidence between a portion of the LM and a portion of the space occupied by the TR and, moreover, it specifies that the LM was conceived of as a container for the TR (Luraghi 2011: 212–213). While these basic configurations largely governed the distribution of spatial relations in Latin (and are partially still observable in more ancient stages of the language, see 2.2.1) in and ad frequently overlap, as ad also occurs in contexts where one would expect in, already in Early Latin (Hofmann & Szantyr 1965: 224; Luraghi 2010: 27).

Location and direction with proper nouns denoting businesses can be also expressed by means of a followed by the definite article, like the other place nouns, Sugnu/Vaiu all’Ikea ‘I am at Ikea/I am going to Ikea.).
Like other corresponding Italo-Romance prepositions (see Rohlfs 1969: 211).

The overlap location/path is not unexpected at the cross-linguistic level (e.g. Engl. Mary walks in the field). For instance, Luraghi (2010: 38) describes this overlap in Latin, where in ‘in’ + ablative profiles the LM as “a bounded region within which the trajector moves” (non arietant inter se nisi in eadem ambulantes via ‘they do not bump into each other unless they are walking in the same street’, Sen. Epist.103,5).

We merely observe here that some of these restrictions also apply to adjectival, verbal and adverbial reduplication. Recursion seems to be the property that most clearly distinguishes the other reduplications from NR; this issue, however, certainly deserves further investigation.

This classification is consistent with Sgarioto (2005), who also indicates a fourth class of verbs occurring with NR, namely transitive verbs denoting a change of state, such as rumpiri ‘to break’, tagghiari ‘to cut’, e.g. tagghiari pizzuddi pizzuddi ‘to cut into small pieces’; this class, however, is not relevant to our purposes, as it does not involve spatial expressions.
For a wider discussion on the presence of Greek in Sicily, see De Angelis (2014).

Data on medieval texts are in parentheses because they are not derived from our direct scrutiny. However, they deserve attention, thus we include them in the general description. Pluses and minuses respectively indicate the presence or the absence of the prepositions listed in the left column along the diachronic stages of the language (represented in the right columns); they should be conceived of as scalar value and, in fact, admit an intermediate stage (±).

title-group.title: Source-oriented and goal-oriented events in old and Modern French
title-group.alt-title: Source-oriented and goal-oriented events in old and Modern French

contrib-group.aff: Laboratoire Dynamique du Langage, UMR 5596 CNRS & Université de Lyon

abstract.p: In the development from Old to Modern French one of the changes involves a morphosyntactic reorganization of the expression of Path of motion. Old French had several micro-systems to express Path including verb prefixes and verb particles. However, their productivity has decreased over the centuries and, as a consequence, the expression of Path in Modern French relies more heavily on verbs. The aim of this chapter is to investigate the effects of this change on the expression of Source-oriented and Goal-oriented events. Based on data extracted from medieval texts and their translations into Modern French, the study shows that the availability of verb prefixes and particles in Old French and their relatively free combinability with verbs of motion allows for a more fine-grained expression of the initial and final component of Path, and a more frequent description of complex Path that includes both Source and Goal-related information. The descriptions of motion in Modern French, on the other hand, put less emphasis on these two parts of Path, leaving, at times, some spatial information to be inferred from the context.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the development from Latin to Romance and later on from Old to Modern French, among several grammatical changes (see e.g. Marchello-Nizia 2002, 2006; Ashdowne & Smith 2007; Fagard, Prévost, Combettes & Bertrand 2008; Ledgeway 2012), one change involves a morphosyntactic reorganization of the expression of motion events (e.g. Kopecka 2006; Iacobini & Fagard 2011; Burnett & Tremblay 2012; Stolova 2015; Iacobini 2015). Old French possessed a variety of means to convey the meaning of directionality, including a rich repertoire of verb prefixes and particles, besides verbs, adverbs, and prepositions (Nyrop 1936; Buridant 2000; Dufresne, Dupuis & Tremblay 2003; Iacobini 2015). This relatively elaborate system of verb prefixes and particles had been, however, progressively reduced through Middle up until Modern French (Foulet 1946; Dufresne, Dupuis & Longtin 2001; Dufresne, Dupuis & Tremblay 2003; Burnett & Tremblay 2012). Consequently, while some residues of the older system persist in the language, in Modern French the expression of directionality (henceforth Path of motion) relies more heavily on verbs.

Previous research has shown that the typological differences between Old and Modern French in the types of linguistic devices used to express Path lead to distinct ways of describing motion events and have an effect on the type of information conveyed in discourse (Kopecka 2009a, 2013). It has been shown, for instance, that lexicalization patterns (cf. Talmy 1985, 1991, 2000) – that is, whether the meaning of Path is conveyed by the verb or by a verb satellite (a prefix or a particle) – have consequences for the ways Manner is expressed in motion descriptions. In Old French, where Path is conveyed by prefixes and particles (satellite-framed pattern) Manner of motion tends to be described more often due to the availability of the verb slot. By contrast, in Modern French, where Path is lexicalized in the main verb (verb-framed pattern), Manner tends to be omitted or, where the context requires, to be encoded periphrastically in an adverbial expression (Kopecka 2009a; see also Slobin 2004 for a cross-linguistic analysis of this phenomenon).1 Furthermore, it has been observed that the morphosyntactic reorganization of motion events has implications for the semantic granularity of Path. That is, the availability of verb prefixes and particles in Old French allows an elaboration of Path in a more explicit and a semantically more fine-grained way. In Modern French on the other hand more emphasis is given to scene-settings, and some Path-related information needs to be inferred from the context (Kopecka 2013).

The aim of this paper is to explore the effects of the typological change in lexicalization patterns from a satellite- to a verb-framed pattern further, and to deepen the analysis of the expression of Path of motion. More specifically, its aim is to investigate how Source-oriented events, which consist in leaving the initial location, and Goal-oriented events, which consist in moving to(ward) the final location (see Stefanowitsch & Rohde 2004; Kopecka & Narasimhan 2012; Goschler & Stefanowitsch 2013) are described in Old and Modern French.

Source-oriented and Goal-oriented events represent an interesting domain to study for both synchronic and diachronic reasons. Source and Goal have been claimed to display some asymmetries in linguistic encoding and cognitive representation (e.g. Bourdin 1987; Ikegami 1987; Ungerer & Schmid 1996; Verspoor, Dirven & Radden 1998; Lakusta & Landau 2005; Regier & Zheng 2007). In particular, it has been postulated that there is a bias towards the Goal over the Source, and that speakers of different languages express the Goal more frequently, and in a more detailed fashion in discourse than the Source. This preference given to the final parts of events has been largely attributed to the pragmatic relevance and the cognitive salience of the Goal, that is its informational value and its perceptual prominence. The present paper explores another factor that might play a role in the expression of Source- and Goal-oriented events, and which has not been the subject of much study so far, namely the role of lexicalization patterns in the more or less asymmetrical encoding of the initial and final part of the events. To examine in what way language-specific patterns shape the expression of Source- and Goal-oriented events, the study adopts a diachronic approach and investigates how such events are expressed at two different time periods in French, the medieval and contemporary period.

In what follows I first present some typological characteristics of Old French in the domain of motion, and show the change that French has undergone in the expression of motion events (Section 2). I next focus on the expression of Path to examine the types of events found in motion descriptions in Old and Modern French and the ways Path is segmented in verb clauses (Section 3). I then examine the attention allocated to initial and final parts of Path (Section 4) and, finally, I consider the role of the particle en ‘from there’ in the expression of Path and its components (Section 5).

sec.title: A typological change in the distribution of spatial semantics in French
sec.p: As mentioned in the introduction, Old French had several micro-systems – verbs, verb prefixes, verb particles, adverbs, and prepositions – to describe Path and its different parts, and it was characterized by a certain “grammatical freedom” with regards to the combinability of these resources in the expression of motion events (cf. Fleischman 1990). To illustrate some of the properties of Old French in the expression of motion, Example (1) below shows how Path could be distributed through the sentence in different grammatical and lexical elements. Example (1) describes a complex motion event in which the main protagonist changes her location with respect to different reference points such as the initial, medial, and final one. The first sequence of the event, expressed by the verb complex s’en torner ‘turn away’, consists in leaving a place. While the verb root torner denotes the change of direction, motion away from the initial location is conveyed here by the particle en meaning ‘from there’. The second sequence consists in passing from one side of a reference point to the other, and it is expressed by the prefixed verb trespasser ‘pass across’. The verb root passer conveys the meaning of translational motion via medial location, and motion across the boundary is specified by the prefix tres- meaning ‘across’. Finally, the third sequence of the event consists of motion directed toward the final location. It is described by the complex predicate revenir arrière ‘come back’ which includes the verb venir ‘come’, the verb prefix re- meaning ‘back’, and the adverbial particle arriere meaning ‘backward’.

Par maltalent s’ en est tornee/ S’ a tres-passee la charrier ;/ A sa dame re-vient arriere.

‘Maddened, she turned away, crossed the street, returned back to her mistress.’

sec.p: One of the interesting aspects of Old French is the fact that it has several pairs of verb particles and verb prefixes encoding the same meaning component. This is shown in (2) where the particles sus, hors and ens convey similar meanings as the prefixes sur-, ex- and en- respectively. It should be noted, however, that, while extensively used in Old French, the co-existence of these two parallel systems was not distinctive of Old French. The two systems date back to Indo-European and are found not only in earlier stages of Romance (see Dufresne, Dupuis & Tremblay 2003 and Marchello-Nizia 2002 for Old French; Iacobini & Masini 2006 for Italian; and Iacobini 2015 for a more general overview of Romance languages) but also in other branches of the Indo-European family (Vincent 1999).

Importantly, verb particles and prefixes could co-occur in the descriptions of motion events and, by doing so, they could each contribute to the expression of Path. In particular, while the combination of two prefixes with the same verb was not common in Old French, a verb particle could co-occur within a verb clause together with a prefix or with another particle. When doing so, the two elements could express the same portion of Path, as in (3) where both the particle en and the prefix de- refer to the initial portion of Path, or describe different portions of Path, as in (4) where the particle amont specifies motion upward and the particle en motion away.2

sec.p: While verb prefixes and verb particles do not have the same morphosyntactic behavior (particles being more independent with respect to the verb than prefixes), they have similar semantic characteristics and form a semantic unit with the verb (for a detailed discussion of the morphological vs. syntactic behavior of prefixes and particles in OF see Dufresne, Dupuis & Tremblay 2003). In Old French, they both formed a productive system and could combine with a great diversity of verbs, including spontaneous and caused motion verbs. Yet, while extensively used in Old French, the system of verb prefixes and verb particles decreased over the centuries. The weakening of their productivity started in the Middle French period (c. 14th–15th century) and took place gradually at different periods for different prefixes and particles (see e.g. Foulet 1946; Dufresne, Dupuis & Tremblay 2000; Dufresne, Dupuis & Longtin 2001).3 Also, although many verbs could combine relatively freely with different prefixes in Old French, some of them lost their lexical autonomy and merged lexically with a prefix (e.g. arriver ‘arrive’ < a- ‘up to’ + river ‘sail along the shore’, affluer ‘flow to’ < a- ‘up to’ + fluer ‘flow’).4

As a result of the declining productivity of verb prefixes and particles along with the univerbation of prefixes and some verb stems (processes that triggered the semantic integration of the directional meaning into the verb), the expression of Path of motion in Modern French relies largely on verbs. Examples (5) from Old French and (5′) from Modern French illustrate this change in the expression of Path. In (5), Path of motion (here the change of location from inside to outside) is specified by both the main verb ist ‘went out’ and the particle fors ‘out(ward)’. By contrast, in (5′), which is a translation of the same event into Modern French, the information about the initial portion of Path is merely conveyed by the verb sortit ‘went out’; there is no particle accompanying this verb.

sec.p: ‘Guillaume went out of the room without having taken leave.’

As shown by the Examples (5) and (5′), the distribution of Path of motion differs: by encoding Path in a verb particle (in addition to the main verb in this particular example), Old French displays the satellite-framed pattern; in contrast, in Modern French, the expression of Path relies on the verb and preference is given to the verb-framed pattern (see also Kopecka 2006, forthcoming; Iacobini 2015; Stolova 2015).

What are the consequences of this change for the expression of Source-oriented and Goal-oriented events? Do the initial and final parts of Path receive the same attention in the descriptions of motion in Old and Modern French? To investigate these questions, I conducted a text-based study using the parallel corpus method. In particular, I compared short narratives from Old French (12th–14th centuries) and their translations into Modern French (Dufournet 1998; Leclanche 2003). The narratives on which this study is based are short satirical tales (fabliaux) about noble medieval society. Besides rich descriptions of people, their habits and behaviors, these texts contain abundant descriptions of motion performed in various scene-settings, representing thereby a valuable source of data. Performed orally by jugglers, these texts are characterized by their vernacular style, and likewise are translated in a colloquial rather than literary register in Modern French. From these texts, I extracted all the descriptions of spontaneous (self-agentive) motion events (as opposed to caused (agentive) motion events, cf. Talmy 2000). In total, the data set consists of 258 verb clauses in Old French, and 261 verb clauses in Modern French.5 The analysis of the data will focus on two phenomena: the types of event descriptions found in narratives, and the attention to the initial and final portion of Path.

sec.title: Types of events in Old French narratives and Modern French translations
sec.p: Let us first examine how Path and its different parts are described in narratives. Are the preferences as to the types of Path encoded in the descriptions of change of location similar or different in Old and Modern French?

sec.title: Simplex vs. complex Path expressions
sec.p: Before we investigate the types of Path components found in the data, let us first examine overall similarities and differences in the ways Path is encoded in Old and Modern French. In general, two main types of expression can be distinguished, simplex and complex Path expressions. Simplex Path expressions consist in encoding one component of Path only, the initial, medial or final one. This is the case in Example (6) from Old French. It expresses a Goal-oriented event in which the final point is indicated by the adverbial expression la sus meaning ‘up there’. The role of the deictic adverb la in this example is to reinforce the spatial particle sus by indicating the final location.6

list-item.p:
Old French (Leclanche 2003: 112, ME 112–113)
Or vos sofrés un poi ichi ; / G’ irai la sus, venés aprés.

‘Now wait here a moment; I will go up there, come after me.’

sec.p: Complex Path expressions, by contrast, comprise two components of Path or more. This is illustrated in Example (7) from Old French, which describes motion away from an initial point via a medial point. The initial part of Path is referred to by the particle en ‘from there’, which occurs in the verb complex s’en va ‘goes away’, and the medial portion of Path is indicated by the prepositional expression par mi meaning ‘through, (lit.) through the middle’.

‘Thus goes away through the hall the priest with his niece (…)’

sec.p: Table 1 below shows the number of occurrences of simplex and complex Path expressions found in OF texts and MF translations. The table also includes the expressions of motion with no overt specification of Path (e.g. ils se hâtèrent ‘they hurried up’ in MF). In both OF and MF simplex Path expressions are the most frequent. Yet, they are more numerous in MF: they account for 84.3% of the verb clauses in the MF data, and 74.4% of the verb clauses in the OF data; accordingly, complex Path expressions are more numerous in the OF data where they represent 20.5% of the verb clauses in OF against 11.5% in MF (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 8.42, p < 0.01).

caption.title: Simplex vs. complex Path expression in OF and MF

sec.title: Types of simplex vs. complex Path expressions
sec.p: Now, if we take a closer look at the parts of Path expressed in narratives, we notice that there are some subtle differences between the OF and MF data. Table 2 below shows in more detail the types of simplex and complex events found in the data. Among simplex Path expressions are (a) Goal-oriented events, which consist of motion directed to a final location, (b) Source-oriented events, which consist of motion directed away from an initial location, and (c) Medial-oriented events, which consist of motion via a medial part of Path. As for the complex Path expressions, there are three types of configuration as well: (a) motion from Source to Goal, (b) motion via Medial to Goal, and (c) motion from Source via Medial.

The main difference between the OF and MF data lies in the expression of simplex Goal-oriented events on the one hand, and complex Source-and-Goal oriented events on the other hand. Goal-oriented events represent 42.2% of the verb clauses in OF and 52.1% of the verb clauses in MF. As for complex Source-and-Goal oriented events, they account for 17.8% of the descriptions in OF and merely 9.2% of them in MF. There is no such discrepancy in the expression of other portions of Path (Pearson’s Chi-squared test: 13.2, p < 0.03).

caption.title: Types of simplex and complex Path expressions in OF and MF

sec.p: As the data suggests, the decrease of the productivity of verb prefixes and verb particles that has taken place in French over the centuries has not only caused a structural change with regard to the preferential locus for Path encoding, but also it has induced a change with regard to the encoding of Path and its different parts. Namely, the results presented in Table 2 above suggests that some of the complex Source-and-Goal events in the OF texts tend to be expressed in MF as simplex Goal-oriented events. We shall explore the role played by verb satellites in the expression of complex Path events in the OF texts later in Section 5.

sec.title: Attention to initial and final portions of Path
sec.p: After having considered the types of Path expressions found in OF and MF data, let us now focus more specifically on the expression of the initial and final portion of Path. In particular, we will examine how these parts of Path are expressed in the OF and the MF texts and to which part, the initial or the final, more attention is given in the descriptions of motion. In what follows we first examine simplex events – Source-oriented (Section 4.1) and Goal-oriented (Section 4.2), and then we investigate complex events oriented from Source to Goal (Section 4.3).

sec.title: Source-oriented events
sec.p: Table 3 shows the types of verb constructions, with and without a satellite (a verb particle or a verb prefix), and their number of tokens in the expression of Source-oriented events in the OF and MF texts respectively.

While the overall proportion of Source-oriented events is alike (N = 58 in OF and N = 56 in MF), there is a notable difference between OF and MF with regards to the use of verbs and satellites in this type of event. Thus, the use of verbs alone accounts for 39.7% of the verb clauses in OF and as much as 71.4% of the verb clauses in MF. Predictably, the use of satellite constructions is higher in OF where it represents 60.3% of the verb clauses in contrast to MF where it accounts for 29.8% of the verb clauses (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 11.63, p < 0.0006).

caption.title: Verbs in Source-oriented expressions in OF and MF

sec.p: In OF, verb satellites found in the descriptions of Source-oriented events include prefixes such as de- ‘off’, es- ‘out of’ and verb particles such as fors ‘out of, outside’, en ‘away, from there (Lat. inde)’. In MF, for describing similar motion events, only two satellites were found, the adverbial particle dehors ‘outside’ and the verb particle/prefix en(-) ‘away, from there’ (as in s’en aller ‘go away’, s’enfuir ‘flee away’).

Now, let us take a closer look at the types of verbs found in the expression of Source-oriented events. Four main categories of motion verbs were found in the data in OF and MF: general verbs of motion, Path verbs, Manner verbs, and verbs lexicalizing both Path and Manner. General verbs of motion include verbs such aler ‘go’ and movoir ‘move’ in OF. It is important to note that the verb aler can also indicate (in both OF and MF) motion away from the deictic center. However, in most of the uses found in the data under study here, aler combines with a great variety of satellites (source, medial and goal) and its deictic meaning is not conspicuous; therefore, it was coded as a general verb of motion. Verbs encoding Path (e.g. arriver ‘arrive’, entrer ‘go in’, sortir ‘go out’ in MF) specify the direction of motion, whether the reference location is expressed or not. Manner verbs (e.g. corir ‘run’, chevaucher ‘ride’, ranper ‘crawl’ in OF) describe the way the moving entity moves without implying any specific direction. Verbs lexicalizing both Path and Manner (e.g. escalader ‘climb, scale’, grimper ‘climb’, pénétrer ‘enter, penetrate’ in MF) describe the displacement of the moving entity in a particular manner and in a particular direction. In MF, the fifth category comprises other motion expressions such as for instance nouns (e.g. chevauchée ‘a ride’, fuite ‘an escape’).

If we now look at the use of different types of verbs in the data, we might note some variation between OF and MF (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 11.29, p < 0.02). First, as Table 4 and Table 5 show, the use of verbs lexicalizing Path differs: in OF, Path verbs comprise 43.1% of the verb clauses, whereas in MF they comprise 66.1% of the verb clauses. The second difference concerns the use of general verbs of motion, and the use of manner verbs. Thus, these two types of verbs are more frequent in OF than in MF. Verbs lexicalizing Manner and Path are less frequent and show less variation.

Moreover, we may also note that in OF, verb satellites combine with semantically varied verbs, including general verbs of motion and semantically specific verbs of motion. In MF, verb satellites, when used, combine preferentially with the general verb of motion aller ‘go’.

caption.title: Verb + Satellite in Source-oriented expressions in OF
Verb + Satellite in Source-oriented expressions in MF

sec.p: These differences between OF and MF have effects on the semantic granularity and the degree of explicitness of Path in Source-oriented events. Namely, the availability of Path satellites in Old French and their combinability with different types of verbs, including verbs lexicalizing Path, often leads to more explicit descriptions of motion events emphasizing the part of Path where the change of location occurs. This is shown in Examples (8) from OF and (8′) from MF. In (8), the information about motion from inside to outside is conveyed by both the particle fors ‘out(ward)’ and the verb issir ‘go out’. Literally, the sentence means ‘he goes out outward of the bath’, and by doing so it lays emphasis on boundary crossing at the initial location. In the MF translation in (8′), this information is conveyed by the verb sortir ‘go out’ only. Note that in both Old and Modern French the preposition du (< de ‘from’ + le ‘definiteness’) contributes to the expression of Source-oriented Path too, as it indicates displacement from the initial location.

Example (9) from OF below illustrates a similar pattern where both the verb saillir ‘spring / jump out’ and the particle fors ‘out(ward)’ convey the meaning of motion from inside. In the MF translation in (9′), as was the case in the earlier example, this meaning is conveyed solely by the verb sortir ‘go out’; the preposition de carries a more general meaning of Source and does not imply the boundary crossing.7

sec.title: Goal-oriented events
sec.p: Let us now consider the expression of Goal-oriented events. As we have already seen in Section 3.2, simplex Goal-oriented events are more frequent in the MF data where they comprise 136 event descriptions in contrast to the OF data where they comprise 109 event descriptions.

Interestingly, as far as the use of verbs and satellites is concerned, there is less dissimilarity between OF and MF in Goal-oriented events as compared to Source-oriented events. Hence, as Table 6 shows, the use of verbs with no satellites accounts for 79.8% of the verb clauses in the OF texts and 81.3% in the MF translations. As for the verbs that occur with satellites, they comprise 20.2% of the OF data and 18.7% of the MF data (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 0.08, p < 0.76).

caption.title: Verbs in Goal-oriented expressions in OF and MF

sec.p: In OF, the descriptions of Goal-oriented events include satellites such as arriere ‘backward’, en ‘in (Lat. in), dedanz ‘inside’, desoz ‘under’, i/y ‘there’, la sus ‘up there’, re- ‘back’. In MF, we mainly find the prefix re- ‘back’ and the adverb y ‘there’.

While OF and MF show a similar tendency with respect to the use of verbs and verb satellites in Goal-oriented events, they reveal some differences in the use of different types of verbs (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 14.27, p < 0.01). As Table 7 and Table 8 show, verbs lexicalizing Path are slightly more frequent in the OF data: they account for 62.4% of the verb clauses in OF against 58.2% of the verb clauses in MF. We may also note that general verbs (aler ‘go’ and s’esmovoir ‘move’) are more often employed in the OF texts than in the MF texts, which, for their part, show more frequent use of verbs conflating both Path and Manner (e.g. pénétrer ‘get into’, grimper ‘climb up’).

caption.title: Verb + Satellite in Goal-oriented expressions in OF
Verb + Satellite in Goal-oriented expressions in MF

sec.p: Furthermore, there are some differences between the OF and MF data in the type of information conveyed in motion descriptions. By combining Path verbs and Path satellites, the tendency in OF is to provide more fine-grained information about the endpoint of the event. This is shown in (10) from OF and in (10′), which is the translation of the same event into MF. Both examples express motion directed to the final location. However, in (10) the final part of Path is indicated by the verb venir ‘come’ and the deictic particle i ‘there’. Furthermore, we may note that the final location is explicitly encoded by the prepositional phrase a la forclose ‘to the outdoor fence’. In MF in (10′), the verb rejoindre ‘join’ is semantically less specific, and the description does not make an explicit reference to the final location (which is a human Goal), as the personal pronoun le (together with the verb) merely indicates that the main protagonist moved to meet someone.

sec.p: In fact, such implicit descriptions are not uncommon in Modern French. This is further demonstrated in Examples (11) from OF and (11′) from MF. Here too, in OF Goal-related information is conveyed in a more explicit fashion by emphasizing crossing the boundary at the final location. Thus, in (11), motion from outside to inside is conveyed by the verb entrer ‘go in’ and the preposition dedanz ‘in(side)’. It is also important to note that the final location vostre chanbre ‘your room’ is explicitly expressed. By contrast, in MF in (11′), Path is expressed by the verb entrer ‘go in’, and the prepositional phrase does not specify the place where the protagonist entered. The final location must be inferred from the context here. Note that the data under analysis here does not reveal the opposite situation where more explicit information would be provided in MF but not in OF.8

sec.title: Source-and-Goal oriented events
sec.p: In Section 3.2, we observed that Source-and-Goal descriptions are more frequent in the OF data, where they represent 48 events, than in the MF data, where they merely comprise 24 events. In fact, if we take a closer look at the structural devices used for encoding such complex events, Old and Modern French show rather similar preferences: as Table 9 shows, constructions with verb satellites, although more frequent in OF (80% of the verb clauses) are also numerous in MF (70.8% of the verb clauses) (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 1.54, p < 0.21).

caption.title: Verbs and satellites in Source-and-Goal expressions in OF and MF

sec.p: Regarding the types of verbs used for expressing Source-and-Goal events, although we find some similarities between OF and MF here as well, we note a greater semantic diversity of verbs in OF (Pearson's Chi-squared test: 4.67, p < 0.32).9 In particular, as Table 10 and Table 11 show, verbs lexicalizing Path are the most frequent; yet, their proportion is higher in MF: they account for 62.5% of the verb clauses in MF against 46.7% of the verb clauses in OF. As for verb satellites, they occur with all types of verbs found in the expression of this type of events, in OF or in MF respectively.

caption.title: Verbs in Source-and-Goal expressions in OF
Verbs in Source-and-Goal expressions in MF

sec.p: Let us now turn back to the main difference, which concerns a greater proportion of Source-and-Goal events in OF, and a greater proportion of simplex Goal-oriented events in MF (cf. Section 3.2). The data show that this variation results from the fact that some complex event descriptions in OF are translated into MF as simplex Goal-oriented events in MF. This is illustrated by Examples (12) and (12′) below. The OF Example (12) describes an event in which the main protagonists leave the house early at dawn to ride to church. While the initial reference location is not explicitly mentioned here (though it can be inferred from the context), motion away from the initial location is indicated by the particle en ‘from there’, and motion toward the final location is given by the preposition a ‘to’ (here the contracted form al < a ‘to’ + the definite article le). If we now consider the translation of the same event in Modern French in (12′), we might observe that the description merely focuses on the final section of the Path by displaying the verb se rendre ‘go to’ and the preposition à ‘at, to’.

sec.p: Yet, while Examples (12) and (12′) illustrate some preferences in the encoding of Path in OF and MF, and the attention they allocate to its different portions, they do not explain these preferences. Section 5 attempts to address this issue.

sec.title: The particle en in Old French
sec.p: Given the difference found in the data between OF and MF in the ways of describing the initial and final component of Path, the main question that arises is: what triggers a more frequent expression of Source-and-Goal events in OF as compared to MF, which tends to favor Goal-oriented events?

The data shows that, in Old French, the availability of satellites for the encoding of Path facilitates the encoding of complex Path in a clause. In particular, the role of the particle en originating from the Latin directional adverb inde ‘from there’ seems to be crucial in this respect. In Old French, en is both frequent in use and productive in terms of combinability with different types of verbs. It can combine with simple verbs and, importantly, with verbs that already carry a prefix or a particle, as is shown in (13).

list-item.p: amont s’en ranper ‘climb up’, arriere s’en retorner ‘(lit.) backward turn back’, en sallir ‘jump’, s’en aler ‘go away’, s’en turner ‘turn away’, s’en returner arriere ‘(lit.) turn back backward’, s’en revenir ‘come back’, s’en venir ‘come’

sec.p: Before examining complex Path expressions to which the particle en contributes, let us first look at the functions of this particle. En had two main functions in Old French, deictic and anaphoric (Buridant 2000). The cataphoric use, although attested, was less frequent (Buridant 2000).

The deictic use of en is shown in Example (14). To give the larger context in which this event takes place, it is a story of a knight riding to a village. On his long journey, the main protagonist asks a man the way to the house of the priest. As Example (14) below shows, the passer-by points to the final destination, takes leave, and goes away. Hence, the particle en, which occurs within a complex verb s’en depart ‘(lit.) leave away from there’, indicates in this context motion away from the deictic center, that is away from the knight.

‘So he shows him the place, then takes leave and goes away.’

sec.p: Example (15) shows the anaphoric use of the particle en. It tells the story of a knight coming back home from a tournament where he lost everything, his money and honor. En, which occurs in s’en vint ‘(lit.) came from there’ plays an anaphoric function in this context inasmuch as it makes reference to the place where the tournament came about, and that was introduced earlier in discourse.

sec.p: Thus, the availability of the particle en in OF allows us to easily maintain the reference to the initial reference point in discourse and, hence, to include the initial location in the description. It is worth mentioning that en is not the only adverbial particle with a deictic and an anaphoric function that we find in the data. The corpus also includes the particle i, which originates from the Latin adverb ibi meaning ‘there’, and which is used to refer to the final location. However, in contrast to en, the adverbial particle i is not frequently used in the descriptions of motion, at least in the data set under study here.10

Now, while previous examples put emphasis on one part of Path, which is its initial part, en is frequently used together with goal expressions. In such descriptions, the final location is typically conveyed by a prepositional phrase, as in (16) where it is expressed by vers le prestre ‘toward the priest’. But, the final part of Path can also be conveyed by a prefixed verb, as in (17) where both the prepositional phrase a son ostel ‘to his hostel’ and the prefixed verb revient ‘comes back’ indicate motion toward the final location.
