title-group.title: Prepositional phrase vs. bare instrumental
title-group.subtitle: The trajectory of motion in Russian

abstract.p: The trajectory of motion in Russian can be expressed by a prepositional phrase with the noun in the dative case or a bare NP in the instrumental case. It is argued that the latter construction is falling into disuse, along with the general trend toward analyticity in Slavic languages (Comrie et al. 1996). In this paper, I present a corpus-based diachronic study of the distribution of the two constructions with respect to various variables, such as noun frequency, the conceptualization of the Ground object, verb aspect, and others. I provide an argument that the bare NP construction is going through lexicalization as an adverb.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There are three strategies of expressing verbal government in Russian: the use of the accusative case, an oblique case (genitive, dative, or instrumental) or a preposition (Comrie et al. 1996). It is not unusual for the same verb to combine several of these options (see Example (1a–d)) that may slightly differ in meaning. The choice of the strategy varies from one case to another, and where more than one option is available, it depends on a combination of synchronic and diachronic factors. For example, in the 19th century the verb blagodarit’ ‘to thank’ was often used with an NP in the dative case because of its diachronic connection to the verb darit’ ‘to give as a gift’, which requires a dative case for one of its arguments (cf. Comrie et al. 1996: 145). Nowadays, it is only used with an object in the accusative case.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘Liza was gazing at him, trying to catch his eye.’ (Unkown, Nesčastnaja Liza)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘His younger brothers were looking for a job in the city.’ (Y. Gajdar, Gibel’ imperii)

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘They were waiting for a mail train to Moscow.’ (I.Bunin, Derevnja)

list-item.label: d.
list-item.p: ‘We are waiting for a letter or a telegraph from you.’

sec.p: A prominent example of an alternating use of two different strategies is the expression of the trajectory of a motion event. In Russian, the same trajectory of motion can be expressed by a prepositional phrase with the noun in the dative case or a bare NP in the instrumental case.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘They went through a forest.’

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘They went through a forest.’

sec.p: In (2a–b) the two constructions are interchangeable, as both can be used to describe the same motion event. This variation is possible in a number of constructions: idti po sadu / sadom ‘to walk through a garden’, projehat’ po doroge / dorogoj ‘to ride/drive down the road’, projti po beregu / beregom ‘to walk along the bank’. However, in some cases, the prepositional phrase is acceptable, whereas the use of the instrumental case either appears odd or is strictly ungrammatical.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘To wander in the park.’

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: (intended meaning) ‘To wander in the park.’

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘To walk in the garden.’

list-item.label: d.
list-item.p: (intended meaning) ‘To walk in the garden.’

sec.p: As shown in (3a–b) and (3c–d), the two constructions are not always interchangeable, and constraints apply to the constructions with the instrumental case.

While the observed differences in the encoding of the trajectory of motion events in Russian are consistent with the general trend toward analyticity in Slavic languages (Comrie et al. 1996), it is still unclear why exactly the bare instrumental construction is infelicitous in some cases, and what licenses its use in others. This is no simple question and, as I will show in Sections 3 through 5, the existing accounts of the differences fail to predict a wide range of cases. More importantly, to my knowledge, previous investigations into the distribution of the two constructions were framed in terms of constraints on the instrumental construction, and their scope left behind the question what historical processes resulted in the current state of affairs.

In this study I will take a different approach: as the existing difference in distribution of the two constructions must have developed against the undercurrent of various factors, the first step to understanding the course of the historical processes that shaped the current preferences in the expression of the trajectory of motion would be to look at the distribution of the two constructions in a corpus of modern Russian. During this first phase, I will apply statistical tools to the corpus data to investigate how likely this distribution is to be influenced by usage frequencies, properties of the verb, the type of motion, and other factors. After the significant factors have been identified, I will look into the diachronic development of the competing constructions to see: (1) whether the factors that influence the distribution of the constructions have changed over time, and (2) whether the generally accepted hypothesis that there is a tendency towards analyticity in Russian is supported by the corpus data.

Finally, I will see how my data correspond to the existing research on motion events. A lot of cross-linguistic studies have been conducted in the past few years to understand how languages structure space and encode motion (Talmy 1983, 1985, 1991, 2000; Slobin 1996, 2004, 2006; Nikitina 2008, 2010). I will investigate whether the choice of a strategy of encoding the trajectory of motion relates to what is already known about motion events in Russian.

In Section 2, I will present the results of the corpus study I conducted based on the National Corpus of Russian.1 In Sections 3 through 5, I will analyze the factors that contributed to the differences in distribution of the constructions encoding trajectories of motion events. In the concluding Section 6, I will investigate the current status of the bare instrumental construction.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: To construct a database of examples, I extracted from the National Corpus of Russian all instances of verbs followed by prepositional phrases and bare instrumental constructions with nine nouns – alleja ‘alley’, bereg ‘shore’, doroga ‘road’, dorožka – diminutive of ‘road’, les ‘forest’, park ‘park’, pole ‘field’, sad ‘garden’, and tropinka ‘trail, path’ – chosen based on how frequently they were used in the bare instrumental form in the corpus. This was done to achieve a more even representation of the two constructions in my database (attaining a completely even representation would be impossible due to the low frequency of the bare instrumental form in the corpus), and to prevent bias in analyzing the distribution of the two strategies. Note that while some nouns (such as put’ ‘way’) had a large number of uses in the instrumental case, they had to be discarded from the dataset due to the prevalence of metaphorical uses – e.g., idti svoim putёm ‘to go your own way’.

I allowed a distance of five words to remain between the main verb of a clause and the noun in order to incorporate clauses where nouns were preceded by a modifier. This criterion also helped me encompass the cases where the nouns were part of a bigger NP, as in (4).

list-item.p: ‘You go fly in the gardens, fields and forests.’ (V.Bianki, Lesnyje byli i nebylicy, 1923–1958)

sec.p: As I was interested in the diachronic aspect of the variation, I divided the examples into two groups: clauses that occurred within the time frame from 1840 to 1880, and those that occurred between 1940 and 1980. The decision on these time frames was made following a qualitative exploratory study of the corpus. Due to the modest diachronic span of the corpus, the biggest challenge was to find two time frames in which both constructions were used frequently and which were separated by a time period sufficient to trace any diachronic changes. The lower bound was determined by the data present in the corpus: the number of occurrences of either construction in the texts collected before mid-1800s was too low for a quantitative analysis. The gap of 100 years was chosen to test Comrie et al.’s (1996) intuition that the split in the use of the two construction occurred between the 19th and the 20th century.

I have set the time limits for each noun individually depending on their frequency, but all of them fall into these time frames. This was done to prevent cases where high frequency of a noun could affect the data. For example, the tendency of a particular noun to be used with manner verbs in the instrumental case could lead to an erroneous conclusion that manner verbs favor bare NPs because the high frequency of the noun would boost the statistics for this factor. For nouns that occurred more frequently in the instrumental form in motion event contexts, I set the limit to 20 years, with all such instances falling in the range from 1840 to 1860 and 1940 to 1960 (bereg ‘shore’, dorožka ‘road’ (dim.), les ‘forest’, pole ‘field’, sad ‘garden’, tropinka ‘path’). For nouns that were less common in motion event contexts (alleja ‘alley’, park ‘park’), I set the limit to 40 years. Finally, I had to set the limit at 5 years (1850 to 1855 and 1950 to 1955) for the noun doroga ‘road’ due to its high frequency in the corpus.
I have subsequently removed all clauses that were unrelated to this study, such as locational PPs (5a) and temporal uses of the NP in the instrumental case (5b).

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘The lands lying on the southern bank of the Rybnaja river.’ (A. Vyšeslavcev, S mysa Dobroj Nadeždy, 1858)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘I lost my cigar case during my trip.’ (A. Pisemskij, Sergej Petrovič Hozarov i Mari Stupicyna, 1851)

sec.p: Likewise, I have excluded all instances of fictive motion, where a motion verb was used to describe a situation that cannot be categorized as a motion event, as in (6).

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘The road went down a thick forest.’ (A. Tolstoj, Knjaz’ Serebrjanyj, 1842–1862)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘Pugachev heard a familiar voice approaching along the shore.’ (V. Šiškov, Jemel’jan Pugačёv, 1934–1945)

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘The path lay across the mountain trails of Taiga.’ (I. Jefremov, Lezvije britvy, 1959–1963)

caption.title: Database

sec.p: The final version of the database (see Table 1) includes 2715 clauses. Of the 1049 clauses from between 1840 and 1880, 852 (or 81%) marked the trajectory of motion with a prepositional phrase, while a bare NP was used in 197 (19%) cases. For the time period from 1940 to 1980, I have extracted a total of 1665 clauses, where a prepositional phrase was used in 1404 (84%) cases, and a bare NP in 261 (16%) cases.

Computing the P value via Fisher’s exact test for these data showed that for most nouns (with the exception of doroga ‘road’), there was no statistically significant decrease in the occurrence of instrumental constructions since the19th century. However, this does not necessarily imply that there is no competition between the two constructions – that is, that there is no tendency toward analyticity in the expression of the trajectory of motion in Russian. While the trend may not be immediately visible in the data due to the relatively short time frame available in the corpus, it will become clearer by looking at the development of factors that contribute to the choice of either construction. As I will show, the shifts in significance of some factors or a growing difference in distribution of the constructions with respect to some factor imply that there is a tendency for the instrumental construction to be used less frequently over time.

sec.title: Constraints on Russian instrumental case
sec.p: I have noted that marking the trajectory of motion with the instrumental case can sometimes yield odd (3d) or unacceptable (3b) results, which suggests that the encoding of the trajectory of motion with the instrumental case must be subject to certain constraints.

Rakhilina and Tribushinina (2010) and Rakhilina (2000) explain this constraint from a noun-centered perspective, arguing that clauses such as *idti pojezdom (in the meaning of ‘to walk through a train’) are ungrammatical because the instrumental case can only be used to mark the trajectory of motion when it is “an established, recognized route through a larger space, such as a field or a forest” (Rakhilina & Tribushinina 2010: 4). While this explanation does account for a number of cases, it leaves some questions unanswered.

For example, idti bolotami (‘to walk through the swamps’) is felicitous in Russian – however, it is not immediately obvious that established, recognized routes are found across swamps. The same can be said about meadows and gardens, while both of these nouns allow the use of the instrumental of path in Russian. Likewise, the constraint would not be able to rule out constructions such as *letet’ nebom (‘to fly by the sky’) as fixed aerial routes do, in fact, exist.

It appears that the fixed route constraint is inefficient in predicting ungrammaticality due to its vagueness: we cannot always assert whether a route in question is well-established (as in the case of swamps); it would also allow ungrammatical constructions such as *letet’ nebom. Similarly, Rakhilina (2000) argues that ??plyt’ rekoj (‘to float down a river’) is odd, because this type of movement presupposes only one possible trajectory. However, phrases like idti dorogoj / tropinkoj (‘to walk down a road/trail’) also describe movement along an object whose meaning entails a singular trajectory, but they sound perfectly natural.

In fact, it is not surprising that general constraints fail to explain the distribution of the strategies of encoding the trajectory of motion. As I show in the following sections, the accessibility of the instrumental construction is determined by a number of factors that are subject to diachronic change. The set of factors affecting the choice of a strategy in each motion event can also be different – reflecting that these factors should be treated in terms of preference rather than strict constraints on one of the constructions. In other words, there is no one factor that is guaranteed to make the use of the bare instrumental form ungrammatical.

sec.title: Configuration of the Ground object
sec.p: As languages tend to be highly schematic in their expression of spatial relations, only certain elements of space are lexically expressed, while others are disregarded (cf. Talmy 1983). This means that various physical Ground objects (such as roads, rivers, plains, forests, etc.) can be idealized (in Talmy’s terminology) to match the schema applied to them, i.e. real physical Ground objects that vary in shape get ascribed common features that make a certain type of movement possible in relation to these objects.

As I was interested in the kind of movement whose schema could be encoded through both the prepositional phrase and the instrumental case, the clauses I have collected from the corpus include nouns of two general types:2

list-item.p: Scene-type nouns (Figure 1) denoting wide areas of terrain of various shapes. In my database, these are the nouns les ‘forest’, park ‘park, pole ‘field’, and sad ‘garden’.

Line-type nouns (Figure 2) denoting long, narrow Ground objects. Nouns in my database that correspond to this type are doroga ‘road’, dorožka – diminutive of ‘road’, tropinka ‘trail, path’, and alleja ‘alley’.

sec.p: The noun bereg ‘bank, shore’ is rather unique, as it can be viewed both as a line-type and a scene-type noun, depending on whether we mean the stretch of land following a river, or an area of land surrounding a body of water.

The key difference between the two types is that scene-type nouns do not directly designate the trajectory of motion, but rather contain it (cf. Ganenkov 2002), while line-type nouns contain more specific information about the trajectory of a moving object. Since the instrumental of path is considered to be associated with a well-known fixed route (Rakhilina 2000; Rakhilina & Tribushinina 2010), I expected that there would be more instrumental constructions with line-type nouns than with scene-type nouns in the corpus. However, this has proven not to be the case.

caption.title: Distribution of constructions according to noun type

sec.p: Table 2 shows the distribution of the two constructions according to noun type. The data from 1840 to 1880 proved to be statistically insignificant (P value = 0.6536), suggesting that the type of noun was not an important factor in choosing a strategy for encoding the trajectory of motion in the 19th century. Data from the 20th century, on the other hand, yielded unexpected statistically significant results (P value = 0.0192): bare instrumental construction occurred more often with scene-type than with line-type nouns.

From the diachronic point of view, the use of line-type objects in the instrumental case dropped from 19% in the 19th century to 14% in the 20th century, which is a significant decrease. Scene-type nouns were used in the instrumental case in 20% of all clauses between 1840 and 1880, and their use only dropped to 19% of all clauses between 1940 and 1980.

sec.title: Noun frequencies
sec.p: The effect of usage frequencies on all levels of language is well-documented (cf. Gahl & Garnsey 2006; Tily et al. 2009; Bybee 2006). It is also generally true for languages that irregular forms usually occur in high frequency environments (Bybee 1985). While the instrumental construction is not an irregular form, it is subject to constraints that do not apply to the prepositional phrase. Therefore, I expected that the frequencies of the nouns selected for this study would have a considerable effect on the strategy of encoding the trajectory of motion.

caption.title: Noun frequencies in the National Corpus of Russia

sec.p: Table 3 shows the total number of words in the National Corpus of Russian for the periods from 1840 to 1880 and from 1940 to 1980, and the frequencies of the nouns in my database for these intervals. All forms of the nouns were included in the search, and the lemmas were searched for as well. I have divided the nouns from my database into two groups: frequent nouns of over five thousand occurrences in each time period (bereg, doroga, les, pole, and sad), and non-frequent nouns of under five thousand occurrences in each time period (alleja, dorožka, park, and tropinka). I then compared the frequency of the nouns with the distribution of the constructions (see Table 4).

caption.title: Distribution of constructions with regard to noun frequency

sec.p: Frequency proved to be an extremely significant factor in the difference in the distribution of the prepositional phrase and bare instrumental for both time periods. Interestingly, the use of the instrumental construction with frequent nouns dropped 5% in the 20th century, which could serve as indirect evidence that it is indeed falling into disuse.

sec.title: Manner vs. non-manner verbs
sec.p: Talmy’s well-known typology of verb-framed vs. satellite-framed languages divides languages according to how they encode information about the path of the motion event. In verb-framed languages, path is usually encoded within the main verb of the clause, while satellite-framed languages opt for means such as verb prefixes, prepositions, specific case marking, etc. Russian is considered a typical example of a satellite-framed language, usually denoting path through a combination of a preposition and a particular case.

Another important typology developed by Talmy (1985, 2000) differentiates languages with respect to lexicalization patterns. According to Talmy, most verbs can be decomposed and represented through simple elements of meaning. The two bigger groups of languages described by Talmy conflate either motion and manner/cause, or motion and path into a single verb; this distinction corresponds roughly to the aforementioned typology of satellite-framed and verb-framed languages (cf. Slobin 2006).

As shown by Slobin’s (2006) cross-linguistic study of the encoding of motion events, Russian is notorious for its vast use of manner verbs, and as many as 100% of all verbs in a narrative could be manner verbs. Since verbs play a highly important role in encoding the trajectory of motion (cf. Talmy 1991, 2000), manner salience of a motion event could be a major factor in choosing between a prepositional phrase and a bare instrumental construction. However, neither Slobin’s study nor Talmy’s original typology offer suggestions as to what properties manner verbs should possess and how they should be differentiated from non-manner verbs.

For the purposes of this study, I employed the following strategy for distinguishing between manner and non-manner verbs: non-manner verbs (such as idti ‘to go’, hodit’ ‘to walk’, jehat’ ‘to go by transport’) describe basic types of motion and their meaning usually cannot be related in simpler terms; manner verbs (such as begat’ ‘to run’, brodit’ ‘to wander’, prygat’ ‘to jump’) contribute extra information about the speed or type of movement.

While this strategy mirrors Talmy’s (2000) and Slobin’s (2006) description of manner and non-manner verbs, the classification is admittedly imprecise. To minimize this imprecision, I relied on Ushakov’s and Ozhegov’s dictionaries of Russian to determine whether the meaning of a word can be rendered in simpler terms. For example, the verb mčat’sja ‘to rush’ is given the definition očen’ bistro jehat’ ‘to drive very fast’ in Ozhegov’s dictionary, and is therefore classified as a manner verb. The verb jehat’ ‘to move via a means of transportation’ itself, on the other hand, does not provide any information about the type of transportation or the kind of movement, and is treated as a non-manner verb.

This approach is not perfect, as it leaves a considerable number of verbs (such as podymat’sja ‘to go up’ or guljat’ ‘to go for a walk’) open to both interpretations. For the purposes of this study, I marked troublesome cases consistently as either “manner” (as is the case with guljat’ ‘to go for a walk’) or “non-manner” (podymat’sja ‘to go up’) in all clauses I collected from the corpus.

caption.title: Distribution of constructions with regard to manner salience of the verb

sec.p: For both time periods – 1840 to 1880 and 1940 to 1980 – the salience of manner turned out to be a statistically significant factor in most cases (Table 5). The statistically significant results show that the bare instrumental construction is used far less frequently with manner verbs than the prepositional phrase, which is used freely with both manner and non-manner verbs. However, the verb’s manner salience is not a strict constraint on the instrumental case, as shown by Examples (7a–c). The main verb of each clause is manner salient, but the phrases sound perfectly natural in Russian.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘He started running through the field towards the forest.’ (Y. Kazakov, Teddi, 1956)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘Run through the gardens.’ (G. Baklanov, Yužneje glavnogo udara, 1957)

list-item.label: c.
list-item.p: ‘I’m walking through the forest again.’ (V. Višnevskij, Dnevniki vojennyh let, 1943–1945)

sec.p: The fact that instrumental constructions are used less frequently in manner-salient contexts could be another sign that Russian is eventually going to opt for the prepositional phrase. If, as Slobin’s study suggests, manner verbs are more natural in Russian motion event descriptions, the difficulty in accessing bare instrumental construction in manner salient contexts could contribute to its obsolescence. However, due to the imprecise nature of the manner / non-manner distinction, these results should be considered preliminary and remain to be verified on a larger dataset or with more formal guidelines for a verb’s membership in either group.

sec.title: Aspect
sec.p: Russian is notorious for its rich aspectual system: its complicated (and seemingly chaotic) patterns of prefixation result in numerous perfectives with distinct meanings. For example, the perfective verbs vyletet’ ‘to fly out’, pereletet’ ‘to fly over’, priletet’ ‘to fly to’, proletet’ ‘to fly past’ all act as aspectual “pairs” to the imperfective verb letet’ ‘to fly’. This behavior is so typical for Russian motion verbs that Janda (2006, 2008) proposes that verbs should be divided into “clusters” instead of traditional pairs, and that a distinction should be established between natural perfectives, specialized perfectives, complex acts, and single acts.
Given the significance of aspect in Russian motion verbs, I suspected it could be yet another factor contributing to the choice between the prepositional phrase and the bare instrumental.

caption.title: Distribution of constructions with regard to aspect of the verb

sec.p: However, the data in Table 6 suggest that there is no specialization of forms according to the aspect of the main verb of a clause. In the cases where the difference was statistically significant (bereg ‘bank, shore’, doroga ‘road’, pole ‘field’), it seems to indicate just that imperfectives are common with prepositional phrases, not that aspect was a constraint on the use of an instrumental NP.

sec.title: Inherent trajectory of the verb
sec.p: In Russian, a number of verbs have two imperfectives with distinct inherent trajectories of motion: one imperfective denotes a determined motion along a singular path, while the other presupposes a non-determined motion along numerous paths. Compare, for example, the verbs idti ‘to walk’ and hodit’ ‘to walk around’, bežat’ ‘to run’ and begat’ ‘to run around’. The first verb in each pair is unidirectional, while the second verb is multidirectional. Multidirectional verbs also have two meanings: (1) that the motion has several directions, and (2) that the motion has a unique direction, but happens regularly, as in (8).

list-item.p: ‘I use this road to go to school every day.’

sec.p: While these pairs do not exist for all motion verbs in Russian, the meaning of multiple trajectories is inherent to verbs such as razojtis’ ‘to walk in different directions’, projtis’ ‘to walk around for a while’, skitat’sja ‘to wander’, etc.

caption.title: Distribution of constructions with regard to the inherent trajectory of the verb

sec.p: Table 7 shows that the verb’s inherent trajectory is extremely significant for scene-type nouns and not particularly important for line-type nouns. This outcome is not surprising, since line-type nouns already contain the meaning of route and so they are expected to favor verbs that express purposeful linear movement. However, since there is a tendency for the instrumental case to be used with scene-type nouns, the verb’s inherent trajectory can still be considered a significant factor contributing to the differences between the two constructions. Again, the constraint on the verb’s inherent trajectory of motion is not a matter of course. In (9a) below, the main verb of the clause denotes a habitual action, and in this case, the use of a bare instrumental is grammatical and not uncommon. In (9b), however, the verb prošlis’ ‘walked around’ denotes a multidirectional motion, and therefore the use of the bare instrumental is rather unexpected. Nevertheless, the sentence sounds natural in Russian.

list-item.label: a.
list-item.p: ‘We used to walk to the railroad through the field.’ (V.Grossman, Vsё tečёt, 1955–1963)

list-item.label: b.
list-item.p: ‘I want us to walk down the bank of the ancient stream.’ (I.Jefremov, Zvёzdnyje korabli, 1944)

sec.title: Verb frequencies
sec.p: While calculating the frequencies of all verbs in the database would be beyond the scope of this study, it would be interesting to consider the verbs most frequently used with bare instrumental constructions. Table 8 shows the most frequent verbs in my database: these verbs were used in at least 5% of all instances of one of the constructions in any of the represented time periods.

caption.title: Most frequently used verbs. Other verbs were used in 5% of instances or less

tr.td: jehat' 'to go by means of transport'

sec.p: The two verbs that are most frequently used with the bare instrumental form are non-manner and unidirectional. Most importantly, the verb idti that was used in almost half of all clauses with the bare NP (unlike the clauses with a prepositional phrase, where it was used in 19% of all clauses between 1840 and 1880 and in 24% of all clauses between 1940 and 1980) in both time periods, is the most generic verb denoting motion. This is congruent with my previous observations that, on the one hand, the use of the bare instrumental NP is limited to expressing general, non-specific information about a motion event, and on the other hand, that it is mostly used in contexts that are learned by rote.

sec.title: Genre
sec.p: Archaic and obsolescent constructions are often considered more literary forms of language, and register is usually expected to play a significant role in the choice between the coexisting strategies for encoding the trajectory of motion. Unfortunately, I have not been able to compare the uses of the two constructions in spoken language due to the moderate size of the spoken corpus of Russian. It is strongly expected, however, that the uses of the instrumental case would be extremely rare in the spoken corpus.

However, my database contains written texts of various genres, and I was able to investigate whether there are patterns in the distribution of the prepositional phrase and the bare instrumental in fiction and nonfiction texts.

caption.title: Distribution of the constructions with regard to genre

sec.p: As Table 9 shows, genre did not seem to affect the choice of a strategy in the 19th century. However, it has become a significant factor for some nouns (bereg ‘shore’, dorožka ‘road’ (dim), tropinka ‘path’ and, to a lesser degree, les ‘forest’), which could suggest that genre is gaining more significance for the encoding of the trajectory of motion in written language. This is an expected development, since archaic forms are usually preserved in the literary forms of the written language, i.e. in fiction.

sec.title: Discussion and concluding remarks
sec.p: The goal of this study was two-fold: firstly, to investigate whether the bare instrumental construction is indeed being ousted by a prepositional phrase, in accordance with the general trend toward analyticity in Slavic languages, and if so, what factors contribute to this development; and secondly, to understand what licenses or bans the use of the instrumental case.

As I have shown, while the instrumental construction is not on decline overall (see Table 1), the distribution of constructions with respect to some salient factors shows a significant decline in its use. I have argued in Sections 4.1 and 4.2 that the manner and inherent trajectory of the verb are some of the key factors that determine the accessibility of the instrumental construction. Bare instrumentals are rarely used with manner verbs, which in itself may indirectly give evidence that the construction is falling into disuse, since Russian descriptions of motion events involve a high number of manner verbs (cf. Slobin 2006). Scene-type nouns have also proven to be dependent on the verb’s inherent trajectory of motion, as instrumental constructions are used more frequently with verbs denoting purposeful motion along a single trajectory.

I have also provided evidence that these factors do not impose strict constraints on the use of the instrumental case, but rather point to preferences of the competing constructions. Additionally, the choice of the strategy of encoding route is typically influenced by several of these factors at the same time. For example, in (10) the verb skakat’ ‘to ride’ is a manner verb, and the noun tropinka ‘path’ is one of the least frequent in the corpus. If frequency or manner salience were strict constraints on the instrumental of path in Russian, this sentence would be ungrammatical. However, skakat’ ‘to skip’ is a unidirectional verb, which makes the clause acceptable in Russian.

list-item.p: ‘In half an hour, we were riding down a charming trail.’ (V.Vonljarljarskij, Noč na 28-e sentjabrja, 1852)

sec.p: Moreover, what seems to be the obsolescence of the bare instrumental construction may actually be an ongoing change in its meaning and grammatical properties – that is, instead of being ousted, this construction is becoming lexicalized as a different part of speech – namely, an adverb.

Brinton and Traugott (2005) define lexicalization as “a historical change that results in the production of new lexical / contentful forms”, and on their account, it is characterized, among other things, by loss of semantic compositionality. Bybee (1985) points to one case of lexicalization where two or more words that share the same meaning tend to pull apart over time, until a lexical split occurs. Among the factors that contribute to the eventual autonomy of a form are high frequency and semantic autonomy.

As I have shown in Section 3.3, frequency is one of the top factors that determine the distribution of the two forms encoding the trajectory of motion in Russian. Bare instrumental, the “weaker” construction, is significantly more accessible to high frequency nouns, suggesting that it is learned by rote and stored separately in the lexicon. Moreover, the instrumental form appears to be used more frequently with scene-type nouns – a semantic preference that could also contribute to a lexical split.

The case of lexicalization of the instrumental of path would not be extraordinary. Russian has a history of forming adverbs from the instrumental forms of nouns: the adverb mimohodom ‘in passing’, for example, comes from the noun mimohod ‘passer-by’. This etymology is obscure to a modern-day speaker, since the noun itself has long fallen into disuse, and the adverb is hardly recognizable as the noun mimohod + the morpheme om. Similarly, the adverbs mel’kom ‘in passing’, nenarokom ‘by accident’, sliškom ‘too much’ were formed from the instrumental case of nouns that are no longer used in any other form. The origins of adverbs such as šagom ‘by walking’ (from šag ‘step’), begom ‘by running’ (from beg ‘the act of running’), are still traceable, although their forms are not readily analyzable as the instrumental case of the respective nouns they were derived from.

The lexicalization theory is further supported by the fact that high-frequency constructions such as idti svoej dorogoj ‘to go your own way’ and idti lesom – literally ‘to go through the forest’ (a phrase used to dismiss someone) – have already been lexicalized as idioms, and differ drastically in meaning from the prepositional forms idti po doroge and idti po lesu. The meaning of the instrumental construction cannot be compositionally derived from its lexical parts.

If the historical process behind the differences in the distribution of the two constructions expressing the trajectory of motion is indeed that of lexicalization, it would be congruent with Brinton and Traugott’s (2005) proposal for an integrated approach to the study of lexicalization and grammaticalization. On their account, lexicalization and grammaticalization do not exist separately and are two parts of the same process. This view seems appropriate for the Russian instrumental of path: on the one hand, separate lexical items are being re-analyzed and lexicalized as adverbs; on the other hand, the instrumental case marker -om/-oj is grammaticalized as a productive suffix of adverbial formation.

One final remark concerns the methodological results of this study. As I noted in the beginning of the paper, my strategy employed both a synchronic and a diachronic approach. On the one hand, looking at the distribution of the constructions expressing the trajectory of motion in the corpus of modern Russian made it possible to identify factors responsible for the differences between the two strategies. On the other hand, looking at the historical development of these factors’ significance made the understanding of the bare instrumental construction’s status more precise. Thus, an approach that combines both a synchronic and a diachronic analysis has proven to be a valuable tool for identifying the processes that underline the encoding of the trajectory of motion in modern Russian, and may be useful for future investigations into the diachrony of motion events.
